HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Indians' Owner Faults Yankees

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: MAYFIELD HEIGHTS, Ohio, July 16 

 BODY:
Larry Dolan, the owner of the Cleveland Indians, said yesterday that George Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, was to blame for some of baseball's economic problems. Dolan criticized Steinbrenner for increasing his payroll through trades for Raul Mondesi and Jeff Weaver. 
"George is a large part of our problem," he said.
 Dolan, whose brother, Charles, is the chairman of Cablevision, said the Yankees were forcing other teams to overspend so they could compete. He used the World Series champion Diamondbacks as an example, saying they "bought themselves a World Series last year." 
 The Yankees, whose cable television games are on the YES Network this year, believe the Dolans are upset because of losing Yankee telecasts from their MSG network, a baseball official said.

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Internet: Hispanics' Use Of Web Surges 

BYLINE:  By Allison Fass (NYT) (Compiled by Gary Bradford) 

 BODY:
 Hispanics' use of the World Wide Web at home is growing faster than that of any other ethnic group in the United States, according to Nielsen/NetRatings. The online Hispanic population grew 13 percent, to nearly 7.6 million, Nielsen/NetRatings found, compared with an overall Web population growth of 3 percent, to almost 105 million. The percentage of Web users who identified themselves as Asian or Pacific Islander grew 6 percent, to nearly 2.4 million; the Caucasian group grew 4 percent, to more than 94 million; and African-American users increased 3 percent, to nearly 7.8 million. The online growth of the Hispanic population is "a great opportunity for marketers and businesses," said Carolyn Clark, a media analyst at Nielsen/NetRatings, based in New York.
 Allison Fass (NYT)

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Internet: Online Job Hunting Rises 

BYLINE:  By Bob Tedeschi (NYT) (Compiled by Gary Bradford) 

 BODY:
 Fifty-two million Americans have looked online for information about jobs, and more than four million do so on a typical day, according to a report to be released this week by the Pew Internet and American Life Project. Up to one-third of those who surf for new jobs do so from their current workplace. 
The figures represent an increase of more than 60 percent in the number of online job hunters from March 2000, the report said, reflecting an increase in Internet use and "turmoil and tightening of the job market." In the survey, which was conducted in January among 2,259 Internet users, eight million Americans who had changed jobs in the last two years said that the Internet was "a vital resource" for finding new work. Bob Tedeschi (NYT)

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE IMPACT -- A HavenNo More; 
America Is Losing Aura of Invincibility

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER and KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
The one place that always seemed safe for the world's investors -- America -- is slowly losing its aura of invincibility. 
 "People have realized that the United States is subject to the same kind of pressures and imbalances as other countries," said Tim Reese of Insight Investment, a London-based money management firm that stopped increasing its American stock holdings a few months ago. "Although there remain some clear advantages to investing in the United States, when you add in the accounting scandals, the picture becomes much more muddled." 
 Investors "want assurance that these things won't happen again," said Angel Knight, the chief executive of the Association of Private Client Investment Managers and Stockbrokers, which represents 260 firms in Britain, Germany, Belgium and the Netherlands.
Foreign investment in American stocks and bonds totaled $100 billion in the first quarter of 2002, slightly less than a year earlier, according to the Treasury Department. That decline follows several years in which annual foreign investment soared, rising from $278 billion in 1998 to $522 billion in 2001.
But investing in America gets riskier for foreign investors as the dollar weakens, and it suffered the minor humiliation of falling lower than the euro this week.
The National Association of Pension Funds, a British group that oversees more than $1 trillion in assets, is reducing its American holdings and investing more in Europe, where valuations are lower, said its investment director, David Gould.
While the United States stock market looks feeble, many other markets around the world have performed even worse. Major European indexes are down more than the 21 percent decline in the Standard & Poor's 500 composite this year. 
Though temporarily disillusioned with the American system of financial oversight, many foreign investors suggest that the government will react quickly, through legal changes and a stimulative monetary policy by the Fed.
Many analysts also say that if there is going to be a global economic recovery, it will be led by the United States.
East Asia suffered its own string of accounting scandals in its financial crisis in 1997 and 1998, when American leaders urged the region to adopt more open business practices, and business leaders in East Asia have been surprised by the recent problems. But they have been even more surprised by the swiftness of the legislative response in Washington, which stands in contrast to the years of wrangling that followed the Asian financial crisis.
"It looks like in a couple of days the new rules are passed, it's really impressive," said James Lin, the general manager of the Taiwan operations of the Union Bank of California.
C. G. Lai, the managing director of fixed- income and treasury trading at BNP Paribas in Taipei, Taiwan, echoed this point, saying, "If anyone can look at this kind of situation and correct it, it's the Americans."
 SUZANNE KAPNER and KEITH BRADSHER

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
Honoring a Father of Labor Economics

BYLINE:  By Louis Uchitelle

 BODY:
More than 100 of JACOB MINCER'S students and colleagues gathered at Columbia University on Monday to honor the professor, who is considered a father of labor economics. The occasion was his 80th birthday -- and a surprise award of a new annual prize ($50,000) in labor economics, from the Institute for the Study of Labor, based in Bonn, Germany. 
KLAUS F. ZIMMERMANN, the institute's director, billed it as a belated Nobel for a giant in the field. 
 Professor Mincer helped shape techniques to explain phenomena like wage inequality and the growing earnings gap between well-educated workers and those with little schooling. Many of his graduate students have become prominent labor economists. One of them, JAMES J. HECKMAN of the University of Chicago, won a Nobel memorial prize in economics in 2000. Dr. Heckman, one of the conference organizers, said on Monday that the research that earned him the Nobel was a direct descendant of his mentor's pioneering formulations about human capital. Louis Uchitelle

HEADLINE: Poland's Solidarity With America 

BYLINE:  By Aleksander Kwasniewski; Aleksander Kwasniewski is the president of Poland.

DATELINE: WARSAW 

 BODY:
When President Bush spoke at Warsaw University last year, he said that the question was no longer what others can do for Poland, but what America and Poland and all of Europe can do for the rest of the world. His words are more true now than ever. The tragedy of Sept. 11 emphasized the importance of trans-Atlantic solidarity and the need to accomplish the "European project" that was started with the first round of NATO enlargement only three years ago and will continue this fall with further expansion of NATO and then the enlargement of the European Union.
 Sept. 11 reminded all of us again that the values of the democratic world cannot be taken for granted. That is why President Bush's words in Warsaw were so important. We in Poland believe our relations with the United States can help democracy's spread in a world that resists old definitions, but whose threats have to be identified and challenged. We cherish our new role because history has left us with little room for mistakes. 
 Poland enjoys a unique geopolitical perspective. Soon after having initiated the process of democratic transformation, which in early 1989 paved the way for changes that brought down the Berlin Wall and gave freedom to the nations of Central and Eastern Europe, Poland found itself surrounded by seven new neighbors -- Lithuania, Russia, Belarus, Ukraine, Slovakia, the Czech Republic and Germany. And with all of them, we have had good relations. Today, we believe we help export political stability and economic progress to our region of the world.
We still need to strengthen our regional identity and develop a common approach to the issues of our region. A good example is the antiterrorism campaign. Soon after the Sept. 11 attack, Poland was host to an international antiterrorism conference at which 17 nations in the region agreed on a plan for sharing information about potential terrorist activities and about procedures to combat money laundering.
This month in Riga, Latvia, in preparation for the NATO conference in Prague in November, I proposed a new dialogue among the nations of Central, Eastern and southern Europe to strengthen our security cooperation against terrorism. The point is not to create a new formal body, but to seek a regional consensus and partnership. This new partnership would be open to all the nations in the region, with participation from Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, three nations that are already members of NATO. For countries in our region that are outside the Euro-Atlantic structures of NATO and the European Union, this dialogue can encourage democratic reforms already begun.
On the economic front, Poland can set an example. Just 12 years ago, more than 70 percent of Poland's gross domestic product came from the state sector. Today, more than 70 percent comes from the private sector. Poland has stabilized its finances. We have been successful in reducing inflation. In 1990, the vast majority of Polish exports went to Eastern European markets, whereas today more than 70 percent of Polish trade is with the European Union. In the course of a decade, we went from a highly centralized, state-controlled economy to an economy with about two million small and medium-sized businesses, which have become the foundation for Poland's economic modernization. Foreign direct investments of more than $50 billion in the past decade have helped to alter the face of Poland and energized a crucial development impulse. American investment is more central to our progress now than ever.
President Bush and I will be discussing these matters in our meetings over the next two days. We will need America as our partner to build on Poland's successes and show the nations of our region that political and economic transformation is possible. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Mayor Indicates Budget Fixes Could Be Sooner Than Usual 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
As the skittish stock market threatens to further deplete New York City's finances, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signaled yesterday that his administration might move to modify the city's month-old $42.3 billion budget sooner rather than later.
 Mayor Bloomberg noted at a news conference that the city had already forecast large deficits for next year and the following year, and said that the volatile stock market could throw those projections off by a billion dollars in either direction. Of the next two years, he said, "nobody should think for a second that we aren't going to have a difficult problem that we have to start facing, and we're going to start facing it very soon." 
 Asked if the mayor was talking about quickly modifying the budget that went into effect on July 1, a mayoral spokesman, Jordan Barowitz, said, "We are aware of the problems in the out years and we will begin to address them presently." 
The city, which just closed a $5 billion budget gap in its new budget, is projecting deficits of $3.7 billion in 2004 and $4.2 billion in 2005. 
Midyear budget modifications are not at all unusual in New York City, which is required by law to end each year with a balanced budget, but significant changes to the budget are not usually made until at least midfall. It is unclear when the Bloomberg administration is thinking about changing this year's budget. 
Mr. Bloomberg made his remarks as City Comptroller William C. Thompson Jr. issued a report cautioning that the city's newly adopted budget still contained a little more than a billion dollars in risks, and a few days before he is scheduled to make a budget presentation to the New York State Financial Control Board. (The board was created during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's and it still monitors the city's budgets.) 
The risks identified in the comptroller's report include federal aid that may not materialize, overtime costs that could turn out to be higher than projected, and new contracts with the city's unions that may prove more expensive than expected. 
The report included a note of warning about the recent corporate scandals that have pummeled the stock market, saying that "the downturn in the stock market doubly affects the city's budget." The loss of earnings will drive down tax collections, the report noted, even as it adds to the city's expenses by forcing the city to contribute more money to its pension funds in order to offset investment losses by the funds.
Mayor Bloomberg said that it was hard to predict what would happen to the economy in the long term, and where it would leave the city's finances. But, he said, "We're going to have to find ways to do more with less, no question about it."

HEADLINE: U.P.S. and Teamsters Reach Deal for a 25% Raise 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Facing the threat of another crippling strike, the United Parcel Service announced yesterday that it had reached a tentative six-year pact that will give 210,000 Teamsters a 25 percent increase in wages and benefits.
 The agreement, covering more workers than any other private-sector union contract in the nation, was a victory for the union in other ways, too. U.P.S. promised to convert 10,000 part-time jobs to full-time and to give raises of more than 50 percent to many part-timers. 
 The accord was the biggest test for the Teamsters' president, James P. Hoffa, and gives solid gains to the union at a time when organized labor and millions of workers face difficulties.
With a strike threatened for Aug. 1, the International Brotherhood of Teamsters capitalized on the company's eagerness to avoid a replay of the walkout in 1997 that stopped business for three weeks and caused United Parcel to lose $750 million and many longtime customers. 
"This appears to be a very strong contract, particularly with what else has been happening in labor," Harley Shaiken, a labor expert at the University of California, said. "U.P.S. did not want a strike, and that gave the Teamsters a lot of leverage. In many negotiations, the issue has been the survival of the union or the extent of the cuts. But here a big company that's very competitive was willing to pay rather than have its future damaged."
Mr. Hoffa and other union leaders said the accord would be a model for millions of other union members. Teamster officials said the pact would cost U.P.S. an additional $9 billion over six years and would not reduce health benefits at a time many corporations were reducing their medical plans.
"These negotiations have taken place in an economic climate in which millions of American workers are seeing their health benefits cut and their retirement savings wiped out," Mr. Hoffa said. "We have shown the nation that job and benefit cuts are not inevitable."
The chairman of United Parcel, Michael L. Eskew, acknowledged that the contract might be generous, but said it was affordable and would help the company grow by assuring customers that there would be no work stoppage for at least six years. 
Last week, executives announced that the company was losing business as customers diverted shipments to other companies because they feared a walkout.
The deal was unusual in that it was reached 16 days before the five-year contract expired.
"It was important for us to settle early," Mr. Eskew said in a telephone interview. "We wanted to give our customers the comfort of knowing that we will be there all the way through for them. Nobody wanted a return of the bad situation of 1997."
On Monday, officials from 200 locals that represent United Parcel workers will meet in Washington to vote on accord. Mr. Hoffa predicted that the delegates would ratify the contract and that the rank and file would vote on it over the next month.
The agreement gives a $5-an-hour raise over six years to full-time drivers and warehouse workers who earn $23.05 an hour. That is an increase of 3.3 percent a year and almost 22 percent over six years.
For part-timers, the deal offers raises of $6 an hour over six years. Part-timers earn $8.50 to $20 an hour. Company executives said many part-timers would not receive the full raise because they were college students who quit after a year or two.
The vice president for investor relations, Kurt Kuehn, said that including increases in pension and health payments overall compensation would increase 4 percent a year.
James J. Valentine, a transportation analyst with Morgan Stanley, said the contract was good for U.P.S.
"When you factor in all the elements of the contract," Mr. Valentine said, "it will be only slightly more inflationary than their contract that's to expire. U.P.S. clearly was seeing a reasonable amount of diversion of business in late June and early July. Getting closure on this contract was critical to stem those volume losses."
United Parcel, whose headquarters are in Atlanta, had net income of $2.4 billion last year on revenues of $30.6 billion.
The contract achieves a goal similar to one that Mr. Hoffa's archrival, Ron Carey, the former union president, sought in the 1997 contract, converting part-time jobs to full-time. The company has now promised to convert 2,500 of its 110,000 part-time jobs to full-time each year in the last four years of the contract.
Mr. Hoffa boasted that he did better than Mr. Carey by persuading the company to let nearly 10,000 nonunion workers become Teamsters. Many of those employees work for subcontractors, mostly performing clerical work, and the company agreed to move those jobs in-house, automatically making many of the workers Teamsters. 
Ken Hall, co-chairman of Mr. Hoffa's negotiating team and five years ago head of Mr. Carey's negotiating team, said the talks nearly fell apart on Friday because the company was refusing to convert any part-time jobs to full-time. Mr. Hoffa joined the negotiations on Friday in Washington, and until the agreement was reached late Monday, the talks continued nearly around the clock.
The union tried to bolster its stand by increasing dues payments and arranging a $100 million credit line. The moves were intended in part to finance strike benefits in a walkout.
Clearly viewing the accord as one of his biggest achievements, Mr. Hoffa said, "It is the richest contract in U.P.S. history and will set the tone for all collective bargaining for years to come."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael L. Eskew, United Parcel Service chairman, left, and James P. Hoffa, Teamsters president, at a Washington news conference yesterday, announcing a tentative contract that Mr. Hoffa called a model. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Dr. Greenspan's Prescription 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, memorably defined an economic moment when he declared in late 1996 that the fast-rising stock market was caught up in "irrational exuberance." He did so again yesterday when he warned Congress that the business world had been gripped by an "infectious greed" and that government must take strong steps to clean up corporate leadership. With Congress divided on how to proceed -- the Senate passed a tough corporate fraud bill this week, while the House adopted a weaker one -- Mr. Greenspan's words give powerful ammunition to those arguing for a hard line. 
 Mr. Greenspan's appearances on Capitol Hill are widely seen as a barometer of the strength of the economy. He was cautiously optimistic on that score yesterday, but he had a larger point to make: If our economic system is to function as it should, corporate America and government must get serious about keeping the system honest. The American economy "depends critically on trust," Mr. Greenspan declared. Investors who lack confidence in the system will be reluctant to buy stocks. 
 The White House has tried to fix blame for Enron, WorldCom and other scandals on a few "bad apples" in the nation's boardrooms, but Mr. Greenspan made a strong case that the problem is systemic. It is not that people are greedier, he argued, but rather that "the avenues to express greed" have "grown so enormously." At the same time, institutions that should be protecting shareholders from corporate ripoffs are failing them. To Mr. Greenspan the best form of corporate governing remains control by a strong C.E.O. But he recommended that in exchange for that power C.E.O.'s bear a heavy burden of accurately reporting on the condition of their companies to shareholders and potential investors. 
In the sharply partisan world of Washington, Mr. Greenspan is widely respected on both sides of the aisle. With the markets continuing to tumble -- the Dow fell 166 points more yesterday -- Congress should follow his prescription: Get tough on corporate malfeasance. As the Senate and House work to reconcile their corporate fraud bills, they should favor the Senate's tougher version. President Bush should, too -- and he should take pointers from Mr. Greenspan on how to craft a speech that explains why all Americans have a vital stake in seeing the system fixed. 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Washington Talk; 
Pay Erodes, Judges Flee, And Relief Is Not at Hand

BYLINE:  By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16 

 BODY:
The men and women in the hearing room were accustomed to exercising power in Washington.
 There were two members of the Supreme Court, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justice Stephen G. Breyer. There was Paul A. Volcker, former chairman of the Federal Reserve. Among others, there were Constance Horner, who once oversaw the federal work force as director of the Office of Personnel Management, and Donna E. Shalala, once again a college president after eight years in the cabinet. 
 They had come together to discuss the erosion in judicial pay, and all agreed that the failure to keep up both with inflation and with salaries available on other legal-profession career tracks had brought the federal judiciary to a crisis point. "It's reached the place where the institution is threatened with irreparable injury," Justice Breyer said as the others nodded sympathetically.
Resignations from the federal bench, where salaries now range from $150,000 in the district courts to $192,600 for the chief justice, were once nearly unheard of. They have become commonplace, with 70 life-tenured federal judges having resigned or retired (as opposed to continuing to carry a caseload as senior judges) since 1990.
"Our system cannot long tolerate the regular loss of experienced, seasoned judges that is now occurring," Chief Justice Rehnquist said, to more nods of agreement.
Yet by the end of the justices' testimony on Monday, at the start of a week of hearings before the National Commission on the Public Service, it was evident that despite the good will and unanimity of opinion, despite Justice Breyer's colorful charts that showed judges falling behind not only law professors but also judges in Canada and England, these powerful people were powerless.
How could members of Congress, politically afraid to raise their own $150,000 salaries yet unwilling to see federal judges' pay outstrip their own, ever be persuaded to help? Ms. Horner called the linkage to Congressional pay and the daunting obstacle it poses "the elephant in the room." Turning to the chief justice, she asked, "What institutions are capable of making the case?"
"You answer that," Chief Justice Rehnquist said to Justice Breyer. "You have more feel for institutions than I have." 
Whether the handoff was gracious -- Justice Breyer spent his pre-judicial years as counsel to the Senate Judiciary Committee -- or ironic, coming from the court's senior member to its most junior, was impossible to tell. In any event, there was a subtext to the two justices' appearance. It was barely alluded to during the hearing but well known to the audience, composed mostly of judicial branch insiders although the hearing, at the Brookings Institution, was open to the general public.
Four months ago, the two were on opposite sides of an appeal that might have placed the court in the middle of a constitutional as well as political debate over judicial pay. Twenty federal judges had brought a lawsuit charging that Congress violated the Constitution when it reneged on a bargain it made with the judiciary in a 1989 law, the Ethics Reform Act. 
Under that law, the judges received a 25 percent raise and the promise of regular cost-of-living increases in return for giving up the right to earn most types of outside income. But in four of five years from 1995 to 1999, Congress blocked the automatic increases, which also applied to Congressional pay and were politically unpalatable to the new Republican majority. The judges' unsuccessful lawsuit argued that this breaking of the promise amounted to a diminution of judicial pay, forbidden by the "compensation clause" of Article III.
The judges appealed to the Supreme Court, where, for all of Justice Breyer's best efforts, they fell one vote short of the four needed for the court to take their case. Chief Justice Rehnquist, despite his many speeches urging attention to judicial pay, would not provide the fourth vote, for reasons he never explained.
But the two were clearly back on the same page at Monday's hearing before the privately financed commission, a replay of a similar inquiry into the problems of federal government service that Mr. Volcker headed in 1988. Among the commission's concerns is a recent survey showing that federal workers are disillusioned, with 41 percent saying they come to work only for their paycheck and revealing a range of intractable quality-of-life problems.
Judges, by contrast, come to work despite their paychecks, to a job they love, as long as they overlook the fact that their law clerks outstrip them in earnings within a year or two. "I think we have a fabulous job," Justice Breyer said.

PERSON: William F. Gorog 

HEADLINE: William Gorog, 76, Businessman With a Bent for High Technology 

BYLINE:  By ARI L. GOLDMAN 

 BODY:
William F. Gorog, a technology entrepreneur who was one of the first to develop the public's ability to pay over the phone with credit cards and later via the Internet, died Sunday at a hospital in Falls Church, Va. He was 76 and lived in nearby McLean.
 The cause was lung cancer, family members said. 
 Over a 40-year career in business, Mr. Gorog founded and developed numerous technologies that were sold or spun off as separate ventures. In the 1960's, he was a founder and chief executive of the Data Corporation, which originated the computerized information retrieval system that is known today as LexisNexis and used by thousands of businesses, law firms and federal agencies. The company later merged with the Mead Corporation.
At his death, Mr. Gorog was the chairman of the InteliData Corporation, which pioneered the development of electronic banking and bill paying. Early telephone bill-paying systems involved delays of sometimes days while banks were notified, checks were cut and bills were paid. 
InteliData was one of the companies that developed computer systems that could almost instantly make deductions from a customer's account to issue payments. Mr. Gorog founded the company in 1990 as US Order and sold some of the company's technologies to Visa International in 1994.
Mr. Gorog also took a break from business to work as an economic adviser in the Ford administration. He served as the deputy director of the President's Economic Policy Board and later as executive director of the Council on International Economic Policy.
After leaving government, Mr. Gorog established a trading company that exported computer products to the Far East. From 1983 to 1987, he served as the president of the Magazine Publishers of America, a trade group.
In 1987, he became chairman of Arbor International, an investment management company involved in financing energy, technology and real estate ventures. The banking and bill-paying business grew out of his work at Arbor.
Mr. Gorog was born in Warren, Ohio, on Sept. 2, 1925. He learned about business from his father, Frank, who turned the family grocery store into a chain of successful supermarkets. He was a graduate of West Point and Ohio State University and served in both World War II and the Korean War.
Mr. Gorog's community activities include serving as chairman of the board of visitors of the Georgetown University School of Business. He was also a member of the Knights of Malta, a lay order of the Roman Catholic Church.
Mr. Gorog is survived by his wife of 53 years, Gretchen, and six children, Robin, of Aspen, Colo.; Jonathan, of Virginia Beach; Christopher, of Toluca Lake, Calif.; Lesley Gorog Harris, of McLean; Jennifer Gorog Nichols, of McLean; and Peter, of Oakton, Va.; and 21 grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Fall as Investors Ignore Greenspan's Assurances on the Economy

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Prices of blue-chip stocks fell for the seventh consecutive session yesterday, as investors and traders ignored generally reassuring comments from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, and data that strongly suggested that manufacturing activity was recovering. 
 "Sentiment and psychology have taken over, and they just don't change that fast," said Philip S. Dow, a managing director at RBC Dain Rauscher in Minneapolis. "This thing will wear itself out, but I don't know when." 
 Although ebbing investor confidence is cited as the major hurdle confronting the market, trading recently has been dominated by computer-generated program trades. 
"We haven't seen program trading levels this high, ever," said Paul Hickey, an analyst at Birinyi & Associates, a stock market research firm in Westport, Conn. 
"If people can get 50 cents on a trade, they will do it," Mr. Hickey said. "They are taking bite-sized pieces, and there is no stability."
With the in-and-out nature of such trades, he added, "there is too much volatility to get a decent picture." 
The Dow Jones industrial average opened lower yesterday, after Monday's startling turnaround, when it fell more than 400 points but retraced nearly all of the decline in the final 90 minutes of trading. A Fed report showing industrial production rose 0.8 percent in June failed to produce buyers.
The Dow fell further shortly after Mr. Greenspan began his semiannual testimony to the Senate Banking Committee at 10 a.m. yesterday. 
The slide moderated at midday, but a big sell program sent the average down again with about an hour left in the session.
By the close, the Dow was down 166.08 points, or 1.9 percent, to 8,473.11. 3M, Exxon Mobil, General Electric and Wal-Mart Stores led the index lower. 
Wal-Mart had its biggest one-day loss in 19 months, falling $3.56, to $49.88.
According to Birinyi & Associates, this decline for seven consecutive sessions is only the third in the last 20 years. The most recent occurred last September.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 16.99 points, or 1.9 percent, to 900.94. Consumer stocks contributed almost half the loss. 
The Nasdaq composite index, down 75 percent from its peak in March of 2000, was up early in the day, but the gains were subsequently erased and the index closed at 1,375.26, down 7.36 points, or 0.5 percent. 
Since the start of the year, the Dow is down 15.45 percent, the S.& P. 500 is off 21.53 percent, and the Nasdaq has dropped 29.5 percent. 
"If I stand on my head, everything looks wonderful," said Al Goldman, chief market strategist at A. G. Edwards in St. Louis. 
"The only good news is that Nasdaq is down 75 percent from the peak. The blue chips that have been holding up well are getting smashed."
In his Senate testimony, Mr. Greenspan said the Fed had raised its forecast for economic growth for this year and for 2003. 
Fed analysts now project the economy will grow 3.5 percent to 3.75 percent this year, up from the 3 percent to 3.25 percent they had forecast in February.
Nextel Communications was one of the few bright spots yesterday. 
The mobile phone company reported second-quarter profit on a 25 percent jump in sales and a gain from retiring preferred stock. 
Nextel shares jumped $1.53, or 31 percent, to $6.53. --------------------

Treasury Prices Fall
(By Bloomberg News) -- Treasuries fell for a third trading day in four yesterday as the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said that the economy's recovery from recession was gaining strength.
By late in the day, the price of the 10-year note declined 15/32, to 101 14/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, rose to 4.68 percent from 4.63 percent on Monday. The 30-year bond dropped 27/32, to 99. Its yield increased to 5.45 percent from 5.39 percent.

HEADLINE: State Officials Ask Bush To Act on Global Warming 

BYLINE:  By JAMES STERNGOLD 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, July 16 

 BODY:
In a letter that attacks what it says is the Bush administration's failure to address the looming crisis of global warming, the attorneys general of 11 states have written to the president pressing for strong federal measures to limit emissions of so-called greenhouse gases.
 The state officials argue in the letter, to be sent on Wednesday to President Bush, that his administration's "regulatory void" has left it to the states to piece together a patchwork of inconsistent regulations on the environment and that a strong federal policy would be far more effective. 
 The letter was written as Gov. Gray Davis of California was scheduled to sign a bill on Monday intended to reduce emissions of heat-trapping gases like carbon dioxide. Mr. Davis's approval of the bill, which would require automakers to sell more fuel-efficient cars, had been widely expected since the Legislature passed it. The passage, despite strong opposition from the automobile industry, could prod additional states to take similar measures, because California has by far the largest automobile market in the nation. 
The officials sending the letter to Mr. Bush, all Democrats, indirectly criticized him for saying that the science on global warming had not conclusively proved its existence. The officials cited a report that the administration issued in May, saying it justified strong action to avoid potentially devastating consequences to the environment and public health.
"For these reasons," the officials said, "we write today to urge you to reconsider your position on the regulation of greenhouse gases and to adopt a comprehensive policy that will protect both our citizens and our economy." 
The letter was spearheaded by the attorney general of Massachusetts, Thomas F. Reilly. It was also signed by the attorneys general of New York, Connecticut, New Jersey, California, Alaska, Maine, Maryland, New Hampshire, Rhode Island and Vermont.
The letter also contended that the administration's environmental policies had made problems worse.
"Far from proposing solutions to the climate change problem, the administration has been adopting energy policies that would actually increase greenhouse gas emissions," it read.
A spokeswoman for the White House, Claire Buchan, noted that the National Governors' Association last year and the state environmental commissioners in 2000 rejected calls for mandatory reductions in carbon dioxide emissions.
"The president is working on a bipartisan common-sense approach," Ms. Buchan said.
Mr. Bush's Clear Skies initiative, she said, "would lead to the largest reduction in power plant emissions ever."
The principal greenhouse gas is carbon dioxide, which automobiles, as well as power plants and numerous industries, release into the air. The carbon dioxide retains heat from the sun in the atmosphere, rather than letting it dissipate, contributing to a slow rising of temperatures.
Scientists have shown that the warming, although measured in just a degree or two on average in some places, has already had effects like allowing a proliferation of insects to destroy spruce forests in Alaska and raising the average levels of the oceans. The scientists warn that the warming, if unchecked, could flood coastal areas, disrupt water supplies, cause heat waves and destroy some wetlands and coral reefs while increasing problems from insect-borne diseases.
The amount of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere was relatively constant for 400,000 years, experts say. But with the industrial revolution 150 years ago, it has soared. Carbon dioxide has an unusually long life in the atmosphere, so even with drastic action, experts say, it could take years for Earth to begin cooling again. 
In an interview, Mr. Reilly, the Massachusetts attorney general, criticized Mr. Bush's dismissal of the science on global warming and said there was a new sense of urgency.
"You can't ignore this any longer," he said. "This is not something you can fool around with. The kind of brushoffs we've gotten from the administration are kind of offensive."
David Samson, the attorney general of New Jersey, added that global warming "poses real and immediate dangers to New Jersey's environment and the health of our citizens."
The authors do not specify what they want, but Mr. Reilly said they were seeking at the least caps on the carbon dioxide that power plants emit, as well as increases in average mileage standards for automobiles.
The authors suggest so-called market-based policies. Under such programs, which are used in a number of industries that produce large volumes of gas emissions, companies can profit from lowered emissions by selling their emission "rights" to other companies that produce more gases. The extra costs and the potential profits give companies an incentive to cut back. Conservatives have embraced such market-driven policies in many instances.
"The letter is one that ought to receive a lot of sympathy in the Bush administration," Richard Blumenthal, the attorney general of Connecticut, said, "because it calls for a market-based approach to capping the total greenhouse gases and allocating credits to industries and companies to buy and sell. It's a very Republican approach."
In addition to the action by the California Legislature, a few other states, including New York, are moving in the direction of limiting carbon emissions. 
According to the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group, automobiles produce 25 percent of the carbon dioxide emissions in the country and power plants produce 40 percent.

HEADLINE: His Global Empire in Disarray, DeutscheTelekom Chief Resigns 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 16 

 BODY:
Yielding to intense political pressure and a stubbornly depressed stock price, the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom, Ron Sommer, resigned today as the head of a company he had sought to transform from a state monopoly into a global communications colossus.
 Deutsche Telekom named a former chairman of its supervisory board, Helmut Sihler, 72, as caretaker chief executive for six months. The decision may calm the company's unions, who fear that an outsider would bring drastic change, but it is unlikely to soothe anxious shareholders. 
 "When a chief executive cannot rely on the full confidence of the supervisory board, resignation is the only responsible step left open," Mr. Sommer said at a news conference at company headquarters in Bonn. "I want to play my part in avoiding further damage to the company." 
Mr. Sommer's ouster came after a relentless campaign by the German chancellor, Gerhard Schroder, who fears that Deutsche Telekom's anemic share price could hurt him in elections this fall. Mr. Schroder's conservative opponent, Edmund Stoiber, has called for the government to intervene in solving the company's problems. 
Deutsche Telekom, Europe's largest communications company with $73 billion in annual sales and nearly 200,000 employees, is still 43 percent owned by the German government. It was carved out of the state postal and telecommunications ministry in 1995 and first issued shares in 1996. For millions of Germans, buying the company's shares was their first foray into the stock market.
Mr. Sommer's departure added a prominent new name to the list of European corporate chiefs who have been pushed from their perches in recent months by a lethal combination of ambitious global expansion, plummeting stock prices and increasingly impatient shareholders.
Experts said it also raised hard questions about Germany's effort to modernize its economy. Toppling Mr. Sommer in the heat of a political campaign, and for only a stopgap successor, is a reminder that politics still plays a disruptive role in this country's largest public companies.
"Shareholders were already expressing their anger toward Deutsche Telekom," said Rudiger von Rosen, managing director of the Deutsche Aktieninstitut, a shareholder research group. "But the whole focus in recent days has been political. That hurts our equity culture."
The finance ministry welcomed Mr. Sommer's resignation, which it said would open the door to a new strategy for the debt-ridden company. But on Monday, as the search for a successor became a messy public exercise -- with a who's who of German executives turning down the job -- Mr. Schroder's advisers distanced him from the whole affair.
The reaction today to Mr. Sihler, a former chairman of the consumer products giant Henkel, was cool. Though respected in German industry, he has not been an active manager for a decade. "An interim solution is no solution," said Ulrich Hocker, managing director of one of Germany's largest shareholder associations. "They should have kept Mr. Sommer until they found a permanent chief executive."
Moreover, Deutsche Telekom's board named Gerd Tenzer, a former civil servant and longtime senior manager, as deputy chief executive. When Mr. Tenzer's name emerged on Monday as the government's preferred candidate to succeed Mr. Sommer, the company's already battered share price fell further.
Despite Mr. Tenzer's chilly reception by investors, Mr. Sihler did not rule him out as a potential future leader. Given Mr. Sihler's age and background, analysts said Mr. Tenzer was likely to take a central role in running the company.
Trading here today in Deutsche Telekom stock was volatile. It jumped 8 percent after Mr. Sommer resigned, then gave back some gains after his successor was announced. Late in the day, the shares rose again, closing at 10.93 euros, up more than 6 percent for the day but still down about 90 percent from their peak in early 2000. In New York, the American depository receipts edged up 15 cents, to $11.06.
At a news conference, Mr. Sihler said his primary task would be to find a new chief executive. He reaffirmed that Deutsche Telekom was receptive to finding a merger partner for VoiceStream, the American wireless provider. Mr. Sommer acquired the company last year in a $35 billion deal that crowned his expansionist strategy but was criticized as being too expensive.
Mr. Sihler said Deutsche Telekom was heartened by recent signs of subscriber growth at VoiceStream. And he said the company would not abandon its ambitions to be a global player. "We want to be an international company," he said. "We cannot and will not be a company only in Germany."
Mr. Sommer, a charismatic, Israeli-born executive who charted Deutsche Telekom's growth, remained defiant even as he took his leave. He said the company was on the right course and he criticized the political interference, which he said had harmed the company.
Mr. Sommer had waged a spirited battle to hold on to his job, taking out newspaper ads in his defense and rallying employees to march in front of corporate headquarters in Bonn before today's meeting.
About 200 employees, who had been bused in from the company's regional offices, blew whistles and carried signs that said, "Without Sommer, things look dim."
Even some Deutsche Telekom investors advocated that Mr. Sommer stay -- which was remarkable, given that they had been calling for his head for months. At the annual meeting in May, a line of angry shareholders castigated Mr. Sommer for the stock price. "We invested in a high-risk junk stock," said Jella Benner-Heinacher, speaking for an association of small investors.
By this week, though, groups like Ms. Benner-Heinacher's had had a change of heart. They argued that retaining Mr. Sommer made more sense than replacing him with a former member of the supervisory board, who did not seem any more qualified to turn things around.
Rolf Drees, an analyst at Union Investment in Frankfurt, said the government wanted to score political points, but was not willing to address the deep-rooted problems at Deutsche Telekom.
"The chancellor said, 'I've got to do something' but he had no solution," remarked Mr. Drees, whose firm owns 45 million shares in the company.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Yes, HeCan Top That

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
"Infectious greed."
 The man who gave us "irrational exuberance" is back, with a phrase that sums up the late 1990's even better than that one did. 
 "An infectious greed seemed to grip much of our business community," the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, told the Senate Banking Committee yesterday. The way he sees it, the incentives created by poorly designed stock options "overcame the good judgment of too many corporate managers."
"It is not," he added, "that humans have become any more greedy than in generations past. It is that the avenues to express greed had grown so enormously." Stock options meant that executives could get rich if they faked profits, and fake them they did. 
Investors followed Mr. Greenspan's words intently yesterday, as always. But it may not have been his views on the speculative excesses of old that affected share prices. Instead his upbeat assessment of the current economy paradoxically may have hurt prices. There was no hint that the current stock market decline would lead the Fed to ease credit again next month, as some had hoped. Instead, Mr. Greenspan seemed to indicate that the next move in rates would be up, although he did not appear to be warning that such a move was imminent.
The Dow Jones industrial average, down 109 points when Mr. Greenspan's prepared text was released, fell a bit more but then rallied as he spoke, a fact several senators noted. But it settled back later in the day, ending down 166 points at 8,473. That is the lowest close since Sept. 21, but it is 228 points above Monday's low.
In 1996, Mr. Greenspan briefly terrified investors after he used the "irrational exuberance" phrase in a rhetorical question. But he soon backed off from it. Any idea that he might try to slow the market's rise, either by raising interest rates or by tightening margin requirements on share purchases, was soon forgotten.
Just for the record, all the major averages are still higher than they were when the phrase "irrational exuberance" entered the lexicon.
By 1999, Mr. Greenspan was giving speeches that reassured the bulls even as stock valuations moved into territory never before seen in this country. A cautious man, he never failed to utter a qualifier when praising the new economy, but there was little doubt which side he was on.
On April 5, 2000 -- less than a month after the Nasdaq peaked and the bubble began to leak -- Mr. Greenspan spoke to the White House Conference on the New Economy, citing Wall Street analysts' forecasts as a reason to think that profits would only continue to rise:
"While growth in companies' projected earnings has been revised up almost continuously across many sectors of the economy in recent years, the gap in expected profit growth between technology firms and others has persistently widened. As a result, security analysts' projected five-year growth of earnings for technology companies now stands nearly double that for the remaining S.& P. 500 firms.
"To the extent that there is an element of prescience in these expectations," he added, "it would reinforce the notion that technology synergies are still expanding and that expectations of productivity growth are still rising."
Then came the qualifier. "There are many who argue, of course, that it is not prescience but wishful thinking," he said. "History will judge."
History now has judged, and Mr. Greenspan was happy to pronounce the verdict yesterday. There was, he said, "a once-in-a-generation frenzy of speculation that is now over."
Mr. Greenspan maintains a unique position among public officials, with a stature so high that few are willing to criticize him and many treat his views as all but unquestionable. So it is regrettable that he was not sounding some of yesterday's warnings when they might have done some good, while the bubble was still inflating. Some of the "significant overcapacity" that still haunts the telecommunications industry might not have been built, and billions of dollars not wasted.
In 1996, Mr. Greenspan's exact words were: "But how do we know when irrational exuberance has unduly escalated asset values, which then become subject to unexpected and prolonged contractions as they have in Japan over the past decade? And how do we factor that assessment into monetary policy?"
On those questions, if Mr. Greenspan does not deserve a high grade for spotting the "escalated asset values" before they deflated, he deserves an A for his monetary policy after the bubble burst. By lowering rates quickly and deeply, he helped to spur housing investment and to keep the recession short and mild.
There are those who think there could be a bubble now in at least some housing markets and who warn of problems to come. But just as Mr. Greenspan once pointed to burgeoning capital investment as a sign of optimism and did not discuss what would happen if there was too much such investment, now he focuses on the benefits of the housing boom, which he said had been critical in supporting consumer spending as homeowners refinanced their mortgages.
One senator tried to get a comment on the level of home prices. "Housing price escalation has exceeded personal income growth for some time," pointed out Senator Evan Bayh, Democrat of Indiana. "Is it your view that this can go on indefinitely?"
Instead of answering, Mr. Greenspan launched into a discussion of productivity in the construction industry, which he said could help to explain why home-price inflation would outpace general inflation. He did not address the affordability question raised by Mr. Bayh.
The economy would be hurt far more now by a slide in home prices than it has been by the stock market slump, for as Mr. Greenspan noted, the vast majority of Americans have more invested in their homes than in their other investments. But while Mr. Greenspan was eager to denounce the excesses of the last decade, he did not choose to address either the likelihood of or the possible damage from an end to the current boom in housing.

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE OVERVIEW; 
FED CHIEF BLAMES CORPORATE GREED; HOUSE REVISES BILL

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, pointed today to a corporate culture blighted by "infectious greed" as the cause of the breakdown in confidence among investors. With political pressure growing and the stock market falling, the House hurriedly passed a measure that would toughen criminal fraud penalties to curb corporate wrongdoing.
 Mr. Greenspan's blunt testimony to Congress about avarice in the executive suite and the rushed effort by Republican leaders in the House not to be outdone by the Democratic-controlled Senate in legislating stiff sentences for corporate wrongdoers were the latest indications of how deeply questions about business integrity are reshaping both politics and economic policy. 
 The rapid-fire legislative maneuvering was noteworthy because the Republican-controlled House, which passed its own accounting and corporate governance measure in April, had previously urged a more limited scope to new laws and regulations than had the Senate and had not initially addressed criminal penalties. But with new accusations of accounting impropriety and corporate misconduct, as well as a continued tumble in stock prices, Republican leaders quickly came up with their own legislation. 
After falling more than 200 points this morning, the Dow Jones industrial average pared its loss to about 20 points during Mr. Greenspan's appearance on Capitol Hill, in which he reassured investors that the economy was fundamentally sound and poised for improvement. Excerpts, Page C8. 
But stock prices headed down again in the afternoon, defying any hope on the part of Mr. Greenspan -- as the market had defied President Bush's two attempts in the last week to instill confidence among investors with speeches emphasizing the positive -- that he might break the negative psychology on Wall Street.
For the day, the Dow dropped 166.08 points, to 8,473.11, bringing its loss over the last seven sessions to more than 900 points.
With both parties watching closely for outcries from individual investors, House Republicans, some of whom had previously warned against overreacting to accusations of falsified earnings and other misconduct, moved quickly today to insulate themselves politically from appearing to be too close to business.
They rushed to the floor a measure that they said would create criminal penalties for corporate fraud as harsh as, and in some case harsher than, those included in the legislation that was passed 97 to 0 by the Senate on Monday evening. President Bush has strongly hinted that he will sign any bill that emerges from Congress.
Among other provisions, the House bill would create a maximum prison sentence of up to 20 years for corporate fraud, or in one case 25 years, twice the maximum sentence called for in the Senate bill.
The House bill passed 391 to 28. Even as most of them voted for it, Democrats said the legislation would actually weaken some provisions of the Senate bill. They pointed in particular to a provision in the Senate bill but left out of the House bill that would extend the amount of time investors have to sue corporations for securities fraud. Democrats said the provision was important because it sometimes takes years before problems with corporate accounting are discovered.
The House bill addresses criminal corporate wrongdoing in "a responsible and measured way," said Representative Michael G. Oxley, the Ohio Republican and chairman of the House Financial Services Committee. Moreover, he said, it does not create "loopholes for voracious trial lawyers." 
But Senator Patrick J. Leahy, the Vermont Democrat and chairman of the Judiciary Committee, who sponsored most of the Senate's criminal-penalties provisions, called the House bill a "weak echo" of his legislation's language. 
"Now is not the time for half-measures and watered-down reforms," Mr. Leahy said.
The House and the Senate are expected to begin negotiations in coming days to reconcile the bills they passed this week as well as a broader bill on accounting standards and corporate governance passed by the House in April. President Bush has said he would like them to deliver a final bill to him before Congress goes into recess next month. Analysts and officials from both parties agreed that it would be extremely politically risky for Mr. Bush to veto the legislation that emerges from Congress, even if some provisions are unpalatable to the White House. 
The politics of the issue are playing out against the backdrop of a muddled economic outlook, in which signs of recovery from last year's recession are offset by the stock market's decline and eroding consumer confidence.
Testifying before the Senate Banking Committee, Mr. Greenspan signaled that the central bank was not in any hurry to raise the interest rates it controls from their current low levels. 
But he gave no indication that the Fed was considering cutting rates to give the faltering economic recovery a boost and put a floor under tumbling stock prices. And while he suggested that Wall Street could take some comfort in evidence that corporate earnings were improving, he said the evaporation of so much stock market wealth would weigh on the economy by holding down consumer spending.
While Mr. Greenspan was nominally on Capitol Hill to discuss the economy, he took the opportunity to make his first extensive remarks on the roots of the problems afflicting corporations and the stock market, and he did not pull any punches.
Mr. Greenspan, who noted that he had served on 15 corporate boards before becoming Fed chairman in 1987, pointed a finger straight at chief executives who put opportunities to cash in on stock options ahead of responsibilities to shareholders.
"The incentives they created overcame the good judgment of too many corporate managers," said Mr. Greenspan, who three years ago began calling for companies to list stock options as an expense on their financial statements. "It is not that humans have become any more greedy than in generations past. It is that the avenues to express greed had grown so enormously."
In his testimony today, the Fed chairman backed the various proposals to stiffen criminal penalties for executives who are found to have defrauded shareholders. He supported the idea of holding chief executives responsible for the accuracy of the financial information their companies disclose. 
In a sign of how much the climate surrounding issues of corporate governance had changed in Washington, Mr. Greenspan, long an advocate of deregulation and reliance on market forces to police good business practices, bluntly acknowledged that he had been mistaken in initially opposing government involvement in oversight of auditing. The creation of a new body to oversee the accounting industry is at the heart of the bills passed by both the House and the Senate in response to the corporate scandals.
"My view was always that accountants knew or had to know that the market value of their companies rested on the integrity of their operations" and that government regulation of accounting was therefore "unnecessary and indeed most inappropriate," Mr. Greenspan said. "I was wrong."
But Mr. Greenspan, who in late 1996 raised questions about "irrational exuberance," did not address whether the Fed's subsequent willingness to keep interest rates low as stocks rose and the economy boomed had contributed to the anything-goes climate he decried today.
In April, House Democrats publicly urged Republicans to allow a vote on legislation by Representative John Conyers, a Michigan Democrat, that included some of the tough new criminal penalties that the Senate approved on Monday. Efforts to bring that bill up were blocked by Republicans, however.
The criminal penalties bill passed today by the House, sponsored by Representative James F. Sensenbrenner, the Wisconsin Republican who is chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, keeps central provisions of the Senate bill. They include the creation of a securities-fraud statute calling for prison time for anyone using a "scheme or artifice" to defraud investors and prison terms for senior executives who "recklessly and knowingly" publish misleading financial statements.
In both cases, the House bill calls for longer maximum prison terms: sentences of up to 20 years or 25 years, versus sentences for up to 10 years for similar infractions in the Senate bill. On another point, however, the House version of the new securities-fraud statute calls for penalties only for those who "execute" a scheme to defraud investors. The Senate, by contrast, also criminalizes "attempts" to defraud. 
The next test of the political potency of the issue is likely to come in how quickly the House and Senate can work out their differences in approach. While there are important differences in their bills, the two chambers have come closer to a common view than anyone predicted even a few weeks ago.
Some Republicans even signaled that they would like the House simply to pass the bill sponsored by Paul S. Sarbanes, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee. Representatives Mark Foley of Florida and Mike Rogers of Michigan gathered 16 signatures this evening from fellow Republicans for a letter urging the House speaker, J. Dennis Hastert, to accept the Senate bill instead of convening a conference committee to reconcile the differences.
Mr. Hastert, an Illinois Republican, has no plan to forgo conference committee and pass the Senate bill, his spokesman, John Feehery, said tonight. 
Representative Billy Tauzin, a Louisiana Republican and chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee, predicted that the House, given the chance, would vote to approve the Senate bill. 
"We'd find a lot of support for that in the House," he said. Mr. Tauzin also said that there were "not a lot of big differences" in the Senate and House bills.
But other House leaders reiterated that they believed that the two chambers were still far apart on some crucial aspects of the legislation -- a split underscored today by the House's rejection of some of the Senate's provisions.
The differences include how much investigative and enforcement power to give to a new regulatory panel overseeing the accounting industry, how much to limit the consulting work that accounting firms can do for publicly traded companies they audit, and whether to keep other provisions that Democrats say are crucial protections but that some Republicans say would be a gravy train for trial lawyers.
Mr. Oxley, who as the sponsor of a bill passed by the House in April to reform accounting laws will play a crucial role in the House-Senate negotiations, said that it would be "rather unprecedented" for Congress to produce a bill out of conference committee by the time Congress goes home next month.
Mr. Oxley said a number of senators had privately told him that there are a "lot of things" they do not like about the Senate bill, but that they voted for it anyway because "nobody wanted to get in front of that train."
If the House-Senate negotiations extend into the fall, the bill's ultimate shape could be heavily influenced by the course of the economy and the financial markets. 
In his public comments, Mr. Greenspan said nothing today to alter the assumption that the Fed would leave its main interest rate, the federal funds target rate on overnight loans among banks, at 1.75 percent at least until the fall and possibly into next year.
"Considerable uncertainties -- about the progress of the adjustment of capital spending and the rebound in profitability, about the potential for additional revelations of corporate malfeasance, and about possible risks from global political events and terrorism -- still confront us," Mr. Greenspan said. "Nevertheless, the fundamentals are in place for a return to sustained healthy growth."

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: NEWS ANALYSIS; 
Who Should Mete Out Punishment?

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 16 

 BODY:
Washington and Wall Street are rarely on the same wavelength: markets judge change in seconds, while politicians take days -- or months -- to sniff the direction of the country and fashion a response.
 But even that traditional disconnect between the country's financial capital and its political one does not fully explain why President Bush and the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, are encountering such trouble calming investors. Yesterday and today they worked in tandem -- both talking about the economy's solid fundamentals that should relieve what Mr. Bush called the national "hangover" from the "binge" of the 1990's. 
 But investors are in no mood to listen. And if the two cities are talking past each other, one reason may be the contradictory incentives that define the worlds of New York and Washington. 
As always, Wall Street wants minimal government interference, figuring that the markets can mete out harsher, swifter penalties to offenders than Washington ever could. And as always, legislators and the president want to placate voters, which means they have to show that a culture of see-no-evil among government regulators is being changed -- for good.
Both have a point. Wall Street fears that the overhaul frenzy now gripping Washington could go too far -- and that Congress could pass draconian changes before thinking through the consequences. It is a view shared by many in the White House, chiefly Vice President Dick Cheney, who has grumbled to many in recent days that even if Congress cannot figure out a way to make it impossible to lose money in the stock market, it will probably try.
But on Capitol Hill, the view is that all the risk is in doing too little. Average investors, the Republicans and Democrats alike say, are looking for justice. "Why else," one Democratic senator asked the other day, "would we be obsessing about the length of jail sentences for C.E.O.'s rather than really thinking hard about the federal government's role in setting accounting standards?"
"Just think," he continued. "Just a month ago the biggest threat to this nation was Al Qaeda. Now its uncontrolled stock options."
The infection has even reached the White House.
Mr. Bush thought he had solved this problem in March, went he ordered the Securities and Exchange Commission to work out 10 new standards for corporate behavior. But in the last few weeks he has found some of his party stalwarts -- including those who raised bushel baskets of campaign contributions from chief executives in election season -- are racing to the microphones to demand stronger reforms than their president insisted upon. 
Mr. Bush's race to catch up with them helps explain why Wall Street has seemed unimpressed by his talk. Some investors worried that the president's heart wasn't really in the effort to clean up the system -- that it would be enough, in the president's mind, to root out what he called "a few bad apples." Conservatives, in contrast, worried that Mr. Bush's political advisers would push him too far, forcing him to sign whatever Congress serves up.
"Clearly the administration's view of this has changed pretty rapidly," said Gary Gensler, a senior official in the Treasury Department during the Clinton administration, who has been helping Senator Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat, in drafting the legislation that passed the Senate 97 to 0 on Monday night.
"But remember that Wall Street initially saw this differently as well. They used words like 'self-correcting,' and took pride in the fact that they were able to kill off some of the bigger reforms in early legislation. What they wanted was the Good Housekeeping seal, but without tasting any of the real ingredients."
Now, Mr. Gensler said, the big investment houses and Congress "can't even agree on who to be mad at." Wall Street executives are likely to focus on the accounting firms; Washington is likely to focus on chief executives.
The White House vigorously denies that Mr. Bush's intention in the last week has been to calm the markets. Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's press secretary, argued today that it would be ridiculous for any president to try to move the markets; he argued that Mr. Bush's best strategy was to focus on long-term policy, like tax cuts, and let the markets sort out the impact. Mr. Fleischer suggested that market players "themselves will recognize that they don't know very much what makes markets go up or down," and that market players in Washington are even worse.
Mr. Fleischer is clearly straining to explain why Mr. Bush's comments in recent days have been followed by some nasty sell-offs. But he may well be right: history suggests that when panic selling starts, almost no amount of political rhetoric leaves a lasting impression.
That was the lesson of the Asian economic crisis of 1997 and the Russian crisis that followed the next year. Once Thailand's and Indonesia's troubles were exposed, and South Korea admitted to some dubious accounting of its reserves, a selling panic swept the emerging markets. Well-run countries suffered alongside incompetently run countries. The word "contagion" took on a new meaning. Whatever reassurances national leaders offered fell on deaf ears.
It is a tempting comparison. But Roger Altman, the former deputy Treasury secretary who is now one of New York's most influential investors, observed today that this sell-off is different -- at once more discriminating and more punishing. "Back then, fund managers just said 'Get me out of any less-developed country' -- they didn't know the difference, and many didn't care. Here they know the companies and focus on them microscopically."
A result, he says, is a pummeling of the stock prices of any company even suspected of playing games with its books. "It's an incredible punishment, far worse than anything the executive or legislative branch could exact," Mr. Altman said. "And that's why the ultimate solution to this -- the restoration of confidence -- can't really come from Washington. It never has, and never will. Sure, there are things governments can do at the margins. But the real force for change has to come from the capital markets themselves, and it will be a long time, I think, before the lessons of the past few months are forgotten."

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT; 
Excerpts From Report By Greenspan at Senate

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, gave his semiannual report on the economy to the Senate Banking Committee yesterday. Following are excerpts from his testimony and from an exchange between Mr. Greenspan and Senator Thomas R. Carper, Democrat of Delaware, in a question-and-answer session after the testimony, as recorded by the Federal News Service Inc. A full transcript of Mr. Greenspan's testimony can be found online at nytimes.com.
 While the economy has held up remarkably well, not surprisingly the depressing effects of recent events linger. Spending will continue to adjust for some time to the declines that have occurred in equity prices. In recent weeks, those prices have fallen further on net, in part under the influence of growing concerns about corporate governance and business transparency problems that evidently accumulated during the earlier rapid run-up in these markets. Considerable uncertainties -- about the progress of the adjustment of capital spending and the rebound in profitability, about the potential for additional revelations of corporate malfeasance and about possible risks from global political events and terrorism -- still confront us. 
 Nevertheless, the fundamentals are in place for a return to sustained healthy growth. Imbalances in inventories and capital goods appear largely to have been worked off, inflation is quite low and is expected to remain so, and productivity growth has been remarkably strong, implying considerable underlying support to household and business spending as well as potential relief from cost and price pressures. . . .
Why did corporate governance checks and balances that served us reasonably well in the past break down? At root was the rapid enlargement of stock market capitalizations in the latter part of the 1990's that arguably engendered an outsized increase in opportunities for avarice. An infectious greed seemed to grip much of our business community. Our historical guardians of financial information were overwhelmed. Too many corporate executives sought ways to harvest some of those stock market gains. As a result, the highly desirable spread of shareholding and options among business managers perversely created incentives to artificially inflate reported earnings in order to keep stock prices high and rising. This outcome suggests that the options were poorly structured, and, consequently, they failed to properly align the long-term interests of shareholders and managers, the paradigm so essential for effective corporate governance. The incentives they created overcame the good judgment of too many corporate managers. It is not that humans have become any more greedy than in generations past. It is that the avenues to express greed had grown so enormously. 
Perhaps the recent breakdown of protective barriers resulted from a once-in-a-generation frenzy of speculation that is now over. With profitable opportunities for malfeasance markedly diminished, far fewer questionable practices are likely to be initiated in the immediate future. To be sure, previously undiscovered misdeeds will no doubt continue to surface in the weeks ahead as chastened C.E.O.'s restate earnings. But even if the worst is over, history cautions us that memories fade. Thus it is incumbent upon us to apply the lessons of this recent period to inhibit any recurrence in the future. 
A major focus of reform of corporate governance, of course, should be an improved functioning of our economy. A related, but separate, issue is that shareholders must perceive that corporate governance is properly structured so that financial gains are fairly negotiated between existing shareholders and corporate officeholders. Shareholding is now predominantly for investment, not corporate control. Our vast and highly liquid financial markets enable large institutional shareholders to sell their shares when they perceive inadequacies of corporate governance, rather than fix them. This has placed de facto control in the hands of the chief executive officer. Shareholders routinely authorize slates of directors recommended by the C.E.O. Generally, problems need to become quite large before C.E.O.'s are dislodged by dissenting shareholders or hostile takeovers. 
Manifestations of lax corporate governance, in my judgment, are largely a symptom of a failed C.E.O. . . .

SENATOR THOMAS R. CARPER -- I want to revisit an issue that revolves around the legislation that the Senate passed yesterday. . . .
Somewhere along the line, we're going to be asking you publicly or privately for your own counsel as to which provisions are most important that we retained from the Senate bill or maybe in which instances you think the House language is preferable. Do you have today any particular thoughts that you might share with me and with us as to what provisions of the Senate bill that you feel are most worth preserving as we go forward? 

MR. GREENSPAN -- Well, Senator, I thought that the initiative that was Senate-produced was very important and very effective. And indeed, as I said to the chairman before the hearing, my original view was that taking accounting standards and moving them out of the private sector was really utterly unnecessary because my view was always that accountants basically knew or had to know that the market value of their companies rested on the integrity of their operations and that, indeed, that signature that they put on an audit reform is where the net worth of the company comes from and that, therefore, their self-interest is so strongly directed at making certain that their reputation was unimpeachable that regulation by government was utterly unnecessary and, indeed, most inappropriate. I was wrong. I was really deeply distressed to find that actions were being taken which very clearly indicated a lack of awareness of where the market value of accounting is.
