HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: THE IMPACT; 
Is Uncertainty The Only Thing That Is Certain?

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
For investors, uncertainty has become the new norm.
 From small brokerage offices to sprawling trading floors, people who buy and sell stocks and were heartened by the economy's surprising resilience after Sept. 11 are asking what else can go wrong in corporate America. Along with millions of mutual fund investors, they want to know whether anybody -- in Washington, on Wall Street or in executive suites -- has a solution that will help them trust business again. 
 "The worst thing now," said R. L. Butler, a retired clergyman in Denver, "is you can't even trust the earnings reports. When you find the auditors in bed with the managers, there is nobody to believe." 
The latest evidence came yesterday, when Alan Greenspan, once the nation's most reliable mover of markets, pronounced the economy healthier than expected in testimony on Capitol Hill. By the end of the day the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen by almost 2 percent, its seventh consecutive daily loss.
Concerns about corporate earnings and stock prices have begun to threaten the unyielding optimism that built up during the long boom of the 1990's, according to surveys and interviews across the country. The optimism has not disappeared, but many people say they no longer assume that every piece of bad news about the economy or the markets will soon be followed by many pieces of good news.
"The question is whether the love affair that Americans had with stocks is dead or whether they're just adjusting their expectations," said Jeremy J. Siegel, a finance professor at the University of Pennsylvania and the author of a popular book on the long-term benefits of stock market investing. "There's a lot of confusion. A lot of people just don't know what to do."
For much of the last decade, the dominant investment strategy for ordinary investors was simple: buy, buy more and hold. The decision was almost always rewarded, as the United States economy expanded for the longest period on record and the nation's chief economic rivals faltered. Stock prices marched ever higher.
But a barrage of corporate scandals, combined with a 37 percent drop in the broad stock market since the beginning of 2000, has caused a questioning of the country's economic and financial future.
More Americans now expect the next five years to include periods of widespread unemployment than say there will be continuous good times, according to the University of Michigan's monthly survey of consumers. In the last month, the drop in confidence has been most pronounced among households making more than $50,000 a year, the same families that tend to own stocks.
"Sept. 11, the recession, the bear market, the renewed bear market and the concern about the profit numbers really have changed people's attitudes," said Robert C. Doll, president of Merrill Lynch's asset management group. "It's been brutal."
Financial advisers say some of the new skepticism is a painful but necessary adjustment to the late 1990's, when many investors came to expect 20 percent annual returns from Wall Street. And long-term confidence in both the economy and the stock market remains far higher than it was at the end of other recent recessions.
Many investors are simply uncertain about when the short term ends and the long term begins.
"I have no confidence in the stock market right now," said Tracey Gialde, a clerk at a mutual funds company in Kansas City, Mo., who moved some of her savings into a money market account last weekend. "There's just too much uncertainty."
Like many other people, however, Ms. Gialde said she refused to succumb to her worries by moving all her savings out of the stock market.
"I've lost money," she said, "but I've got 10 to 15 years before I retire, so I expect it to come back."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A Manhattan pedestrian checks stock prices at a TD Waterhouse brokerage firm office on Sixth Avenue at 44th Street. Investors are wondering if anyone can be trusted. (Ting-Li Wang/The New York Times)(pg. C9) Chart: "First Enron . . . Then the Deluge"When Enron filed for bankruptcy last December, the reaction among many investors was initially ho-hum, partly because it appeared that the economy was beginning to recover. But even as growth resumed, other companies revealed similar problems, shaking confidence in businesses and sending the market down. DEC. 2, '01 -- Enron files for bankruptcy, and in the weeks and months that follow, reports emerge about allegations of self-dealing among some of the top executives, particularly its former chief financial officer, Andrew S. Fastow. JAN. 22, '02 -- President Bush assails the executives of Enron, who contributed heavily to his campaign, for their handling of the company. JAN. 28 -- Global Crossing files for bankruptcy, becoming the largest telecommunications company to do so. The Securities and Exchange Commission and Congress begin investigations after questions arise about the company's accounting and insider selling by top executives before the company collapsed. MARCH 14 -- Arthur Andersen, Enron's auditor, is indicted on a charge of obstruction of justice after the collapse of Enron. It is the first major accounting firm to be indicted on a criminal charge. Three months later, on June 15, a federal jury convicts the firm, effectively putting it out of business. MARCH 27 -- Adelphia Communications discloses that it guaranteed billions of dollars in loans to the company's founders, the Rigas family. The company, the nation's sixth- largest cable operator, subsequently delays its annual report and later seeks bankruptcy protection. APRIL 1 -- Xerox says it overstated revenues for several years by almost $2 billion and agrees to pay a $10 million fine, the largest in history. MAY 21 -- Merrill Lynch agrees to pay $100 million in penalties and change the way it pays stock analysts to end an investigation by Eliot L. Spitzer, the attorney general of New York, into whether Merrill promoted stocks of companies whose investment banking business it wanted. JUNE 3 -- L. Dennis Kozlowski, chairman and chief executive of Tyco, is forced to resign just before he is indicted on a charge of evading more than $1 million in sales taxes. JUNE 25 -- WorldCom says it improperly accounted for $3.8 billion in expenses in 2001 and the first quarter of 2002. It fires its chief financial officer only weeks after forcing out its founder and chief executive, Bernard J. Ebbers. Congress and the S.E.C. begin investigations into the company's accounting. JULY 9 -- President Bush makes proposals to toughen penalties for people convicted of financial crimes and calls on companies and executives to be more accountable. Some critics say the proposals do not go far enough, and the Senate promptly passes a bill that is more far-reaching. JULY 10 -- Qwest Communications discloses that it is under criminal investigation by the Justice Department. The company had extensive dealings with Global Crossing. HEADLINE: Still Thinking Outside the Box 

BYLINE:  By ERIC A. TAUB 

 BODY:
BECAUSE the world is three-dimensional, there are those who believe that every representation of it should be in 3-D as well. Entrepreneurs and enthusiasts have long tried to convince the public that 3-D photographs, films and television shows are the next best thing to being there.
 Since 1838, when Sir Charles Wheatstone's stereoscope first enabled viewers to see a photograph in three dimensions, the 3-D fad has regularly surfaced. The 3-D film arrived in theaters in the 1920's, and the craze reached its peak in the 50's with B-movies like "Bwana Devil" and "House of Wax." Television picked up the cause later, with the first commercial 3-D shows broadcast in 1980. 
 Now a new set of entrepreneurs has taken up the banner, creating the latest iterations of 3-D systems for television and computers in a belief that the public's embrace of DVD's and wide-screen plasma displays will assure the programming's success. A company has even developed a technology that uses software and modified flat-panel screens to eliminate the need for the special eyeglasses that became synonymous with 3-D. 
But the question, now as then, is whether 3-D has staying power or will remain a gimmicky fad.
"Three-dimensional television is like the circus: it comes and it goes, and people line up to see it every time it appears," said Daniel Symmes, president of Dimension 3, a 3-D-television production company in Woodland Hills, Calif. Mr. Symmes was responsible for the first 3-D production on commercial television, a 1980 broadcast of the 1953 film "Miss Sadie Thompson" and a Three Stooges short on the SelecTV pay service.
Some 3-D advocates believe that this time, 3-D is here to stay. One reason it has not caught on before is that "no one wants to wear those crazy glasses," said Bruce Ettinger, a vice president of Dynamic Digital Depth, a company in Santa Monica, Calif., that is developing the 3-D system that requires no glasses. "Our market studies show that a good 3-D effect helps create the best viewer recall."
Others are not so sure. "The press always asks if 3-D is the next big thing, but then it never goes anywhere," said Mark Schubin, a television industry technological consultant. "No matter how well it's done, one always experiences eyestrain after a while. It would be hard to watch an entire football game in 3-D."
Technological issues aside, some argue that reality and the small screen are fundamentally different environments and should be treated as such.
"Is the logical progression of filmed entertainment from black-and-white to sound to color to 3-D?" asked Gerald Marks, a New York artist who creates 3-D video. "No, no, no.
"If people craved 3-D, it would have taken off, like color TV and stereo. But it hasn't. Movies, TV and still images are just fine without 3-D."
Even Mr. Symmes, who is as entranced with 3-D television as anyone, said he preferred it in small doses. 
"I like 3-D TV because it's magic," he said. "It's not real, it's realer than real. When you see a ball coming at you, you duck, even though you know it's only on television. But I don't want to watch 'Wheel of Fortune' in 3-D."
Most 3-D systems rely on the principle of binocular vision to achieve their effect: each eye receives a slightly different image corresponding to what it would see in reality. The brain then fuses the two images to create a sense of depth.
In his work, Mr. Symmes mostly uses the anaglyph 3-D method common to many films and comic books. The left and right images are superimposed and colored either cyan or red. When looking through glasses with cyan and red filters, each eye sees only the corresponding left or right image.
The anaglyph method allows for the "out of box" imagery that 3-D fans love: the sword emerging from the screen, the bats flying into one's face.
But the illusion works better in a theater than on television. Once an object seems to appear in front of the television screen, its perceived size shrinks rapidly because the viewer now compares it with the surrounding objects in the room. Suddenly, what looked like an imposing monster appears to be no bigger than a doll.
Watching an anaglyph-encoded program without special glasses is virtually impossible because trying to concentrate on only one of the superimposed images creates eyestrain. Although the Federal Communications Commission has allowed anaglyph-encoded programs to be broadcast, it is a poor economic proposition for a network if most of the audience has not bothered to pick up the free pair of glasses.
That is one reason some television executives have warmed up to the Pulfrich method, a system that also uses special glasses but presents a completely normal picture to those viewers who are not wearing them. (Another popular 3-D film technique, which uses polarized light, is not applicable to a TV or computer screen.) 
Based on the findings in 1922 of Carl Pulfrich, a German astronomer, the Pulfrich principle recognizes that the rods of the eye -- the receptors that work in dim light -- take longer to perceive light than do the eye's cones, which work in brighter light.
Using special glasses that have one clear lens and one lens dark enough that only rod-sensitive light will pass through, the two eyes will see the same object a split-second apart. The brain will perceive that object to be closer than a stationary one. For that effect to be apparent, however, the image must move.
The technique has been used on some television shows, including the 1989 broadcast of the Tournament of Roses parade in Pasadena, Calif., segments of the sitcom "Third Rock From the Sun" and a Rolling Stones music video.
In the Rolling Stones production, Mick Jagger pops off the screen as the cameras circle around him in a continuous dance. It is an effective if dizzying technique, one that no one would want to experience while watching the local news or "The Charlie Rose Show."
"The Pulfrich Effect is exceedingly limiting," said Mr. Marks, who created the Rolling Stones video and consulted on the 3-D presentation of the Tournament of Roses parade. "It's only good for short pieces. Still, it's the best technology from an artistic point of view."
Art aside, other companies are hoping to market 3-D by using techniques that avoid the limitations of the anaglyph and Pulfrich methods. The X3D Technologies Corporation, for example will begin shipping a $99 system that uses "flicker" technology to create a 3-D effect. For TV viewing, specially encoded DVD's alternately display left- and right-eye images on the screen; lightweight plastic glasses equipped with liquid crystal shutters open and close each lens in sync with the displayed image.
The technique, which is similar to that used in some Imax 3-D theaters and some 3-D computer game systems, works on PC monitors and TV's, but it has its own limitations, including flicker, reduced screen brightness and lower resolution.
But the big problem with glasses-based techniques, some argue, is that they create an isolated rather than a shared viewing experience. Dynamic Digital Depth, the company creating the glassless 3-D technology, says its system more accurately mimics the way people watch television: collectively and from different viewing angles.
The company uses several techniques to display 3-D. One involves placing a special lens over a flat-panel display, a sophisticated version of the lenticular lens on the plastic cards found in cereal boxes and on greeting cards that causes the image to change as the card or the viewer moves. Another involves placing a special barrier screen over the display that allows only the pixels that should be seen by the right and left eyes to pass through the screen at any time. The program's depth information is stored in a small separate data channel that can be transmitted along with a broadcast or DVD signal and decoded using a special set-top box. 
The company's technologies work from multiple viewing angles, so several people can sit together and experience 3-D. In a demonstration of the system, the effect ranged from strong to barely noticeable. And both brightness and effective resolution appeared lower than those on a regular flat-image plasma display. The company expects to improve both later this year with new techniques created for television and PC applications.
But regardless of what system is used to create a three-dimensional effect, the perceived quality always depends on how well the original material was processed. Unless the program was shot using two cameras mounted side by side to simulate the views received by each eye, the material must have depth information added to it. All too often, that means simply assigning different depths to various objects; the objects themselves then look flat but appear to be in different planes. It is as if a viewer were looking at cardboard cutouts of actors scattered throughout a scene.
Dynamic Digital Depth has created software to solve the depth problem. Working with a still frame from the moving image, an operator assigns any number of depth values to it by clicking on various points of an object in the frame. Those assigned values stay with the image as it moves throughout the frame and on to successive frames.
Still, the effect depends on the engineer's skill and how much time is available. "When you post-produce 3-D, you really need an infinite number of planes to create a good effect," Mr. Marks said. "I can spend up to two days working on just one still image to create the proper look."
But even the latest techniques do not erase the fundamental question about whether most people want to be entertained in 3-D.
The companies involved, not surprisingly, answer yes. "Three-dimensional TV is a bigger change to television than the switch from standard definition to HDTV," said Chris Yewdall, president of Dynamic Digital Depth. Others seem to agree; the company recently raised $10 million in public money.
Despite his own involvement in 3-D, Mr. Marks remains unconvinced.
"The only people who want 3-D television all the time are the people trying to sell it," he said. "3-D television is like caviar. You buy a little. But if you had to live on the stuff all the time, it would be awful."

For viewers without glasses, the image is unaffected.; The flicker technique involves using glasses with a liquid-crystal shutter system that allows alternating left and right images on the screen to reach the eyes in turn.; The anaglyph technique, in which offset red and cyan images on the screen are filtered by glasses, was used for the earliest 3-D TV broadcast, in 1980. HEADLINE: Not Just Closing a Divide, but Leaping It 

BYLINE:  By MICHEL MARRIOTT 

DATELINE: BOSTON 

 BODY:
DENNIS PAIZ-RAMIREZ listened intently as professional video game designers spoke of the challenges of guiding a creation from imagination to store shelf. As they described the intricacies of what goes into a game cartridge, he nodded knowingly. 
 For five weeks, he had toiled over a game of his own, Buzz, pitting a wasp against swarms of increasingly troublesome foes. The development laboratory was not a company cubicle or a computer geek's bedroom. For Dennis, 16, it was a clubhouse in Albuquerque created to help young people in low-income areas apply digital skills to creative use. 
 With suggestions from the clubhouse coordinator and its collection of expensive software, Dennis had decided to do more than just make a game. He wrote, illustrated and printed an instruction booklet, designed packaging and produced an animated commercial for it, including an electronically produced soundtrack. Now he put his creation to a professional test. 
"That's cool," declared John Beauchemin, an animator for Helixe, a game development studio in Lexington, Mass., paying the game world's ultimate compliment. 
Dennis was among more than 100 young people from the United States and abroad who spent four July days here to share and further their accomplishments in the Intel Computer Clubhouse Network, a program designed to foster not only computer skills but collaboration and leadership as well. 
The program's goal echoes a rallying cry in the debate over what has come to be known as the digital divide. New studies show that the gap in computer access based on differences in race, income or educational level is narrowing -- although whether that progress justifies curtailing federal efforts to close the gap, as the Bush administration contends, remains in dispute. 
In any case, some educators, technology experts and community organizers say the challenge is more complex than providing equipment, Internet connections and basic training. What young people need, they say, is help in developing fluency with advanced computer hardware and software. 
"Access is not enough," said Mitchel Resnick, associate professor of learning research at the Massachusetts Institute for Technology's Media Laboratory. "Access is just a starting point." 
In 1993, with money from the Intel Corporation, Professor Resnick helped establish the first site of what is today an international network of 50 Computer Clubhouses, including the New Mexico center that Dennis visits at least three times a week. The clubhouses are places where boys and girls, 8 to 18, can "really feel in charge of the technology," Professor Resnick said.
"It's not about playing games, but about making your own games," he said. "It's not about surfing the Web, but it's about making your own Web pages. It's not just about downloading MP3 music files, but doing your own music composition." 
Roma Arellano, worldwide community education manager for Intel, said the goal was to cultivate technologically confident thinkers, collaborators and problem-solvers, regardless of their economic origins. "We want to see young people literally taking their own ideas and creating," she said. 
For Dennis, the issue is not access to a computer: he shares a reasonably powerful, though crash-prone, home PC with his mother and his 14-year-old brother. But at home he does not have the microprocessing power, expensive programs and occasional help required to work on his games and related projects. For that he goes a few blocks from his high school to the Albuquerque clubhouse, which operators say about 25 young people visit on a typical weekday. 
"The clubhouse gives you a lot of freedom to see what you really want to do and gives you the tools to create it," Dennis said. "I always wanted to make a video game, but never had the software to make it. I didn't know where to start." 
The clubhouse network, which extends to such countries as Ireland, Israel, India, Germany, the Netherlands and the Philippines, has a $32 million commitment from Intel through 2005, in addition to hardware, software and services donated by technology companies including Adobe Systems, Macromedia, Hewlett-Packard and Autodesk. 
Such private-sector efforts may be all the more important if federal initiatives aimed at closing the digital divide are indeed cut back. But even those who agree that a divide exists do not necessarily agree on how to go about eliminating it. 
For example, at Playing2Win, a 22-year-old community center in Harlem supported by foundation grants and other contributions, the emphasis is on teaching work and life skills, said the center's director, Ka Ogunka. That can encompass computer repair as a way to teach problem solving, and employment-oriented goals like mastering word processing programs and other basic office software. 
"It's hard to keep the interest of our students if we don't show how this can immediately benefit them," Ms. Ogunka said. "We have to show them that the skills we're teaching them are worth learning and that they are applicable in the real world." 
Otherwise, she added, "they might take a job at Domino's before coming to us." 
At the Computer Clubhouse, in contrast, there are no formal instructors, only mentors, a clubhouse manager and small staff. Learning is gently guided, and areas of interest are usually identified by the young people. 
At the flagship clubhouse here in Boston, tucked away in the training wing of the Museum of Science along the Charles River, the most popular activities include creating custom animations, music videos, digital comic books and games, and mechanized robotics, said Marlon Orozco, the center's soft-spoken manager. 
One of the biggest draws is the digital studio, a glass-enclosed back room equipped with a synthesizer, microphones and a CD-burning computer loaded with software to create and edit music. During recording sessions, the glass trembles with booming bass notes and synthesized percussion. 
At first, anyone could drop in and use the studio, "but so many people were going back there that it got to the point where we had to put in some limits," said Mr. Orozco, 27, who began working with the clubhouse when he was 18. "Some people were dominating the room." Now a sign-up sheet hangs outside the studio's glass door.
Stephen Ruggs, 18, of Boston is a regular. For more than a year he has been working almost five days a week on a collection of rap music he has largely created, recorded and mixed at the clubhouse.
Adept on a computer keyboard, he manipulates software to serve the needs of his hip-hop alter ego, named Square-Route. But he prefers to write and edit his lyrics in longhand because, he explained, he has little access to a computer before he arrives at the clubhouse after school. 
Introduced to basic computing in high school, Stephen said he practically taught himself how to use music software at the clubhouse, which has become an informal hangout for him and friends lured there by the cutting-edge technology. 
"Everything is generated by computers," he said during a break after starting what he hopes will be his demo CD for a lucrative recording contract, titled "One Route 2 Da Game." "We couldn't do what we do without these computers." 
Most of the youths who regularly flock to the clubhouse are black, like Stephen, or Hispanic, like Dennis Paiz-Ramirez.
From the beginning, Professor Resnick said, the Computer Clubhouse took an approach that differs from those of other technology centers. "There were other places kids could go and get access to computers, places they could go and play games or take a course and learn some application," he said. "There's nothing wrong with that. But it wasn't satisfying the need that we saw that was out there for kids to express themselves, to create something, to have a sense that they could bring about change with the technology." 
Dennis is convinced that his command of game technology may well change his future. Despite the care he has taken in the presentation of his game, he says he has no intention of selling it. He is rather hoping to use it as a digital portfolio to give prospective employers and college admission officers a glimpse of what he can do with keyboard, mouse, imagination and determination. 
"I'm psyched about it," he said as the three-member team from the Helixe studio gathered over his game for a second time. "All of this is so cool."

HEADLINE: Environmental Justice 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "In Ecuador's Banana Fields, Child Labor Is Key to Profits" (front page, July 13) and "Bangladeshis Sipping Arsenic as Plan for Safe Water Stalls" (front page, July 14):
 In reporting on the intersection of the environment, poverty and justice with respect to both banana plantations and arsenic-tainted water, you highlight the importance of environmentalism in an international context. 
 As both human and ecological problems become ever more pressing, the new millennium is witnessing an emerging environmentalism that moves beyond merely preserving pristine wilderness and also calls for clean air and water as human rights as well as environmental necessities. 
Some politicians and business leaders tout an environmentalism that makes economic sense. As these articles demonstrate, environmentalism can also make sense for people, preserving the places they live and working toward social justice.

KEVIN DELUCA
Athens, Ga., July 15, 2002

The writer is assistant professor of communication and ecology, University of Georgia, and the author of a book about environmental activism.

HEADLINE: An Industrial City's Architectural Rebirth; 
New Museums Brighten Manchester

BYLINE:  By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: MANCHESTER, England 

 BODY:
For the better part of a century, this city was the industrial and commercial engine of Britain's imperial might, a place as proud as it was powerful. Then came the bombing of World War II, the loss of colonial markets, the closing of the cotton mills and a prolonged slide into economic depression. The final blow was struck on June 15, 1996, when an I.R.A. bomb flattened a large area of downtown Manchester.
 That bomb proved to be an awakening. Like many rundown cities, Manchester decided to use cultural buildings by well-known architects as motors of urban regeneration. Frank Gehry's Guggenheim Museum in Bilbao, for instance, had just such an impact on that northern Spanish city. With the opening this month of Daniel Libeskind's Imperial War Museum North, a sculptural composition as dramatic as his Jewish Museum in Berlin, Manchester, too, can boast a head-turning symbol of rebirth. 
 The aluminum-clad museum, with its sweeping roof and curved tower representing shards of a war-shattered globe, stands on the edge of the Manchester Ship Canal, the 19th-century waterway that turned this city into a major port. During World War II, the Luftwaffe attacked it not only for its docking facilities, but also for a nearby industrial park where engines were manufactured for Spitfire fighters and Lancaster bombers. 
Although the area is still largely undeveloped, the new museum is not alone. Across the canal, where Salford Quays once stood, the steel-and-glass Lowry Center, designed by Michael Wilford & Partners, has been drawing crowds since its opening in 2000. A pedestrian bridge links it to the Imperial War Museum North.
In the heart of the city, near the site of the 1996 bomb, another new museum, Urbis, designed by Ian Simpson Architects, opened late last month in a striking glass-faced building that has been nicknamed "the Ski Slope." Nearby, Tadao Ando has built a curving white pavilion in the new Piccadilly Gardens, themselves landscaped by the design firm EDAW. Barely a mile away, an extension designed by Michael Hopkins & Partners has been added to the Manchester Art Gallery, the work of Charles Barry, the early-19th-century architect of the Palace of Westminster in London.
One reason for the rush to open the new buildings is that starting July 25, Manchester will be host to the Commonwealth Games, which will attract athletes from 72 countries to an elegant new $115 million stadium, designed for the occasion by Arup Associates. So the city is back in the limelight. Mancunians, as the locals are known, have always liked to vaunt the glories of their faded past; now, at least in architectural terms, they can say they have vaulted from the 19th century to the 21st.
The truth may be a bit more nuanced, because central Manchester still carries the scars of the ugly, utilitarian, boxlike architecture that was a quick and cheap way of rebuilding after World War II. Similarly, there is a dismal postmodern sameness to the shopping malls and office blocs that have sprung up on the outskirts of the city since the early 1990's. But yes, amid the architectural potpourri, 19th- and 21st-century buildings seem to fare best.
Of the new designs, the Imperial War Museum North is the most daring. It is Mr. Libeskind's third completed museum, after the small Felix Nussbaum Haus in Osnabruck, Germany, and the Jewish Museum in Berlin. A Polish-born, American-trained architect who is an Israeli citizen and lives and practices in Berlin, Mr. Libeskind is also designing the Copenhagen Jewish museum and extensions to the Denver Art Museum and the Royal Ontario Museum in Toronto.
The warm reception by British architecture critics and museum directors to the Imperial War Museum North, though, has special significance. In 1996, the Victoria and Albert Museum in London chose Mr. Libeskind's ultra-modern design for a $100 million extension, but the project was refused a grant from the profits from Britain's national lottery and is still short of funds. The Victoria and Albert now hopes that acclaim for Mr. Libeskind's museum here will help win new financial support for its own project.
Inexplicably, the Imperial War Museum North was also denied lottery funds, prompting speculation that Britain's cultural purse-holders were simply terrified by Mr. Libeskind's architecture. As a result, the museum's construction budget was slashed to $45 million from $60 million, forcing the architect to use steel and aluminum instead of concrete and to abandon plans for adjacent landscaping. The museum's original form, however, survived.
"The challenge of architecture is to produce the maximum of architecture with the minimum of resources," Mr. Libeskind noted stoically.
As he often does, he began this museum with a concept, that of a globe shattered and reshaped by war. He then tested his idea practically at his office in Berlin.
"I wrapped a ceramic teapot in a plastic bag and dropped it from my window," he said in an interview. "I had the idea of the world as fragile, but I also wanted to see how it breaks. I saw a structural breakage of perfect geometry, and I saw that I could select three pieces that would be enough to represent the entire curvature of the universe. I was also aware of the light here. It often rains. The curves give life to the building."
In turn, the three pieces became symbols of three fields of conflict: the 95-foot tower, which resembles a sturdy sail, denotes air; the vast sweeping roof, which covers the entire exhibition space, stands for the earth; and a smaller shard, which contains a restaurant with a view of the canal, represents water.
As he did with the zigzag shape of the Jewish Museum in Berlin, Mr. Libeskind likes to disorient visitors: here he has done so by repeating the curvature of the roof on the floor of the exhibition space. At the entrance, it is six feet higher than its far edge.
"Actually, as you move around, I think the curvature helps orient you where you are," he said. "Most people don't know it's curved, yet they feel the difference."
The entire design is Mr. Libeskind's response to the challenge posed by what he jokingly calls "the three worst words" in the English language: imperial, war and museum. The museum is so named because it is a satellite of the Imperial War Museum in London, but Mr. Libeskind does not shy from the word war. "The museum records the struggle for peace," he said, "but it recognizes that war is a reality, not just in the past, but in the world we live in. It also addresses the question: is all conflict bad?"
The main exhibition area has some artifacts of war, like a Harrier jet used by the United States Marines, a Soviet tank and a World War I artillery piece. The space is also broken up into different rooms, referred to as silos, that explore themes like women and war; science, technology and war; and Empire, Commonwealth and war. Hourly, using the walls and silos as screens, the museum shows one of three 15-minute slide shows: "Why War?," "Children and War" and "Weapons of War."
The war museum has one major advantage over Urbis: the planners knew what to put in the building. Much like the ill-fated Millennium Dome in London, Urbis appears to have begun as a $45 million urban and architectural project, with events organizers rather than curators left to define its contents. The result, a so-called urban experience built around audio-visual snippets of major cities, is an interactive show that fails to engage the visitor.
The Manchester Art Gallery, which has doubled its exhibition space, has made much better use of its $52.5 million transformation. The collection is largely from the 19th century, when cotton barons decided that art could add refinement to their image. The excellent Pre-Raphaelite collection is now splendidly displayed, but the museum also has room for its 20th-century works and contemporary shows.
The Lowry Center takes its name from Manchester's best-known artist, L. S. Lowry, who recorded the city's early-20th-century industrial life. A show of his works is on through Sept. 22. The building's two theaters have proved enormously popular, and in its first year, the center had over a million visitors.
On their own, these projects may not suffice to transform this city. But they are powerful symbols of a more confident future, offering fresh proof of architecture's ability to have both real and psychological impact on an urban environment.

HEADLINE: Politics Hastens the Corporate Goodbye in Europe 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, July 17 

 BODY:
The European corporate chief long protected by cozy politicians, boardroom cronies and compliant shareholders -- is suddenly an endangered species.
 The ouster this week of Ron Sommer as the chief executive of Deutsche Telekom is the strongest evidence yet that the web of ties that once shielded European bosses from the wrath of the market is fraying. 
 From Percy N. Barnevik, the patrician former chairman of ABB Ltd., to Jean-Marie Messier, the flashy would-be mogul at Vivendi Universal, the heads of European companies are being ushered out of their jobs at a rate, and for reasons, that would have been unthinkable a few years ago.
Now, whispers are circulating about the fate of other beleaguered bosses, notably Michel Bon, chief executive of France Telecom, which is suffering even more acutely than Deutsche Telekom from soaring debt and a swooning stock price. 
"The Europeans are, for good or ill, moving faster to remove people," said Jeffrey Sonnenfeld, an associate dean of the Yale School of Management and an expert on the role of the chief executive.
"When a major political force gets involved, it's not even a debatable point," he added. "The guy is gone."
That was the case with Mr. Sommer, the charismatic, Israeli-born salesman appointed by the former German chancellor, Helmut Kohl, in 1996 to transform Deutsche Telekom from a sheltered state monopoly into a publicly traded company with shareholders around the world.
Mr. Sommer enjoyed the support of Mr. Kohl's successor, Gerhard Schroder, even while piling up $67 billion in debt and presiding over the decimation of the company's stock, the most widely held in Germany.
Then, two weeks ago, Deutsche Telekom's shrinking share price became a political issue in Germany's coming federal elections, when Mr. Schroder's conservative opponent, Edmund Stoiber, seized on it to illustrate what he sees as the chancellor's shaky economic policies.
With a swiftness that Jacques A. Nasser, late of Ford Motor, or Richard A. McGinn, former chief of Lucent Technologies, could appreciate, Mr. Sommer's support withered, and he was forced to step down.
"People said, 'Mr. Chancellor, you must do something because the decline in Telekom's share price is hurting the small investor in Germany,' " said Boris Boehm, a fund manager at Nordinvest, an asset management firm in Hamburg that owns 1.3 million shares in the company.
Nearly 13 million Germans, or about 20 percent of population, now own stocks. That compares with 13 percent in 1999 and only 9 percent in 1997. Though Germany trails the United States, where about half of all adults own stock, shareholders have become a powerful constituency.
With the rise of shareholders has come the rise of shareholder activists, big and small, who think nothing of filing motions against chief executives or publicly scolding them for laggard results.
At Deutsche Telekom's annual meeting in May, Mr. Sommer and his colleagues fidgeted on the stage as a shareholder representative, Jella Benner-Heinacher, took them to task for a lucrative share-option plan.
"People who buy caviar in a time of cholera shouldn't expect the understanding of small shareholders," she said.
In Switzerland, the billionaire shareholder Martin Ebner agitated successfully against Mr. Barnevik, the Swedish executive who orchestrated the merger that created the Swiss-Swedish giant ABB in 1987.
Though Mr. Barnevik was seen as a champion of shareholder rights -- Europe's answer to John F. Welch Jr. of General Electric -- his credibility was steadily eroded by Mr. Ebner's protests. In late 2001, he resigned as chairman of ABB to shoulder blame for the 60 percent drop in the company's share price.
Mr. Ebner was not deterred by the Wallenbergs, the powerful Swedish family that owns a major stake in ABB through its publicly traded investment company, Investor. Indeed, Mr. Barnevik soon also stepped down as the chairman of Investor. Mr. Ebner even clamored for him to give back $90 million in ABB pension fund payments, and Mr. Barnevik agreed to pay back part of that sum.
"For a long time, shareholders deferred to the Wallenbergs as though it was noblesse oblige," Mr. Sonnenfeld of Yale said.
Shareholders also played an important, if more behind-the-scenes, role in ousting Mr. Messier at Vivendi, the trans-Atlantic entertainment company. The Bronfman family, the largest single shareholder in Vivendi, tried to mobilize opposition to Mr. Messier on the board, which is dominated by French executives.
Initially, the French directors seemed determined to protect their countryman. But then a respected French industrialist, Claude Bebear, chairman of the giant insurer AXA, publicly criticized Mr. Messier and lobbied against him with French directors. Within days of surviving a no-confidence vote by the board, Mr. Messier was negotiating the details of his severance package.
Some experts said the Messier case showed less how much had changed than how much had stayed the same.
"What took so long?" asked Sophie L'Helias, an adviser to investor groups in Washington. "Messier had to goof up so badly, so egregiously, that they had no choice but to oust him."
Ms. L'Helias said there was a political dimension to Vivendi that made it hard for the board to move against Mr. Messier. He was building France's first truly global media conglomerate -- an ambitious plan that had been blessed by the government and carried no small measure of national pride.
Similar considerations, Ms. L'Helias predicted, will make it tricky to unseat Mr. Bon as chairman of France Telecom. Although the company is by some measures worse off than Deutsche Telekom -- its debt situation is more parlous -- Mr. Bon has extremely close relations with the French government.
The state still owns 55.5 percent of France Telecom, and as long as President Jacques Chirac supports Mr. Bon, it is difficult to imagine a shareholder revolt strong enough to oust him.
Still, these are turbulent times in Europe. As some experts point out, national pride can cut two ways.
"Obscenely overpaid C.E.O.'s with global ambitions and bad strategies are hurting national pride across Europe," Mr. Sonnenfeld said. "There is grass-roots pressure for the governments to respond."

HEADLINE: Corus to Buy Steel Maker In Brazil for $2.1 Billion 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, July 17 

 BODY:
The Corus Group, the British-Dutch steel-making giant, said today that it had agreed to acquire Companhia Siderurgica Nacional of Brazil, one of Latin America's leading steel producers, for $2.1 billion in stock. Corus will also assume $2.1 billion in C.S.N.'s debts.
 The deal is subject to approval by shareholders of both companies and by Brazilian and British regulators. 
 Adding C.S.N. to Corus would yield a company, yet to be named, that would rank fifth among world steel producers with 24.4 million tons of output a year. Corus alone is now eighth. 
More important for Corus, itself the product of the 1999 combination of British Steel and Royal Hoogovens of the Netherlands, acquiring C.S.N. would give it a guaranteed supply of iron ore from C.S.N.'s Casa de Pedra mine, at a time when control of world ore supplies is concentrating in the hands of a few suppliers. Production at the mine is set to triple, from 10 million tons a year to 30 million, after $300 million in planned improvements to the mine and a nearby port, C.S.N. executives said.
"What this deal is about is growth, growth, growth," said Benjamin Steinbruch, chairman of C.S.N. "This step will lead to the enlarged group's becoming a truly international company, and the transaction should benefit investors, customers and employees."
Investors will get 26 new shares in Corus for each C.S.N. share they hold, giving them a 37.6 percent stake in the combined company. The deal values C.S.N. at a premium of about 80 percent over its market value Tuesday. 
One possible obstacle to the deal is a guarantee made to Brazil's development bank, which pledged a controlling stake in C.S.N. as security. Mr. Steinbruch said today that he expected the price premium in the Corus offer and the greater liquidity that the combined company's shares will enjoy to persuade the bank to bless the merger.
Mr. Steinbruch is to become vice chairman of the combined company, and will succeed Corus's current chairman, Sir Brian Moffat, who is due to retire by April 2004. Tony Pedder, chief executive of Corus, will continue in that role after the merger, the companies said.
As part of Corus, C.S.N. would gain economies of scale, better access to world markets and cheaper credit than it can manage alone, according to Tom Meyer of UBS Warburg in New York. For its part, analysts said, Corus stands to lower its global production costs, in part by relying more on C.S.N.'s raw slab steel, produced at about half the cost of American slabs, and concentrating its efforts on turning them into higher-value finished products.
The down side for Corus is the exposure to C.S.N.'s debts it acquires and the risks of the Brazilian economy. Moody's Investors Service said the deal might lead it to downgrade Corus's credit rating to below investment grade. 
Still, Corus and C.S.N. executives said they expected the deal to enhance earnings next year, and that it might reduce annual costs by as much as $250 million once the companies are fully integrated. "The fundamentals of the proposed merger are robust, despite recent market volatility," the company said in a statement. 
As a glut of steel pushed prices to 20-year lows in the last few years, Corus has aggressively closed plants and eliminated thousands of jobs. It put its aluminum operation up for sale to focus on carbon steel.
Brazil's steel industry is one of the world's most competitive, because of cheap labor costs and easy access to huge iron ore reserves, and it has been attracting investment. Arcelor, the world's biggest steel maker, and California Steel Industries together own 46 percent of California Steel Industries, C.S.N.'s main Brazilian rival, and Dongkuk of South Korea has joined with Companhia Vale do Rio Doce, a big mining company, and other investors to build a new steel slab plant in the northeast.
Gerdau, another major Brazilian producer, said today that its profits for the first half rose 29 percent from a year earlier -- but much of the gain came from improved results in the United States, where Gerdau owns seven plants and where prices have risen because of the protective tariffs announced by the Bush administration in March.
Analysts said lowered costs would make a C.S.N.-Corus combination a much tougher competitor for the four largest steel makers -- Arcelor, NKK-Kawasaki and Nippon Steel of Japan, and Posco of South Korea. But some analysts said Corus had less scope to cut costs than Arcelor had when it was formed last year in a three-way merger of Aceralia of Spain, Usinor of France and Arbed of Luxembourg.
C.S.N.'s American depository receipts rose $2.25, or about 14 percent, to $18.50. Corus shares fell 2.5 pence, or 3.5 percent, to 69 pence in London. --------------------

Retaliation Considered
By The New York Times
BRUSSELS, July 17 -- The European Union said today that the United States had offered its steel industry only "manifestly inadequate" relief from the effects of the protective tariffs the Bush administration announced in March, giving a strong signal that the union will decide on Friday to retaliate.
The so-called safeguard tariffs affect about $2.3 billion in European steel shipments to the United States, the European Commission said, but the exemptions offered by Washington so far would spare only $230 million worth from the tariffs' effects.
Under World Trade Organization rules, the commission has until Friday to decide whether to impose retaliatory sanctions it is considering that would affect $300 million worth of American products.
The European Union, China, Japan, Brazil and other nations have complained that the American tariffs are unjustified and in violation of trade treaties, and that they were imposed for political rather than economic reasons. Administration officials have defended the tariffs as necessary to allow American steel makers breathing room to reorganize and cut costs.

HEADLINE: Profit Drops 6% at Bank of New York 

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
The Bank of New York Company said yesterday that its quarterly profit fell 6 percent, held down by severance costs, lower securities gains and a decline in profits from foreign exchange and trading. 
 The bank, based in New York City, earned $361 million, or 50 cents a share, in the second quarter, including a severance expense of $16 million, or 1 cent a share, for cutting 400 jobs. 
That contrasted with $385 million, or 52 cents a share, in the 2001 quarter. 
 Wall Street analysts expected profit of 51 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. 
Lower volatility and narrow spreads caused foreign exchange and trading revenues to drop to $72 million from $98 million a year earlier. Stable interest rates also hurt results in the hedging and risk management operations.
The provision for credit losses remained stable at $35 million.
Fees from securities servicing increased 9 percent from a year earlier, to $473 million, helped by new business and acquisitions.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Have First Winning Session in Nearly 2 Weeks

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street scratched out its first winning session in nearly two weeks yesterday in volatile trading that had investors vacillating between bargain hunting and profit taking.
 Analysts were skeptical the gain would last, characterizing the advance as a brief rebound in the market's eight-week sell-off. Although some second-quarter earnings reports this week have been encouraging, significant doubts remain about whether stocks still have further to fall. As a result, many investors are reluctant to make big or lasting commitments. 
 The Dow Jones industrials rose 69.37 points, or 0.8 percent, to close at 8,542.48, after advancing as much as 250 points earlier in the day and then falling into negative territory. Still, the gains were enough to interrupt a seven-session, 900-point plunge.
Broader indicators were also higher, despite losing ground from earlier in the session. The Nasdaq composite index jumped 21.99 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,397.25, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.99 points, or 0.6 percent, to 906.04.
The last time all three indexes closed higher was July 5.
The gains yesterday, although modest, were a respite from the spate of volatility the market has been suffering for weeks.
"You're witnessing a pitched battle between two camps," said Kevin Caron, market strategist at Ryan, Beck & Company in Livingston, N.J. "You've got the bearish contingent concerned about accounting scandals, and you've got value investors who are looking for bargains."
In trading yesterday, Boeing rose $2.07, to $42.94, after beating expectations by 12 cents a share.
Ford Motor advanced 2 cents, to $12.52, on a sharp jump in second-quarter profits that beat analysts' expectations by 5 cents a share. This broke a string of four consecutive losing quarters.
But Coca-Cola fell 37 cents, to $50, despite reporting a 15 percent jump in second-quarter profits.
Financial stocks were mixed. Citigroup, the parent company of Salomon Smith Barney and Citibank, rose 73 cents, to $36.93, after reporting results slightly ahead of expectations. But J. P. Morgan Chase fell 36 cents, to $28.14, on results that missed Wall Street forecasts.
Technology stocks fared better. Intel soared $1.08, to $19.44, even with disappointing second-quarter results and news of 4,000 job cuts. Juniper Networks rose 90 cents, to $9.21.
The fluctuations came on another day of testimony from the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, who told a House committee he did not think the chief executives of all publicly held companies should be required to verify the accuracy of company finances with federal regulators.
Analysts said investors were focused on preserving their portfolios and whether the market would continue to fall. The market's volatility, which was attributed to everything from low investor confidence to computer program selling and buying that kicks in at certain stock prices, is giving many investors few reasons to expect improvement soon. Until that changes, a sustainable rally is unlikely.
Also yesterday, the Commerce Department reported housing construction fell 3.6 percent in June, but analysts said the figures were still healthy and suggested that demand remains strong.
Treasury bond prices rebounded from earlier losses to end the day mixed. 
The 10-year Treasury note was unchanged at 101 14/32 . The note's yield remained at 4.68 percent.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond fell 4/32 , to 98 28/32 . Its yield rose to 5.46 percent from 5.45 percent on Tuesday.

HEADLINE: Pataki Critics Are Kicked Out Of a Parade 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
A group of unemployed workers who distributed fliers critical of Gov. George E. Pataki were ejected from the Dominican Day Parade in the Bronx on Sunday, after the governor's re-election campaign questioned the workers' presence.
 The jobless workers, members of a group called the New York Unemployment Project, said police officers surrounded them and herded them off the Grand Concourse, where they had been marching with members of a union that represents janitors and security guards. 
 The unemployed workers, some of whom lost their jobs because of the World Trade Center attack, were carrying signs calling for extended unemployment insurance benefits. But they were also distributing fliers in English and Spanish that accused the governor of "keeping our families poor" and "ignoring the unemployed."
Supporters of the governor had the group removed from the parade after they saw the fliers, said Jonathan Rosen, an organizer of the Unemployment Project. "People involved in Governor Pataki's campaign were visibly irked by our presence," he said. "There was a lot of buzzing on cellphones, and an hour later we were kicked out."
Mollie Fullington, a spokeswoman for the governor's re-election campaign, said, "We did make a simple inquiry with organizers and with the police" about the group, "to see if it had a permit" to march. But she said any decision to remove the group was made by others.
Lt. Brian Burke, a police spokesman, said the parade's organizers "informed us this group was not permitted to march" and asked community affairs officers to remove it.
But Rosa Ayala, director of the parade organization, said the police made the decision to eject the group. Though the unemployed workers had been brought by 32BJ, the building service union, she said, the workers' group was not on an official list of participants.
The incident seems to reflect the Republican governor's acute political sensitivities involving Latino voters in heavily Democratic New York City. Earlier this month, two Spanish-language television stations stopped running advertisements critical of Mr. Pataki after his aides objected to them. This prompted one of his Democratic challengers, State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, to accuse Mr. Pataki of trying to muzzle those who opposed him. The governor's office said the ads, which criticized Mr. Pataki's plan to change the Rockefeller drug laws, were "blatantly untruthful."
The governor has been endorsed by the hospital workers' union, 1199/SEIU, and he was marching in the parade with its leader, Dennis Rivera, a Democrat. They were directly behind the 32BJ members, who are also affiliated with the SEIU but have not endorsed a gubernatorial candidate. The unemployed workers had already begun marching in the parade when "an officer from the N.Y.P.D. is saying 'Hold it, hold it!' and all the cops surrounded us," said Mitchell Price, who lost his job as a car-service dispatcher in December. But the tactic backfired, Mr. Price said, because members of his group then heckled the governor all along the parade route.

HEADLINE: Coke Says Profit Rose 15% Despite Weak Markets Abroad 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its second-quarter earnings increased 15 percent despite weak economic conditions in several of its international markets. It attributed the increase primarily to product innovation and strong sales in North America and Asia.
 The company also said that it was comfortable with analysts' estimates for 2002 earnings and that it would stand by its projections for volume growth, or the amount of beverage shipped. Analysts expect the company to earn $1.75 to $1.80 a share for the full year, according to Thomson First Call. 
 "They're starting to deliver consistent, as-promised growth both in volume and profit," said Caroline S. Levy, a beverage analyst at UBS Warburg. "I think this is a market where that's much appreciated. There really were no surprises."
But the company's stock, which surged more than 3 percent after Coke announced its results, finished down 37 cents, at $50 a share, as investors began to question whether too much of Coke's volume growth had come from its lower-margin juice brands, analysts said.
"It's going to be a tight dance over the next several years to try and balance that growth if it's coming in lower-margin areas and still deliver the kind of 9 to 10 percent operating profit that investors are looking for," said John A. Faucher, an analyst at J. P. Morgan.
In the second quarter, net income rose to $1.29 billion, or 52 cents a share, compared with $1.12 billion, or 45 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Those results, which included a deduction of 2 cents a share because of foreign currency adjustments, were in line with Wall Street's expectations. Revenue increased 15 percent, to $5.37 billion from $4.65 billion.
Seventy-six percent of Coke's profit comes from sales outside the United States. Lackluster performances in Latin America, where volume grew by only 1 percent in the second quarter, and in Europe, where growth was hampered by cool weather, were offset by returns in Asia and Mexico that were better than expected, the company said. 
"We're still facing difficult economic environments in many regions; however, our business operations are adjusting well in these situations," Gary P. Fayard, the chief financial officer, said in a conference call yesterday. Mr. Fayard also said he expected weakness in foreign currency to pull down profits by 8 to 10 cents a share for the year. 
Still, analysts say that after several quarters of sluggish sales, Coke is finally on the path to improvement.
In North America, volume climbed 4 percent for the second quarter, with sales of the trademark Coca-Cola brand rising 2 percent. The bottled water brand, Dasani, jumped 40 percent in the quarter, and Minute Maid, its primary juice brand, posted double-digit growth, the company said. 
"The company is stable in a very difficult global economic environment," said Bill Pecoriello, a beverage analyst at Morgan Stanley. "Just being stable in this environment is an achievement." 
Earlier this week, Coke announced that it would begin counting the stock options it grants its executives and employees as an expense. The accounting change will be reflected in fourth-quarter earnings and is expected to cost the company a penny a share this year.
Coca-Cola Enterprises, Coke's leading bottler, said yesterday that it had no immediate plans to follow Coke's lead. Coke owns about 40 percent of the bottler. In reporting its second-quarter earnings, the bottler said its net income rose to $214 million, or 47 cents a share, compared with $104 million, or 24 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: Parent of American Airlines Reports Loss of $495 Million 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
AMR, the parent of American Airlines, reported a net loss of $495 million for the second quarter yesterday, reflecting three months of lagging recovery for the airline industry as business travelers continued to stay away from high-priced tickets.
 The loss was $3.19 a diluted share. Last year, AMR lost $507 million, or $3.29 a diluted share for the corresponding period. It reported $4.48 billion in revenue, down 20 percent from the 2001 quarter. 
 The second-quarter loss included a $30 million after-tax charge from an expected loss of foreign tax credits.
Excluding that charge, AMR lost $465 million, or $3 a diluted share. Analysts had expected a loss of $3.04.
Shares of AMR hit a 52-week low of $12.87 yesterday, down 40 cents.
"We continued to see a very weak revenue environment in the second quarter," Donald J. Carty, the chief executive, said in a statement yesterday. "And although traffic has rebounded nicely since last fall, average fares are at 15-year lows, sharply depressing yields."
Jamie Baker, an analyst at J. P. Morgan, said, "It's losing money because corporations are spending little on air travel, and that's the real problem here."
AMR's unit revenue, which accounts for flying one seat one mile, was 9.83 cents, down 10.6 percent from last year.
That shows that people are staying away from the astronomical walk-up fares that airlines began charging in the late 1990's.
Now, anecdotal evidence and surveys show that many corporate travelers have taken to other modes of transportation, are buying cheaper restricted tickets or are buying tickets on no-frills carriers like Southwest Airlines and JetBlue. American's chief financial officer, Jeff Campbell, acknowledged in a conference call yesterday that the low-fare carriers had essentially become the leaders in the industry for now.
"Our view is it's really Southwest and JetBlue who are going to drive a lot of the pricing environment," he said. "We really do need to make some fundamental changes."
Southwest, which reports it earnings today, is expected to be the only major airline to post a profit for the second quarter. Analysts are expecting the entire industry to declare losses of up to $1.4 billion for the second quarter.
American said that if spending patterns did not change, it would "post a sizable operating loss in the third quarter."
The carrier has cut capacity in markets that used to be inundated with business travelers, like Silicon Valley, as well as taking flights out of Latin America, where economic and political turmoil have slowed travel, Mr. Campbell said. American is also trying to cut costs by making its operations efficient, an effort that includes tinkering with its flight schedule in Chicago and eliminating paper tickets. But analysts say more radical solutions are needed.
For example, American has yet to address high labor costs and worker dissatisfaction.
"If you're talking about a revolutionary change where you can get to a period of sustained profits, that has to entail cooperation with labor on a revolutionary scale," said Kevin C. Murphy, an analyst at Morgan Stanley. "There just wasn't any suggestion that that was going to occur."

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: INVESTING; 
2 Brokers Offer Warm Comfort in a Cold Market

BYLINE:  By N. R. KLEINFIELD 

 BODY:
Down. The market was down. Of course it was. Always down. 
 Ernest Raab and Emilio Valdes, comrades against the degradation of the stock market, were doing what they do all day, extending succor last week to the bereaved. They're stockbrokers who work as a synchronized team at A. G. Edwards, and as such are the persona of the dark heart of this market to their clients. 
 They have no idea when the wretched market, with its hourly drip of heartbreak, will turn up. And despite the first move upward in the Dow yesterday after seven consecutive days of losses, people want to know more than ever: How much longer will they be whipsawed? 
A few years ago, in those lustrous 90's, stockbroking seemed like the most pleasant occupation, outside of being a dot-com founder. Every client was earning big money. Every stock you mentioned rose, by the minute. Everyone wanted to talk to you, and buy, buy, buy.
Nowadays, too many stocks seem to keep going down, by the minute. Corporate America is awash in accounting scandals, its chief executives being threatened with prison stripes. Regulators and legislators have scolded brokerage houses for allowing the analysts that recommend stocks to become too cozy with the investment bankers. Even the president is mad.
Three days sitting with Mr. Raab, 57, and Mr. Valdes, 34, at the front lines of a market in tumult, gave a glimpse of what it is like in what has become one of the more nerve-racking jobs in America.
Over those three days last week, the Dow eliminated nearly 600 points. The Nasdaq plunged by 100. Mr. Raab and Mr. Valdes didn't do much buying or selling -- some bonds here, some mutual funds there -- but delivered an abundance of therapy. They have a conservative bent -- be diversified, buy quality for the long term. They're not tip-of-the-day brokers. "If you want to gamble, go to Atlantic City," Mr. Raab tells clients. "At least you'll smell the salt air and see a good show."
During the 90's, they talked clients down from getting too gutsy and buying nonsense stocks. Now they talk them down from surrender.
An addled client called, after spotting some disturbing accounting news about Merck on CNBC. The brokers had a screen on their computers that listed stocks mentioned on TV. During the rah-rah 90's, clients would call 5 to 10 times a day wanting to buy something recommended on the air, having no idea what it was. That doesn't happen anymore. 
The addled man tended to meditate on every blip. Now he needed to know: Should he dump Merck? Mr. Valdes talked him through it. He played a tape of the opinion of an Edwards analyst -- that he could see no effect on Merck's income, any selling was an overreaction, "an effect of Enronitis." 
The man stood pat. Merck went down that day. And the next day. And the next day.
Here was an e-mail message. A client, another of their "nervous Nellies", wanted to sell all his stocks and funnel everything into bonds. Whoa! They set up an appointment to help him get his bearings.
When he goes out socializing, Mr. Valdes says he hears a lot of sympathy. People say, "I wouldn't want to be in your shoes." Or "I'd hate to do what you do." 
They work in adjoining offices, with a sliding glass window between them, in the airy Edwards office on Park Avenue and 48th Street. Their "book," as it's known in the trade, consists of about 400 households, some with investments in the millions and a nurse who started the other day with $100. Some retired clients are mainly in income-producing investments like bonds that have chugged merrily along during the market's precipitous fall. Others have very much felt Wall Street's wicked sting. 
"That's not pleasant," Mr. Raab said. "But nobody is out on the street selling apples, nobody is threatening my firstborn and I'm still listed in the phone book under my name and not my wife's maiden name."
Outside the heat was rising, pushing into the 90's. The market was ice cold.
Mr. Raab took a call. Man going on vacation, wondering how much worse it will get.
"You know, the stock market doesn't go straight up," Mr. Raab said.
"I know, but I want it to," the man said. "I got used to it." 
Mr. Raab said: "I want you to have a peaceful vacation. Focus on your family and your kids and your tan."
The man said, "But I'm warning you, if I come back and have to eat dog food, I know where you live." The man laughed. He was kidding.
"Well, I'll be eating dog food with you," Mr. Raab said. "You think I don't have a 401(k)?"
Again and again, the brokers offered pet phrases like "it's mean, nasty and ugly" or "if it's any comfort, I haven't sold anything either."
Actually, not all of their clients are frazzled. They have a couple who, when they tell them they lost money, chuckle.
The Dow off 130. A man showed up for a quarterly review. His name was Anthony Rotolo, a real estate broker in his 50's. 
"Let's talk about the mean, nasty and the ugly," Mr. Raab said. He ran through the somber market numbers, then examined Mr. Rotolo's bruised accounts.
"I don't think there's good choice and bad choice," Mr. Raab said. "It's just ugly choices. I'd say let's bite the bullet, turn the page and learn not to overweight certain sectors."
Mr. Rotolo said, "Traditional wisdom is you don't sell when it tanks unless it's beyond redemption."
"It's down over 50 percent," Mr. Valdes replied.
Mr. Rotolo agreed to replace it.
"O.K., hope it hasn't ruined your day totally," Mr. Raab said.
"No," Mr. Rotolo said with a tight smile. "It was already ruined." 
A broker in a nearby office could be heard saying, "They ought to burn Wall Street!"
Mr. Raab and Mr. Valdes are pleasant and unpretentious, but different. They have been a team for six and a half years, and came to Edwards in early 1998. Mr. Valdes prefers financial planning and the macro picture, while Mr. Raab likes to do the micro picture, stock by stock.
Mr. Raab is a city person, and lives with his wife in a loft in the Flatiron district of Manhattan. He is fond of model trains, and has a train room, with tracks that snake through the walls and a glass case. He likes classical music and opera. Mr. Valdes is a suburbanite, and lives with his wife and two young children in Middletown, N.J. He likes classic rock music and has no trains.
Neither has witnessed a market this sadistic. The stress gnaws at them, too. Mr. Raab has started getting a massage every Friday after the market closes. And, he said, "I listen to a lot more Mahler." 
Mr. Valdes surrounds himself with friends, because socializing calms him. And there is his Yankee index. When the market does poorly, he watches more Yankee games. He figures he has watched 25 to 30 percent more Yankee games this savage year.
Most of their income derives from fees on how much is invested with them rather than commissions on trades, and so while their income has fallen off, it has not been a sharp decline. Mr. Valdes knows a broker who had to get a second job delivering newspapers in the morning.
They have been fortunate in not having put clients in some of the biggest meltdowns -- Enron, Tyco, Worldcom. A number of clients, though, took a drubbing on Lucent Technologies.
Woe be the market. Dow down 200.
"How you doing big guy?" Mr. Valdes called a client he hadn't spoken to in a couple of weeks. A heavy-duty worrier, not unconvinced that the American economy couldn't dissolve entirely. 
The man complained his investments kept sinking. He constantly watched the market. As he spoke to Mr. Valdes, he quoted where the Dow was, down to the decimal point.
"The only thing I can do is offer you ideas on how to be conservative," Mr. Valdes said.
The man moaned about one of his holdings. Then he asked for Edwards's year-end targets for the market. Mr. Valdes didn't like to give them out. Projections in this market were too tenuous. But the man wanted them. Mr. Valdes mentioned many caveats and read them off: Dow, 10,600; S.& P. 500, 1,160; Nasdaq, 1,700 -- all well above today levels.
The man said lots of people were making money. He rattled off George Soros, Warren Buffett and short sellers, who profit from stock declines.
"Are these the same people who go to Atlantic City and don't lose money?" Mr. Valdes said.
The man said a friend of his girlfriend bragged that for the last two years her portfolio had done nothing but go up. He was sick of going to parties and hearing her crow.
"I tell you, that's all noise," Mr. Valdes said. "Ask her what she's investing in."
The man mentioned someone else.
"He's sucking wind now, too," Mr. Valdes said.
Some firms have been squeezing their brokers, reducing their compensation, pressing them to shed smaller accounts. A. G. Edwards has not. It has, however, told brokers to call their clients to talk about allocations. Mindful of how far the market has sunk, the firm has also advised brokers that clients may have too little in the market and, hard as it may be in this brutal climate, to talk to them about buying stocks.
Mr. Valdes and Mr. Raab, though, are too leery of the market. "Quite frankly, we're a little gun shy about adding to the market just now," Mr. Valdes said. 
Since Edwards derives just 11 percent of its revenue from investment banking, Mr. Rabb and Mr. Valdes said they didn't feel concerned that the firm's analysts were promoting stocks to attract investment banking business, one of the hot-button issues on Wall Street. In any event, they said they weren't beholden to Edwards analysts. In fact, they swap research notes with friends at other brokerage houses to absorb multiple views.
Mr. Valdes noticed that Merck had fallen for the third consecutive day. He called a woman who owned it. 
The woman pondered the sour news. "They're cooking the books, aren't they?" she said.
"I don't know," Mr. Valdes said.
"I hope they discover a cure for AIDS tonight,"' she said.
"Yes, if they discovered a cure for AIDS it would go through the roof," Mr. Valdes said. "And it would be good for society as well."
Down, down, down went the market.
In the next office, Mr. Raab checked some of the Dow components, McDonald's, Philip Morris and Johnson & Johnson among them. "Mickey D is up," he said. "Merck the Jerk is down 2.16. Big Mo is down a buck 52. Johnny Johnny is down 2.33." 
He shook his head. The Dow had shed 283 points, the Nasdaq 35. 
"It's mean, nasty and ugly," he said.

PERSON: Joseph Marie Antoine Hubert Luns 

HEADLINE: Joseph Luns, 90, NATO Chief In Crucial Cold War Decades 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER MARQUIS 

 BODY:
Joseph Marie Antoine Hubert Luns, a former Dutch foreign minister and NATO secretary general, died yesterday, Dutch government officials said.
 Dr. Luns was 90 and living in Brussels. He suffered a stroke five years ago and had required close medical attention ever since. 
 A hard-charging diplomat with a provocative wit, Dr. Luns parlayed his position as foreign minister of a small country to become an influential architect of the European Economic Community and NATO before he retired in 1983.
Tall, ebullient and outspoken, Dr. Luns was known for shaking up fusty meetings with candid observations, even as he set about the serious business of negotiating the future of Berlin and paving the way for self-rule in the former Dutch colony of New Guinea four decades ago.
As president of the NATO Council in 1959, Dr. Luns defended the West's decision to stand firm on shielding West Berlin from Soviet and East German pressure. Within two years, the East German government had erected the Berlin Wall.
"Appeasement is surrender in installments," Dr. Luns said. "These crises are provoked by the Soviet to seek out our weak spots."
Widely known as a friend to the United States, Dr. Luns was a frequent visitor to this country in a career that spanned three decades. Known as Joe to his American colleagues, he met with successive United States presidents, beginning with President Eisenhower, and served as a bridge to Western Europe in coordinating a cold war strategy.
But Dr. Luns, who became secretary general of NATO in 1971, after 19 years as foreign minister, did not shy away from confronting Washington. Despite his anti-Communist views, he was a strong advocate of a United States-Soviet rapprochement, and in his final years at NATO, he chided the Reagan administration for seeking military superiority over Moscow at the expense of arms control agreements.
Early in his career, Dr. Luns was an avid supporter of European political integration and his efforts paved the way for the formation and expansion of the six-nation European Economic Community in the aftermath of World War II. When Britain balked, Dr. Luns held the door open; when France threatened to withdraw over voting and sovereignty issues, he called its bluff.
Throughout his career, Dr. Luns wryly referred to his predicament as a public servant with strong personal views. Shortly after he took over as NATO secretary general, he observed: "Of course, I am as wax in the ministers' hands. But wax, when it is cold, is tough, yes."
He was attuned to the dictates of domestic politics. When Hubert H. Humphrey, then vice president, called on Dr. Luns during a European tour in 1967, Mr. Humphrey praised some Girl Scouts who had greeted him and said they were "getting prettier every year."
Dr. Luns teased the vice president. "You are going into politics over here?" he asked.
Born in Rotterdam on Aug. 28, 1911, Dr. Luns studied law at Leyden and Amsterdam Universities, then studied political economy at the London School of Economics. 
He joined the foreign service in 1938 and married Baroness E. C. van Heemstra the following year. They lived in Bern until World War II broke out, when he was told to move to the Dutch Legation in Lisbon. In 1943 he became second secretary of the Dutch government-in-exile in London. After the war, he spent three years as the Dutch representative to the United Nations and was appointed foreign minister.
Dr. Luns and his wife had two children, Hubert and Cornelia Sophie, but officials did not verify survivors.
