HEADLINE: After Roll Call, Baguette Class; 
Baking School Offers Job Skills in an Old Specialty

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
Give a man a loaf of bread, and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to bake bread, in, say, a converted pajama factory in Queens, and his prospects will brighten considerably. 
 That, at least, is the concept behind a school in Long Island City that is teaching the jobless the lost art of making bread by hand in an effort to revive a dying New York City industry. 
 Eighteen students, covered in flour and sweat, assembled recently on the first floor of the school, the Artisan Baking Center, and spent much of the day scurrying among huge barrels of flour, poppy seeds, brown sugar and oats. The students include New Yorkers moving from welfare to work, ex-convicts, high school dropouts, professional bakers taking refresher courses and the unemployed, all potentially part of a new generation of fancy-bread bakers. 
One of the students, Peggy Moore, 49, says she harbored a secret dream of baking bread for a living throughout the 17 years she worked in advertising. Now that she has been laid off from her job producing ads for an agency in Manhattan, Ms. Moore, who loved to bake prune bread and sweet rolls as a child, has joined others to learn dough twisting, baker's math and other basics of the trade at no cost to the students.
"I might as well try something I love," Ms. Moore said. "People respond to it. You come home with boxes of eclairs and cream puffs and bread and people flock to your door. I can't produce forever, but I think I could probably bake for as long I'm standing."
The baking industry, once a thriving piece of the New York City economy that employed thousands of bread, cake, bagel and bialy bakers, has been in sharp decline since the 1970's. Large bakeries have moved their operations elsewhere and automation has replaced bakers with machines. However, the demand for handmade bread has surged in the United States in the last decade, as more Americans choose focaccia or olive sourdough baguettes over factory-made loaves. 
With skilled bakers in short supply, the federal Department of Labor identified New York City as a place in need of a baking school and, in 2000, gave $1.7 million to help start the first formal baking training program in the city and one of the few such programs in the country. 
The organizers of the Queens school, on 37th Street in Long Island City, which opened as a pilot program last year and is expected to train from 400 to 500 prospective bakers a year, are working with New York State officials to grant the school official apprenticeship status. If they succeed, according to the center's director, Rebecca Lurie, the school would become the first bread-baking apprenticeship program in the United States. 
So far, the center has placed 27 people in jobs, and employers have begun recruiting directly from the center. To qualify for the program, students must be able to prove that they have been actively looking for work. 
Until now, anyone serious about learning the art of baking artisan, or handmade, bread typically went to Kansas, to the American Institute of Baking, a consultant for the Queens center, or enrolled in an expensive course or two at the Culinary Institute of America in Hyde Park, N.Y. 
But, as the students in Queens can already surmise, baking is not the easiest line of work. As one of the instructors, David Bernstein, a baker for more than 60 years who trained in Kansas, put it, "You can't have bad feet."
Mr. Bernstein said the decline of the artisan bread industry was driven in part by many bakers' reluctance to give away their recipes for breads and other goods. When their sons and daughters decided not to go into the baking industry, they often closed up shop without passing along their trade secrets, he said. 
"The true craftsmen were afraid to teach," Mr. Bernstein said. "But we're bringing back an old tradition."
In 1971, 12,402 people in the five boroughs -- the majority in Brooklyn and Queens -- were employed by bread and cake bakers, according to the Empire State Development Corporation. In 1997, the last year for which similar data was available, there were 4,555 people employed in the same industry. 
However, as more small retail bakeries in New York City have begun selling fancy baked goods, the number of jobs in that niche has increased. In 1986, there were 11,789 jobs in small bakeries, but by 2000, there were 12,414, according to a recent report by the New York Industrial Retention Network, a citywide economic development group based in Brooklyn.
Many of those workers surely needed on-the-job training. In 2000, the Department of Labor conducted a survey of 15 New York bakeries that reported 73 percent of their workers lacked basic skills.
Supplementing the federal grant with state and local financing, the Queens center was created in a joint effort between the Consortium for Worker Education, an employment training agency that is working with thousands of people left jobless after Sept. 11, and the New York City Central Labor Council. Several industry employers and the Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers International Union, Local 3, are collaborating.
In class the other week, Mr. Bernstein led his students -- the 18 students were the largest group that has enrolled yet -- through a brownie session and then moved on to making rye, semolina and Italian baguettes. 
Mr. Bernstein, 74, said he had baked his way across the country, making bread and other goodies in 40 states, and that when he told his employers he was a baker from Brooklyn, they invariably asked, "Do you know how to make New York cheesecake?"
He does, and it's a specialty. But his students are not yet ready for cheesecake because they are still learning the basics. A basic baking course should make students proficient enough to find jobs in the industry and move from entry-level positions, which pay from $7 to $10 an hour, to higher-level jobs, which can pay up to $18 an hour. 
Ms. Moore and her classmates were enrolled in a six-week basic class. 
The center, which moves from a pilot program to a permanent school in the fall, also offers courses on pastry, wedding cakes, holiday baking, pastry and "Baking for Restricted Diets." 
The ingredients are measured in quarts, pounds and scoops, instead of cups and teaspoons, and the recipes are called formulas.
After the baking session, Ms. Moore stood with a classmate at the back of the room, comparing notes. She said she had always dreamed of opening a bakery in her neighborhood, the Inwood section of Manhattan, but acknowledged that she was worried that working with such large quantities of the ingredients might lead to disaster.
"I keep having his image of the bread rising and taking over the whole apartment, like a scene from 'I Love Lucy,' " she said. 
The baking session was followed by a class lecture in an air-conditioned conference room across the hall, where Mr. Bernstein, who refused to discuss his brownie recipe in front of a reporter, reviewed various bread formulas and tackled the pressing questions of the day. They included how to make sesame seeds stick to dough and how to make sure there is a blueberry in every bite of a blueberry muffin.
Mr. Bernstein looked for a show of hands and said, "Any other questions before we get to the rye bread?"

CORRECTION-DATE: July 26, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on July 18 about a federally supported school in Queens for artisan bread baking referred incorrectly to its uniqueness. It is New York City's first such baking school, not the city's first baking training program. Other cooking schools have long had baking training programs.

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
Limiting Possibilities Downtown

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap 

 BODY:
WITH the curtain up on six remarkably similar concepts for the World Trade Center superblock, it has become graphically evident that the planning of its future rests on one day in its past: April 26, 2001.
 That was when the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey entered into a 99-year, $3.2 billion lease on four of the trade center buildings, including the twin towers and the underground shopping concourse, with Silverstein Properties and the retail operator Westfield America. 
 "One of my first goals was privatization of this world famous symbol of the vitality and economic might of the New York region," Gov. George E. Pataki said that day. But in a way no one could have imagined, the arrangement may now be a cautionary tale about privatizing public resources. 
For it seems that the trade center lease, more than any other single thing, is shaping the rebuilding plans. The powerful Port Authority, which managed to clear the whole site in the 60's, is now legally bound to protect the right of two private companies to recover their lost commercial potential.
This obligation has momentarily trumped other questions, among them whether downtown needs 11 million square feet of new offices, 600,000 square feet of stores and a 600,000-square-foot hotel.
Almost every element of the plan is shown in a variety of ways: the size of the memorial, the layout of the transportation hall, the treatment of West Street and the division of the superblock into smaller parcels. Even the notion of hallowing the twin tower footprints is up for discussion.
But not the size of the leasehold. That is fixed. In fact, the architects and planners working for the Port Authority and the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation were instructed not only to restore every square inch of commercial space but to increase the retail area by 40 percent.
"New plans for the site should recognize and address the contractual right and obligation of Westfield America to an expansion of up to 600,000 square feet of retail space," the guidelines decreed. One plan calls for one million square feet.
Neil D. Levin, the executive director of the Port Authority, who was killed in the attack, explained in April 2001 why the lease was so important as a matter of public policy. "Privatizing the World Trade Center," he said, "means a dependable source of revenue to fund regional transportation improvements over the next 99 years."
And from the tenants' perspective, it is perfectly reasonable for Silverstein and Westfield to expect to get the space they bargained for.
Yet there are only so many ways to package that much space while preserving open land for the memorial. That is why it is hard at first to tell the difference among plans by Beyer Blinder Belle, Architects and Planners; Peterson/Littenberg Architects; Skidmore, Owings & Merrill; and Cooper, Robertson & Partners.
Four plans show buildings of 50 to 85 stories in an L shape around the memorial site. Two plans, both involving some construction on the tower footprints, show buildings of 32 to 72 stories in a U shape.
To be fair, these renderings capture a moment that may be 10 years distant, if it comes at all. They show the site as if it were fully built, when in fact each building will rise as the market dictates.
IMAGES of the plan, which can be seen online at www.renewnyc.org and beginning next week in Federal Hall National Memorial at Wall and Nassau Streets, depict a vast area in small scale. Differences that appear minuscule on paper or on screen would be enormous in reality. "Look more closely," said Louis R. Tomson, president of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, "and you'll see differences that are quite profound."
The views do not presume to show architectural details, and officials emphasized that the first six concepts are not blueprints but merely starting points for discussion. Given that, though, it would have been a public service to present at least one Plan X, a rendering that conveyed a sense of what the site would look like if designing started afresh.
The government's first choice is a solution that accommodates the lease, though John C. Whitehead, chairman of the development corporation, said on Wednesday that if it is "not possible to rebuild and still meet those requirements and have the kind of beautiful center that we want this to be, then we will change our plans."
He and others have insisted all along that the planning of Lower Manhattan would be transparently open to public scrutiny. What the public may really be learning is how limited planners' choices can be.

HEADLINE: More Cafes May Sprout on Sidewalks 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
The sidewalk cafe -- that seasonal fixture suggesting summer in the city, leisurely lunches, Paris on the Hudson -- could become even more visible in New York's streetscape under a Bloomberg administration plan.
 Taking restaurant diners, literally, to the streets, cafes have been hugging sidewalks from Madison Avenue on the Upper East Side to DeKalb Avenue in Brooklyn, and now city officials are working on a way for more of them to become legitimate. 
 "We consider them an important amenity for the city," said Gretchen Dykstra, commissioner of the Department of Consumer Affairs, which regulates the temporary spots. "People like them. It's why we go to Paris, and why people like to stay in the city over the summer." 
Despite changes over the years, the permit application process for open-air cafes has remained a multiagency muddle for restaurateurs, who can wait as long as a year for approval of a permit that is good for, at most, two years. Unwittingly, the bureaucracy has encouraged many to break the law, Ms. Dykstra said.
As a result, while the Department of City Planning considers lifting some restrictions on where the cafes are allowed, Ms. Dykstra's agency is creating a plan to simplify and quicken the permit process for restaurant owners.
"We want to make it easier for legitimate businesses to open sidewalk cafes and operate them," Ms. Dykstra said.
The effort comes as restaurateurs, hurt by a flagging economy and decreased tourism, are seeking similar changes.
Still, one man's bastion of charm, or income, can be another's scourge. Neighborhood residents and community boards, contending that sidewalk cafes clog pedestrian arteries and cause unwanted noise, have complained bitterly about unenforced violations.
"Sometimes we'll have a licensed cafe and then there's another table all the way at the curb," said Kenneth M. Moltner, chairman of Community Board 8, which includes the Upper East Side and Roosevelt Island. "The practical effect is that you have a blocked street where people can't walk: people with baby carriages, people with packages, people who just want to walk along the street. And there is also an issue of noise with neighboring apartments."
The current approval process involves half a dozen separate agencies, while the proposal under consideration would centralize that system within consumer affairs, Ms. Dykstra said. Restaurants would "self-certify" that they were in compliance with zoning and other technical regulations, avoiding the need to circulate copy upon copy of an already complicated application, she said.
At the same time, the plan would give Ms. Dykstra's agency the authority to shut a restaurant for violating the regulations, power that currently rests with the Department of Health.
"We think that's the hammer we need," she said.
For now, the department is focused on getting through a glut of pending cafe applications the old way, a process Ms. Dykstra called "extraordinarily unwieldy and bureaucratic." With 539 sidewalk cafes licensed, according to officials, the department has 59 applications pending, down from a backlog of nearly 250 in April.
Under the new plan, which officials hope to have in place by next spring, applications would still have to go through a public review and approval process.
"We want to encourage them to be legal and, to be fair to them, put them through the process quickly," Ms. Dykstra said.
Many restaurants have just accepted fines, which can run $100 a day, as a cost of doing business, Ms. Dykstra said. In other situations, inspectors may go out and confiscate the outdoor furniture, but owners "just go out and replace the chairs at Costco for $200," keeping the cafes running after the inspectors move on.
Kevin B. McGrath, a lawyer representing restaurant owners seeking the kinds of zoning and permit changes the city is considering, said that sidewalk cafes should be allowed wherever the zoning automatically allows restaurants and bars. He said that he had just sent a letter suggesting as much to the Bloomberg administration.
But many communities have been relentless in pushing to deny cafes sidewalk spots, particularly in Manhattan. "The affluent of Manhattan have decided that there are 45 areas where they don't want them," Mr. McGrath said. "The entire length of Madison Avenue. Ridiculous."
Mr. Moltner said his community board generally supported anything that would help ease the way for legitimate businesses to get permits and for the city to crack down on violators. But not without reservations.
"The board understands that restaurants need to operate and make a living," he said. "But the other legitimate part of the community are the residents."

GRAPHIC: Photo: City Hall is trying to ease the permit process for sidewalk cafes like the one at Pellegrino's in Little Italy. (Michael Nagle/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Albany Chosen as Research Hub For the Next Generation of Chips 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 17 

 BODY:
The world's largest computer chip makers plan to build a major center for research and development on the next generation of chips here, at the State University of New York, a plan that state officials hope will bring thousands of jobs to the Hudson Valley.
 State officials and a consortium of the chip manufacturers are to announce the $400 million project on Thursday, after almost a year of intensive, secret negotiations between the industry and Gov. George E. Pataki's office. 
 Despite the weak economy and a slumping technology sector, state and industry officials, as well as people who follow the industry, say the project could draw investments worth several times the cost of the project to the region.
The only other such center created by the computer chip consortium, International Sematech, was built in the late 1980's in another state capital and college town, Austin, Tex. Over the next decade, Austin became one of the best places to be in the high-tech world: It experienced explosive economic growth, drawing makers of chips, related materials, manufacturing tools and software to the region. 
"I would expect it to have the same transformational impact on the regional economy here," Mr. Pataki said. "I honestly think this could be the most important economic development for upstate New York since the Erie Canal."
While such talk may be hyperbole, the announcement could be a political boon to Mr. Pataki, a Republican. As he runs this year for a third term, he can cite the center to counter his Democratic opponents, who are blaming him for the weak state of the upstate economy.
Though the economy in Albany, with its government offices and college campuses, has remained strong, and the Hudson Valley has by far the healthiest economy in New York State, officials say the center could create a multitude of jobs within commuting distance of struggling cities like Schenectady and Troy.
Members of the industry consortium include seven United States firms: I.B.M., Intel, Motorola, Hewlett-Packard, Texas Instruments, Advanced Micro Devices and Agere Systems, until recently a part of Lucent Technologies. 
There are also five overseas companies: Royal Philips Electronics, the Dutch giant; Infineon Technologies of Germany; STMicroelectronics of France; Hynix of Korea; and TSMC of Taiwan. Officials of the consortium declined to say much about the deal before the announcement.
American chip makers, with the support of the federal government, created Sematech in the 1980's, when they feared that Japan would become the dominant force in chip manufacturing. Foreign makers were allowed into the consortium in the 1990's. Sematech plays the leading role in developing the basic architecture for computer chips. Individual manufacturers still compete to improve on that architecture, but the industry standards set by Sematech ensure that their products are compatible, even interchangeable.
Sematech also leads in developing the materials and tools needed to produce chips, and tests products. Officials say the Albany center's first task will be to develop improved methods of chip lithography, the etching of minute patterns into chips, particularly with ultraviolet light.
In describing the undertaking, New York officials repeatedly referred to the experience of the Austin area, which gained about 100,000 tech-related jobs and saw its population double in the decade after Sematech located there. Much of that growth, particularly in chip manufacturing, was directly related to Sematech's presence, according to economists and industry analysts.
"Sematech coming here will make Albany the lead R.&D. hub in the world for this industry," said Alain E. Kaloyeros, dean of the School of Nanosciences at SUNY Albany.
But several analysts cautioned that while the development was almost certain to boost the regional economy, Albany in 2002 is not Austin in 1988, and there is no guarantee that the effect will be the same.
For starters, the tech sector of the economy is slumping, as is Sematech itself; the consortium has been cutting its workforce. Any benefits to the industry or to New York from the new center could be delayed until a rebound, and analysts are split on whether to expect one soon.
Kenneth Flamm, a professor of economics at the University of Texas in Austin who studies the semiconductor industry, said, "Sematech being here drew a lot of companies here, because Austin became the logical place to do the materials manufacturing. But our growth was due to other factors, as well, though it's hard to attribute cause and effect for much of it." 
Austin's great advantage, he said, was a a large, first-rate engineering school at the University of Texas that supplied a steady stream of professors and graduates to high-tech industries. It remains to be seen whether SUNY and Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, in nearby Troy, can be a similar source of talent.
The upper Hudson Valley's relatively low cost of living "is very much in its favor" in attracting new investment, said Richard A. Shaffer, principal of Technologic Partners, which advises venture capitalists on high-tech investments.
"To develop that kind of a regional economy like in Austin is a slow process that requires a gradual change in outlook among the people, the banks that do the lending, everybody," he said.
In its 1987 search for a home for its first center, Sematech considered offers from 36 states -- New York was one of the finalists -- trying to top each other in financial sweeteners. In the end, the chip makers contributed $125 million and the federal government $100 million. Texas put up $62 million to buy an existing factory for Sematech to convert and use, and made low-interest mortgages available to Sematech employees. But money alone did not carry the day -- New York had offered $80 million and Massachusetts more than $200 million.
This time, the consortium negotiated seriously with only New York and a few foreign governments. And while the state will put up $210 million over the next five years for the new center -- Sematech will supply $193 million -- it did not agree to give the consortium any tax breaks or loans, a frequent element of the state's deals with private industry.
The State Legislature will have to approve the $210 million allocation, but representatives of both the Assembly and the Senate said yesterday that there was widespread support. Sheldon Silver, the Democratic Assembly speaker from Manhattan, is scheduled to appear at the announcement of the agreement.
Talks began last summer, when the Semiconductor Industry Association held a meeting at Lake George, where the governor addressed the group and met many of the industry leaders for the first time. Industry officials and analysts said that I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., heavily influenced the decision to focus on New York. They also said that the companies were impressed by the growing high-tech sector in the Hudson Valley.
As recently as 1995, I.B.M. was considering leaving New York State, but Mr. Pataki persuaded the company to stay, in part with a generous package of financial incentives. I.B.M. then decided to build a $2.5 billion computer chip plant, now nearing completion, in East Fishkill, in Dutchess County. It will be the only major chip factory in the state and one of only a handful in the world to carve chips from wafers 300 millimeters wide, soon to be the new industry standard; this is expected to allow cheaper production than the long-used 200-millimeter wafers.
Mr. Pataki and the Legislature have invested more than $100 million in making SUNY's Albany campus a center for computer chip research, including early work on 300-millimeter wafers, and last year the governor established a "center of excellence" in nanotechnology there. The effort has drawn a $100 million commitment from I.B.M., as well as a number of grants from the federal government and other chip makers.

CORRECTION-DATE: July 19, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article yesterday about plans by a consortium of computer chip makers to build a research and development center in Albany misidentified the headquarters country of STMicroelectronics, one maker. Though the company was formerly based in France and keeps many operations there, its headquarters are in Switzerland.

HEADLINE: States Say Bill Would Open Bermuda-LikeTax Loophole 

BYLINE:  By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
As lawmakers debated in Washington yesterday how to close the loophole that allows companies to avoid United States taxes by acquiring a Bermuda mailbox, a bill advanced with a provision that state officials say would let companies avoid state and local taxes using some of the same techniques as the Bermuda loophole. 
 American Express, Walt Disney, Viacom, Cisco Systems, Eastman Kodak, Johnson & Johnson, the Limited, Lowe's and Microsoft are among the major corporations lobbying for the bill, which was approved by a House Judiciary subcommittee on Tuesday at a hearing held on such short notice that state officials said they could not attend. A full committee vote is expected soon. 
 The drive to restrict the authority of states and local governments to tax national companies comes as a study, to be released today by the Internal Revenue Service, shows that corporations gave themselves a huge tax cut beginning in 1996 by using tax shelters. 
The legislation to restrict state and local taxing authority would cost the states $9 billion in annual revenue in the first few years, a figure that could quickly grow as companies adjust operations to make full use of the proposed loophole, according to the Multistate Tax Commission, which represents states on tax matters. Cities and counties stand to lose billions more. 
The bill's promoters insist that if the bill becomes law, the obligation to pay state and local taxes will merely be shifted, benefiting only those places where the companies use state and local services because they have invested in offices, factories and computer servers. 
"There need be not one penny less of state tax revenue collected," said Arthur R. Rosen, the head of state and local taxes at the law firm of McDermott, Will & Emery, which represents the companies supporting the bill.
Mr. Rosen acknowledged that taxes would be reduced or eliminated under the bill if companies arranged their operations to owe taxes in jurisdictions that imposed little or no tax, but said he had no dollar estimates.
Representatives Robert W. Goodlatte and Richard Boucher, Virginia Republicans who are co-chairmen of the Congressional Internet caucus, asserted that the bill was needed to stop abusive state tax practices. 
"This bill targets states that have abused their authority to impose taxes," Mr. Goodlatte said yesterday. "It will curb the tax frenzy on the part of those states imposing unreasonable taxes" on companies that make sales, do nominal advertising or sell online in a state.
But Elizabeth Harchenko, chairwoman of the Multistate Tax Commission and director of the Oregon revenue department, wrote yesterday to the House Judiciary Committee that the bill "would legalize and expand abusive corporate tax sheltering that undermines state business activity taxes." 
"In recent years," Ms. Harchenko wrote, "several states have undertaken efforts to curtail aggressive tax shelter activity. This legislation would pre-empt those state efforts to ensure that those who do business within a state pay a fair share of state and local taxes."
She and others said that under the bill a company could use interest payments, royalties and management fees to transfer taxable income in one state to its headquarters in a state where corporate profits are not taxed. That is the same technique that companies use to avoid federal taxes when they acquire a Bermuda mailbox and hold an annual board meeting in Barbados.
Mr. Rosen said "the states have all the authority they need to stop profit shifting" and that if individual state legislatures fail to do so it is their problem, not that of his clients.
The bill to restrict the power of states and cities to tax companies is being driven in large part by the growth of electronic commerce and the sale of products and services that are called intangibles because they cannot be measured easily like a crate of oranges. Some corporations oppose state and local efforts to capture revenue from the digital economy.
The pressure for reduced state taxes on national companies is coming despite a sharp drop in their tax bill. State corporate business activity and related taxes equaled 5.2 percent of company profits in 2000, down from 9.6 percent in 1980, the Multistate Tax Commission said. 
This lower effective tax rate meant companies paid $32 billion in such taxes instead of about $60 billion. But tax breaks enacted by state legislatures explain only about $5.6 billion, or 20 percent, of this drop in corporate taxes. This suggests that the use of tax shelters is costing the states and also that companies have increased efforts to shift revenue and profits from states that tax to those that do not. 
The effect of tax shelters on federal revenue is examined in a study that the I.R.S. will publish today in the quarterly Statistics of Income Bulletin. 
Untaxed corporate profits rose to 24 percent of the profits reported to shareholders in 1998, up from 14 percent in 1996, an increase of two-thirds. This increase meant that the amount of corporate profit not taxed rose by $66.5 billion from 1996 to 1998. 
The I.R.S. analysis follows a March study by a Harvard economist, Mihir A. Desai, who sifted through reports to shareholders to determine whether the use of tax shelters was a significant issue and found evidence that the problem was much larger than the I.R.S. study. 
In 1988, less than 62 cents of each dollar of shareholder profit turned up on tax returns, down from 84 cents in 1996, Professor Desai said. Untaxed corporate profits totaled $247 billion in 1998, Professor Desai found, but deductions for stock options and other known legitimate deductions explained only about $88 billion of this amount. 
His study suggests that in 1998 $155 billion or so of corporate profits were hidden from the I.R.S. in tax shelters, costing the government as much as $54 billion in taxes. That figure is more than five times the $10 billion cost of abusive tax shelters cited by in 1999 by Lawrence H. Summers, who as Treasury secretary then started a campaign to crack down on tax avoidance and evasion by large companies. 
Professor Desai said his analysis of shareholder and taxable profits from 1998 to 2000 found that until 1995 the relative difference was stable and followed expected shifts caused by tax rules. But starting in 1996, he said, the gap between taxable profits and those reported to shareholders began to widen apparently because of tax shelters.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL: YANKEES NOTEBOOK; 
Yankees Tell Dolan Hard Work Is the Key

BYLINE:  By TYLER KEPNER 

 BODY:
George Steinbrenner fired back yesterday at Larry Dolan, the owner of the Cleveland Indians, with a nearly 300-word statement asserting that hard work, not inherent advantages under baseball's current economic climate, had made the Yankees so successful.
 Dolan criticized Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, on Tuesday, saying that he is "a large part of our problem" in baseball. 
 "I do not believe Mr. Dolan appreciates what it has taken to build the New York Yankees, to develop its brand and provide a winning team for New York and Yankee fans everywhere," the statement began. "In as much as Mr. Dolan is only in his third season in baseball, he may not know that when I acquired the team in the early 1970's, we actually had to pay WMCA just to carry Yankee games on the radio and that attendance was at an all-time low, averaging less than 1,200,000 fans per year from 1972-1975. 
"Since the day that Babe Ruth was acquired, the Yankees have been the envy of many in the game and subject to the jealousies that success brings. In reality, it is the Yankees' success and commitment to providing a consistent winner that is at the center of the criticism. No one complained when the Yankees did not have success on the field. Our revenues have not been developed and increased accidentally. They are directly attributable to hard work and continuing investment in the team. 
"I have run the Yankees the best way I know how and will continue to do so. In the wake of the most recent lawsuit, which has created even more turmoil for Commissioner Selig and his officers, I think it best for me not to comment any further at this time."
Steinbrenner did not mention the continuing dispute between the Dolan family's Cablevision empire and Steinbrenner's YES network, even though a baseball official said the Yankees believed that issue had motivated Dolan's comments.

Johnson Is Secure
The Yankees are happy to have starting pitcher Jeff Weaver, and the Detroit Tigers are happy to have Carlos Pena, the first baseman they acquired from Oakland in the three-way trade that sent Weaver to the Yankees two weeks ago.
But before the Tigers settled on Pena, they asked the Yankees for Nick Johnson. General Manager Brian Cashman turned them down and was willing to pass on Weaver if it meant giving up Johnson.
Johnson, who won Tuesday's game with a ninth-inning home run in Toronto, was not aware of that. But he said his goal through the minors had been not just to play in the majors, but to stick with the Yankees.
Even though Johnson's homer Tuesday was his first in 59 at-bats, he said he never expected to have 12 homers by mid-July. But he also never expected to have an average of about .240. Manager Joe Torre has stuck with Johnson, 23, as an everyday player.
"You make that commitment," Torre said. "You make that decision long before what you see in the games, and you know when you go out and play at the big-league level, there are experiences you have to go through."
Cashman said: "The bottom line is, there are players you really feel strongly about. We felt strongly about Soriano, Jeter, Pettitte, Rivera and Bernie. We've had temptations along the way with a lot of those guys, and Nick Johnson as well.
"But there's something about those players we feel strongly about, and we want to keep them. Nick's one of those guys we definitely want to keep and be a part of our future."

Mendoza Improving
Reliever Ramiro Mendoza, who was not available during the Yankees' two-game series in Toronto because of a sore right elbow, played catch for five minutes before last night's game and said he could pitch.
Mendoza said he had felt discomfort in his elbow when he threw his curveball, but there were no more problems yesterday. "I'm good," he said.

Jeter Is Honored
The Sporting News named shortstop Derek Jeter its No. 1 Good Guy in Pro Sports for 2002, recognizing Jeter's Turn 2 Foundation, which has awarded more than $1.5 million for children's programs since 1996. "If you can affect a child's life off the field, it means a whole lot more to me" than baseball, Jeter said. "I'm very proud of the number of children we've been able to help."

HEADLINE: Polymath Selects Polymath to Direct Bard Arts Center 

BYLINE:  By MEL GUSSOW 

 BODY:
Jonathan Levi, 46, an arts educator, editor and writer, today was named director of the new $62 million Bard Performing Arts Center, designed by Frank O. Gehry as a kind of Bilbao on the Hudson. The center is to be completed in January and open in April as a home for music, theater and dance. The building's two theaters will be used both for academic purposes and as a public space for international cultural events.
 In announcing the appointment of Mr. Levi, Leon Botstein, president of Bard College, stressed the multiplicity of his experience, especially his work as a founding editor of Granta magazine and his role as an assistant to Harold O. Levy, New York City schools chancellor. At the Board of Education he was in charge of arts and cultural affairs for New York City schools. With Mr. Levy, he was instrumental in creating the Bard Early College High School program, in which New York schoolchildren could begin to do college-level work. 
 Searching for a director for the Gehry showplace, Mr. Botstein said, he and his associates looked for someone who "could help invent an institution as opposed to someone walking in with a kind of formula." They chose Mr. Levi because they saw him as an initiator and curator rather than simply an arts presenter. He is, Mr. Botstein said, "a guy who makes things happen."
Crediting Mr. Levi with boldness, a quality that fits in with the nature of the Bard center, Mr. Botstein said, "Risk aversion is the most boring criterion of the success of people who reach the top of their organizations." He added that the center was a very risky undertaking, especially in the current economic environment: "We need someone who is confident and has no fear of failure."
Mr. Levi said he was drawn to the position by the Gehry building and Mr. Botstein's own polymath background. He is an orchestra conductor as well as college president, and he assured Mr. Levi that he could continue his own outside activities.
Besides his other accomplishments, Mr. Levi is a novelist and one of the artistic directors of the Nine Circles Chamber Theater, which presented an opera based on his short story "The Scrimshaw Violin" last December at the 92nd Street Y in Manhattan.
He said that one reason Mr. Levy put him on the Board of Education was his belief in the importance of arts education as "one of the strongest engines for learning."
In a joint interview in Bard's Manhattan office, Mr. Levi and Mr. Botstein overflowed with enthusiasm for their project. At one point, Mr. Botstein spoke out against the separation of managerial and creative roles in arts institutions and said that Goethe and Mahler were examples of artists who worked in both capacities. Then he switched signals to attack "the bureaucratization" of the arts in the late 20th century.
With a laugh, Mr. Levi interrupted him to say, "I thought you were going to suggest that I was an heir to Goethe and Mahler."
Like the Guggenheim Museum that Mr. Gehry designed in Bilbao, Spain, the Bard center is highly distinctive with a series of low-lying steel canopies that look like large, overlapping ribbons. "It's going to go down with the Colossus of Rhodes as one of the great wonders of the world," Mr. Levi said.
After a local protest about the site as an incursion into a historic landscape, the center was redesigned and was moved to the northern part of the campus. In the process it doubled in size.
The building will have two major performing spaces, a lyre-shaped 900-seat opera house and a black box theater for experimental dance and drama. During the academic year, the black box theater will be used by the college's dance and drama departments under the direction of Jean Churchill and JoAnne Akalaitis. Both Mr. Levi and Mr. Botstein emphasized the intimacy of the two houses.
"You don't want to look at a concert with a telescope," Mr. Botstein said, criticizing Tanglewood and Saratoga as "mad outdoor places that have to be amplified and are ideas from the past."
The acoustics were designed by Yasuhisa Toyota, a director of Nagata Acoustics, Japan's leading acoustical consulting firm, and the Bard opera house will also serve as a concert hall. The American Symphony Orchestra, with Mr. Botstein as conductor, will be the resident orchestra. The hall will also be converted for dance and theater pieces, but Mr. Levi said the conversion would take 80 man-hours.
The building is to open with two weekends of performances, to be followed next summer by a festival of the arts. The festival that first season will center on the work of Janacek. In a sense it will be an extension of the Bard Music Festival, which Mr. Botstein has helped run for more than a dozen years, weaving together concerts and operas with recitals and panel discussions. Next year, in the new location, there will be related theater and dance events.
Looking back on his days at Granta, Mr. Levi said that organizing the Bard festival would be something like editing that magazine, offering a prismatic view of a central subject. The idea is to overlook Janacek's most popular operas (like "The Cunning Little Vixen") and concentrate on his lesser-known works. As an adjunct, there will be consideration of related subjects such as Kafka, Czech national identity and the political history of Central Europe.
Contrasting his festival to those at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and Lincoln Center, Mr. Levi said that he hoped to have at least one international company in residence every year and to involve that company and other participants in the curriculum. He said he was drawn to Bard by the international outlook on campus and the presence of such artists as the novelist Chinua Achebe on the faculty.
One of the attractions of Bard, for the public and for students, is its rural location in Annandale-on-Hudson. It is 90 miles from New York City (a train to Rhinecliff, and a bus from there to the college). Across the river is the Storm King sculptural park.
Mr. Botstein said that "people are going to want to see this building and to experience the architecture." It will be the first major Gehry building in the New York area. Mr. Levi added that he could imagine the festival as a kind of Glyndebourne in the Catskills, including picnics on the grass during the intermission.
One thing that Mr. Levi and Mr. Botstein share, in addition to enthusiasm, is that both were trained as violinists, with Mr. Levi playing jazz and classical music. Each said he had no intention of appearing as an instrumentalist at the Bard center, not even for a benefit performance. As Mr. Levi said, "It would be a benefit if we didn't play."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Jonathan Levi, educator, editor, writer. (Sara Krulwich/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Turkey Says Debt Negotiations Aren't Linked to Stand on Iraq 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL SIMPSON 

DATELINE: ANKARA, Turkey, July 17 

 BODY:
Turkey wants the United States to write off more than $4 billion in debt, but government officials said today that they were not naming a price for their support of military action to topple President Saddam Hussein of Iraq.
 Turkish officials, who publicly oppose any operation against Iraq but privately concede they may be willing to compromise, said they had discussed cancellation of money owed for arms purchases with the deputy defense secretary, Paul D. Wolfowitz, during his talks here. 
 "The economic support we discussed was independent of any other issue," a senior government official said. Ankara also wants Washington to hasten Congressional approval for a $228 million aid package that the Bush administration has earmarked for Turkey, according to officials of both countries. 
But the Turkish government was at pains to emphasize that this did not amount to laying down conditions for an operation in which the support of Turkey, NATO's only Muslim member, would be vital.
Before leaving Ankara, Mr. Wolfowitz emphasized that Washington was not asking for Turkey's clear backing for an attack on Iraq.
"We did not come here asking for decisions -- we haven't made our own decisions ourselves," Mr. Wolfowitz told reporters in Ankara, the capital. He said that before making such decisions, it was important for Mr. Bush "to have the benefit of perspectives of key countries who are key partners, and Turkey is as important as any country in figuring out how to grapple with this issue."
Turkey, mired in its worst recession since 1945 and a political crisis that has brought about early elections, publicly repeated its reservations about a renewed offensive against Iraq after its request for economic assistance.
Mr. Wolfowitz assured the Turks, who say the 1991 Persian Gulf war and subsequent sanctions against Baghdad cost billions of dollars in lost trade, of American support to ease a crippling economic crisis that has made Turkey the International Monetary Fund's biggest debtor.
"Turkey's economic situation is something of great concern to the United States," he said.
He also sought to ease Turkish fears that an attack on Iraq could create problems with Kurds who are demanding independence. 
Since Kurdish fighters wrested control of northern Iraq from Baghdad after the gulf war, the United States has protected the breakaway region. But Mr. Wolfowitz ruled out the creation of a separate state, which Turkey has long opposed, fearing its own large Kurdish minority would be encouraged to renew a guerrilla struggle for independence.
"There is a lot of agreement with Turkey on what we would like to see after Saddam," Mr. Wolfowitz said. "We're both opposed to Kurdish states. We're both concerned about the rights of minorities."
He also reminded Turks that they stood to gain from a change of regime in Baghdad, where the Iraqi president was defiant today, insisting there was no way Washington could bring an end to his 23-year rule.
If Iraq were to become a democratic state, "it won't only be the people of Iraq who benefit from that, it will be the whole world and very much this region," Mr. Wolfowitz said. "Turkey stands to benefit enormously when Iraq becomes a normal country."

HEADLINE: Olympic Site Committee Denies New York Is Out of the Running 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg and the United States Olympic Committee denied reports yesterday that New York City was losing out in the bidding to serve as host of the 2012 Summer Olympics.
 New York is vying with San Francisco, Washington-Baltimore and Houston to win the nomination as United States candidate for host of the 2012 Olympics. The site-selection panel of the United States Olympic Committee, which visited each city in recent weeks for a final review, will announce its choice on Nov. 3. 
The Washington Post reported on Wednesday that Washington-Baltimore and San Francisco had vaulted into front-runners' positions in the competition, citing an unnamed official involved in the process. New York had lost ground, the paper reported, because of an inordinately high $4 billion in construction costs.
But the U.S.O.C. denied the report, saying that "the notion that we have already tabbed favorites is a complete work of fiction and imagination."
Mayor Bloomberg sounded relieved yesterday.
"I think we have a compelling case," Mr. Bloomberg said. "It is just inconceivable to me that there is another city that better represents everything the Olympic movement stands for, or any other city that can, in today's world, provide the facilities and the security and the transportation and the spirit and the venues to have the world's greatest sporting event."
Before joining the Bloomberg administration, Daniel Doctoroff, Mr. Bloomberg's deputy mayor for economic development, led the Olympic effort in New York almost single-handedly. Mr. Doctoroff has said that the Olympics could be a tremendous boost for New York that would leave a legacy of public sports venues and economic development. Meantime, the city and the state must decide whether to help build a $1 billion Olympic stadium on the west side of Manhattan and an extended subway line, both of which are critical components in New York's bid.
The site committee's tentative plan is to meet in Chicago on Aug. 26 to pare the list of potential host cities to two finalists. The U.S.O.C. will ultimately submit its nomination to the International Olympic Committee, which will choose the site in 2005 by secret ballot. London, Paris, Rome, Moscow and Berlin are also expected to be in the running.
One member of the American site-selection team dismissed the report in The Washington Post.
"We haven't even spent time discussing the data yet," he said. "The best you could have gotten out of anyone inside the room is their own preference."

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Fall, But Activity Stays Strong, Experts Say 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17 

 BODY:
Starts on new housing fell 3.6 percent in June after a surge the previous month, the government said today, but economists, including the Federal Reserve chairman, Alan Greenspan, said housing remained at strong levels.
 "There's no evidence that one can see that the fairly significant strength in the housing market is in any way impeded," Mr. 
Greenspan said at a House hearing on the economy, in response to a question about the report. 
 Groundbreaking for new homes eased to a seasonally adjusted 1.672 million units a year from an upwardly revised rate of 1.735 million units in May, the Commerce Department reported.
Starts were below the projections of analysts polled by Reuters, who had forecast a 1.677 million unit rate.
Despite the decline in June, analysts noted that building and sales activity remained at historically high levels.
"Over the past 20 years, the level of single-family activity posted in June was exceeded only three times. And two of those occasions occurred this year," said Joel Naroff of Naroff Economic Advisors.
Permits, an indication of future activity, rose 1.4 percent, to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.7 million.
Regionally, starts were mostly lower, falling 7.6 percent in the South -- the busiest home-building region -- 2.2 percent in the West and 0.9 percent in the Midwest. Groundbreaking for new homes climbed 6.1 percent in the Northeast.
Another survey released today by the mortgage bankers trade association showed that mortgage applications fell in the week ended July 12, while refinancings rose as the national average on the 30-year fixed-rate mortgage slid to almost 6.5 percent.
Although applications are also still at strong levels, the housing market may not show the same levels of growth over the second half of the year, said David Seiders of the National Association of Home Builders.

HEADLINE: Republicans Point Corporate-Abuse Finger at Democrats 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 17 

 BODY:
Republican state party leaders went on the offensive today against Democratic attacks on corporate wrongdoing. Some asserted that the problems had begun under President Bill Clinton, while others even promised to hold Democrats accountable for the difficulties on Wall Street.
 The party leaders spoke as they arrived here for a Republican National Committee summer meeting, in which they will discuss strategy for trying to retake control of the United States Senate in November. They are also facing potential losses in several governor's races. 
 While some Republican leaders said they hoped that the issue of corporate abuses would move off center stage before the campaign season becomes more intense, others said they feared the party's political prospects would suffer if the economy is on a downturn.
"If the market gets worse, if there's a sense that not much is being done, it could be a problem," said Al Cardenas, the chairman of the Florida Republican Party.
Many Republican leaders expressed frustration at what they said was the effort by Democrats to blame their candidates for wrongdoing by corporate leaders. They suggested that President Bush had at first been slow to respond to it. Some Republicans, hinting at an aggressiveness in the campaign ahead, said the party should set the problems at the feet of Democrats.
"Take a look at this realistically; when did this corporate abuse start?" said Ronald Eibensteiner, the Minnesota Republican chairman. "It didn't start when George Bush became president. If there ever was a decade of greed, it was the 1990's when Bill Clinton was president. There was this whole culture of, if you can get by, that was O.K. And if you got caught, just stonewall. When the president of the United States, Bill Clinton, did that, other people began to think, 'Hey, we can do that.' "
Marty Ryall, the chairman of the Arkansas Republican Party, said Democrats were just as reliant on support from errant corporations as Republicans.
"I don't think the public is going to buy into the idea that the Republicans brought this on," Mr. Ryall said. "These accounting problems with Enron and the other companies were going on for some time. It's not something that happened in the last year. I think Democrats will try that, to say that Republicans were more tied to corporate America than Democrats, but I think Republicans can make a counter issue."
The remarks came at a decidedly uneasy time for the Republican Party. Its leaders girded for what they said they expected to be a concerted attack by Democrats, first in the halls of Congress and then in dozens of Congressional and Senate races across the country. While many expressed confidence that they could deflect such attacks, they acknowledged that was a potentially significant concern in an election where their margin of error is small.
The Democrats currently control the Senate by one seat, and of the 36 governor's seats being contested this year, 23 are held by Republicans. As a matter of history, the party in power in the White House loses seats in mid-term Congressional elections.
Accordingly, some party leaders said they would be satisfied if the Republicans just held their own in November. "A break-even for us at the federal level would be historic, though I'm not sure the press would report it that way," said Marty Connors, the chairman of the Alabama Republican Party. Others, perhaps reflecting the exuberance that tends to be found at these kind of partisan gatherings, said they believed that the Republican Party would buck the trend, in no small part because of the nation's approval of Mr. Bush's efforts to counter terrorism.
"I know it's against the traditional tide to gain seats in the midyear of the presidency, but I think we're in a position do to that," Mr. Ryall said. "It depends on the confidence that the public has in the economy in the fall."
Other Republicans said the outcome in November depended as much as on how Mr. Bush and Republicans in Congress handled the economic questions in coming weeks, and how the Democrats played the subject.
"If the president can put his game plan on the table, as he's been doing, and if a game plan is communicated properly to the public, and if the public thinks it's the right game plan, and if the Congress does something about it, and the markets start rebounding, than I think the public will be fine," Mr. Cardenas said.
Mr. Connors added: "I don't think anybody who is walking around thinks this started the day George Bush was sworn into office. This is a cumulative affect that's happened over time."
John Dowd, the New Hampshire Republican chairman, said: "I don't think it's President Bush's fault, and people would be hard-pressed to blame it on him. The American people have already figured out that it has nothing to do, or very little to do, with politics."
Nonetheless, Republican leaders here said they had been closely watching Democratic attempts to portray the Republicans as close to business, and opposing Congressional efforts to regulate accounting and corporate practices.
"They think they can make hay with it, but I don't think people are going to buy that," Bob Kjellander, a national committee member from Illinois, said tonight. "This is a bipartisan problem."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-8

2 Bombers Kill 3 in Tel Aviv In New Wave of Violence
Two Palestinian suicide bombers killed three people in Tel Aviv, a day after eight Israelis died in a West Bank bus ambush. The attacks shattered a calm that had followed an Israeli Army move in the West Bank. A1

Britain Rethinks Criminal Laws
The government proposed scrapping the ancient double-jeopardy rule that prevents people from being tried twice for the same crime, making hearsay evidence admissible and letting jurors know of suspects' previous crimes. With British crime levels soaring, confidence in the police and the courts has been plunging. A8

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Americans Express Concern On Corporate Tug on Bush
Americans worry that President Bush and his administration are too heavily influenced by big business, fear that Mr. Bush is hiding something about his own corporate past and judge the economy to be in its worst shape since 1994, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
 The survey suggests that the unfolding disclosures about corporate misconduct and inflated earnings hold considerable peril for the White House and Mr. Bush's party in this Congressional election year. Page A1. 

Pitt Is Soon Freed of Restrictions
Harvey L. Pitt, the head of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said that with the expiration of ethics restrictions that have bound him during his first year in office, he would play a direct role in enforcement cases involving companies and accounting firms that were once his law clients. His background as a securities lawyer was an asset, he said, not a liability as some critics have charged. A1.

House Bill Would Add Tax Loophole
A bill advanced in the House with a provision that state officials say would let companies avoid state and local taxes. C4.

Ford Returns to a Profit in Quarter
Ford Motor returned to profitability after four quarters in the red but said it expected to lose money this quarter. C6.

2 Big Banks Post Increased Earnings
Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase reported increased quarterly profits, with strength in consumer banking and credit cards compensating for continued weakness in investment banking. Market Place. C8.

Wall St. Has a Rare Upbeat Day
Wall Street returned to positive territory. The Dow industrials rose 69.37 points, to 8,542.48. The Nasdaq composite climbed 21.99 points, to 1,397.25, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 4.99 points, to 906.04. C8.

Chip Center Planned for Albany
Top computer chip makers plan to build a center for research and development on the next generation of microchips in Albany, a decision that state officials hope will bring thousands of new jobs to the Hudson Valley. A1.

Advanced Micro Devices, the No. 2 chip maker behind Intel, posted a quarterly loss. C7.

Accounting Firm Settles Charges
PricewaterhouseCoopers settled charges that it violated rules requiring auditors to remain independent of clients. C3.

15% Jump in Profits at Coke
Coca-Cola said that its second-quarter earnings increased 15 percent, to $1.29 billion, or 52 cents a share, in line with expectations. The positive performance came in spite of weak economic conditions in several of its international markets, primarily because of product innovation and strong sales in North America and Asia. Its shares fell 37 cents, to $50. C6.

AT&T President Is Named Chief
David W. Dorman, president of AT&T, will succeed C. Michael Armstrong as chairman and chief executive next year. C8.

U.S. Said to Violate Trade Rules
The World Trade Organization said the United States government is violating trade rules in a victory for the European Union, Canada and other United States trading partners. C2.

Roles of Incentives and Competition
Business "reforms" should not ignore the positive roles of incentives and competition. Virginia Postrel: Economic Scene. C2.

HEADLINE: CORPORATE CONDUCT: LEGISLATION; 
Ina Shift, Republicans Pledge to Pass Accounting Bill

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and DANIEL ALTMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17 

 BODY:
In an abrupt about-face, Republicans in the House pledged today to reach final agreement by next week with the Senate on a sweeping overhaul of laws concerning accounting and corporate behavior.
 The move today illustrated the political burden on House leaders not to be seen as obstructing or watering down legislation meant to prevent future corporate scandals, even as some rank-and-file Republican House members expressed worry that attempts to delay the legislation would hurt the party in the November elections. 
 Michael G. Oxley, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Financial Services Committee, said this afternoon that he thought that competing proposals by the House and Senate were mostly "very, very similar." He also promised lawmakers that differences in the bills would be worked out before the House adjourns next week for the monthlong August recess. 
The comments were striking because Mr. Oxley, who sponsored the House legislation, had repeatedly said in the last week that the Senate bill had substantial flaws and that lawmakers needed a "cooling off" period so they could negotiate a more reasoned bill in a less politically charged atmosphere.
But skeptical Democrats said today that they thought that Republicans might still try to kill the bill -- or water it down substantially -- by delaying negotiations long enough so that outrage over the current wave of corporate scandals subsides. That would make it easier, they said, to soften the legislation when negotiators from the House and Senate meet in conference committee to reconcile differences between the approaches. Today, both chambers appointed the lawmakers who will handle the negotiations.
Also today, Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, warned that the wave of earnings restatements that have hurt stock prices lately was not over. But he also reiterated his faith in the economy's fundamental strength. Mr. Greenspan, testifying before Mr. Oxley's panel, also predicted that the "frenzy" of companies trying to drive up stock prices is mostly finished. "The shock of what has happened will keep malfeasance down for a while," he said.
The Senate bill, sponsored by Paul S. Sarbanes, the Maryland Democrat, calls for more far-reaching corporate changes and regulations than legislation passed by the House. Both chambers have also passed tough new criminal penalties for corporate wrongdoing, with the House approving on Tuesday even longer prison terms than what the Senate approved on Monday. The proposals are an outgrowth of the accounting scandals at Enron, WorldCom and other companies that have rocked Wall Street and undermined investor confidence. 
But Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, said that Republicans were trying to "act like you're trying to get something done, but really slow it down and water it down."
"That's their goal," he added. "That's their game plan."
Mr. Gephardt and other Democrats had seized on a threat by Republican Bill Thomas, the House Ways and Means Committee chairman, to use a parliamentary tactic to block the Senate bill. But within hours, Republican officials said they did not plan to issue a so-called blue slip on the legislation that would have invoked a constitutional argument -- that portions of the bill that "raise revenue" did not originate in the House -- to block the bill. According to a Republican aide, House leaders told Mr. Thomas that while they thought his objections had merit, it was not feasible politically to use the maneuver to block the Senate bill.
Still, Mr. Oxley and other leading Republicans reiterated today that they had problems with the Senate bill. That includes the amount of investigative and enforcement power the bill grants to a new regulatory board to oversee the accounting industry and other provisions that Republicans say will spur needless lawsuits against business -- but which Democrats say are needed to protect whistle-blowers and investors. 
Mr. Oxley also cited the need to require companies to make real-time disclosure of material financial information and a Republican proposal for a mechanism to recoup money that investors have lost because of corporate wrongdoing. "We are seeking to strengthen the Sarbanes approach with a number of specific improvements," Mr. Oxley said.
But some rank-and-file Republicans remain worried that attempts to tinker too much with the legislation, or water it down, will hurt their party politically. Two Republican House members, Mark Foley of Florida and Mike Rogers of Michigan, have collected signatures from 16 other Republicans urging the House to simply accept the Senate bill.
Peter T. King, a New York Republican, said most Republicans want to pass something quickly, even if it closely resembles the Senate bill.
"I think they want something close to the Sarbanes bill," Mr. King said. "The last thing we want to be seen as is obstructionist. They would like to get this done sooner rather than later."
In his comments before Mr. Oxley's committee, Mr. Greenspan was critical of one crucial part of the House and Senate proposals: requiring senior executives of publicly traded companies to certify the accuracy of their financial statements.
That proposal, made initially in the Senate but later approved by the House, goes much farther than a plan by the Securities and Exchange Commission to require chief executives and chief financial officers at about 1,000 of the biggest companies to certify their financial reports.
"I'd hate to have to administer something of that dimension," Mr. Greenspan said, citing concerns about an overload of paperwork at the S.E.C. "I am fearful of the resources that inevitably would go in that direction would impede the much smaller group which you really need to oversee in that respect."
Mr. Greenspan confirmed his support for counting employee stock option grants as business expenses, but he said Congress should allow the Financial Accounting Standards Board to make the change. "If you leave it to F.A.S.B. and you don't interfere with what they're going to do, they'll get it right," he said.
The Fed chairman said Congress should avoid increasing investors' ability to sue companies that manipulate their books to inflate share prices. "I don't see that that has any particular economic advantage," he said, suggesting that legal actions ought to be left to the S.E.C.
He also showed little enthusiasm for an attempt by Congress to close off foreign tax havens where American businesses have sheltered hundreds of billions of dollars in revenue. "If you're going to have a free market system," he said, "you have to have freedom of movement."
Separately, President Bush said today that he was confident an inquiry by the S.E.C. into accounting at the Halliburton Company would exonerate Vice President Dick Cheney, its former chief executive. Until today, the White House had declined to comment on the inquiry to avoid being accused of trying to influence it. Mr. Cheney has not discussed the inquiry.

HEADLINE: House Conservatives Budge on Arts Spending 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 17 

 BODY:
After a brief rebellion by conservative Republicans, the House today approved a $19.8 billion spending measure for public lands and cultural programs after increasing spending for a once-divisive arts programs. The final vote was 377 to 46. 
 That came after lawmakers agreed, on a 234-to-192 vote, to give $126 million to the National Endowment for the Arts, a $10 million increase, and $131 million to the National Endowment for the Humanities, an increase of $5 million. 
 The arts endowment in particular has been a past target of conservatives on the grounds that it financed obscene and inappropriate projects and drew the government into the subjective area of artistic merit. 
Republicans quickly took aim at the program when they gained control of the House in 1994 and sought to eliminate the agency a few years later. It was kept alive by the Clinton administration and sympathetic senators. But financing has remained stagnant and is now more than 40 percent below the years leading up to the Republican takeover.
"Shame on us," said Representative Lynn Woolsey, Democrat of California, who chided opponents of the program for leaving the country "culturally impoverished.'
Representative Louise M. Slaughter, Democrat of New York and chairwoman of the Congressional Arts Caucus, noted that President Bush had recognized the role of arts in schools. "Now it's time to show us the money," Ms. Slaughter said.
Even critics of the program said changes had made it more acceptable in recent years. Still, they said that the initial spending levels approved by the Appropriations Committee were sufficient. Forty-two Republicans and 191 Democrats backed the increase, while 177 Republicans and 14 Democrats opposed it; two independents split.
At the urging of California lawmakers, the House agreed to prohibit federal spending on the development of three dozen oil leases off that's state's coast. The authors of the amendment said California deserved the same consideration as Florida, where the Bush administration recently agreed to buy back oil leases opposed by Gov. Jeb Bush.
Representative Lois Capps, Democrat of California, who wrote the amendment, said she hoped the 252-to-172 vote would lead to a permanent prohibition on new drilling.
"Passage of this amendment is a major step toward terminating the leases that threaten the Central Coast's environment and economy," Mrs. Capps said. 
In a sign of tensions in Congress, consideration of the spending measure to finance the Interior Department and other agencies -- the third of 13 spending measures that will be considered in the House -- was slowed on Tuesday by resistance from conservative Republicans. They were seeking to cut up to $775 million from the measure, saying they did not want it to exceed the requests of President Bush.
The group sought to make its point procedurally by offering amendments to cut spending, beginning with a reduction of $162 million for the Bureau of Land Management.
Challenging their own party's leadership of the appropriations process, the conservatives said they were worried that passing "bloated" measures in the early stages would make it much more difficult when the House turned to the larger spending measures for health, justice, housing and veterans.
"If the Houses passes the first appropriations bills at levels significantly above the request, I think we will be forced at the end of the process to break the bank," said Representative Peter Hoekstra, Republican of Michigan.
Though the proposals to enact the cuts were overwhelmingly rejected, the debate kept the measure from being moved forward and frustrated House leaders who want to make progress on the spending bills.
Representative Patrick J. Toomey, Republican of Pennsylvania and one of the leaders of the rebels, said the spending foes agreed to drop their amendments today in exchange for a promise from Republican leaders that the first spending measure to be brought up after the August recess would be the labor and health measure, one of the largest.
Democrats described the feud as an intramural Republican fight caused, they said, by Mr. Bush's tax cuts, which reduced the money available.
"We are seeing a philosophical war within the Republican party," said Representative David R. Obey of Wisconsin, the ranking Democrat on the Appropriations Committee.
The bill contains almost $520 million more than last year for the Interior Department and appropriates $2.4 billion for the National Park Service, $39 million more than sought by the president. It also includes $700 million in emergency money for fighting wildfires.
