HEADLINE: Poll Finds Concerns That Bush Is Overly Influenced by Business 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON and JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
Americans worry that President Bush and his administration are too heavily influenced by big business, fear that Mr. Bush is hiding something about his own corporate past and judge the economy to be in its worst shape since 1994, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.
 The survey suggests that the unfolding revelations about corporate misconduct and inflated earnings hold considerable peril for the White House and Mr. Bush's party in this Congressional election year. Not surprisingly, Democrats sounded particularly troubled about the administration's handling of the corporate issue, but even Republicans shared many of the concerns. 
 By more than two to one, the poll's respondents said the administration was more interested in protecting the interests of large companies than those of ordinary Americans. That concern was expressed by more than a third of Republicans and an overwhelming majority of Democrats. 
Two-thirds of all respondents, and slightly more than half of Republicans, said business interests had too much influence on the Republican Party. Slightly less than half of all those polled said business exerted too much influence over the Democrats. Many Americans also expressed concerns that Mr. Bush and Vice President Dick Cheney had not been sufficiently forthcoming about their own past business dealings.
With the stock market falling, concern about the economy intensifying and the United States facing the continued threat of terrorist attacks, the poll found a surge since the start of the year in the percentage of people who think the country is on the wrong track. It also found that Americans' trust in government, which climbed after Sept. 11, has slid significantly.
For all the reservations respondents expressed about the administration's commitment to looking out for them -- and about the business ethics of administration officials when they were in the private sector -- Mr. Bush remains personally popular. His approval rating stands at 70 percent, continuing a steady decline from its peak of 89 percent after Sept. 11, but still impressive by any standard.
Asked whether Mr. Bush "cares about the needs and problems of people like yourself," 68 percent responded yes.
The nationwide telephone poll of 1,000 adults was conducted Saturday through Tuesday. It has a sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points.
People who participated in the poll and agreed to follow-up interviews said that they often separated Mr. Bush's performance as commander in chief from his performance on domestic issues, and that they tended to give greater weight to the fight on terrorism in judging him.
"Bush is doing his job well in Afghanistan, but the economy is falling down around us," said Debbie Wilson, 40, an unemployed hairdresser from Elmira, N.Y.
"As far as big business's influence on the administration, it's hard to be sure of what is really going on," Ms. Wilson, a Democrat, said. "I watch the news about him and Cheney and the tycoons, and you don't know where you're at. The whole country seems to be too influenced by business, but there is not enough information given to the public."
Paula Pittman-Troisi, 40, of Birmingham, Ala., said she thought Mr. Bush had been a great leader in the fight against terrorism. But she had questions about the influence of campaign contributors and big business on government.
"Though the intertwining of raising campaign funds and big business worries me, it doesn't worry me enough to lose my faith in George Bush," said Ms. Pittman-Troisi, a part-time securities saleswoman who is an independent voter.
Still, among the survey's most striking findings were the responses concerning the past business practices of Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney. Though most of those polled said that they did not know much about the business dealings of the two, the respondents expressed skepticism about whether the president and vice president were being candid and open.
Asked whether Mr. Bush was telling the truth about his dealings at Harken Energy, an oil company where he was a director and consultant from 1986 to 1993, 48 percent of those surveyed said that they believed Mr. Bush was hiding something; another 9 percent said they thought he was mostly lying. Seventeen percent said they believed that Mr. Bush was telling the entire truth.
Yet when asked whether they thought Mr. Bush had acted honestly and ethically in his business practices while in the corporate world, 43 percent of the survey's respondents said yes, more than double than the 21 percent who said no.
Mr. Bush has maintained that all his actions at Harken were proper, and at a White House news conference yesterday he reiterated that a Securities and Exchange Commission investigation into his sale of Harken stock in 1990 ended with no action taken against him.
Mr. Cheney's role as chief executive of the Halliburton Company, the oil services giant whose accounting practices during Mr. Cheney's tenure are being investigated by the S.E.C., drew similarly skeptical responses. Forty-three percent of those polled said they thought Mr. Cheney was hiding something, 10 percent said they thought he was mostly lying and 11 percent said they thought he was telling the entire truth.
Asked specifically whether they thought Mr. Cheney had done anything unethical while running Halliburton, 23 percent said yes and 32 percent said no.
Mr. Cheney has declined to comment on his involvement in Halliburton's accounting policies, citing the S.E.C. inquiry. Asked about Mr. Cheney yesterday, Mr. Bush defended him as a "fine business leader."
While questions about the corporate careers of Mr. Bush and Mr. Cheney were most pronounced among Democrats and independents, Republicans also expressed concern. Thirty-nine percent of the Republicans polled said that Mr. Bush was hiding something; 37 percent said Mr. Cheney was doing so.
Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's spokesman, said the poll results were evidence "of a nation that continues to strongly approve of the job the president is doing and a nation that knows the president is honest and ethical and shares the nation's moral values."
Mr. Bush registered positive approval ratings for his handling of foreign policy. Also, 80 percent of those polled said that Mr. Bush shared the moral values most Americans try to live by.
At the same time, people remained split about whether Mr. Bush is really in charge of what goes on in his administration.
The corporate scandals and the questions about the honesty of corporate earnings reports are clearly touching the public. Sixty-two percent of those surveyed called the issues very serious, and another 29 percent said they were somewhat serious.
The poll also found that 43 percent of respondents did not think Mr. Bush's proposals for addressing the problems went far enough, but 36 percent said they were about right.
The poll found that 58 percent of all respondents -- and 38 percent of the Republicans -- said that business has too much influence on Mr. Bush himself. Two-thirds of all those surveyed, and slightly more than half the Republicans, said business has too much influence on the administration generally. 
Few administrations have come to office with more corporate experience than Mr. Bush's. But with both politics and the economic outlook being recast by the volatility on Wall Street and the reports of malfeasance within corporations, business experience that had once been the highlight of the administration's resume has increasingly given Democrats an opportunity to portray Republicans as detached from the concerns of average people, the poll showed.
Those surveyed were divided over whether Mr. Bush was personally more interested in helping corporations than in helping ordinary people, but 58 percent said the Republican party was primarily interested in protecting big business. Slightly more than half the Republicans polled said that business interests had too much influence with their own party.
The poll found that big business is held in relatively low regard. More than a third said they have very little confidence in big business, and 71 percent said business does only a fair -- or poor -- job of making sure its executives adhere to ethical and legal standards.
The survey's findings about the business scandals were mirrored by general declines in trust in government and in views about the economic outlook. 
Asked to rate the state of the economy, 49 percent said very good or fairly good, while 49 percent said fairly bad or very bad. It was the most pessimistic assessment since early 1994, when the economic boom of the last decade was just getting under way.
Larry Shepler, 42, of Chesapeake, Va., a high school teacher, said in a follow-up interview that he thought Mr. Bush was doing a good job because the country was moving in the right direction, the economy had stabilized and the war on terrorism was going reasonably well.
Mr. Shepler, a Republican, said: "Though big business has always been too involved in the government because lobbyists for big business have always had too much influence and carry more weight than the average person, it is only coming out now because companies are in financial trouble and people are being made more aware of it."

How the Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted Saturday through Tuesday with 1,000 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to listed and unlisted numbers alike. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variation in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the margin of sampling error is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Variation in the wording and order of questions, for example, may lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Posada Foils Tigers, Making Pettitte a Winner

BYLINE:  By TYLER KEPNER 

 BODY:
As Mark Redman bounded for the mound before the bottom of the ninth inning last night, a new feature appeared on the Yankee Stadium scoreboard. Instead of the usual clip of John Belushi rallying the boys in "Animal House," a fan in the bleachers did his own Belushi routine.
 It was never over with DiMaggio and Mantle, the fan bellowed, and it's not over with Jeter and Giambi. 
 Redman never heard it. The 28-year-old Detroit Tigers left-hander said he concentrated on the sounds of deflation he produced all night, the groans and grunts of fans in the crowd of 49,116 who expected more from their team's intimidating lineup. 
"There's not a hitter out there that will get me rattled," Redman said. "Babe Ruth is no longer playing, so I guess I don't have to worry about him."
But the bombast from the bleachers was prophetic. The Yankees came back in the ninth inning to foil Redman, 2-1, earning a victory for their own left-hander, Andy Pettitte, who also worked a complete game. Jorge Posada's two-out, line-drive single to left scored Derek Jeter from second base with the winning run.
Pettitte's complete game was his second in his last four starts. He allowed 11 hits, but was much more dominant than that; five of the hits were infield singles, and another was a broken-bat blooper. Pettitte is making something of a season that started in distress.
"There were times early on when I wasn't sure how I was going to do this year, if I was going to be able to come through it," said Pettitte, who missed two months with elbow tendinitis. "To be able to see that my arm strength is there is a great sign for me."
The Yankees were handcuffed by Redman's changeups for eight innings, held mostly to dribblers or pop-ups as the Tigers clung to a 1-0 lead. But Alfonso Soriano led off the Yankee ninth with a double that skipped past Shane Halter at third. Soriano leads the majors in extra-base hits, but Halter was playing in, out of respect for his speed and the possibility of a bunt. He could not react in time.
Jeter walked on a full count, the first walk of the game by either pitcher, and after a conference on the mound, Redman retired Bernie Williams on a popout. Jason Giambi lashed a single to center, tying the game, but Raul Mondesi popped out for the second out.
Then Posada, batting right-handed, came up and got ahead in the count, 2-0. He looked for a high changeup and blistered it over Halter's head and into the left field corner. Jeter knew the Tigers had no play, and he started cheering before he had rounded third.
"We were just trying to do too much early," Posada said. "When we got to the ninth inning, we said, 'Let's calm down.' Soriano got a double; the ball took a funny hop on the third baseman, and that was it. You get a double leading off the inning with nobody out and Derek gets a walk, you've got a pretty good chance."
Pettitte gave the Yankees that chance by stifling the Tigers after Damion Easley's run-scoring single in the third. The Tigers hit Pettitte hard in the fourth, but Mondesi squelched that rally.
Halter led off with a single, and Robert Fick dumped a broken-bat single into right. Halter kept going, challenging Mondesi's strong arm. Few, if any, runners had challenged Mondesi since his trade to the Yankees on July 1, and he fired a strike to third. Robin Ventura tagged Halter on the shoulder for Mondesi's first assist with the Yankees.
Mondesi slapped his glove with his hand and Pettitte pointed to him from the infield. Pettitte took care of things himself the rest of the way, pounding four-seam fastballs -- the pitch he throws hardest -- on the inside corner. 
"I was throwing nothing but four-seam fastballs, not many balls to the outside corner," Pettitte said. "For me to be able to do that and face guys four or five times and still be doing that in the ninth inning is a good sign for me. I wanted to put a second good start together, so that was nice. I want to go on a run."
Pettitte, who won in Cleveland last Thursday in the first game after the All-Star Game break, would have been the losing pitcher had Redman survived the ninth. He nearly did, with a fastball that probably did not hit 90 miles per hour but a changeup that devastated a team of power hitters.
"He had a good changeup going tonight, and he wasn't making a lot of mistakes with it," Giambi said. "He was keeping it down in the strike zone and then all of a sudden popping one in there and jamming guys. He did a great job changing speeds."
The Yankees' lineup came in with 2 hits in 28 career at-bats off Redman, who did not want to share his secrets. But he did say the environment made him better.
"I think it's the atmosphere, the history, the stadium, the respect that this team has around the league," Redman said. "They win."
They were not winning last night until the last pitch Redman threw. Then, as any fan in the bleachers would have been happy to remind him, it was over.

INSIDE PITCH
ORLANDO HERNANDEZ might be suspended for throwing at CARLOS DELGADO in Toronto on Monday, but he should make his scheduled start for the Yankees against the Boston Red Sox on Saturday. Baseball's chief disciplinarian, BOB WATSON, said last night that he was not close to a decision. Watson said that he was reviewing tapes but that had not spoken to the umpires from Monday's game. Watson did interview Manager JOE TORRE and General Manager BRIAN CASHMAN on Tuesday. Hernandez and Torre, who were ejected, earned automatic fines but may face additional punishment.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Cain and Abel Played Out in a Run-Down Amazon Port

BYLINE:  By RICHARD EDER 

 BODY:
THE BROTHERS
By Milton Hatoum
Translated from Portuguese by John Gledson.
226 pages. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $23.
 "The world turns many times and yesterday a tower fell," the Spanish saying goes. Two towers in New York, and a metaphorical as well as a literal fall: our twin trusts in physical security and economic integrity. 
 In the years when we were continentally assured, the world felt like somewhere to visit, not somewhere that would visit us. When our literature now and then dealt with abroad, it was usually a matter of us in another place, not of them in ours. (Except for Henry James, whose Americans, whether at home or in Europe, harbored inklings of inner invasion.)
The point was to get "us" right, in a different setting. It seems time for our imagination to make room for "them" and listen to voices coming from far off.
Art has only a low-powered microphone; it requires our ears. We have to bend them to hear the voices of Milton Hatoum's Lebanese immigrants living some 50 years ago in a decayed Brazilian river town. Partly, what makes them audible and affecting is the timbre of Mr. Hatoum's sentences and sensibility; partly, perhaps, it is that in the world's growing wilderness we may want to pay heed to the messages conveyed by small sounds.
"The Brothers" is a harsh story told in lush tropical colors that veil its harshness. Mr. Hatoum, a Brazilian of Lebanese descent, has placed it among his own people. Whether the plot is invented or borrows from reality, it takes second place to a teeming memory of place and culture. More exactly, to the imagination of memory: blurring the edges in legend while intensifying its emotional resonance.
Manaus, far up the Amazon River, is the setting. Once the El Dorado of world rubber production, it was ruined -- thanks to purloined seeds or cuttings -- by British plantations started in Malaya. It has lived since then in a teeter of stagnation, revival and backsliding. The river meant trade, though: small trade conducted by small traders, many of them immigrants from the Middle East.
"The Brothers" tells of Halim, a peddler grown into a shopkeeper; his wife, Zana; and their twin sons. More than Cain and Abel, the enmity between Omar and Yaqub resembles the fratricidal cycle of the blue shark, whose progeny tear at each other while still unborn.
When the twins are 8, Zana's beloved father dies on a visit to his village in Lebanon. Her mourning is extravagant: a temporary ban on the voracious sex she enjoys with Halim, and her insistence on sending one twin to stay for a while with her father's relatives. Doting on Omar, she selects Yaqub, but World War II stretches the boy's exile to five years.
The story begins when he returns at 13 with rough peasant manners and little Portuguese. Working with taciturn brilliance to catch up, he wins a coveted place as an engineering student in Sao Paulo. Success follows, with rare visits home; his long-forced absence remains an unhealed wound. So does his pain over Zana's near-incestuous passion for his brother.
Omar grows up to be a dissolute, arrogant, womanizing layabout. His own resentment of his brother's success -- apart from everything else, Yaqub stole his girlfriend when they were young and later married her -- erupts in a series of physical assaults over the years, capped at last by Yaqub's cold vengeance.
Mr. Hatoum evokes better than he narrates. His family epic is a series of episodes confusedly linked. The chronology is hard to follow and occasionally hard to believe. Important developments are casually introduced, seemingly dropped, revived. Mysteries planted with no great conviction (among them the true identity of the narrator, raised as the twins' half-brother) are resolved or partly resolved with no great impact. It is a narrative without vertebrae, oozing forward and back as a worm does, and not so much progressing as pulsing.
In the pulsing, though, lie the book's allure and eventually its wisdom. The twins are not true characters in themselves (and without a character behind them Omar's repeated wastrelings become tedious), but blows of fate. The victims are Halim and Zana, along with Domingas, whose relationship is more than that of a servant.
Beyond the parents' vulnerability is the frailty of family, token of seeming permanence but subject to time and vicissitude. Beyond this is the precariousness of a particular community and culture in a city that has itself known a sudden transition from riches to ruin due to events as far away as the Far East and as close as an Englishman carrying off a package of propagating material. A package no larger, perhaps, than a few box cutters. The rubber trees of Manaus fell like towers.
Who would care, of course, about towers, cities or even families if all these weren't different crystallizations of hopes, achievements, affections and griefs? Mr. Hatoum lustrously evokes, in a mode as much of comedy as nostalgia, the life of his Lebanese riverside community. He evokes the smells, savors, noises and bustle of Manaus's old town and waterfront.
He gives us the stumbling, intensely human characters of Halim and Zana. The young peddler is too timid to court directly the beautiful daughter of the local cafe owner. A friend writes him a ghazal -- an Arabic love poem -- which he recites in the stunned silence of the cafe. Zana takes two weeks to consider his courtship, then accepts under stringent conditions. Her severity, along with her helpless pleasure in Halim's leonine lovemaking, mark their early marriage.
Later come her obsession with Omar and, in her last years, a burning hope for her sons to be reconciled. To burn is to burn out.
Dying, Zana lifted her head up and asked in Arabic, so that only her daughter and her friend, herself nearly a hundred, could understand: "Have my sons made their peace with each other yet?"
"No one answered. Then Zana's smooth, almost unfurrowed face vanished; she merely turned her face to one side, searching for the only tiny window in the gray wall, where a patch of evening sky was gradually going dark."

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Viennese Tales From the Berkshire Woods

BYLINE:  By HOLLAND COTTER 

 BODY:
VIENNA in the Berkshires in the summertime sounds like a publicist's dream. And in a sense the series of cultural events called the Vienna Project, under way this summer in western Massachusetts, is exactly that. Nearly a dozen local museums, theaters and musical institutions are offering 20th-century Viennese fare, which means Strauss lieder, paintings of alpine landscapes and a "Sound of Music" singalong.
 But historically, Vienna has meant many other things, too, and they aren't all pretty. It has meant Sigmund Freud and Gustav Mahler but also the young Adolf Hitler. It has meant a rich, imperial capital in decline; a city of abject poverty and radical social ideas; an ethnic melting pot that nurtured the seeds of Aryanism. In recent years, a vivacious contemporary-art scene has formed, but so has an atmosphere of right-wing xenophobia. In short, travel brochures may serve up Vienna mit schlag, but it is a confection that can leave a bitter aftertaste. 
 In the Vienna Project, four museums share the task of presenting art produced in the city throughout the 20th century and up to the present: the Sterling and Francine Clark Art Institute and the Williams College Museum of Art, both in Williamstown; the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art, or Mass MOCA, in nearby North Adams; the Berkshire Museum in Pittsfield; and the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge. Technically, all four can be visited in a day, but only if you're in hit-and-run mode. The Clark alone has several interrelated shows of circa-1900 Viennese work; they're small, but even small takes time. So, of course, does big, which is what you find at the cavernous but art-friendly Mass MOCA, where new conceptually based Viennese art requires sustained attention to make its effect. And then you have a drive: North Adams and Stockbridge are about an hour apart. So spreading a Viennese visit over two days might be an idea.
"Gustav Klimt Landscapes" at the Clark Art Institute is the summer's sure-fire Berkshire art draw, both because shows at this exquisite museum always are and because Klimt is a familiar name, known for his paintings of women swathed in gilded, pattern-flecked cloaks and gowns that virtually define the Jungendstil movement.
Born in Vienna in 1862, Klimt began his career as a muralist whose talent and ambition early on landed him juicy public commissions. His brilliant career-on-the-rise veered off the mainstream track, however, when his experiments with content and style drew the censure of the academic establishment. Always a self-confident leader, he responded by spearheading a separatist art movement.
Called the Secession, it held its own exhibitions and found a steady source of patronage in the city's wealthy bourgeois elite. In line with his outsider status, Klimt worked a bit at being a character. He took to dressing in blue, muumuu-like floor-length smocks inside and outside the studio, and had himself photographed in them, looking soulful.
I've always had trouble with Klimt's iconic figurative paintings. Their insistent visual flash looks as hard and sleek as the surface of a credit card; their sexiness seems lacquered over and their Byzantine theatricality slightly silly and already old-fashioned. (It's useful to remember that Cubism was being invented in Paris at the same time.) But the 15 landscapes in the Clark show, organized by Stephan Koja, a curator at the Galerie Belvedere in Vienna, are different.
They aren't particularly innovative paintings: they are basically a goulash of Impressionism, Symbolism and 19th-century Austrian realism. But they have an appealing elasticity and fleetness, and a sense of unmystical mystery. They share the sensuality of Klimt's pattern-wrapped figures, but add breath and a pulse.
Many of the landscapes were done during Klimt's annual summer stays in the Austrian and Italian countryside; he painted them for himself, not on commission. The earliest in the show are near-abstract expanses of flickering water and shadowed fairy tale forests. Then come paintings of thick, wall-like, flower-dotted foliage, images that have almost no foreground or sky: they feel as dense as a patch of peat moss cut straight from the earth. (Klimt, it seems, used a telescope to compose many of his landscapes, which helps to explain their sense of squashed space.)
Later come scribbly paintings of flowers and pointillistic depictions of lakeside towns. Despite their basis in naturalism, these images look as elaborately, self-consciously decorative as most Secession work. And just how decorative this can be is made clear in satellite exhibitions at the institute featuring two of Klimt's colleagues, the designer Josef Hoffmann and the architect Otto Wagner.
The Hoffmann show is made up of furniture and tableware that he -- or rather the Wiener Werkstatte, the artisanal association he helped found -- produced for the Wittgenstein family, high-powered Viennese industrialists. It's off-putting stuff. When a design is clean-lined, it seems to weigh a ton: a writing desk on view is as thick and blank as a safe. And when it's ornamental, as in the case of a solid silver vertical vitrine encrusted with enamel and moonstones, it is fantastically, grotesquely, unstoppably so.
The same applies to Otto Wagner's design for a hall of a new Academy of Fine Arts, seen at the Clark in an 1898 table model. Conceived to be sited on the edge of the Vienna Woods, where nature and culture met, it is a Neo-Classical nightmare of decorative excess or, if you prefer, a bold, proto-postmodern example of architectural pastiche. Anyway, it was never built.

Williams College Museum of Art
For every successful Klimt that Vienna turned out, it also produced hundreds of failures: -- artists who came, and saw, and didn't conquer the art world. One of them was Hitler, who at 18 arrived from Germany with stars in his eyes. He wanted to be a painter or architect or theater set designer, and above all, something great. And at first he adored the city: he attended the opera nonstop, joined the crowds to watch the elaborate public spectacles that surrounded the imperial family and diligently prepared for his entrance exams to the art academy.
He failed the exams; who knows how different 20th-century history might have been if he had passed. Broke, depressed and resentful, he was reduced to sleeping in shelters for the homeless and to selling drawings of landscapes and cityscapes to earn a little money. (One of his drawings is in the show; it's not bad.) Many of his friends at the time were Jewish, but his politics were growing increasingly reactionary. When he learned that his mother was dying, he returned to Germany, embittered by his Viennese experience and filled with a hatred for the city that never subsided.
The story of Hitler's sojourn there and how it affected his later life is considered in minute, fascinating detail by "Prelude to a Nightmare: Art, Politics and Hitler's Early Years in Vienna, 1906-1913" at the Williams College Museum of Art. Organized by Deborah Rothschild, curator of exhibitions, it uses films, photographs, books, drawings and a wealth of period ephemera to travel between two conjoined but very different cities. One was the glittering Vienna of imperial ritual and bourgeois wealth. The other was the impoverished, dirty, overcrowded Vienna whose citizens were growing more restive by the day in the years preceding World War I. Hitler had contact with both cities and learned from each.
From working-class Vienna he absorbed a strain of radical populism that he later twisted into a German nationalist political platform. From imperial Vienna, he picked up tips on how to produce effective political theater. In a 1907 Viennese photograph, for example, we see little girls with wreaths of flowers in their hair lined up to honor the Hapsburg emperor. Identical girls in the same bucolic attire appear in a German photograph, but now it is 1937, and they are giving the Nazi salute.
The exhibition, which was inspired by Brigitte Hamann's book "Hitler's Vienna: A Dictator's Apprenticeship" (Oxford University Press, 1999), requires patient reading -- there are many wall labels -- as well as looking, but it is worth the effort. It suggests that while Vienna certainly wasn't the birthplace of Nazism, as filtered through one man's eyes, it contributed to the movement's final shape. The city changed Hitler's life, and by default changed the lives of millions of other people, many of whom never set foot in its streets.

Mass MOCA
The Nazis' arrival in Vienna in the 1930's more or less put an end to innovation in the visual arts. Modern styles were banned as degenerate; private patronage, much of it Jewish, was eliminated. A once multicultural metropolis became a monocultural island.
In the 1970's, an internationally visible vanguard art known as Viennese Actionism briefly emerged with a brutalizing version of Conceptual and performance art. Then after the collapse of the Soviet empire in 1989, a new art scene began to coalesce, thanks in part to an influx of artists from Eastern Europe, whose presence helps to re-establish the multiethnic culture of old.
Some of these contemporary developments are surveyed in "Uncommon Denominator: New Art From Vienna" at Mass MOCA in North Adams. Organized by Laura Stewart Heon, a curator at the museum, the exhibition includes work by 15 artists who live in the city (but only half are Austrian by birth). 
The art shown is uneven -- little of the large-scale painting is of much interest --but a sense of exploration is palpable, as are links, affectionate or otherwise, to the past. The spirit of Klimt pops up repeatedly. He's there in the pattern-on-pattern self-portrait drawings of Adriana Czernin, a 33-year-old artist from Bulgaria, and in a video that shows her struggling to free her head from a suffocating flower-print scarf.
There are echoes of Klimtian landscapes in a wall drawing of woodland trees by Barbara Eichhorn, and in a film titled "Hole" by Hans Schabus, in which the artist is seen digging a ditch in a forest clearing. The setting, with its towering trees and filtered sunlight, is gorgeous. But the shoveler's ceaseless and apparently purposeless activity -- the video is a continuous loop, without beginning or resolution -- undercuts the ideal of repose in nature that seems to have inspired Klimt's summertime paintings.
In fact, culture, not nature, is the subject of much of the rest of the show. Mr. Schabus has a second, very funny video, in which he gives a horror-movie suspense to the story of an artist -- himself again -- working in his studio. Heimo Zobernig also pursues an art-about-art ad absurdum tack, in installations and videos that treat classical Modernism as a kind of do-it-yourself kit of formal effects. And as far as references to the original Secession's ornament fixation, Peter Kogler has the final word in a room-filling digital projection of constantly shifting and morphing linear grids.
Other contributions play down visual in favor of conceptual concerns. Vienna's historically diverse but economically inequitable social and cultural makeup is touched on both in paintings by Johanna Kandl and in an installation by Lois Weinberger titled "Portable Garden." Mr. Weinberger has grown weeds -- plants either ignored or actively eradicated -- in plastic shopping bags of a kind commonly used by poor European and African immigrants to hold their belongings.
By contrast, wealth is the subject of a set of outsize BMW promotional products created by Swetlana Heger and Plamen Dejanov, while conspicuous consumption finds an apt embodiment in Erwin Wurm's "Fat Car II," a normal automobile transformed into a bulging mass of dimpled and puckered pink flesh that gives the phrase "gas guzzler" fresh meaning.
Finally, many of the exhibition's themes come together in the work of Franz West, Vienna's most frequently exported contemporary artist. His deliberately tatty, handmade, handpainted, portable and usable furniture is a reminder both of the city's elite and illustrious design tradition and of its invisible populations who are forced to recycle their lives from the street.

Berkshire Museum
For a quick recap of early modern Viennese art at its best, you won't do better than the succinct exhibition titled "Secession Graphic Art Through World War I: Posters of the Vienna Secession," at the Berkshire Museum in Pittsfield. The dozen or so posters, on loan from the Historisches Museum der Stadt Wien, were made by artists to advertise the movement's exhibitions, and practically anybody who was anybody, Secession-wise, in the early days is represented here.
Klimt's poster for the first exhibition, in 1898, is here. It shows a nude Theseus slaying the Minotaur to rescue the noble youth of Athens, much as Klimt and his fellow refuseniks imagined themselves freeing Viennese art from the ogres of the academy. In this case, he paid a price: the poster was cited for indecency, and he had to scratch out the genitals of his mythical liberator.
Also in the show are a melancholic image by the death-haunted Swiss painter Ferdinand Hodler; a picture by Egon Schiele of artists working together around a table like disciples at the Last Supper; and a famous Alfred Roller poster in which the repeated "s" characters in Secession unfurl from the top to the bottom of the sheet with the grace of Islamic calligraphy. Roller was particularly renowned as a church muralist and opera designer. (He did the original sets for "Der Rosenkavalier.") The young Hitler worshiped him as a hero. 

Norman Rockwell Museum
In "Lisbeth Zwerger's Land of Oz," at the Norman Rockwell Museum in Stockbridge, you will find more contemporary Viennese art, but with scant immediate resemblance to that at Mass MOCA. Ms. Zwerger, who was born in Vienna in 1954 and works there, is a children's-book illustrator; the delicate watercolor paintings and pencil drawings on display were recently done for a new edition of L. Frank Baum's "Wonderful Wizard of Oz."
For years, the idea has circulated that Baum intended his book, first published in 1900, as a Populist allegory, with the Tin Woodman representing the American worker, the Scarecrow the American farmer, and the Wizard himself President Grover Cleveland, or maybe William McKinley. The show's organizer, Stephanie Plunkett, associate director for exhibitions and programs at the museum, has looked into the matter and found no evidence that Baum actually intended such a reading, giving us the option of enjoying Ms. Zwerger's designs without a political gloss.
Her take on the story is remarkably fresh, partly because she has never seen the Hollywood film. She turns an American adventure story of moral valor and folk wisdom into a delicate Neverland ballet. Each scene is as airy as a stage set, and although the characters are rendered with wit and charm, they have dark moods and cast long shadows. The effect, in short, is bittersweet, the characteristic Viennese blend.

Want to Waltz On By? Where the Shows Are

 CORRECTION:
An art review in Weekend yesterday about the Vienna Project, a series of joint cultural endeavors in western Massachusetts this summer, misspelled the middle name of the curator of the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art in North Adams. She is Laura Steward Heon, not Stewart.
An art review in Weekend last Friday about the Vienna Project, an arts festival in western Massachusetts, misstated Hitler's whereabouts immediately before and after he went to Vienna in 1907 at age 18 to seek a career in the arts. He came from and returned to Upper Austria, where he was born, not Germany; he moved to Munich in 1913.

HEADLINE: THE GRAND HOTELS; 
Not Your Usual Roadside Rest Stop

BYLINE:  By NANCY M. BETTER 

 BODY:
 Once the pride of a nation, the vast majority of great American lodges have been lost to fire, neglect or the ravages of time. The following resorts survive intact, and have been designated national historic landmarks. 

The Ahwahnee

LOCATION -- Yosemite National Park, Calif.

YEAR OPENED -- 1927

ROOMS -- 123

CONTACT -- (559) 252-4848; www.yosemitepark.com/html/accommodation.html.

STYLE -- Epitome of rustic luxury, with rough granite piers and concrete formed and stained to imitate wood. Extensive use of stained-glass windows and murals in Indian and Art Deco designs.

CLAIM TO FAME -- From 1943 through 1945, the Ahwahnee was used by the Navy for the war effort. It became the foremost rehabilitation hospital for the Seventh Fleet.

Grand Hotel

LOCATION -- Mackinac Island, Mich.

YEAR OPENED -- 1887

ROOMS -- 381

CONTACT -- (800) 334-7263; www.grandhotel.com.

STYLE -- Huge white clapboard structure on a bluff. No two rooms are decorated alike.

CLAIM TO FAME -- At 660 feet, the Grand Hotel's front porch is said to be the world's longest. No motorized vehicles are allowed on Mackinac Island; all transportation is provided by horse and carriage or bicycle.

El Tovar

LOCATION -- Grand Canyon National Park, Ariz.

YEAR OPENED -- 1905

ROOMS -- 127

CONTACT -- (888) 297-2757; www.grandcanyonlodges.com.

STYLE -- Unusual cross between Victorian and rustic styles.

CLAIM TO FAME -- Designed by a Santa Fe Railway architect, El Tovar was built right on the Grand Canyon rim. In 1902, the local newspaper wrote: "The building itself will be worth a trip to the canyon. It will be a combination of the architecture of the castles of the Rhine and that of the Swiss chateaux. . . . It will be in harmony with the wonderful scenery of the canyon rather than a blot on its beauty."

Mount Washington Hotel

LOCATION -- Bretton Woods, N.H.

YEAR OPENED -- 1902

ROOMS -- 225

CONTACT -- (800) 258-0330; www.mtwashington.com.

STYLE -- Sprawling wood-framed structure built in the Spanish Renaissance style, with two five-story octagonal towers.

CLAIM TO FAME -- Its isolation and scale made it the choice location of the 1944 Bretton Woods conference, an international gathering of economists and politicians that established the World Bank.

Paradise Inn

LOCATION -- Mount Rainier National Park, Wash.

YEAR OPENED -- 1917

ROOMS -- 118

CONTACT -- (360) 569-2275; www.guestservices.com/rainier.

STYLE -- Rustic Gothic design, largely the work of a German carpenter, Hans Fraehnke.

CLAIM TO FAME -- The Paradise Inn closes for the winter season, from October through May, because of heavy snowfall on Mount Rainier. Each spring, a crew of employees shovels the hotel out from hundreds of inches of snow to prepare it for summer tourists.

The Balsams

LOCATION -- Dixville Notch, N.H.

YEAR OPENED -- 1874

ROOMS -- 204

CONTACT -- (800) 225-0600; www.thebalsams.com.

STYLE -- Consists of the rambling white clapboard, green-shuttered Dixville House and the six-story stucco Hampshire House.

CLAIM TO FAME -- Every four years, residents of Dixville Notch gather in the Ballot Room at midnight to be the first Americans to cast their ballots in the presidential election. NANCY M. BETTER

HEADLINE: Philip Morris Profit Up 14%, Helped by Foreign Sales 

BYLINE:  By GREG WINTER 

 BODY:
Despite a constant erosion in the national demand for its cigarettes, the Philip Morris Companies said yesterday that its profits grew 14 percent in the second quarter, primarily because its prices continue to climb and the appetite for American cigarettes remains particularly strong overseas. 
 With the average price of premium-brand cigarettes like Marlboro now at $3.64 a pack, about 31 cents higher than they were at the beginning of last year, Philip Morris has been more than able to make up for the steady decline of smokers in the United States. 
 Even though the company sold 7.4 billion fewer cigarettes to wholesalers across the country over the last few months, a drop of nearly 14 percent from last year, its operating profit in the United States still rose to $1.45 billion in the quarter from $1.38 in the period a year earlier, in part because Philip Morris cut back on promotions and has raised cigarette prices by about 12 cents a pack so far this year.
"That's the beauty of pricing," said Bonnie Herzog, a tobacco analyst with Salomon Smith Barney. "You may lose some customers, but for the ones who continue to buy, your profits are very high." 
More important for Philip Morris, its international sales grew 3 percent during the quarter, totaling more than 185 billion cigarettes -- four times as many as the company sells in the United States.
That growth, occurring on virtually every continent but particularly pronounced in Asia and Eastern Europe, helped push Philip Morris's profits up to $2.6 billion for the quarter that ended in June, compared with the $2.28 billion it earned during the corresponding period last year. 
Per-share earnings also rose, to $1.21, from $1.03. Were it not for certain unusual expenses, like the cost of integrating its two food businesses, Nabisco and Kraft, the company said its earnings would have been $1.24 a share, about a penny more than what Wall Street expected.
Overshadowing the results was a subtle acknowledgment that the company's dominance in the United States has slipped, if only slightly, for two consecutive quarters. Since the start of the year, Philip Morris cigarettes have lost nearly 1 percent of market share in stores, to 50.2 percent, particularly as prices go up and smokers switch to generic, discount cigarettes that are often half the price of well-known brands. Besides Marlboro, other Philip Morris brands include Benson & Hedges, Parliament and Virginia Slims. 
To combat the slide and reach more overseas smokers, the company said it would spend an extra $350 million this year on promotions, a move that would bring its earnings down to "the lower end" of its 9 to 11 percent growth target. And while there is little chance that prices will come down, few analysts expect them to rise quite as fast as in the past. 
Since the 1998 tobacco settlement, cigarette prices have gone up by $1.46 a pack, according to Prudential Securities. On top of that, no less than 14 states, racing to plug the sudden holes in their budgets that appeared when the economy started slowing down, have raised cigarettes taxes to an average of 53 cents, up from 42 cents a pack in the last year. 
Yet because the increase has come in a series of small increments, usually no more than a few percentage points, smoking rates have hardly deviated from their historic rates of decline of roughly 1 percent a year.
"If people bought all their cigarettes for the year upfront and had to pay $5,000 at once, it would make a huge difference," said Robert T. Campagnino, a Prudential analyst.
Shares of Philip Morris fell $1.67 yesterday, to $42.45.

HEADLINE: How Pitt Could Make Fraud Less Tempting 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
WHEN Republicans are demanding the kind of prison terms for accounting shenanigans that used to be reserved for drug dealers, you know you're seeing what a British prime minister once called "the unacceptable face of capitalism."
 But the possibility of long prison terms won't end corporate fraud any more than it has halted the sale of heroin. There's more than enough money in drugs to entice dealers to take the chance. And nothing has been done to end the easy millions that bosses can get from even a temporary rise in a share price. 
 And that is where Harvey L. Pitt should come in. Until 1991, top executives cashing in stock options could not do so quickly. The Securities and Exchange Commission required them to wait six months between the time they bought stock, whether in the market or by exercising options, and the time they sold it. If they did not wait, trading profits had to be turned over to the company.
But the S.E.C. changed the rule so executives no longer had to take any risk when cashing in options. An S.E.C. official back then told me that "better economic analysis" had convinced the S.E.C. that "the opportunity to profit begins when the option is acquired," so that is when the holding period began. Within a few years options became the biggest part of the pay packages for many bosses. Among 50 big American companies last year, chief executives received options valued, on average, at $6 million each.
An interesting study by Jennifer N. Carpenter of New York University and Barbara Remmers of Virginia Tech shows that in the old days, bosses who had to hold on to shares for six months exercised options when the shares were likely to rise. Under the new rule, it appears that chief executives of smaller companies developed a tendency to take option profits shortly before their stocks declined. Did someone say "inside information"?
As Mr. Pitt ends his first year as S.E.C. chairman, he can point to an impressive record of enforcement actions, including two cases this week. One showed that PricewaterhouseCoopers had allowed two companies, Avon and Pinnacle Holdings, to inflate profits by wrongly accounting for consulting fees they had paid to -- you guessed it -- PricewaterhouseCoopers. Another showed that even after Enron collapsed, PNC Financial was using off-balance- sheet magic to mislead investors about its growing portfolio of bad loans.
But that record has not helped Mr. Pitt's public image very much. Repealing the misguided 1991 rule change might help him establish a reputation as a reformer. Now that we know that some executives fake profit numbers, requiring a holding period of at least six months makes more sense than ever. 
Another good move for the S.E.C. would be to force companies to disclose important information more often. More and more investors now understand that the failure to treat the value of options as an expense is deceptive. And they realize that optimistic assumptions on pensions have allowed companies to manufacture dubious profits. But disclosures on those issues are only in annual reports, and companies are not eager to change that. (I.B.M. ducked questions on both issues in its conference call this week.) Such numbers should be in every quarterly earnings report.
Similarly, debacles at Kmart and Enron have shown that it can be crucial to know whether a company could be forced to repay debt early if its bond rating was cut. Moody's reports that hundreds of companies with such triggers have not disclosed them to investors. The S.E.C. could order such disclosures immediately.
Mr. Pitt has had a rocky first year at the S.E.C. Making option-rich bosses take risks again, and giving investors better information, would get his second year off to a good start.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
S.&P. 500 Index Drops to Its Lowest Level Since 1997

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell yesterday, driving the Standard & Poor's to its lowest level since 1997, as companies including Automatic Data Processing, Eli Lilly and PNC Financial Services lowered profit forecasts and executives said there was little sign of a rebound in technology spending by businesses.
"The earnings picture is not strong enough to get stocks out of their funk," said James Awad, who invests $900 million as chairman of Awad Asset Management.
 The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slid 24.48 points, or 2.7 percent, to 881.56. Financial and health care stocks contributed about half the loss. The United States stock benchmark has not been that low since Oct. 27, 1997. 
 Declines in Coca-Cola and Philip Morris led the Dow Jones industrial average down 132.99 points, or 1.6 percent, to 8,409.49. The Nasdaq composite index dropped 40.30 points, or 2.9 percent, to 1,356.95.
The broadest measure of the United States stock market, the Wilshire 5000 total market index, has dropped 15 of the last 17 weeks. This month, 36 of the S.& P. 500's stocks have gained.
About two stocks fell for every one that rose on the Nasdaq and on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. About 1.7 billion shares traded on the Big Board, 20 percent above the three-month daily average.
Microsoft, which reported earnings after the close, led a decline in computer-related shares. Its shares fell 89 cents, to $51.11. 
Thomas M. Siebel, chief executive of Siebel Systems, said sales at his company, a maker of customer service software, would probably not improve for the rest of the year. Joseph M. Tucci, chief of EMC, a maker of computer data storage systems, echoed the Siebel forecast. Siebel dropped $2.12, to $9.62; EMC declined 23 cents, to $8.40.
Stocks extended their slide after the Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank said its general economic index expanded in July at the slowest pace in seven months, as weaker orders and shipments brought activity down from a four-year high.
Eli Lilly shed $2.36, to $48.54. The company, the maker of the antidepressant Prozac, cut its 2002 earnings targets, saying regulators' concerns about manufacturing problems may delay new products. Lilly reported that second-quarter earnings fell 20 percent as generic competition reduced Prozac sales.
Banks were the second-biggest decliners in the S.& P. 500 after PNC said profit might be hurt by a settlement with regulators over how the company accounted for units it created with American International Group.
PNC fell $6.91, to $39.69. American International, the largest insurer, dropped $3.67, to $57.23.
Automatic Data Processing fell $9.75, to $31.60, after the company, the largest payroll processor, said 2003 results would be hurt by slumping United States business spending.
Philip Morris fell $1.67, to $42.45. The company, the world's largest tobacco company, reported second-quarter profit that missed estimates and projected 2002 per-share earnings growth at the low end of the 9 percent to 11 percent range.
Coca-Cola dropped $2.07, to $47.93. After Coke reported earnings on Wednesday, investors questioned if too much of Coke's volume growth had come from lower-margin juice brands.
Bonds surged as investors ran from equities. By late in the day, the price of the 10-year note rose 19/32, to 102 1/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.61 percent from 4.68 percent on Wednesday. The 30-year bond climbed 22/32, to 99 18/32. Its yield dropped to 5.41 percent from 5.46 percent.

HEADLINE: When a Crop Becomes King 

BYLINE:  By Michael Pollan; Michael Pollan is the author, most recently, of "The Botany of Desire: A Plant's-Eye View of the World."

DATELINE: CORNWALL BRIDGE, Conn. 

 BODY:
Here in southern New England the corn is already waist high and growing so avidly you can almost hear the creak of stalk and leaf as the plants stretch toward the sun. The ears of sweet corn are just starting to show up on local farm stands, inaugurating one of the ceremonies of an American summer. These days the nation's nearly 80 million-acre field of corn rolls across the countryside like a second great lawn, but this wholesome, all-American image obscures a decidedly more dubious reality. 
 Like the tulip, the apple and the potato, zea mays (the botanical name for both sweet and feed corn) has evolved with humans over the past 10,000 years in the great dance of species we call domestication. The plant gratifies human needs, in exchange for which humans expand the plant's habitat, moving its genes all over the world and remaking the land (clearing trees, plowing the ground, protecting it from its enemies) so it might thrive. 
 Corn, by making itself tasty and nutritious, got itself noticed by Christopher Columbus, who helped expand its range from the New World to Europe and beyond. Today corn is the world's most widely planted cereal crop. But nowhere have humans done quite as much to advance the interests of this plant as in North America, where zea mays has insinuated itself into our landscape, our food system -- and our federal budget. 
One need look no further than the $190 billion farm bill President Bush signed last month to wonder whose interests are really being served here. Under the 10-year program, taxpayers will pay farmers $4 billion a year to grow ever more corn, this despite the fact that we struggle to get rid of the surplus the plant already produces. The average bushel of corn (56 pounds) sells for about $2 today; it costs farmers more than $3 to grow it. But rather than design a program that would encourage farmers to plant less corn -- which would have the benefit of lifting the price farmers receive for it -- Congress has decided instead to subsidize corn by the bushel, thereby insuring that zea mays dominion over its 125,000-square-mile American habitat will go unchallenged.
At first blush this subsidy might look like a handout for farmers, but really it's a form of welfare for the plant itself -- and for all those economic interests that profit from its overproduction: the processors, factory farms, and the soft drink and snack makers that rely on cheap corn. For zea mays has triumphed by making itself indispensable not to farmers (whom it is swiftly and surely bankrupting) but to the Archer Daniels Midlands, Tysons and Coca-Colas of the world. 
Our entire food supply has undergone a process of "cornification" in recent years, without our even noticing it. That's because, unlike in Mexico, where a corn-based diet has been the norm for centuries, in the United States most of the corn we consume is invisible, having been heavily processed or passed through food animals before it reaches us. Most of the animals we eat (chickens, pigs and cows) today subsist on a diet of corn, regardless of whether it is good for them. In the case of beef cattle, which evolved to eat grass, a corn diet wreaks havoc on their digestive system, making it necessary to feed them antibiotics to stave off illness and infection. Even farm-raised salmon are being bred to tolerate corn -- not a food their evolution has prepared them for. Why feed fish corn? Because it's the cheapest thing you can feed any animal, thanks to federal subsidies. But even with more than half of the 10 billion bushels of corn produced annually being fed to animals, there is plenty left over. So companies like A.D.M., Cargill and ConAgra have figured ingenious new ways to dispose of it, turning it into everything from ethanol to Vitamin C and biodegradable plastics.
By far the best strategy for keeping zea mays in business has been the development of high-fructose corn syrup, which has all but pushed sugar aside. Since the 1980's, most soft drink manufacturers have switched from sugar to corn sweeteners, as have most snack makers. Nearly 10 percent of the calories Americans consume now come from corn sweeteners; the figure is 20 percent for many children. Add to that all the corn-based animal protein (corn-fed beef, chicken and pork) and the corn qua corn (chips, muffins, sweet corn) and you have a plant that has become one of nature's greatest success stories, by turning us (along with several other equally unwitting species) into an expanding race of corn eaters.
So why begrudge corn its phenomenal success? Isn't this the way domestication is supposed to work? 
The problem in corn's case is that we're sacrificing the health of both our bodies and the environment by growing and eating so much of it. Though we're only beginning to understand what our cornified food system is doing to our health, there's cause for concern. It's probably no coincidence that the wholesale switch to corn sweeteners in the 1980's marks the beginning of the epidemic of obesity and Type 2 diabetes in this country. Sweetness became so cheap that soft drink makers, rather than lower their prices, super-sized their serving portions and marketing budgets. Thousands of new sweetened snack foods hit the market, and the amount of fructose in our diets soared. 
This would be bad enough for the American waistline, but there's also preliminary research suggesting that high-fructose corn syrup is metabolized differently than other sugars, making it potentially more harmful. A recent study at the University of Minnesota found that a diet high in fructose (as compared to glucose) elevates triglyceride levels in men shortly after eating, a phenomenon that has been linked to an increased risk of obesity and heart disease. Little is known about the health effects of eating animals that have themselves eaten so much corn, but in the case of cattle, researchers have found that corn-fed beef is higher in saturated fats than grass-fed beef.
We know a lot more about what 80 million acres of corn is doing to the health of our environment: serious and lasting damage. Modern corn hybrids are the greediest of plants, demanding more nitrogen fertilizer than any other crop. Corn requires more pesticide than any other food crop. Runoff from these chemicals finds its way into the groundwater and, in the Midwestern corn belt, into the Mississippi River, which carries it to the Gulf of Mexico, where it has already killed off marine life in a 12,000-square-mile area. 
To produce the chemicals we apply to our cornfields takes vast amounts of oil and natural gas. (Nitrogen fertilizer is made from natural gas, pesticides from oil.) America's corn crop might look like a sustainable, solar-powered system for producing food, but it is actually a huge, inefficient, polluting machine that guzzles fossil fuel -- a half a gallon of it for every bushel. 
So it seems corn has indeed become king. We have given it more of our land than any other plant, an area more than twice the size of New York State. To keep it well fed and safe from predators we douse it with chemicals that poison our water and deepen our dependence on foreign oil. And then in order to dispose of all the corn this cracked system has produced, we eat it as fast as we can in as many ways as we can -- turning the fat of the land into, well, fat. One has to wonder whether corn hasn't at last succeeded in domesticating us.

HEADLINE: TRACES OF TERROR: LEGAL STRATEGY; 
Rebuff for Shoe-Bomb Defendant

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BOSTON, July 18 

 BODY:
A federal judge denied a motion today to throw out statements made to investigators by Richard C. Reid, the man accused of trying to blow up a Paris-to-Miami flight with bombs hidden in his sneakers.
 Lawyers for Mr. 
Reid, 28, a British citizen, argued that he had invoked his right to remain silent after his arrest on Dec. 22. But Chief Judge William G. Young of Federal District Court found that Mr. Reid had been read his rights several times and still agreed to talk to investigators. 
 According to a memorandum prosecutors filed in court in May, Mr. Reid told law enforcement agents after his arrest that "he decided to choose an American target after the United States began bombing the Taliban in Afghanistan."
The memorandum said Mr. Reid "claimed to have chosen to attack an airplane because he believed an airplane attack, especially during the holiday season, would cause the American public to lose confidence in airline security and stop traveling, leading to a substantial loss of revenue which would, in turn, hurt the American economy."
Prosecutors say Mr. Reid, while aboard American Airlines Flight 63, tried to light a fuse sticking out of the tongue of one of his black high-top sneakers. Flight attendants and passengers overpowered Mr. Reid, and the flight was diverted to Boston. 
Mr. Reid has pleaded not guilty to attempted murder and attempted use of a weapon of mass destruction. His trial is scheduled for November.

HEADLINE: Albany No Longer a Secret In High-Tech Chip World 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA

DATELINE: ALBANY, July 18 

 BODY:
It sounded forced when, a few years ago, local officials took to calling the verdant Hudson River basin Tech Valley. More people scoffed at the nickname, and the strained boosterism it represented, than used it.
 No one was scoffing today, when a consortium of the world's biggest computer chip makers announced that they would plant their new, $400 million research and development center here, at the State University of New York. The consortium, International Sematech, and state officials predicted that the project would have something of the same effect here as its precursor did in Austin, Tex., drawing a range of computer-related businesses to the area. 
 To much of the rest of the world, the choice of New York, and particularly this somewhat sleepy city, came as a surprise. As Gov. George E. Pataki said, "There are a lot of places where jaws have been dropped."
Linley Gwennap, principal analyst at the Linley Group, which studies technology markets, said: "Albany certainly wouldn't have been on my list of places to go. I'm just not that familiar with what's going on there."
Albany reached the top of Sematech's list through years of commitment by New York State leaders to the highest-level chip research -- work that drew little attention outside that field -- and an aggressive selling job over the last 10 months by Governor Pataki and a handful of others.
It began last Sept. 10, when the Semiconductor Industry Association, which includes the Sematech consortium members, met at the Sagamore, a grand 19th-century resort on an island in Lake George. Mr. Pataki addressed the group and met the consortium leaders for the first time.
"I've seen the Silicon Valley," the governor said he told the chip executives. "It's hot, it's dry, it's very expensive, they have earthquakes, the lights go out. Come look at Albany."
At that point, the Sematech members had just begun talking about a new research center, more advanced than the one in Austin, to develop new methods of making faster, smaller, more capable chips. When officials here learned of that plan, Mr. Pataki and a few of his aides; Karen R. Hitchcock, president of SUNY Albany; and Alain E. Kaloyeros, dean of the university's School of Nanosciences, began lobbying hard to have the industry put that center here.
Today, industry officials said they were impressed by the involvement of Mr. Pataki and Dr. Kaloyeros in the months spent romancing the consortium. Juri Matisoo, a vice president of the Semiconductor Industry Association, referred to the governor's "clear vision and remarkable determination."
To outsiders, the most surprising element of the process may have been its secrecy, in contrast to the public competition among states that the consortium held in 1987. Until the news broke today, few people outside the consortium, SUNY or the governor's office knew Sematech was even considering sites for the new center, and no serious talks were held with other states. 
When asked about that secrecy, C. Robert Helms, president of Sematech, said, "It was clear who the winner was going to be in the first place."
That was, in part, because I.B.M., perhaps the most influential member of the consortium, is a New York company, based in Westchester County, and liked the idea of having the research center nearby. Mr. Helms said, "I wouldn't minimize the support we've received from I.B.M., just to help us understand what is here, what the advantages are to this region."
Industry executives said that in the end, it came down to Albany versus some foreign contenders, particularly a proposal from Belgium. They said the federal government, particularly the Department of Defense, voiced some concerns about putting such valuable technology overseas. Mr. Helms confirmed that, but insisted it did not influence the final decision.
Sematech officials said they saw a value in choosing an area that was not already a high-tech hub or a crowded metropolitan area. They liked the region's cluster of colleges and universities, and the fact that the cost of living and doing business is lower here than in established high-tech capitals.
But chip makers said the most important factor was the caliber of work already being done at SUNY Albany, and the enthusiastic backing it had had from the governor and the Legislature. The university created a center for advanced chip research in the mid-1990's, the state invested more than $100 million in it, and I.B.M. pledged $100 million more.
That center will essentially play host to the new Sematech plant, which will be housed in two adjoining buildings on university-owned land. The state will contribute $210 million to the project and the chip makers will put in $193 million.
In June, Mr. Helms led a delegation from the major chip makers on a tour of the Albany campus. "There were a lot of skeptics, but not by the end," he said.
And then, too, there was that talk of "Tech Valley," and the grain of truth behind it. I.B.M. is nearing completion of a $2.5 billion microchip plant in Dutchess County. General Electric recently decided to build a $100 million research center outside Schenectady. Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's industrial park in nearby Troy has drawn a number of computer-related businesses.
"I've gone to economics conferences around the country where people talk about the high-tech economy, and people there know that it's an up-and-coming area," said Dr. Ann E. Davis, director of the Bureau of Economic Research at Marist College in Poughkeepsie. "But the public hasn't really known. Not yet."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Business leaders applauding the announcement that a computer chip consortium will build a $400 million research center in Albany. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Daimler Profit Up 52%; Restrained Optimism for Rest of Year 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT, July 18 

 BODY:
DaimlerChrysler reported today that its second-quarter profit jumped 52 percent, buoyed by cost-cutting at Chrysler that is running ahead of the company's turnaround plan. 
 Thanks to improved results, Jurgen Schrempp, the chief executive, said Daimler expected its 2002 results to be at least triple the $1.3 billion profit it forecast at the start of the year. 
 But Mr. Schrempp said analysts should not expect Daimler simply to repeat its performance in the first half -- in which it had $3.7 billion in net income, in contrast to a $1.6 billion loss in the period a year earlier -- warning that the industry outlook is uncertain for the rest of the year. 
"The signal that we are receiving from our main markets do show a rather growing uncertainty as far as political and economic developments are concerned," he said, noting that the current period, the third quarter, is usually the weakest of the year for the industry.
For the second quarter, DaimlerChrysler, based in Stuttgart, Germany, posted net income of $1.1 billion, or $1.08 a share, compared with $720 million, or 72 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier. Revenue declined 5 percent, to $40.8 billion.
Mr. Schrempp declared himself "obviously very pleased" with progress made by the Chrysler unit, its largest operation based in Auburn Hills, Mich., which had an operating profit of $408 million, in contrast to a $179 million operating loss in the period a year earlier.
Mr. Schrempp attributed the gain largely to job reductions, cost savings on auto parts and manufacturing efficiencies, as well as to slightly stronger sales. Chrysler's share of the United States market has stabilized this year at 15 percent, and sales rose in the second quarter for minivans and the PT Cruiser.
Under a turnaround plan announced in January 2001, Chrysler pledged to cut costs by $8 billion through 2003. Last year, it saved $3.3 billion, $200 million more than its initial goal. This year, its savings goal is $2.6 billion. Company officials declined to say how much Chrysler has saved thus far in 2002 -- only that it is ahead of schedule.
DaimlerChrysler's chief financial officer, Manfred Gentz, acknowledged, however, that Chrysler's pension plan, which was fully financed at the beginning of the year, is now underfinanced by $3.5 billion to $4 billion, and that the gap could grow if investment markets continue to decline. If it remains underfinanced, the company will have to decide whether to inject cash or shift equity.
Mr. Gentz said the action would not affect the company's bottom line. "We remain comfortable with our pension status," he said. Concerns about General Motors' pension fund have hurt its stock price and overshadowed its earnings improvement this year.
Elsewhere, Mr. Schrempp said Mitsubishi Motors, in which Daimler holds a 37.3 percent stake, was also ahead of schedule on cost cuts, even though its sales had fallen in Japan this year. In March, a Daimler executive, Rolf Eckrodt, took charge at Mitsubishi, which has been stymied by debt and quality issues. 
Daimler's most profitable unit in the second quarter was its Mercedes-Benz and Smart car division, whose earnings rose 3 percent, to $833 million, although vehicle sales were flat. But Mr. Schrempp said he expected sales gains from a new version of the E-class sedan, which is to reach the United States this fall. It is already selling well in Europe.
Another car that may be headed for the United States is the smallest Mercedes auto, the A-class. Mr. Schrempp said Daimler was studying "whether it wouldn't make sense" to ship the A-class to America once a new version is ready in 2004. A decision will be made in the next 12 months, he added.
"There is some risk there," said Michael Luckey, president of the Luckey Consulting Group in Kinnelon, N.J. "But as long as the car is a good car, and the quality is good, and as long as it is viewed as premium, that's the key." Once the price gets down too low, he said, "it's a real stretch to call them luxury vehicles."
Mr. Schrempp indicated that the A-class cars would cost less in the United States than the least-expensive Mercedes, the CLK, which starts at around $25,000. The A-class had a rocky start in 1997, tipping over when Swedish journalists ran it through the "elk test," a course designed to see how cars maneuvered around unexpected obstacles, like an elk in the road. Daimler briefly took it off the market to install stability controls, and it has since sold well.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Two models from the small Mercedes A-class. DaimlerChrysler is studying whether to ship future A-class cars to the United States. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Microsoft Results Beat Expectations

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 

 BODY:
Buoyed by strong revenue across a range of its businesses, Microsoft reported fourth-quarter financial results today that slightly exceeded analysts' expectations.
 The company said that despite shrinking personal and corporate computing markets, it had continued to find strength in the sales of the new XP version of its Windows operating system, growth of its Office desktop software business and improved performance of a number of its consumer lines, including its MSN online service. 
 "We're finally really seeing the fruits of the long-term R.& D. investments Microsoft has been making in its Windows operating system," said John G. Connors, the chief financial officer. He also said that the company had paid greater attention than in the past to controlling its expenses. 
The largest disappointment for the company was sales of the Xbox gaming system, which the company said had sold 3.9 million units by the end of the quarter. Microsoft had originally projected sales as high as 6.5 million for the year, but the system has so far done poorly, particularly in Europe and Japan.
Shares fell as low as $50.07 after the report. They lost 89 cents, to close at $51.11 in regular trading.
Although the company continued to see no reason for optimism during the second half of 2002, Mr. Connors said that he still believed that "mid-single-digit" growth would be possible during the second half of its fiscal year.
The company called the past year "challenging" and Mr. Connors acknowledged that Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., had outperformed the computing world by growing while the rest of the industry shrank.
This evening the International Data Corporation released sales data for the personal computer industry indicating that for the second quarter of 2002, global PC shipments shrank by half a percent, to 31.1 million machines.
Financial analysts said that the company's impressive performance in view of the widespread difficulties of many of its hardware business partners highlighted the company's remarkable business position.
"This is testimony to how strong and unique their business model is," said David Readerman, a partner and director of growth equity strategy at Thomas Weisel Partners, the San Francisco-based investment firm.
Microsoft said it earned $1.53 billion, or 28 cents a share, in its fiscal fourth quarter ending on June 30, up from $65 million, and sales climbed 10 percent, to $7.25 billion.
Excluding the charge, Microsoft earned 43 cents a share. The earnings included an after-tax charge for investment impairments in telecommunications and cable industry investments of $806 million, or 15 cents a share. Analysts had been expecting Microsoft to report earnings of 42 cents a share, on sales of $7.1 billion, according to a consensus of 24 analysts polled by Thomson First Call.
For the year the company said its revenue was $28.37 billion, an increase of 12 percent over the $25.30 billion reported last year. Net income was $7.83 billion, or $1.41 a share, an amount that included after-tax charges for investment impairments of 53 cents, estimated expenses in connection with consumer class-action lawsuits recorded in the December 2001 quarter of 8 cents, and a one-time gain on the sale of Expedia, recorded in the March 2002 quarter, of 15 cents.
Despite forecasting personal computer growth in single digits for next year, Mr. Connors said that he expected Microsoft's revenue next year to grow by 11 to 13 percent.
For the fourth quarter, desktop software revenue grew 9 percent, to $4.97 billion, driven in particular by its desktop operating system, Windows XP, which posted growth of 20 percent in revenue during the same period.
In contrast, the enterprise software business was up only 4 percent, to $1.35 billion. 
During a conference call with analysts, Mr. Connors repeatedly stressed what he referred to as the "long-term view" of the company's two leading executives, Bill Gates, the chairman, and Steven A. Ballmer, the chief executive.
But he acknowledged that if the economy failed to rebound next year, Microsoft would be unlikely to continue to defy gravity.
"If there were a further contraction it would certainly hit us as well," he said.
