HEADLINE: Divided by a Call for a Common Language 

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN 

DATELINE: GREEN BAY, Wis., July 18 

 BODY:
One board member called the resolution the "least significant document" to cross his desk in a decade on the Brown County Board of Supervisors. Yet Nancy Nusbaum, the county executive, said it would most likely prompt her first veto in 15 years.
 The resolution, making English the official language of county government here, has no practical impact -- the county translates documents and provides interpreters only when required by federal law. But the symbolic effects have already torn through this fast-changing city in weeks of angry debate. 
 "Either you just don't get it, or you just don't care," Kevin Kuehn, a supervisor who opposed the resolution, told his colleagues before the bitterly divided board voted 17 to 8 on Wednesday night in favor of the resolution. "Is it that you don't understand? Is it that you have fear? Or is it a racist act? Because I don't understand what else it can be."
In passing the resolution, which also calls on the state and federal governments to pay for English classes for immigrants, Brown County joins at least 11 other Wisconsin counties, and 27 states, that have adopted English as their official language. Though the movement has gained strength in recent years as part of a backlash against growing numbers of immigrants, it has taken on particular force since Sept. 11, fueled by patriotic fervor and fears about an uncertain economy.
"English has been the most important unifier of our country for the last 200 years -- it's a symbol of being American, right up there with the flag, 'The Star Spangled Banner,' the Pledge of Allegiance," said Valerie Rheinstein, a spokeswoman for U.S. English, a Washington group that advocates such resolutions. 
"You're free to come here and you're free to make a life for yourself, but you're also free to leave," Ms. Rheinstein added. "You're coming here to be an American. Being an American means you're going to have to speak English."
Here in Green Bay, the battle over the English resolution has exposed the discomfort that quietly accompanied the shift from a largely homogenous town united in devotion to the Packers football team to a city where Hmong farmers pick cilantro and onions in community gardens and Mexican flags flap from cars on the Cinco de Mayo holiday. 
According to the 2000 census, 7 percent of Green Bay's 102,313 residents, and 4 percent of Brown County's 226,778, are foreign born, up from 2 percent of the city and 1 percent of the county in 1990. Two decades ago, Green Bay was 97 percent white; now it is 85 percent. The county is home to 5,000 Asians and 9,000 Hispanics.
Amid the apartment buildings along Imperial Lane, near the Packerland meat processing plant where some 70 percent of the workers are immigrants, a barrio has sprouted, with signs marking tenant parking in English and in Spanish. In the basement of the First Presbyterian Church, where Hmong girls learn traditional dances for New Year's, twin yellow posters in two languages announce free immunizations.
When Isaias Alvarez opened La Guadalupana, a Mexican grocery, three years ago, he had to drive to Chicago weekly to stock his shelves with flax seed, epazote and chile morita. Now, with about 10 bodegas in town, delivery trucks arrive every Thursday with those spices, along with Spanish-labeled products like Nestle's La Lechera, a form of sweetened condensed milk, and Knorr's Caldo de Tomate, tomato bouillon. 
Karl Txajkaug Thoj, director of the Hmong Association of Green Bay, sees the resolution as an unwelcome mat that says to his community, "You're not important, forget about your culture, forget about being different." After Mr. Thoj protested the measure at a public hearing, he received an anonymous letter. "Yes, you people are not welcome in Green Bay," it said. "Green Bay was nice until you freeloaders came. You multiplied like animals and want everything for nothing."
Noting that the 26 members of the county board are all white, a columnist in The Green Bay Press-Gazette likened the resolution to apartheid. Green Bay's mayor and the Chamber of Commerce have joined nuns and rabbis in opposing it.
In a series of contentious public hearings over the past two months, residents favoring the resolution expressed concern that the county would have to spend money translating documents and providing interpreters as the community continued to diversify. Invoking the Americanization of their European ancestors, they said the resolution would unite the community, not divide it. 
"If I cannot exchange ideas with you, we're already divided," Mary Verheyen told the board at a June meeting. "We need one thing to unite us. Let it be we can understand each other."
But the measure's opponents make the same point. May Xiong, whose family were the first Hmong to arrive in the area in 1976, and who now owns an Asian grocery where Hmong videos and shaman's incense sticks are for sale, recalled her years as a nurse treating bleeding American soldiers in the Vietnam War.
"They do not speak any Lao," she said. "What would happen to their legs, their arms, their eyes? They need a translator."
On Wednesday night, 31-year-old Sean Ryan, who owns a fast-food restaurant, stood in a corner of the crowded hearing room holding aloft three sarcastic signs. "Mi casa NO es su casa," one read. Another attributed a quotation, "More conformity is better for all of us," to Hitler and Brown County.
After several contentious meetings over two months, the supervisors changed the title of the resolution from "Resident Responsibility Act" to "Brown County Diversity Resolution," and tried to soften its language. Proponents said it was aimed at unity.
John VanderLeest, a supervisor who voted for the resolution, said he hoped it would push people to learn English more quickly, thus enabling them to find better jobs and become citizens. Pat Collins, who sponsored the initiative, said that "the vast majority of the middle of this county" supported it and that calls from constituents had been 9 to 1 in favor.
"When we pass it, the sun's going to rise in the morning, people will get on with their lives," Mr. Collins said. "This county will have made a statement. That's all it is."

May Xiong, who as a nurse in the Vietnam War treated American soldiers, none of whom spoke Lao, said: "What would happen to their legs, their arms, their eyes? They need a translator." (Photographs by Mike Roemer for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Sun Microsystems Has Profit But Expects Losses to Return 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, July 18 

 BODY:
Sun Microsystems Inc. reported today that it had achieved its first quarterly profit in a year. But the company forecast another loss as it fought for deals in the midst of the technology downturn.
 Sun, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif., and makes computers that manage networks, said it had missed profit-margin targets but beat Wall Street revenue expectations, in part because it had cut prices in the current tough environment. 
 "People think we're getting squeezed, yet we're gaining share," Scott G. McNealy, the chief executive of Sun, told investors in a conference call.
Sun shares dropped in after-hours trading to $4.90 on Instinet from a close of $5.80 on the Nasdaq, where they had gained 2.11 percent during the day.
Sun reported a profit of $20 million, or 1 cent a share, in contrast to a loss of $88 million, or 3 cents a share, in the fiscal fourth quarter a year ago, when the company posted its first loss in a decade.
Sun earned $28 million, or 1 cent a share, excluding an $18 million loss on equity investments, a $4 million credit for adjustments to restructuring charges, and a $6 million benefit for related tax effects.
Revenue was $3.4 billion, compared with $4 billion in the quarter a year ago.
Analysts polled by Multex had expected on average a profit of 1 cent a share on revenue of $3.3 billion, with a range of forecasts from a 1-cent loss to a 2-cent profit.
Sun has cut jobs and trimmed costs to lower its break-even point, but its gross profit margin fell from the previous quarter to 41.1 percent of sales in the fourth quarter, while the company had forecast a slight improvement on the previous quarter's 42.1 percent.
Sun's chief financial officer, Steve McGowan, said he expected a slight loss in the fiscal first quarter and a decline in revenue of 10 percent to 15 percent from the fourth, although he saw revenues rising 10 to 15 percent for the full year and earnings of 10 to 15 cents a share.
"The revenues look great, but margins are a lot worse than I would have guessed as well," said Daniel T. Niles, a Lehman Brothers analyst. "Guidance was disappointing."
Mr. McGowan, responding to analysts, said Sun had not cut prices at the end of the quarter to make up for a revenue shortfall.
"Our intention is to take market share," he said. He added, "The state of the economy is still unchanged and uncertain."
Shares of Sun have fallen more than 50 percent this year, compared with a nearly 30 percent fall for the American Stock Exchange computer hardware index. 
The company also announced that another senior executive -- Masood Jabbar, head of global sales operations -- was stepping down, after retirements by a number of his colleagues. Sun said Mr. Jabbar would be succeeded by the Europe, Middle East and Africa sales chief, Robert Youngjohns.

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS; 
Alarm Bells Louder Than Even Selig's

BYLINE:  By Richard Sandomir 

 BODY:
If only Major League Baseball could blame its financial woes on illegally inflating losses from the sale of corked bats, disguising billions of dollars in profits as clubhouse catering costs or burying revenues in off-balance-sheet limited partnerships called "Mo Vaughn's Diet" and "Goes Well to His Right."
 If those things were true, there would be indictments, Senate hearings and the deployment of Strat-O-Matic to bring Gerald Ford-like calm to the troubled industry. 
 But if there are no baseball Enrons and no illegal shredding of Yankees yearbooks by a rogue official scorer, the fault is a flawed economic model that is worse off than Commissioner Bud Selig is saying, said Sal Galatioto, managing director of the sports advisory and finance group at Lehman Brothers.
"I think he's understating the crisis," Galatioto said, referring to reports that two teams, Detroit and Tampa Bay, recently avoided missing paying their players. "He's in a tough spot. If he says that too many teams are in trouble, it hurts the teams' abilities to get financing." 
Galatioto is one of the leading investment bankers in sports; his group, first at SG Cowen and now at Lehman, has provided financing for some of the largest team and stadium deals of the past few years. 
He is an unabashed sports fan who happens to be a confidant of owners like Jerry Colangelo of the Arizona Diamondbacks and Daniel Snyder of the Washington Redskins. One of his cherished possessions, a Redskins helmet signed by the team, was lost when his former office at the World Financial Center was damaged during the Sept. 11 terror attacks.
He consorts more with owners than with players, but he sounds like someone sounding an alarm to warn anyone who wants to buy any team except for the wealthiest ones.
"I have no upside in saying the sky is falling," he said Wednesday.
When potential buyers approach Galatioto about buying a baseball team, he said he asks, "How much can you afford to lose?" He continued, "And I tell them if you can break even and take advantage of the tax-shelter aspect, you should be happy, because as a straight investment, you won't get a cash-on-cash return."
His view of baseball is bleak: teams with too much debt; a diminished capacity to borrow from banks that are uncertain about the future baseball economy; owners who are less wealthy and liquid than in the past; and possible bankruptcies and chaotic contraction.
"Two years ago, I said baseball had overexpanded and should contract, and they were very unhappy with me about that," he said. But in Congressional testimony last year, when Selig trumpeted a two-team contraction, "he referred to me as an interested outside observer."
"I went from being an idiot to an interested observer," he said.
He added: "I don't know why you need 30 teams. You can have a viable 24-team league and placate the players association by adding two roster spots." But he is realistic: a two-team contraction is more likely.
Listen to Galatioto and this is what you hear: The union will care about the financial crisis he is outlining only when teams file for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection or liquidate through Chapter 7 proceedings.
He sees a strike, and its aftermath, hurting teams at the gate and causing economic distress, especially to teams that have borrowed heavily for stadiums or for working capital. He sees those franchises, some of them in good baseball markets that deserve teams, folding under the weight of debt and lower revenues.
"If revenues decline because attendance is down or the media contract is down, no amount of revenue-sharing can fix it," he said.
In his scenario, there could be forced contraction, not one like Selig's unfulfilled plan to lop off Minnesota and Montreal. Major League Baseball now runs the Expos; Galatioto figures it can't prop up too many other sagging teams.
Galatioto said that in a bankruptcy, an owner can affirm or reject player contracts. If a contract is affirmed, the player is paid as an employee.
"But if you reject a contract, and the player has $50 million coming over 10 years, he'll get what he can get after the secured creditors are paid off," he said. 
In bankruptcy proceedings, banks and other secured creditors would be paid first, with players falling into the ranks of unsecured creditors, a less important category.
"If the players win, they lose," Galatioto said, "because some teams can't function under this economic model."
Galatioto doubts that a strike or a lockout will solve anything, and offers this prescription:
*Contract at least two teams.
*Increase revenue-sharing, but not to such a level that the redistribution hurts the value of the richest clubs. "If you dilute the value of the Yankees, Dodgers and Red Sox, you won't get any improvements by helping Milwaukee," he said. 
*Forget the salary cap and hope that a draft of contraction-freed players would stabilize salaries; that assumes, perhaps with too much hope, that the supply of better players would exceed the demand from two, four or six fewer teams.
*Set a minimum payroll that would force needier teams to spend most of the cash they get from revenue-sharing, rather than pocket it.
"It's not that complicated," he said. "I'm not the sharpest tool in the shed. If I were, I'd be doing exotic derivatives. All I can say is it's a basis for negotiations."

HEADLINE: Greeks Claim Victory Over Terrorist Group But Questions About Suspects' Ties Remain 

BYLINE:  By ANTHEE CARASSAVA 

DATELINE: ATHENS, July 18 

 BODY:
After decades of elusiveness, the guerrilla group November 17 has suddenly cracked.
 On Wednesday, five government agents surrounded a Paris-born intellectual on a remote island in the Aegean. Today the police identified the man, Alexandros Yiotopoulos, 58, as one of a handful of leaders of November 17, a small but persistent group that has killed at least 23 people in Athens in a sporadic anti-American, anti-imperialist campaign over nearly three decades. 
 Three other suspects, already in custody, were charged today with offenses that included first-degree murder, bomb attacks and bank robberies. The police say they have confessed and have described the crimes. 
"This has been a very good effort by Greek authorities," said the State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher. "We commend them." The group's latest victim was the British defense attache here, Brig. Stephen Saunders, who was shot and killed two summers ago. A spokesman for the British Embassy said today, "We are encouraged by the progress made." 
The breakthrough comes as Greece prepares to be the host of the 2004 Summer Olympics, an honor it nearly lost because November 17 members remained at large. The government had made no progress for years in its investigation, despite pressure from the United States, which even provided a list of suspects.
Greece's government is dominated by a Socialist party, Pasok, and some American experts contend that both the party and November 17 arose out of the same opposition to the military junta that ruled Greece from 1967 to 1974. The government has scoffed at that idea, but a string of retired American officials, including Thomas Niles, a former ambassador to Athens, have seen links between Greece's political elite and November 17. 
The group, which took its name from a bloody 1973 student uprising that helped bring down the junta, was understood to be small. Its top level consisted of perhaps three people, the police have said, and its small troop of foot soldiers numbered perhaps 10. At least seven people connected to the group are now in custody.
Starting in 1975, with the assassination of the Central Intelligence Agency's station chief in Athens, Richard Welch, the group managed to identify and kill American intelligence officers, Turkish diplomats, a British military officer and several Greek businessmen, offering justifications for those and other attacks in long, sometimes hardly intelligible proclamations. 
In one of its more recent tracts, found in a garbage bin shortly after after the June 2000 killing of Brigadier Saunders, the British officer, the group railed against NATO's bombing campaign to stop the Serbian assaults on Kosovo. "Even the greatest criminals of the 20th century, the Nazis, look like romantic humanists, compared to 78 days of bombing NATO and American force waged against a Yugoslavia without an air force," that tract read. 
The group often used one of two .45-caliber guns, both American-made, for its assassinations. 
After the military government fell, left-wing and anti-American sentiment was strong across the country. Yet some Greek officials have speculated that the organization's beginnings could lie within the country's secret service or police apparatus, a situation that would make its leftist statements a cover for an ultranationalist ideology. 
In a report two years ago, L. Paul Bremmer, a former diplomat appointed to lead a Congressional inquiry into world terrorism, suggested that the State Department impose sanctions against Greece for its failure to crush November 17. For many years the State Department has listed the group as a wanted terrorist organization. 
Many in Washington disagreed with the Bremmer recommendation, but he warned at the time, "The Greeks are but a bullet away from losing the Games, especially if it's aimed at another American."
Capt. William Nordeen of the Navy, the American Embassy's military attache, was killed in a car bombing in 1988. His widow, Patricia Nordeen, said that she was stunned by the news of Mr. Yiotopoulos's arrest and that she was preparing to fly to Athens. 
"It's almost beyond belief that after so many years, progress has finally been made," she said, by telephone from her home in Rhode Island. "I'm numb."
Greek news reports described Mr. Yiotopoulos as a former professor of mathematics. The police commissioner, Fotis Nassiakos, said Mr. Yiotopoulos was suspected of being "the ideological instructor of the group and the writer of its proclamations."
The group's hatred of the United States arose from American backing of the junta. During its rule, from 1967 to 1974, hundreds of leftists fled to France. Paris proved the breeding ground of the Greek resistance movement that helped topple the junta, in 1974. 
"Among the then-youth leaders, a Trotskyite by belief, was Yiotopoulos," said a source close to the police investigation. Lofty, lanky and code-named Lambros by his comrades, he ended up back in Greece operating under the alias Michalis Economou. He is believed to have written at least some of the proclamations the group issued. His wife, a French national, was being pursued by the police. 
The group began unraveling on June 29, when a 40-year-old icon painter, Savas Xiros, was injured in a botched bomb attack at the country's largest port, Piraeus, and was held by the police. He apparently began cooperating with them, and within a week, they had stormed two Athens apartment buildings used by the group and found a Smith & Wesson handgun that November 17 used in many of its attacks. 
They also found Mr. Yiotopoulos's fingerprints. 
Mr. Xiros remains in the hospital, where he was visited by two of his brothers. All three have now been arrested. They are the sons of a Greek Orthodox priest, and the police describe them as executioners for November 17. 
The three have confessed to "involvement or active participation" in a string of attacks claimed by November 17, Mr. Nassiakos, the police commissioner, said today. 
When armed agents today raided Mr. Yiotopoulos's flat on the high hills of the Athens suburb of Vyrona they found a typewriter, a computer and a box of financial records linked to his operations with November 17, a senior police official said.

GRAPHIC: Photos: The Greek police have arrested Christodoulos Xiros, left, and his brothers Savas and Vassilis. The three said they committed killings, often using the .45-caliber gun at right, as part of the group November 17. Alexandros Yiotopoulos, upper right, suspected of being one of the group's leaders, was also arrested. (Photographs by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Fare Drama Alters Cast, But the Plot Is Familiar 

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The mayor of New York City, desperately looking for ways to repair his broken budget, decides to give less help to subways and buses. Transit advocates fear a fare increase as a result. Both the mayor and the governor -- the man who ultimately decides whether to raise fares and knows the political risks -- decry the very idea of an increase.
 And what happens in the end? An increase, the largest in the transit system's history, plus the most extensive service cuts in a decade. 
 This was the situation in 1994 and 1995, the last time transit fares were raised, to $1.50 from $1.25. The mayor has changed since then. But the governor, George E. Pataki, is the same, and in many ways so is the stylized public dance that has begun this month, with Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg suggesting, as he did again yesterday, that he might try to save money by cutting the annual subsidy for mass transit. 
This time around, however, there are significant differences that many people say could mean not only that a fare increase is inevitable, but that it will inevitably be even steeper than the last one.
In 1994, for example, when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani announced that he planned to cut $100 million from the city's subsidy to mass transit, New York City Transit, the agency that runs subways and city buses, was running a rosy surplus, mostly the result of greater-than-expected increases in ridership.
Today, the transit agency's finances could hardly present a more stark contrast: the parent Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which also operates commuter trains and bridges and tunnels, has projected a deficit of more than $600 million for the next fiscal year.
Pieces of an array of taxes that go to support the operating budgets of the subways and buses have, along with the economy, grown smaller -- from January to May of this year, the taxes contributed $58 million to mass transit, compared with $115 million in the same period in 2001.
In addition, labor costs are certain to rise as contracts expire this year. And debt service -- paying the interest on billions in bonds that are used to buy new trains and to refurbish stations -- is growing rapidly, expected to eat up as much as 13 percent of the transit operating budget within two years.
Even taking into consideration that transit deficit projections are notoriously slippery -- as much about politics and strategy as about accounting -- the picture is not a healthy one.
The possibility that the city, and perhaps the state, might reduce aid to mass transit to help solve their budget problems has caused many transit advocates and city officials this week to start talking about the specter of an unusually large rise in the fare, perhaps to as much as $2, which could become reality in short order after the elections in November.
Such an increase, they argue, would essentially make transit riders, among them the poorest city residents, disproportionately responsible for footing the bill for many other things that the city must find money for. 
It also, they say, puts Mr. Bloomberg into a highly contradictory position: he campaigned on the importance of mass transit, has so far honored his pledge to take mass transit to work every day (usually the jampacked Lexington Avenue line) and has shown a willingness to try to push drivers out of their cars and into subways and buses.
But unlike Mr. Giuliani -- who at least publicly opposed a rise in the fare and denied that his reduction in subsidies had anything to do with it -- Mr. Bloomberg's message seems to be: An increase is inevitable, I won't pretend to stand in its way, and since an increase is coming, why not make it big enough to relieve the city of some of its burden in paying for subways and buses?
"I think this is unique in the annals of New York City politics," said Gene Russianoff, a staff lawyer with the Straphangers Campaign, who opposes a rise in the fare and complains that Mr. Bloomberg's unusual stance makes it much more likely by relieving some political pressure on Mr. Pataki. (Mr. Pataki, when asked yesterday about the possibility of an increase after the election, said, "I certainly hope not.")
Beverly Dolinsky, executive director of the M.T.A.'s Permanent Citizens Advisory Committee, said that while Mr. Bloomberg wants to be seen as a cheerleader for mass transit, "he's one who wants someone else to pay for it."
"I think it would be unrealistic to think that there's not going to be a fare increase," Ms. Dolinsky said, "but the city doesn't have to make it worse."
Ms. Dolinsky, along with members of the city's Independent Budget Office, analysts with the state comptroller's office and others who monitor the M.T.A.'s finances, says she believes that a fare increase of some kind has been inevitable for months, and that one was prevented this year only because Mr. Pataki decided to speed state subsidies to the transit agency to prevent an increase as he campaigned for re-election.
The M.T.A. itself, while repeatedly saying that there have been no discussions about an increase, talked about the possibility of one during a conference with institutional investors in April, saying that one way to close its projected budget gap was to "increase fares and tolls." The other possibilities, transit officials said, were to scale back or eliminate "new service improvements or expansions" or "certain customer amenities," although it is unclear in both cases what exactly this would mean.
The only other way to close the gap, the agency said, would be to "secure extra intergovernmental assistance," a remedy that now seems especially remote.
But transit advocates contend that it has been next to impossible over the last year to determine exactly how much financial trouble the agency is in, because it has not released detailed budget numbers.
The M.T.A. contends that it did not do so last year and will not this year "due to the extraordinary circumstances relating to the terrorist attack" on the World Trade Center. But some advocates maintain that the lack of hard numbers is purely a political strategy, a way for the agency to improve its bargaining position in upcoming labor negotiations and to justify a fare increase.
"We are talking about a fare hike in a vacuum, essentially," Mr. Russianoff complained.
As a result, he and other advocates say, there has been almost no informed debate on the possibility of an increase and what could be done to avoid it.
Preston Niblack, a deputy director of the Independent Budget Office, said he believed there were still ways to avoid an increase or to make it smaller, such as devoting larger portions of some taxes to mass transit and making an effort to reinstate the commuter tax, which the State Legislature abolished two years ago and which would now be worth about $500 million a year to the city. But those solutions also seem unlikely in an election year.
And so, as November approaches, the perennial ritual that always seems to precede a fare increase continues.
Asked yesterday about the possibility of an increase, Mr. Bloomberg said that he had no choice but to balance the city's budget, and so some things had to give.
"All I can tell you at this point is there's clearly a problem, and the law does not allow you to sweep a problem under the rug and hope it goes away," he said. "It's not going to go away."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 20, 2002

 CORRECTION:
A news analysis article yesterday about budget pressures that could lead to fare increases at the Metropolitan Transportation Authority misstated the view of analysts at the state comptroller's office. While they say a fare increase might be needed, they have not said an increase is inevitable.

HEADLINE: Still Poor, Latin Americans Protest Push for Open Markets 

BYLINE:  By JUAN FORERO

DATELINE: AREQUIPA, Peru, July 13 

 BODY:
The protest that shook this colonial city last month was very much like others in Latin America recently. There were Marxists shouting 60's-era slogans, and hard-bitten unionists. But there was also Fanny Puntaca, 64, a shopkeeper and grandmother of six.
 Though she had never before protested, Ms. Puntaca said, she could not bear to see a Belgian company buy what she called "our wealth" -- the region's two state-owned electrical generators. So armed with a metal pot to bang, she joined neighbors in a demonstration so unyielding that it forced President Alejandro Toledo to declare a state of emergency here, suspend the $167 million sale and eventually shake up his cabinet. 
 "I had to fight," Ms. Puntaca said proudly. "The government was going to sell our companies and enrich another country. This was my voice, my protest." 
Across Latin America, millions of others are also letting their voices be heard. A popular and political ground swell is building from the Andes to Argentina against the decade-old experiment with free-market capitalism. The reforms that have shrunk the state and opened markets to foreign competition, many believe, have enriched corrupt officials and faceless multinationals, and failed to better their lives.
Sometimes-violent protests in recent weeks have derailed the sale of state-owned companies worth hundreds of millions of dollars. The unrest has made potential investors jittery, and whipsawed governments already weakened by recession.
The backlash has given rise to leftist politicians who have combined pocketbook issues and economic nationalism to explosive effect. Today the market reforms ushered in by American-trained economists after the global collapse of Communism are facing their greatest challenge in the upheavals sweeping the region.
"The most worrying reading is that perhaps we have come to the end of an era," said Rafael de la Fuente, chief Latin American economist for BNP Paribas in New York. "That we are closing the door on what was an unsuccessful attempt at orthodox economic reforms at the end of the 90's."
For a time the policies worked, and many economists and politicians say they still do. The reforms increased competition and fueled growth. Stratospheric inflation rates fell back to earth. Bloated bureaucracies were replaced with efficient companies that created jobs.
The formula helped give Chile the most robust economy in Latin America. In Mexico exports quintupled in a dozen years. In Bolivia, poverty fell from 86 percent of the population in the 70's to 58.6 percent today.
Still, the broad prosperity that was promised remains a dream for many Latin Americans. Today those same reforms are equated with unemployment and layoffs from both public and private companies, as well as recessions that have hamstrung economies.
"We privatized and we do not have less poverty, less unemployment," said Juan Manuel Guillen, the mayor of Arequipa and a leader in the antiprivatization movement here. "On the contrary. We have more poverty and unemployment. We are not debating theoretically here. We are looking at reality."
Indeed, 44 percent of Latin Americans still live in poverty, and the number of unemployed workers has more than doubled in a decade. Tens of millions of others -- in some countries up to 70 percent of all workers -- toil in the region's vast informal economy, as street vendors, for instance, barely making ends meet. Economic growth has been essentially flat for the last five years. 
Popular perceptions -- revealed in street protests, opinion polls and ballot boxes -- are clearly shifting against the economic prescriptions for open markets, less government and tighter budgets that American officials and international financial institutions have preferred.
A regional survey supported by the Inter-American Development Bank found last year that 63 percent of respondents across 17 countries in the region said that privatization had not been beneficial.
"It's an emotional populist attitude people have," said Larry Birns, director of the Council on Hemispheric Affairs, a Washington-based policy analysis group. "It may not be reasoned, but it's real, and it's explosive and it's not going to be easily contained by coming up with arguments that free trade is the wave of the future."
In Brazil, South America's largest country and its economic engine, revulsion with American-led market orthodoxy has fueled strong support for the labor leader Luiz Inacio da Silva, known as Lula, who is now the front-runner in the October presidential election, to the chagrin of worried financial markets.
In Paraguay protests last month blocked the $400 million sale of the state phone company by President Luis Gonzalez Macchi, whose government has been dogged by a dismal economy and corruption charges. This week deadly demonstrations led the president to declare a state of emergency. 
In Bolivia the country's political landscape was redrawn this month when Evo Morales, an indigenous leader who promised to nationalize industries, finished second among 11 candidates for president.
This spring, the sale of 17 electricity distributors in Ecuador fell through in the face of political resistance, a blow to a country that has adopted the dollar as its currency and is heavily dependent on foreign investment. 
Meanwhile, in Venezuela, President Hugo Chavez's left-leaning government has been intent on scaling back reforms, exacerbating the divisions that led to his brief ouster in April.
The backlash in many of these countries gathered momentum with the economic meltdown in Argentina, which forced a change of presidents after widespread rioting in December.
While the causes are multifold, many Argentines blame the debacle on a combination of corrupt politicians and the government's adherence to economic prescriptions from abroad that have left the country with $141 billion in public debt, the banking system in ruins and one in five people unemployed.
Argentines now look for possible salvation from Elisa Carrio, a corruption fighter in Congress who has been scathing in her criticism of the International Monetary Fund. She is now the early favorite in the upcoming presidential election.
"This has created the backlash because now there's a debate all around Latin America," said Pedro Pablo Kuczynski, Peru's former economy minister and a favorite of Wall Street who resigned under pressure last week. "Everywhere you look, people say, 'The guys followed the model and they're in the soup. So obviously the model does not work.' "
The backlash comes as foreign direct investment in Latin America has fallen steeply, dropping from $105 billion in 1999 to $80 billion in 2001. A big reason for the decline is that many big-ticket sales of state companies to private investors have already been completed. But economists like Mr. Kuczynski, who say market reforms must continue for capital-poor Latin economies to progress, are worried.
Bolivia, for instance, was an early convert along with Chile in the 1990's to what is called the neoliberal model. It reined in loose monetary policies and shrank the government by unloading dozens of state-owned companies to private international investors. The results, particularly in taming inflation and reducing poverty, were impressive.
But in one of Latin America's poorest nations, it is hard for Bolivian officials to talk about progress to the wide portion of the population that continues to live in grinding poverty and feels that entitlements the government once provided in the form of subsidized rates for water and electricity have been stripped away.
The better services that have accompanied the sale of state enterprises have left many indifferent, particularly in impoverished areas where residents had invested their own money and sweat to string up electrical lines or put in water pipes and drainage.
"Clearly if you're poor and have no water, sewage and live in a rural area, having three long distance telephone companies when you have no phone lines doesn't make a bean of difference," Bolivia's president, Jorge Quiroga, acknowledged in an interview.
In Peru the resistance to privatization and market reforms is especially pronounced and, for its government, puzzling.
Unlike most of Latin America, the economy here has steadily grown since Mr. Toledo's election in June 2001 as the government has continued sales of assets begun during the decade-long rule of Alberto K. Fujimori.
Government officials say the program has been successful. Phone installation, which used to take years and cost $1,500 or more, now costs $50 and takes a day or two. Electrical service, once shoddy and limited, has spread across the country.
The privatization of mines, which is nearly complete, has improved efficiency and output so much that employment in that sector and related activities has increased to more than 60,000 today from 42,000 in 1993.
But government belt-tightening also led to widespread layoffs. Mr. Toledo's government has been hit hard by protests and popular discontent, much of it fueled by its inability to alleviate poverty. Many have blamed the privatizations, seeing them as a vestige of the corruption-riddled presidency of Mr. Fujimori, who is now in exile in Japan.
Here in Arequipa, where the economy was already limping, when word came that the government was about to sell the two state-owned electric companies, Egasa and Egesur, people recalled that Mr. Toledo had campaigned on a pledge never to sell the companies to private owners. 
It did not matter that the government promised Arequipa half the sale price, and that the investor, the Brussels-based Tractebel S.A., would invest tens of millions of dollars more to improve services.
The promises were not believed. Soon the workers federation, neighborhood organizations and university students organized protests, suspecting that higher electricity costs and layoffs were on the way.
"Thanks to our fight, our perseverance, the government backed down," Alejandro Pacheco, a leader in the protests here, told a roomful of supporters this week. "Now we need to do this in the rest of Peru."

HEADLINE: SHAKE-UP AT AOL: THE FORMER EXECUTIVE; 
The Fading Fortunes of AOL's 'Bob Pitchman'

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
On his ascent to the No. 3 position in the world's largest media company, Robert W. Pittman earned the nickname "Bob Pitchman," the best marketer of his time.
 But as Mr. Pittman resigned his post at AOL Time Warner yesterday under pressure from the company's board, it appeared that he had fallen victim to his own sales pitch. Once seen as a master manager who could serve as the bridge between the old media and the new, Mr. Pittman came to personify the failures of the AOL-Time Warner merger. 
 In part, that was because he was the executive charged with selling the notion of synergy as profit, both inside and outside the company. With his trademark blend of self-confidence and statistics, Mr. Pittman insisted to Wall Street, investors and employees that the company could meet revenue projections viewed as unrealistic by many analysts. Their skepticism turned out to be justified.
Some executives of the old Time Warner saw Mr. Pittman as brash and hubristic. His credibility as the manager most responsible for building America Online into a mainstream consumer brand was undermined as the online service -- promoted as the growth engine of the merger -- instead faltered and dragged the company's share price down.
Although Mr. Pittman began his career at Warner Amex Satellite and rejoined Time Warner in the early 1990's, he was largely seen in New York as an outsider trying to impose the cowboy culture of the Internet industry on a venerable media company, even as the dot-com economy was beginning to be seen as hollow and corrupt.
Even at AOL headquarters in Dulles, Va., where Mr. Pittman was long viewed as a hero, the stock ticker perpetually open on many computer screens served as a deeply demoralizing force in the face of what some saw as his political maneuvering to gain power in the company.
But whatever Mr. Pittman's personal or diplomatic flaws, friends and colleagues said yesterday that his downfall might have been his belief in his own message.
"Bob is a true believer," said Henry Silverman, the chief executive of Cendant, who hired Mr. Pittman to save Century 21 in 1995. "I think he really believed what he was saying. It just didn't turn out to be right."
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Pittman was careful to avoid saying directly that he had been made a scapegoat. Still, he noted that his job as chief operating officer was to carry out the strategy set by Stephen M. Case, the company's chairman, and Richard D. Parsons, its chief executive.
"The promises were not my job," Mr. Pittman said. "I was the operations guy. My job was once someone made the promise to make it happen." 
Mr. Pittman's inability to make it happen came from a combination of the difficult economic climate, a weak strategy and his own weaknesses as a manager, analysts said yesterday.
The son of a Methodist minister from Mississippi, Mr. Pittman built his career in start-ups and turnarounds, where a certain religious zeal came in handy. After helping to start MTV in the 1980's, he went on to bolster the flagging business of the Six Flags theme parks, and then to revive the real estate company Century 21. In 1996, Mr. Pittman joined America Online, where he oversaw its transition from an obscure technology company to an enormous online service that everyone's mom could understand.
The dense bureaucracy and scale of AOL Time Warner was a sharp contrast to the previous organizations he served, and some analysts said it simply might not have been the kind of environment where Mr. Pittman could thrive. 
Tom Wolzien, an analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein, remembered Mr. Pittman's appearance four years ago at the company's annual conference for pension and mutual fund managers at the Plaza Hotel as a revival meeting where many were for the first time converted to the idea that an online service could be attractive to a mass market. Last month, Mr. Pittman appeared again to sell the synergy message.
"It was not the old Bob selling AOL," Mr. Wolzien said. "He was playing the corporate thing as opposed to being the preacher. It didn't fit him as well."
That may be because the synergies envisioned in the merger -- like inducing AOL's 34 million members to buy more Time Warner movies, magazines and music, or to subscribe to Time Warner Cable's broadband Internet services -- have not materialized.
Last December, Mr. Pittman said he believed that the company could increase the amount the average household spends on the AOL service from $20 a month to $150 by offering "old media" products like magazine subscriptions and other information and services through its new-media outlets. Likewise, he said it might be possible to coax $200 a month out of each home that now subscribes to its cable service for $60 a month by selling other AOL Time Warner products. Nothing like that has happened either.
In April, Mr. Pittman was sent to revive America Online, which is suffering from an advertising slump and sluggish subscriber growth. Mr. Pittman promised analysts that he could recreate the service as a growth engine of the company by selling more advertising and other services, but that also proved more difficult than he realized, and he lost his chance to be seen as a savior.
"You have to go bang some heads together, and it appears that that urgency has not permeated the organization," said Adam Klein, lead partner of the media and entertainment practice at Booz Allen Hamilton. "Inasmuch as a strategy has been articulated and not implemented, that's the piece Pittman is carrying responsibility for here."
Still, Mr. Pittman was working in a uniquely hostile environment. "People had these stock options and they were planning their futures based on them, and they blame the AOL people," said David Geffen, co-founder of DreamWorks and a friend of Mr. Pittman. "Who are the AOL people? Steve Case does not have an operations job. The only person who had an operations job is Bob Pittman and he took the fall." 
Mr. Pittman, 48, who like many AOL executives grew wealthy by selling his stock over the years, said yesterday that he planned to take at least six months off to spend time with his family before contemplating a return to the business world.
As AOL Time Warner executives try to determine what caused the gap between promises and delivery in the coming months, however, Mr. Pittman may not be able to keep quite as low a profile as he might like. "It's going to get worse for Bob before it's going to get better," one industry executive predicted.

HEADLINE: New Aid Claims by Jobless Fall 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The number of Americans who filed for state unemployment benefits for the first time fell sharply last week to its lowest level in 17 months, the Labor Department reported yesterday, offering some hope for a largely stagnant job market.
 A separate report yesterday showed that a crucial gauge of economic activity remained unchanged in June, a further sign of an uneven recovery. 
 "The numbers reflect the slow nature of this recovery," said Mark Vitner, an economist at Wachovia Securities. "We may see a few more discouraging numbers in the next couple of weeks, but nothing suggesting that the recovery is faltering."
The Conference Board, a private research group based in New York, reported that its index of leading economic indicators held steady last month, at 112.4, after rising by a revised 0.6 percent in May. The June figure met analysts' expectations.
Consumer expectations and falling stock prices put pressure on the index, the Conference Board said. Another weak area was manufacturers' new orders for nonmilitary capital goods.
"We continue to be in a jobless, profitless recovery," said Ken Goldstein, the group's economist.
The index measures where the economy is headed in the next three to six months. It stood at 100 in 1996, its base year. June's figures are the third instance in the last four months of the index's failing to increase.
Initial jobless claims fell by 28,000 last week, to a seasonally adjusted 379,000, the Labor Department said. The decline, which was larger than many analysts expected, came after claims shot up by 21,000 the week before. The more stable four-week moving average of new claims edged down to 391,000 last week, the lowest level since the beginning of March.

HEADLINE: Downtown Visions: Remembrance and Resolve; 
Master Builders

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The horrors of Sept. 11 have given New York City an opportunity to offer a bold new vision of architecture and urban planning to the national and international communities. 
 To rebuild should mean to create the sort of breakthrough structures envisioned by architects like Frank Lloyd Wright, Louis Kahn, I. M. Pei and Frank Gehry. Instead, the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation has offered six variations of a mediocre office complex surrounding a lawn (front page, July 17). 
The World Trade Center was an architectural icon. Should its replacement be anything less?

DANIEL WEINER
Jersey City, July 17, 2002


LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Senators Question Credibility of Army Secretary on Enron 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 18 

 BODY:
Thomas E. White, the Army secretary and a former top executive for the Enron Corporation, told a Senate committee today that he was unaware of any efforts by Enron to manipulate energy prices in the California power crisis of 2000 and 2001.
 But in heated exchanges with Mr. White, Democrats on the panel said they doubted his credibility, and they called on the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission and the Securities and Exchange Commission to investigate his role in the energy crisis and his sale of millions of dollars in Enron stock last year. 
 "There is substantial evidence that Mr. White misled investors," said Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon. "What especially troubles me is that I don't see any evidence to date that these actions are being timely and thoroughly investigated by this administration's regulators." 
Mr. White, who was vice chairman of Enron Energy Services before becoming Army secretary, is the most senior member of the Bush administration to have worked for Enron, and his 11-year tenure at the company has come under intense scrutiny by Democrats. Today's appearance was Mr. White's first sworn testimony before Congress concerning the Enron scandal.
California energy regulators contend that Enron engaged in sham transactions in late 2000 that drove up electricity prices and deepened the energy crisis in the West. The regulators have said that Enron Energy Services was one of several Enron divisions that participated in the phony transactions.
For two hours today, five Democrats on the Senate Commerce, Science and Transportation Committee peppered Mr. White with questions about his knowledge of the California transactions. They also asked about numerous contacts -- 77 in all -- he had with former Enron colleagues after becoming Army secretary in May 2001, the accounting practices at his former company and his use of Army jets for personal trips.
Only two Republicans appeared at the hearing, and they offered Mr. White little support, an indication of the political power that the issue of corporate malfeasance holds just now. But Mr. White, his knees bouncing nervously under the committee's oak table, vigorously defended himself, saying he was "ashamed" about revelations of improprieties at Enron -- while also insisting that he played no part in any wrongdoing.
"While I was employed in the private sector, I carried out my responsibilities in an entirely ethical manner, just as I did over the 28 years that I served my country in the United States Army," Mr. White, a West Point graduate and retired brigadier general, said in his opening statement. 
At the heart of the Democrats' attack was what Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota, called "smoking gun" evidence of wrongdoing: Enron memorandums released by California regulators in May that outlined strategies to inflate prices artificially in California's deregulated energy market.
At least one of those documents mentioned Enron Energy Services, and Mr. Dorgan seized on that fact to allege a conspiracy to drive up prices in California involving Mr. White's former division and Enron's energy traders.
"The scheme of Fat Boy could not possibly work without E.E.S.," Mr. Dorgan said, using the code name for one of the strategies. 
When Mr. White denied having had any prior knowledge of Fat Boy or the other trading strategies, Mr. Dorgan fired back: "You're all kissing cousins here. You're under the same corporate umbrella."
Mr. White replied that Enron Energy Services maintained an "arm's length" relationship with the wholesale division, which he said developed Fat Boy and the other strategies. "When we had our profit and our numbers and our targets to make, and the wholesale group had separate targets to make, we were not kissing cousins," Mr. White said. 
The secretary also exchanged sharp words with Senator Barbara Boxer, Democrat of California, who raised questions about telephone calls Mr. White made to friends and former colleagues at Enron at the same time that he was selling $3 million in Enron stock last fall.
"Calling all those insider people, it just doesn't look right," Ms. Boxer said. "Just like it doesn't look right for Martha Stewart."
Mr. White said the calls were personal, and he objected to Ms. Boxer's suggestions that he was spending too much time making phone calls to friends while the country was at war. 
"I never said you didn't work hard to prosecute the war," she said.
Mr. White shot back, "Well, yes you did." 
After the hearing, Ms. Boxer sent a letter to Mr. White saying she found his answers "evasive, deceptive, argumentative, and not helpful in any way."
Senator Max Cleland, a Democrat from Georgia who was a decorated Army captain in Vietnam, chided Mr. White for earning more than $12 million on Enron stock sales last year when small-time investors and low-level employees were losing their savings. 
"In combat, officers eat last," Mr. Cleland said. "In the economic turmoil, the economic warfare that they faced, Enron officers ate first."
Mr. White said that he was required to sell his stock under government ethics rules and that he also suffered financially when the stock's price plummeted last fall. He said he returned options for 665,000 Enron shares in January after they had become worthless. 
"I am ashamed of what's happened to that corporation," Mr. White said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thomas E. White, the secretary of the Army and a former top Enron executive, appeared yesterday before a committee of largely hostile senators. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Economy May Be Stabilizing 

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez)

 BODY:
 New York City's economy is showing signs of stabilizing, if not recovering, according to economic data released yesterday by state and city agencies. The unemployment rate, which had risen sharply over the last year, was unchanged in June at 8 percent, the New York State Department of Labor said. 
And while the total number of jobs in the city dropped last month because of a decline in government employment, private companies added about 1,500 employees, according to William C. Thompson Jr., the city comptroller. Both reports are adjusted for seasonal variations in employment. The city and state budget gaps will continue to hurt the outlook for government jobs, Mr. Thompson said in a statement. "In the near future, to increase jobs we will have to rely on the private sector," he said. Leslie Eaton (NYT)

LENGTH: 2030 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film. Ratings and running times are in parentheses.

Now Playing

"THE BOURNE IDENTITY," starring Matt Damon and Franka Potente. Directed by Doug Liman (PG-13, 113 minutes). Mr. Damon plays Jason Bourne, a C.I.A. superassassin with amnesia who is chased across Europe in the company of a charming German waif (Ms. Potente) by his employers. There are espionage writers who use the genre to explore the complexities of geopolitics, but Robert Ludlum, on whose novel this competent, enjoyable picture is based, was not one of them. At a time when thrillers are shadowed by real-world anxieties, the implausibility and irrelevance of this movie, which amusingly imagines the C.I.A. as a supercompetent, virtually omniscient operation, comes as something of a relief. Mr. Damon handles his character's existential crisis with fierce adroitness, and Mr. Liman's direction has an old-fashioned swiftness and efficiency (A. O. Scott).

"THE CROCODILE HUNTER: COLLISION COURSE," starring Steve Irwin. Directed by John Stainton (PG, 90 minutes). In addition to the crocodiles that are his specialty, the irrepressible Mr. Irwin, an Australian naturalist whose hyperactivity has made him a star of American cable television, wrangles poisonous snakes and fanged spiders. His shenanigans, during which he addresses the audience in his trademark Down Under idioms ("crikey!," "have a go at that!"), are bundled into a ludicrous, amusing story of international intrigue involving a spy satellite, an ornery Queensland rancher and a pair of C.I.A. operatives whom Mr. Irwin treats as another peculiar species of wildlife. Though Mr. Irwin's antic good spirits can be annoying (one occasionally envies the reptiles' inability to hear), they can also be very funny. Whether you're laughing at him or with him, you will find yourself laughing a lot (Scott).

"LIKE MIKE," starring Bow Wow, Eugene Levy and Morris Chestnut. Directed by John Schultz (PG, 100 minutes). A 13-year-old orphan named Calvin (Bow Wow) turns around the fictional Los Angeles Knights pro basketball team, courtesy of a pair of magic sneakers that he finds. Calvin's new powers are observed when he wins a chance to shoot against a spoiled N.B.A. star during a half-time stunt. Naturally, he's asked to join the team. The successful kid rapper Bow Wow is a talented actor whose boyish eagerness here is a marked contrast to his taciturn rappadocio. The director's breezy steadiness keeps the movie from hitting us over the head -- well, not too hard, anyway, no small feat since the steroid-juiced sentimentality of the ending may force some to flee before the outtakes unspool under the credits (Elvis Mitchell).

* "LILO AND STITCH," with the voices of Chris Sanders, Daveigh Chase, Tia Carrere and Ving Rhames. Written and directed by Chris Sanders and Dean Deblois (PG, 89 minutes). In this charming exercise in intergalactic multiculturalism, Stitch, the snaggle-toothed, ill-behaved result of an alien genetic experiment, crashes to Earth, where he is adopted by a young Hawaiian girl named Lilo. The pair must contend with extraterrestrial law enforcement and a nosy earth-bound social worker, and their triumph over these adversities involves the usual Disney blend of comic anarchy, musical numbers (this time with an Elvis theme) and heart-tugging sentimentality. The movie's family relationships are addressed with low-key realism, and the animation has a lovely, gentle precision, with plenty of room for visual comedy but less of the noise and chaos that have become the hallmarks of 3-D animation. This movie suggests that the old-fashioned, flat, painted kind of animation still has much to offer (Scott).

* "LOVELY AND AMAZING," starring Catherine Keener, Brenda Blethyn, Dermot Mulroney and Emily Mortimer. Written and directed by Nicole Holofcener (R, 91 minutes). This smart, acidic comedy by the director of "Walking and Talking" could be described as a West Coast answer to "Sex and the City," minus that series' high-gloss glamour and erotic joie de vivre. Ms. Keener and Ms. Mortimer are sisters, both attractive and in their 30's, who have major self-esteem problems and poor taste in men. Ms. Blethyn is their vain mother who develops complications after liposuction. The movie zeroes in on contemporary narcissism with a relentless, needling accuracy that illustrates exactly the way some people allow their insecurities to poison their intimate relationships. But once it has limned its characters (Ms. Keener's is by far the most vivid), it doesn't go anywhere in particular (Stephen Holden).

"MEN IN BLACK II," starring Tommy Lee Jones, Will Smith, Lara Flynn Boyle, Rip Torn, Rosario Dawson and Tony Shalhoub. Directed by Barry Sonnenfeld (PG-13, 82 minutes). If your memory of the first one is a little hazy, don't worry: that was the point all along. And in any case this sequel provides the same pleasant, pointless mixture of whimsy and kineticism. Of course, like the "Ghostbusters" and "Austin Powers" sequels (to give only two out of several thousand possible examples), the fun has diminished because the novelty has worn off. Mr. Smith and Mr. Jones coast along, joined by Mr. Torn and Mr. Shalhoub (and a talking bulldog) from "Men in Black," and a host of creepy, scaly, funny aliens, including Ms. Boyle, her icy charms enhanced by hundreds of slimy tentacles and an extendable green tongue (Scott).

* "METROPOLIS," starring Rudolf Klein-Rogge, Gustav Frohlich and Brigitte Helm. Directed by Fritz Lang (not rated, 120 minutes). Lang's silent modernist fever dream -- a nightmarish grand opera of romantic love, alienated labor and technological power -- is one of the most studied and imitated films of all time, and has been reissued many times. Except for a brief theatrical run in 1927, though, the movie as Lang made it has never been seen. This latest version, the result of a four-year restoration project using archival materials and new digital techniques, may not be the director's cut, but it is as definitive a "Metropolis" as we are likely to see. The new 35-millimeter print is beautiful, the score has been newly recorded, and Lang's swirling, visionary stew of Christian symbolism, Expressionist set design and political anxiety is more grand and troubling than ever (Scott).

"MINORITY REPORT," starring Tom Cruise and Colin Farrell. Directed by Steven Spielberg (PG-13, 140 minutes). This atmospheric new thriller is a muscular and dense exercise of skill and verve. (Ironically, this exercise may be the most adult film that Mr. Spielberg has made in some time; it's about the bloody blurring of passion and violence -- a compassionate noir.) In 2054, a law enforcement unit called Pre-Crime exists to stop murders before they begin; three Pre-Cogs -- beings who float in a nutrient-rich fluid -- can predict when a crime will be committed and know the identity of the perpetrator. When the unit's chief, John Anderton, is accused of a crime he hasn't yet committed, he's soon on the run. Mr. Cruise does as much sprinting in this picture as he has in his entire filmography. The fluid bursts of quick-cut images seen on the monitors also show that Mr. Spielberg isn't about to be shown up by those quick-fingered, compulsively exhibitionistic upstarts like David Fincher. With "Minority Report" he toys with the idea that there's more -- and less -- to Mr. Cruise than meets the eye and says we shouldn't trust our eyes anyway. But doesn't he always? (Mitchell).

"MR. DEEDS," starring Adam Sandler and Winona Ryder. Directed by Steven Brill (PG-13, 91 minutes). It could be said that the remake of Frank Capra's "Mr. Deeds Goes to Town," starring Mr. Sandler in the title role, is redundant, since the actor has been remaking Capraesque movies for most of his career. As in Capra's original 1936 classic, Longfellow Deeds still lives in Mandrake Falls, is an aspiring greeting-card poet and has no patience for pretension. And once again, he is left a fortune by a distant relative: adjusted for inflation, the amount is $40 billion instead of $20 million. He's taken to New York, where he'll presumably be enticed by the city. But Mr. Sandler's Longfellow Deeds is too austere ever to be tempted by Manhattan's bright lights. Mr. Sandler's films are always about the arrogant getting a deserved comeuppance at the hands of humbler types, but this is the first time he seems a little smug himself. "Mr. Deeds" has him rehashing a role he has performed so many times before he could be doing this picture in his sleep. The result is likely to be that he'll put audiences to sleep, especially those he won over with "Happy Gilmore" and "The Wedding Singer" (Mitchell).

"PUMPKIN," starring Christina Ricci, Hank Harris and Brenda Blethyn. Directed by Adam Larson Broder and Tony R. Abrams (R, 116 minutes). In this uneasy mixture of satire and sentiment, Ms. Ricci plays Carolyn McDuffie, a Southern California sorority sister who risks everything -- the respect of her peers, her tennis-star boyfriend, her very sanity -- to pursue a love affair with a young retarded man named Pumpkin (Mr. Harris). The movie is sometimes sweet and often incisive in its mockery of social ambition and phony compassion, but the filmmakers have not figured out how to balance earnestness and mockery, and they end up sneering at the charming, naive love story they have, perhaps in spite of themselves, created (Scott).

* "ROAD TO PERDITION," starring Tom Hanks, Paul Newman and Jude Law. Directed by Sam Mendes (R, 119 minutes). This solemn, rain-washed period gangster film based on a graphic novel is a cool but stately work that achieves the grandeur of a classic Hollywood western. An exploration of father-son relationships viewed largely through the eyes of a 12-year-old boy, it follows the fugitive journey of Michael Sullivan (Mr. Hanks), a hit man for the mob outside Chicago, who flees the wrath of the middle-level boss (Mr. Newman) who is also his surrogate father. Filled with memorable tableaus, the movie is a serious picture show whose cinematography by Conrad L. Hall lends every frame an Edward Hopper-like mood. Mr. Newman (with an Irish brogue) steals the movie as Rooney, the mob boss faced with agonizing life-and-death choices. Mr. Hanks holds his own as the movie's enigmatic antihero on a vengeful mission: a killer-for-hire with a social conscience and a devotion to his young son (Holden).

"SCOOBY DOO," starring Freddie Prinze Jr. and Sarah Michelle Gellar. Directed by Raja Gosnell (PG, 105 minutes). The old Hanna-Barbera cartoon was cheap, silly and occasionally charming in its blithe stupidity. This adaptation, combining live action with 3-D computer-generated animation, looks pretty expensive, and its stupidity is, for the most part, charmless. The human cast -- Mr. Prinze, especially -- does a good-humored job of sending up and paying homage to the old show, but its efforts are overwhelmed by a relentless pop music score, hideous special effects and a plot that violates all the rules of the old series for no good reason (Scott).

* "SUNSHINE STATE," starring Edie Falco, Angela Bassett, Mary Alice, Mary Steenburgen and Timothy Hutton. Written and directed by John Sayles (PG-13; 141 minutes). Mr. Sayles's panoramic exploration of life in Delrona Beach, a fictional Florida coastal town in the throes of development, is as rich and even-handed a mosaic of American life as any filmmaker has brought to the screen. The overlapping stories revolve around two families, one white, the other black, who are being pressured to sell their property to greedy developers. Among more than a dozen characters who cross paths in the course of the story, the most compelling are Marly Temple (Ms. Falco), a sardonic young woman who runs her family's motel, and Desiree Perry (Ms. Bassett), a former teenage rebel who returns after a 25-year absence to confront her straitlaced mother (Ms. Alice). More than a probing civics lesson, the movie takes the political and spiritual pulse of our restless national psyche (Holden).

GRAPHIC: Photo: Tom Hanks is a gangster trying to protect his 12-year-old son in "Road to Perdition." (Francois Duhamel/DreamWorks Pictures)

HEADLINE: Better Development Through Democracy 

BYLINE:  By Jennifer L. Windsor; Jennifer L. Windsor is executive director of Freedom House, a nonprofit organization that monitors political and human rights around the world.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
African leaders meeting in Durban, South Africa, recently dissolved the moribund Organization of African Unity and replaced it with a new and purportedly more powerful body called the African Union. By pledging to conduct democratic elections and respect the rule of law -- and to intervene when member states violate human rights -- these leaders hope to attract more than $60 billion annually in new trade and investment from wealthy countries. Their efforts to link politics and economic growth, spearheaded by President Thabo Mbeki of South Africa, have received widespread praise.
 While hopes are high for the new organization, the promise of a regional union for better development through democracy could rapidly become a charade. For example, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi, Libya's sole ruler for more than 30 years, and President Daniel arap Moi, who has thwarted any democratic reform in Kenya for two decades, have joined the steering committee of the New Economic Partnership for Africa's Development, a program endorsed by the African Union that is supposed to reward democratic practice with increased aid and investment. Colonel Qaddafi's declaration in Durban -- "We accept help, but we refuse conditions" -- epitomized tensions between democratically accountable statesmen like Mr. Mbeki and the older autocratic rulers like Colonel Qaddafi, Mr. Moi and President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe. 
 While outside support can help, the African Union and the new economic partnership will only be realized in full when elected African leaders bring democracy to the forefront of their push for economic development.
How timely, then, that in recent speeches President Bush has articulated a new foreign assistance policy, one that is of historic significance. The new Millennium Challenge Account, created by the Bush administration, represents a $10 billion total increase in American aid by 2006. It aims to reward governments that "make the right choices for their own people." The choices Mr. Bush emphasizes include a respect for human rights and a commitment to root out corruption.
Through the Millennium Challenge Account, the president has elevated the connection between democracy and development. In the past, development experts have simply ignored the political environment in which assistance programs operate, believing they could help those in need in a purely technical way without immersing themselves in the messy business of politics. In more recent years, the need for good governance and citizen participation has gained credence even among supposedly nonpolitical multilateral institutions. But the word democracy has still largely been avoided.
Basing the allocation of foreign aid on the commitment of a government to rule democratically is perhaps the best way to avoid the problems that have plagued previous development efforts. If the president's experiment works, it could fundamentally change the way America spends the rest of its official foreign development aid, totaling some $10.9 billion in 2001 alone.
Administration officials are now working hard to develop criteria for selecting countries to receive challenge-account funds, and economists are busily trying to find links between specific governance measures and economic outcomes. Some want to weaken the democracy and human rights criteria to make them fit the best theoretical economic model. That would risk losing the core of President Bush's development ideal.
We should be making the principles governing the Millennium Challenge Account clear to the world. The United States will not support governments that refuse to listen to their own citizens or be held accountable to them. We will not subsidize regimes that violate universally accepted principles of political rights and civil liberties.
That means we should not compensate countries like Vietnam that pass legal reforms but fail to recognize the basic due-process rights of their own citizens. We should not reward countries like Uganda and Egypt that curtail freedom of association, including the right to form political parties and politically active civil society groups. And we certainly should not support countries like Zimbabwe and Pakistan that fail to hold elections that meet international standards.
No regime can have sustainable development -- even with sizable foreign assistance -- without being accountable to its people. If there is one lesson to be learned from earlier decades, it is that democracy matters.

HEADLINE: Mayor Warns of More Belt Tightening 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Just 18 days after his first budget took effect, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg called yesterday for city agencies to gird themselves for another round of cuts to make sure that the budget stays balanced and to save money to offset next year's deep deficit.
 Mayor Bloomberg said that the city would withhold 7.5 percent of the funds for every agency this year, for a savings of roughly a billion dollars, and that budget officials would begin negotiating specific cuts with each commissioner soon. 
 The mayor outlined the plan at the annual meeting of the New York State Financial Control Board, which was created during the fiscal crisis of the 1970's and which monitors the city's finances.
While specific service cuts will not be chosen until September, a series of contingency cuts that the Bloomberg administration considered earlier this year may offer clues as to the kinds of city services that could be affected. That plan called for fewer garbage collections, further cuts in the size of the police force, removing fire companies from some fire stations that house more than one, and closing a number of health clinics. 
"It will be painful," Mr. Bloomberg said. "And if the economy recovers, and tax revenues along with it, faster than what we're projecting, nobody will be happier to take that money and to spend it on providing things that the citizens of New York City need.
"But we want to start now, anticipating the deficit problem, and a solution to that in the future. Anything we can save in fiscal 2003 will help us with our problem in 2004."
The mayor made his call for further cuts during a week in which the city comptroller, William C. Thompson Jr., the state comptroller, H. Carl McCall, and the financial control board all issued reports warning that the city's current budget relies on more than a billion dollars in revenues and savings that may not materialize. They all warned that the city would face gaps of at least $3.7 billion next year.
By immediately announcing that he was calling for another round of budget cuts, the mayor preemptively addressed many of their concerns. He also sent a message to the credit ratings agencies, whose assessments of the city's bonds can save or cost millions.
But after a rare month of budget peace at City Hall, after the successful negotiation with the City Council that managed to avoid most painful cuts, the mayor appeared to be initiating a new round of wrangling over potential cuts. 
City Council officials played down the threat of further cuts, noting that past mayors have often called for potential cuts in the summer as a sort of exercise. David Weprin, the chairman of the Council's finance committee, said that just because the mayor was asking agencies to identify cuts did not mean they would be made.
"It's a responsible thing to do, to set a reserve fund," he said. "That doesn't mean that there are going to be any service cuts. It just means that we are preparing for the worst."
Mr. Bloomberg made it clear that while cuts of 7.5 percent were the target, he would be flexible as to how much each agency would be cut.
"I don't plan to hew to that 100 percent," he told the financial control board. "If the streets are in danger of becoming unsafe, we will spend the money, we will find the money to keep the streets safe."
The current budget already reduces the size of the police force to 39,110 positions from its recent peak strength of 40,710. A previous plan called for reducing it by a further 1,320 positions.
Mr. Bloomberg said he would make sure that cuts to education would not affect classrooms.
"I have made a commitment that we will not cut services in the classroom, moneys to instruction," he said. "We will not do that."
By effectively reopening the city's budget, the mayor injected a note of drama into the control board meeting. The meetings used to be of paramount importance to the city back when the board actually oversaw the city's finances, to help it out of the fiscal crisis. But now that the board merely monitors the finances, the meetings have become more of a formality. The board voted that since the city had ended the past year in balance and could still sell bonds, there was no need to take over the city's finances.
There was politics afoot as well, as is perhaps inevitable when one member of the board, Mr. McCall, is seeking the office held by another, Gov. George E. Pataki. Governor Pataki, who acted as a sort of M.C., twitted Mr. McCall for arriving late. And the City Council chose Randi Weingarten, the head of the teachers' union, as its representative at the meeting. She thanked the officials for giving raises to teachers. 
Speaking for the Council, Ms. Weingarten called for reinstating the commuter tax, which was long levied on people who work in the city but live elsewhere. Mayor Bloomberg did not call for the tax this year, maintaining that state officials, including Governor Pataki, would be unwilling to approve a tax increase while seeking re-election. 
Yesterday Mr. Bloomberg indicated that he would entertain the possibility of raising taxes next year.
"I think Ms. Weingarten, on behalf of Speaker Miller, is correct: You cannot just look at expense cuts," he said. 
"To put it in perspective, a 7.5 percent cut, thereabouts, would roughly reduce the deficit by a billion dollars," he continued. "The deficit is projected to be anywhere from four to six billion, depending on the economy. So this is a step going in the right direction, but if anybody thinks it is a total solution to the problem, they are unfortunately mistaken."
