HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
In CD Sales, Contrarian Runs Away From Pack

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
NO ONE who knows Michael Koch would be surprised that in the middle of a recording industry slump that shows no signs of easing, he has picked this moment to expand. 
 Sales of CD's are down 14 percent this year over last, itself a dreary period, and the future is clouded by disputes over which recording formats. But Mr. Koch, an Austrian-born music entrepreneur, says his company expects to outpace its 2001 sales of $117 million by as much as 20 percent. 
 Mr. Koch is merely doing what he always does: forging ahead in precisely the opposite direction as the rest of the pack.
He has built his 15-year-old company, Koch Entertainment in Port Washington, into the country's largest independent distributor of recorded music largely by rereleasing performances of classical, jazz and ethnic music that slipped out of the catalogs years ago. He remains an industry contrarian who does not flout the rules so much as ignore them.
"I think one reason we have succeeded is because we didn't realize how much we didn't know," he said. "We learned by doing. We made mistakes, and we learned important lessons."
Mr. Koch started out as the American sales representative for his father's CD-pressing company in Innsbruck. It took some effort, but record executives gave him a chance, and he made the most of his opportunities. "I polished lots of doorknobs, and learned I might hear 'yes' if I heard 'no' 15 times and didn't give up," he said. 
In 1999, he founded his own record label, also called Koch Entertainment, based in Manhattan, and started signing up artists like Carole King and Charlie Daniels whose glory days might be behind them but whose fans still buy their recordings, albeit in numbers too small to interest larger labels.
"The major labels get rid of artists who don't go gold or platinum," Mr. Koch said. "We can make money with an artist who sells 100,000 recordings, or even 50,000." 
Koch Entertainment also produces its own jazz, classical and country recordings. "We're still a small label, but I think we're getting known pretty fast, in part because we have the distribution already in place," said Bob Frank, the label's president. "The label already produces maybe 40 percent of the company's revenues."
Last month, Mr. Koch celebrated his company's 15th anniversary by making a few characteristically contrarian deals. The largest was the acquisition of a neighboring building in Harbor Industrial Park in Port Washington, which will provide 30 percent more warehouse space for his distribution subsidiary.
"Whatever is going to be the future of the CD as a music recording medium, we know it's going to be around for another five to 10 years at least," Mr. Koch said.
Those who know Mr. Koch often say his work ethic is his defining characteristic. In recent weeks, as many of his larger-living competitors slipped away on vacation, the soft-spoken but highly focused Mr. Koch stayed on the job and reached a series of distribution agreements to give his label more muscle in the urban music category. Johnny Wright, the manager of artists like Britney Spears and Sean Combs, will bring Triple Image, a pop trio aimed at young audiences, to Koch. Koch will distribute FUBU Records, the label formed last year by the urban-wear fashion entrepreneurs, and will reissue the Suave House Records catalog. 
Somewhat improbably, the rappers, hip-hoppers and rhythm-and-blues performers will be joining a distributor teeming with reissues of classical, jazz, ethnic, folk and spoken-word albums, many of them connoisseurs' choices pressed decades ago that met with critical acclaim but tepid sales. Through Koch, these performances have found a new generation of enthusiasts.
The reissued recordings represent 70 independent labels, including prestigious and decidedly noncommercial American labels like Smithsonian and Arhoolie and imports like Kyrichord Discs, Chandos and Melodiya. The operation has made the Port Washington warehouse a repository for performers as varied as Cajun accordionists, Celtic fiddlers and Peruvian pipers, music prized by collectors but unlikely to wrest shelf space from pop albums.
By massing the catalogs of dozens of small labels, Koch has achieved an economy of scale previously limited to the largest pop labels, making hundreds of obscure recordings profitable their second time around. 
In buying up rights, Mr. Koch specifies that his company be the sole distributor, in contrast to traditional arrangements. "If there was one thing we did that made us successful, it was probably insisting on exclusivity," he said. 
Michael Rosenberg, the president of the distribution subsidiary, predicted that record sales to adults would rebound, possibly soon. "People over 35 don't go into CD stores and browse very often," he said. "Older consumers will learn about a recording if it's mentioned in the news or if it's a soundtrack to a film they see. Otherwise, they feel they already own enough CD's. The key is to get them interested in a new recording and then reach them with other recordings that are similar in some ways but different in others."
Along with the old recordings, Koch also distributes hundreds of albums by contemporary performers, including those on a Buffalo label called Righteous Babes Records, founded by the singer and songwriter Ani DiFranco, called "the poster child for grass-roots indie success" by Billboard magazine.
Scot Fisher, Ms. DiFranco's manager, credited Koch with helping her recordings reach a wider audience. "It's important for Ani to have complete artistic control over her recordings, and we found out that isn't possible when you get distributed by the companies controlled by the major labels," he said. "You want a big distributor to go and kick the door in at Tower Records and get you in the bins, based on the muscle they have from their big-selling artists. But they want things their way in terms of the recordings."
"With Koch," he added, "Ani was able to keep artistic control over her CD's and at the same time get into the listening posts that Koch has set up at Tower Records. That was so important. Whatever Koch may lack in size, we saw them make up for it in hard work for their labels."
Koch has just 220 employees, and its current market share, just above 2 percent, is puny by the standards of the major record companies, but impressive for a business built on Elgar and Rossini, mariachi bands and readings by Gregory Corso, the Beat poet.
Holly Rosum, the director of membership services at the National Association of Recording Merchandisers in Marlton, N.J., said she found that Koch employees brought a combination of enthusiasm and expertise to their work that helped them compete against deep-pocketed competitors.
"They're passionate about their recordings and at the same time extremely knowledgeable," she said. "The people they deal with on all levels start feeling that way, too, about their products."
"These are thousands of marvelous recordings getting a second chance to be heard because of Koch," she added. "Without them, they'd be getting moldy in boxes in people's attics."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Michael Koch, left, the founder of Koch Entertainment, and Michael Rosenberg, the president of the company's distribution subsidiary, at its CD warehouse. (Phil Marino for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: First Take on New Taxes 

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN S. TOY 

DATELINE: HICKSVILLE 

 BODY:
DOMINICK DELIA gave the letter from Nassau County announcing the new assessed value of his house a quick read and then set it aside.
 "You have to be a lawyer to understand all this, and I'm not a lawyer," he said. The letter showed a lower assessment that would have meant a $198 reduction in his property taxes for this year. But with the wisdom of his 87 years, Mr. Delia said, "It looks like the taxes are down, but I'll believe it when I see it on the real bill." 
 This month, Mr. Delia and about 12,000 other homeowners in Hicksville became the first to receive notification of their new assessments. The county sent out about 143,000 letters in the last two weeks as part of Nassau's first countywide reassessment in 64 years. The remaining 273,000 notices will go out to property owners by Sept. 1. 
Interviews with about two dozen Hicksville homeowners found that many, like Mr. Delia, were a little befuddled by their assessment notices. But since the average assessment in Hicksville decreased by about 6 percent, many had received lower assessments and seemed content to leave well enough alone.
In fact, many believed the market value the county had assigned to their home might actually be a little on the low side, meaning their homes might be underassessed. But even if their letters showed a tax decrease, many were deeply skeptical, especially as next year's tax rates have not been calculated yet and their tax bills may still go up.
Take Matthew Fine, a Hicksville homeowner and hospital lab technician, who said his assessment notice showed a tax reduction. "But I don't believe it's going to happen," he said. "I mean, come on, taxes never go down."
There also was no shortage of homeowners who believed their homes might have been overassessed. In the four days after the Hicksville letters went out, 265 homeowners, most of them out to challenge their new assessments, had already made appointments to meet with officials from Cole-Layer-Trumble, the Ohio-based consultant the county hired to do the reassessment.
"I'm not surprised at all that some people obviously disagree with their new assessments," said Edward P. Mangano, the county legislator for Hicksville. "Errors were going to be inevitable in a process this monumental."
County officials said Hicksville was chosen as the first community to receive its new assessments because it is centrally located and it also fit the prediction that the revaluation would result in a third of assessments going up, a third going down and a third staying roughly the same. They hoped to learn from the response of Hicksville homeowners and use it to plan for the coming months as notices are sent out to the rest of the county.
The county usually handles about 50,000 residential assessment challenges a year, but Charles O'Shea, chairman of the county board of assessors, has already predicted a record number of challenges. The new assessments will be entered onto county tax rolls in January and will be used to calculate taxes starting in October 2003.
"Obviously people who get increases are not going to be happy and I expect challenges will be up," Mr. O'Shea said. "But these numbers will hold up to challenge."
He said that given the size and scope of the revaluation, "there are going to be some inaccuracies because we're only human." But, he added, "I think people will find in the end that this is not going to be as bad as they thought it would be."
County officials started the reassessment process two years ago in hopes of eliminating a widening disparity between tax bills and actual market values. The archaic system often benefited wealthy homeowners at the expense of lower-income homeowners and prompted charges of racism and thousands of lawsuits. Paying refunds to property owners who have successfully challenged their tax bills has cost the county about $100 million a year in the last decade and accounts for about $1 billion of the county's current debt, which is nearly $3 billion.
While most municipalities base their assessments on market value, Nassau used complicated formulas based not on market value but on construction costs of 1938 and land values of 1964. The method ignored long-term shifts in property values, leading residents of struggling communities where values have dropped over time to complain that they were being overtaxed while people in higher-priced areas paid similar or sometimes lower taxes.
The new system assesses properties at 1 percent of estimated market value, meaning a home assessed at $4,290 would sell for $429,000.
For people like Mr. Delia, whose assessment went down, the revaluation was welcome relief. Mr. Delia, a retired engineer for New York City's hospital system, said he long suspected his assessment was too high. But while the county assessed his home at $3,097, meaning an estimated market value of $309,700, he said he suspected he could get as much as $350,000 for his four-bedroom home. "I'm not going to tell them that, though," he said sheepishly.
Sean Acosta, president of Property Tax Reduction Consultants, an East Hills firm that works with about 10,000 Nassau County homeowners every year, said there would probably be thousands of homes assessed either too high or too low. Since only those whose properties are overassessed are likely to challenge their assessments and people like Mr. Delia can be expected to keep mum, equity even under the revaluation is relative, he said.
"You're never going to have 100 percent of the county fairly taxed because the market changes so quickly," he said. "But it's like income taxes. Is everything fair? No, but you have to settle on some kind of method to collect the taxes."
One source of confusion and skepticism among homeowners is that assessment changes do not necessarily translate into similar changes in tax bills. So just because average home assessments in Hicksville went down by 6 percent, estimated taxes did not go down by 6 percent.
That is because the consultant's estimates include recalculated tax rates designed to make sure localities continued to collect their full tax levy. If the overall assessed values within a school district went down, for example, the tax rate would be raised to keep the district's property tax revenues level. Nassau has nearly 400 different taxing jurisdictions, which together collect $3.5 billion in taxes annually.
The tax estimates also include calculations for tax exemptions like those for veterans, the elderly or the clergy. But the formulas are often complex, and homeowners looking for easy equations to check their tax figures will be out of luck.
Frank P. Cifarelli, for example, couldn't understand how the assessed value of his four-bedroom house could have been reduced from $5,000 to $3,000 and yet his projected taxes showed an increase of nearly $700. He said he suspected that his tax exemption under the state's School Tax Relief program might have been miscalculated, and an official told him on the phone that he might be right but that the exemption would have to be reviewed at a scheduled appointment with a consultant from Cole-Layer-Trumble.
Mr. Cifarelli, a retired county public works employee, said he also had questions about the $3,000 assessed value of his home, which means the county believes its market value to be $300,000. "That sounds high to me," he said. "It almost seems like they want to raise it to make you feel good, like your house is worth more and you can say, 'Hey, I got a $300,000 house here.' "
Ben Nadola, a spokesman for Cole, said the multistep reassessment process was thorough and ultimately "the marketplace dictates what the assessments are."
The first step involved the photographing of virtually all of the 416,000 properties in the county. The firm then reviewed property records for each structure at the county's Department of Assessment and compared the information with what they could see of a building from the curb.
Property owners then received a letter asking them to verify Cole's synopsis of the property. About 65,000 owners responded, resulting in revised records for 49,000 parcels, with changes like the addition or subtraction of a bathroom, garage or deck. Then for each home, the firm identified five comparables, similar homes in the same area that had been sold in the last three years, and calculated an average sale price to set the full market value, then divided by 100 to get the assessed value. Mr. Nadola said that the market value was a weighted average, meaning a comparable that more closely matched the subject home would be given more emphasis in the calculation, and that sales in which a buyer clearly seemed to have overpaid or underpaid were thrown out.
Mr. Cifarelli was told he would be given the addresses of the five homes used to figure out the market value of his home, and he said he was eager to see them. "I personally doubt that they could show me five houses that sold for that amount," he said.
Regardless of what the revaluation did for their property, most homeowners said they believed the reassessment was long overdue.
"I'm glad they finally changed the system," said Bob Findlay, a retired economist. "You couldn't explain it to anyone without getting laughed at."
In Mr. Findlay's notice, his three-bedroom home was assessed at $2,687, a figure he thinks is in the ballpark for homes that have sold recently in his neighborhood. Even though his taxes would have gone up by about $200 using the new assessed value, he said he would probably not challenge the assessment. "Taxes are reasonable here to begin with," he said, noting that Hicksville has a healthy commercial tax base, which helps keep residential taxes down.
Honey Skolnick, a 72-year-old grandmother who works part time at a local gift shop, was notified that the three-bedroom house she has lived in for 50 years had a market value of nearly $300,000. "That pleased me," she said. "Not bad from the $11,590 I paid for it." A tax reduction of more than $400 was also good news, and she said she did not even mind that she might have been overassessed for many years.
"It was time for a reassessment when you look at all the rich areas that paid nothing compared to the poor areas that were paying much more than their fair share," she said. "Some people will be hurt by it, but it was time for it all to be equal."

Dominick Delia's home, left, was also reassessed, with a tax reduction, but Mr. Delia says he'll believe it when he sees it. HEADLINE: Library Caught in Financing Feud 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM S. BEAVER 

 BODY:
HOME to international dance programs and the second-highest circulation of Westchester County's 38 libraries, the New Rochelle Public Library is a model of success.
 But instead of focusing on serving patrons and sponsoring events this summer, the library is struggling for survival after its $3.4 budget was defeated in two votes. 
 On July 9, the budget was defeated 3,948 to 3,770 as voters flocked to 12 polling places. In an earlier vote, held June 12 at only one polling place, the Huguenot Children's Library, the budget was defeated 2,208 to 1,518. 
Until recently, money for the library has come from the city's municipal budget. The total 2002 city budget is $76.6 million, of which $2.8 million is allocated for the library.
But New Rochelle learned this year that it was not in compliance with a state law passed in 1996 that requires school districts to submit their budgets to a public vote. The legislation also affected four Westchester public libraries that were chartered by local school districts. 
Ossining and Chappaqua have voted on library budgets for decades and Mamaroneck has done so since 1990. Not a single one of those budgets has been voted down. 
Maurice J. Freedman, director of the Westchester Library System and president of the American Library Association, said support for libraries in the county was very strong and the budget votes were usually a formality.
"Who really wants to say no to libraries?" Mr. Freedman said. "Most people would pay an extra penny of tax to give their librarian an appropriate salary."
In fact turnout was high in both library votes. By comparison, in a May vote on the school district budget, 2,650 of New Rochelle's 37,000 registered voters went to the polls.
But the issue in New Rochelle has moved beyond the issue of support for the library. 
"The Republicans are making this a political issue," said Arnold Klugman, chairman of the Democratic city committee. "We have tough economic times and they are using the library just to make matters difficult for the city's Democratic administration."
Republicans say the library's budget is inherently a political issue because the library's board of trustees, who are not elected, are creating a new tax.
"The city has been mismanaged for the last 10 years under the Idoni administration and Democrat-controlled council," said Douglas Colety, chairman of the Republican city committee. "They tried to use the library as a way to circumvent tax caps that protect the people and cover up their financial troubles."
Under the proposal put before voters, the library would be financed by a new tax, approximately $200 annually for a family of four, on residents' property tax bills.
The New Rochelle City Council had hoped to use the money previously set aside for the library to cover a projected deficit. Now it is scrambling to cut costs. On Tuesday night, the council voted to cut $1.39 million from the budget, eliminating 27 city jobs, street cleaning and closing one firehouse. 
The library board of trustees will meet Tuesday to explore options and has retained a lawyer, said Rob Seitz, a trustee.
The city will continue to provide the money to keep the library open through this year. 
If a budget approved by voters is not be in place by the end of the year, the alternatives include continued city funding, direct state aid, temporary closure and emergency intervention by the commissioner of education.
While the library's fate is uncertain, what's clear is that the issue has set off an intense political feud.
"It's going to be war until next November," said Mr. Colety.

GRAPHIC: Photo: New Rochelle Public Library, whose $3.4 million budget has been turned down twice by voters. (George M. Gutierrez for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: The View From/Fairfield; 
A Fitting Place for Artists to Take Up Residence

BYLINE:  By KENNETH BEST 

 BODY:
DURING its peak as one of Fairfield County's first-tier retailers, the D. M. Read Company was not only the department store of choice from 1926 to the mid-1970's, but it also served as a cultural center.
 In addition to presenting highly decorative window displays, Read also sponsored exhibitions by artists and craftsmen from the region and around the world. 
 Situated at the corner of Broad and John streets in downtown Bridgeport, the 100,000-square-foot store played host to afternoon book discussion groups led by such literary luminaries as Clifton Fadiman, a former book editor at The New Yorker magazine.
Now, after being abandoned since 1981, the old department store is coming full circle as clean up is under way to convert the building into an artists' colony by sometime in mid-2004. 
The renovation of Read is being directed by Artspace Projects Inc. of Minneapolis, a nonprofit agency that provides long-term living and working space for artists and their families at below-market rates.
"It's a really exciting project," said Thomas Nordyke, vice president of Artspace. "I think one of the things that has helped is that it is modeled around other projects in other cities.
"Every community we approach as a long-term commitment, not to do one project and go home. Hopefully that's the beginning of a long-term relationship with that community."
The $11.5 million project is the latest in a series of redevelopment efforts aimed at reviving activity in the Park City's downtown area (adjacent to Interstate 95) and a previously dormant waterfront.
During the last five years, the downtown area has been awakened by the relocation of Housatonic Community College from the city's East Side and the construction of the Ballpark at Harbor Yard, home to the Bridgeport Bluefish, a minor league baseball team, and the Bridgeport Barrage of Major League Lacrosse.
Last year there was the opening of the Arena at Harbor Yard, which in addition to bringing minor league hockey and Division I college basketball games to the city, also became the new site of the circus founded by the city's most famous citizen, P. T. Barnum. The circus returned to the city for the first time in nearly a half a century.
The Read building will be transformed into 63 one-, two- and three-bedroom apartments that combine studio and living space ranging from 1,100 square feet to 1,600 square feet. There will also be exhibition space on the first level of the building.
Sarah Constant, president of Mission First, a real-estate development group assisting Artspace, said the artists would pay from $260 to $820 a month for rent, in addition to having "tremendous benefits, such as well-designed space for their work needs, high ceilings and plenty of natural light."
One of the artists who hopes to live in the building is Jim Reed, a professional printer since 1970 who has lead a nomadic existence as an artist. Through the years he has had to move his 30 lithography stones, three presses and various other equipment several times as landlords have sold properties or evicted him. He creates his own work but is also a printmaker for other artists.
Mr. Reed lives in an apartment in Ansonia. His studio is at the Remington Arms building on the East Side in Bridgeport. He has previously lived and worked in Milford and South Norwalk and once worked in a storefront in Norwalk. "This eviction thing has taken a toll on me over last 20 years," Mr. Reed said. "It would be nice to know things are stabilized and not have to look over my shoulder from a landlord." 
The Bridgeport project came about after the city of Norwalk rejected the idea of converting an old lock factory into space for living and working for a group of artists.
C. William Kraus, an independant consultant, first contacted Artspace when he was trying to relocate the artists in Norwalk.
Mr. Kraus was referred to several economic development people in Bridgeport and eventually came in contact with the Bridgeport Economic Development Corporation, which obtained financing for the project after working with city officials and private groups.
William Finch, a state senator and the president of the Bridgeport Economic Development Corporation, said he was surprised by the response to a meeting in December 1999 to determine the interest in the Artspace project.
"We put a flyer out around town and 60 people showed up," he said. "We didn't realize how many people thought artist housing in downtown Bridgeport was an exciting idea. It got a lot of people's imagination."
Mr. Kraus said: "It was a very interesting and great response. It tells you a couple of things. It tells you there are a lot artists in the region and that people are willing to relocate to Bridgeport from a great distance. This kind of building in an urban setting can be an attraction for new urban pioneers. Not only is it great to have artists in the community but, from an economic point of view, they are a catalyst for attracting other businesses." 
Eileen Walsh, who began working in metal sculpture three years ago, said she would be looking forward to living and working in the same space. With a day job as a manager of recreation art therapy at a Stamford adult day-care center for people with Alzheimer's disease, she creates her artwork after hours.
Ms. Walsh, a native of Bridgeport who now lives in Stamford, used to visit the Read store regularly as a child with her grandmother. 
"You never can find space; you're always getting kicked out," said Ms. Walsh, who started doing sculpture art after taking a class at Bullard Havens Regional Vocational Technical School in Bridgeport. "I did work at Bullard Havens when I was signed up as a student but I had restricted hours. I do most of my work at night. I'm a night person. Having your own studio to work at your own creative time is important."
Giving new life to the building will also help efforts to restore the adjacent properties in the area, said Michael V. Rosso, a vice president of People's Bank, who is the chairman of the Bridgeport Economic Development Corporation.
A fire earlier this year damaged the adjacent Pollock Building, which housed a restaurant, a sandwich shop and is also part of the cluster of buildings that includes the historic Arcade Mall and Hotel.
"The concept is to create a nice corridor starting on Fairfield Avenue and running right down to State Street," Mr. Rosso said. "There are some beautiful historic buildings rehabbed with law offices, and the new federal courthouse."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Above, the old D. M. Read Department Store, which is being converted into living and working space for artists. Top right, C. William Kraus discussing plans for the project with Dave Biega, right, a contractor. Left, a worker at the site. (Photographs by Thomas McDonald for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Fairfield House Prices Jump, but Rentals Mark Time

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES 

 BODY:
WITH interest rates lingering at attractively low levels and little land available for new development, the demand for Fairfield County houses continues to be strong, except for homes at the extreme high end of the price scale.
 A similar fever is evident in the market for condominium apartments. This is in sharp contrast with the rental market, where some complexes are offering concessions to individual tenants and leasing blocks of apartments to corporations as inexpensive substitutes for hotel rooms. 
 Nationwide, exceptionally strong demand for houses seems to be confined mainly to the New York metropolitan area, Washington and San Francisco, according to John Tuccillo, an economist and real estate analyst in Arlington, Va. These areas, he said, "are in a bubble, in danger of a repetition of the 80's, yet there is no bubble nationally." He expects little change in the next 15 to 24 months. 
In the meantime, brokers in the county are riding high. Paul Breunich, managing partner at William Pitt Real Estate in Stamford, is exuberant. "Our first six months are off the charts," he said. "We are up 30 percent in closings and up to 12 percent in prices."
But other executives take a bit more cautious view. "Prices reached a point where the consumer got smart," said Mary Ann Evick, president of Raveis Homelink Real Estate. "Some inventory seems to be sitting. What sold in a day is now taking three weeks." 
The median price of homes listed for sale in Greenwich is currently $2 million, according to figures compiled by Raveis, and in Stamford, $670,000. But the prices of actual sales in January to June of this year were $1.39 million and $501,000, respectively, up 24.1 percent and 16.6 percent from a year earlier. 
Even in Greenwich, though, not everything is lofting toward the stratosphere. Victor Borge's house overlooking Greenwich Harbor has been on the market for a year and two months, said Gideon Fountain, a broker at the Cleveland Duble & Arnold Corporation. "It started at $30 million, came down to $18 million, then $16 million. The only soft spot is the very high end. Everything else is selling fast."
Overpricing has caused some houses to linger on the market, said Elayne Jassey, sales executive at Prudential Connecticut Realty in Stamford. "Buyers are willing to pay -- they know its a seller's market -- but they're not willing to be gouged," she said.
There has been a trend in Fairfield of trading up within the same town, as home buyers and their agents make private contacts through cocktail party chatter.
Vincent DiMasi, for instance, paid $350,000 three years ago for a two-bedroom cottage on an acre in Westport. "He put very little money into it," said his broker, Addie Conti of Raveis Real Estate. "We sold it last month for $860,000 and sold him another house in Westport for $805,000."
"The stock market has declined," said Mr. DiMasi, whose business is insurance and finance. "So I thought spending a bit more on real estate would yield potential profits. Before we can put the new house on the market, it needs about $120,000 worth of landscaping and interior work." The four-bedroom 2,800-square-foot house was built in 1942 by an architect with a taste for the unique, he said. "It will go back on the market for $1.43 million in about a year, and I'll probably buy another house in Westport." The cottage he sold will be knocked down by its new owner, who will build a new house for around $3 million, Ms. Conti said.
The condominium market in the county also seems energized. Many units are being snapped up by downsizing empty-nesters who want a local pied-a-terre for the months they do not spend at a vacation home elsewhere. Condos are also sought by young couples, young families and singles who are not ready for a house but prefer to build equity in a condominium rather than in the troubled stock market. 
This renewed popularity has pushed condo prices up in tandem with single family homes. Raveis's figure for the median sale price in Stamford in January through June was $215,000, up from $190,000 last year. In Norwalk the median was $226,000, up from $174,000 last year.
The robust demand for condominiums has produced a major change in plans for a large mixed-use development on the Stamford waterfront. Admiral's Wharf, a $250 million complex proposed by Collins Enterprises Inc., was to include 620 rental apartments in four buildings, but the company recently applied to city boards for a switch to condominiums.
"We will have 580 condos," said Arthur Collins Sr., the company's chief executive. "The market is much stronger for condos than rentals, although some of the affordables may wind up as rentals." The reduced number of units reflects the fact that condominium apartments tend to be larger than rental apartments, he said. Final approvals are expected in August with construction to start in the fall. "There's so much rental supply, it could take years before it's absorbed," Mr. Collins said.
Richard Redniss, a principal at Redniss & Mead, development consultants, has participated in the development of some 1,200 apartments in Stamford in the past few years. "This is not overbuilding," he said. "This is a correction. We have had a lot of demand for rental housing, and developers and investors have been trying to beat that demand and make money. We are beginning to catch up, but it takes time, especially when we have vacant commercial space and fewer jobs pushing the demand down."
The weakness of the rental market is not limited to apartments; a similar slump is recorded in the market for summer vacation properties. "For the first time in memory," said Eugene Kelly, head of Kelly Associates in Darien, "summer rentals are not renting. Year after year we'd rent the same houses for the same people who go to Nantucket and Martha's Vineyard and Fisher's Island. They've gone, but they won't be picking up that income."
The combination of high prices for homes and a glut of rentals has some people holding off on buying houses, according to Garth Schwamm, a rental broker at Prudential in Stamford. "They feel rentals are so good they are comfortable renting for a year or two, thinking maybe the housing bubble will burst." He noted that the Classic and the Windermere, large apartment buildings that usually rent in-house now welcome real estate agents.
A BANQUET of concessions is being offered at a number of apartment complexes. At Newbury Commons on Washington Boulevard in Stamford, the first month's rent is free and rents have been reduced for one-bedroom apartments from $2,200 to $1,995; two-bedrooms from $2,500 to $2,200 and three-bedrooms from $4,500 to $3,500. Included in the rent are a health club with trainers, indoor parking, an indoor-outdoor pool, 24-hour concierge service, a convenience store that delivers cooked meals, an A.T.M., a business center and dry cleaning and laundry service. 
The inducements being offered by AvalonBay Communities, which has a nationwide presence and deep pockets, are a bit narrower. According to Mark Forlenza, regional vice president of development, "rents that vary widely in the five Stamford complexes have been reduced 4 percent and any additional concessions have been targeted to only 50 apartments out of over 1,800." 
Empty apartments are frequently turned into corporate accommodations, many of them negotiated by Oakwood Corporate Housing, headquartered in Los Angeles. "We have 50 units at Avalon Grove," said Susan DeSimone, the district manager in Stamford. "We usually take a block of apartments, furnish them, supply linens, dishes, electronic and kitchen appliances. It's a turn-key situation." Leases are by the month at $135 to $155 a day, depending on the number of bedrooms. "We deal with Fortune 1,000 companies like Cendant, Purdue Pharma, Kraft, UBS, Xerox and G.E.," she said. "Right now we have no vacancies." 
Robin Stein, Stamford's longtime land-use planner, remarked: "We knew sooner or later that the rental market will have to adjust, that supply was increased dramatically in the last couple of years."
He predicts that the sales market will also eventually experience changes. "When interest rates start creeping up," he said, "the high-priced houses will again be worth less than their mortgages."

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
A Question Of Accounting Has No Easy Answer

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
WASHINGTON and Wall Street are buzzing with speculation that companies may soon be required to treat stock options as expenses. The options are worth something, because they give employees a chance to buy company stock at a discount in the future. Calling them expenses, of course, would take a bite out of reported earnings. Yet much of the debate has lacked careful consideration of the question that matters most: How would the decision affect the economy as a whole?
 Economists' knee-jerk answer is "not at all." Companies have been offering options as compensation for years. One has only to read and understand the footnotes in reports by publicly traded companies to the Securities and Exchange Commission to learn how many options were granted in a year. Simply calling the options expenses changes the accountant's bottom line, economists say, but it doesn't change the economic bottom line. There is no free lunch; investors should know that the company will bear the cost of the options either way. 
 Unfortunately, it's not quite that simple. Even though the information is readily available, not everyone puts in the time and effort to read all the footnotes.
Robert Willens, a managing director specializing in taxes and accounting at Lehman Brothers, was surprised at how few of the specifics his clients knew. "They weren't quite as familiar with the procedures and the amounts as I thought they might have been," he said. "I'm finding that they weren't familiar with the footnote or they weren't aware of the information."
To the extent that investors are surprised by the amount of options that companies grant, those companies would indeed suffer reversals. The investors would lower their expectations for earnings, and share prices could take a one-time hit. That could limit companies' ability to grow by acquisition.
That said, the hit might not be very big. Mr. Willens does not expect companies to dole out fewer options, he said, because they would still cost slightly less than grants of stock. "Even expensing, you still get something of a break compared with other forms of compensation," he said.
Without a change in compensation, employees still have an incentive to work hard, leaving a company's prospects intact. There would be no reason for share prices to fall. Investors would then see price-to-earnings ratios rise, but with no cause for concern.
This still sounds fairly rosy, but there's one more fly in the ointment. Figuring out how much those options are worth is downright difficult, and it could open the door to more problems.
Mark Rubinstein, a finance professor at the University of California at Berkeley, explained it this way: To figure the value of an option when it's granted, you have to estimate the company's future ability to generate dividends and the volatility of its share price. These tasks are manageable for the kind of short-lived options that trade like wildfire in over-the-counter derivatives markets, but they're not at all easy for the sort of long-term options companies use to pay their employees.
"The percentage error that you make in dividends isn't too important for a short-lived option, but for a long-lived option it affects the value much more," Professor Rubinstein said.
In the case of volatility, he added, "if you go out longer, of course it gets harder to estimate." The combination of these problems means that two people, using the same formula for an option's value but with varying assumptions, would reach different estimates.
THAT kind of uncertainty could make investors less willing to invest, which could ultimately reduce the amount of capital available to a company. Companies in need of capital to grow might shy away from options and remove performance incentives from pay packages. Workers might put in less effort, reducing productivity and slowing the rate of economic growth.
One way to encourage a company to get the options valuation right, Professor Rubinstein said, is to bind it to its mistakes. A company would have to declare as an expense its estimate of an option's value on the date an employee could exercise it and buy the stock. If the guess proved too low, the company would have to book extra expenses to make up the difference. 
This solution could lead to some pretty complicated accounting. Any alternative, though, could be better than the present situation. As Robert H. Herz, the new chairman of the Financial Accounting Standards Board, put it, "When you have accounting that masks reality, you're going to get all sorts of strange things happening."

GRAPHIC: Chart shows estimated value of options awarded by Standard & Poor's 500 companies, measured in billions, from 1998 to 2001. (Source: Bear Stearns)

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Is the P/E Ratio Becoming Irrelevant?

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN 

 BODY:
IN the stock listings in many newspapers, only one calculated statistic appears next to the trading activity for every issue: the price-to-earnings ratio. But lately, an avalanche of earnings restatements has made the denominator of the ratio, earnings, a flimsy indicator of real money-making at a growing number of the country's biggest businesses -- tarnishing the ratio, too.
 Little wonder that some mutual fund managers are thinking twice about using P/E ratios even as a first cut for picking stocks. But what should they -- and individual investors -- use instead? 
 There are no easy answers. "The valuation process is an art as much as it's a science," said Thomas J. Dillman, co-chief of global research at Deutsche Asset Management. He and his colleagues have spent more time lately questioning the assumptions of their formulas. 
"There's a lot more conversation about how you really got to the numbers that you're using to determine whether a stock is overvalued or undervalued," he said.
The P/E ratio, typically calculated using the latest 12 months' earnings but often using year-ahead projections, was once the undisputed champion of stock eyeballing. As Robert J. Shiller, the contrarian Yale economist, wrote in 1996, "The simplest and most widely used ratio used to predict the market is the price-earnings ratio."
Many stock pickers used it as late as the mid-1990's as the first measure of a share's prospects. High P/E ratio? That meant either a growth stock, worth the risk for participation in a bright future -- or maybe one that was just overvalued. Low P/E ratio? That meant a value stock -- possibly good for steady dividend income.
In the Internet boom, that logic went out the window. Companies' prospects were measured in page views, clicks and how fast the businesses were burning capital. After the start-ups unwound in 2000 and 2001, investors may have thought it safe to trust the ratio again. No such luck. Those reported earnings could vanish with the wave of an accounting whistle-blower's hand.
SOME stock pickers still stand by the P/E ratio as a useful tool. "The first issue from my perspective is generally valuation, and the major valuation measure from my perspective is price-to-earnings ratios," said Douglas D. Ramos, a senior equity portfolio manager at Dreyfus.
But even Mr. Ramos does not always use P/E ratios. Companies with few or no earnings are not rejected out of hand but are subjected to other metrics.
There are alternatives. "We're using cash flow available for dividend payments," said Marilyn G. Fedak, the chief investment officer for American value stocks at Sanford C. Bernstein. She said her company had never used P/E ratios. Looking at cash flow, she said, "helps you get behind all the accounting issues that can cloud how much you understand, as an outside investor, of what a company is really doing."
Mr. Dillman's company prefers to gauge stocks' prospects with a statistic called cash flow return on investment, a measure that compares a company's cash receipts to its cost of capital and the return on competing investments. But can ordinary investors make sense of such a mouthful? "Some of the caveats and assumptions that underlie all of these things are pretty arcane," he allowed. "If we started to put cash flow return on investment numbers instead of P/E's, no one would know what they meant. I can't think of anything that would be necessarily better in terms of what belongs in the newspaper."
Accounting shenanigans can render substitutes for P/E ratios based on cash flow just as useless, analysts warn. "The problem with cash flow," said Burton G. Malkiel, a professor of financial economics at Princeton, is that it "is subject to exactly the same kinds of problems that the 'E' is subject to." 
Analysts often use earnings measured before a company pays taxes and interest on debt, or deducts depreciation and amortization, as a proxy for cash flow. But this measure, called Ebitda, also ran into problems recently, said Mr. Ramos at Dreyfus. "WorldCom has sort of showed you that you can't necessarily trust cash flow either, as defined by Ebitda," he said.
Even an apparently transparent measure of a company's potential, like the price-to-sales ratio, can be misleading, according to Professor Malkiel.
"Think of the telephone companies that would swap their fiber optic networks," he said. "They've got all this excess fiber optic capacity in the ground. At an inflated price, I sell you some fiber optic capacity; you sell me some fiber optic capacity. They tell you there's a business purpose for this, but then the sales are overstated."
A certain amount of analysis of a company's books will always be based on trust, Ms. Fedak at Sanford C. Bernstein observed. "Unless you're going to sit there and you're going to count -- looking through all the invoices and receipts -- you can't be 100 percent sure," she said. 
Mr. Ramos agreed that putting companies under multiple microscopes would help. "You look at the balance statement, you look at the footnotes, you do a lot more fundamental research, and you question things more in this market environment," he said, "although you should have been doing that two years ago."
When companies can be trusted to disclose their true earnings, Professor Malkiel said, one can again look at P/E ratios. "I don't think there's anything wrong with the valuation metrics that we use, including price-to-earnings multiples," he said.
Even if all companies told the truth, there would still be some wiggle room. Many economists recommend using forecasts, rather than earnings from the past year, to calculate P/E ratios. A share's price represents the value of profits yet to be earned, the thinking goes, so the appropriate ratio would use the company's best guess about those profits. But that guess is inevitably subjective.
"A lot of what goes into that P/E is a lot of variables based on individuals' and analysts' expectations of the future," Mr. Dillman said.
Those views can change with the market, Mr. Ramos added. "What you're dealing with is investors' time horizons," he said. "They expand in bull markets and they contract in bear markets. The fact of the matter is that the reality is somewhere in between."
The cautious mood on Wall Street is likely to affect those expectations and horizons. Even companies that have not had to restate earnings from previous years may rein in their forecasts. That could mean that investors will have to become accustomed to higher price-to-earnings ratios.
Indeed, P/E ratios may have been held down artificially for a long time. Ms. Fedak said she believes that earnings have been inflated for years before the recent periods for which companies have been revising results. "There have been all kinds of ways, over time, that companies have used for creative accounting," she said, adding that she expects P/E ratios to creep upward.
This trend is likely to be accelerated by corporate decisions, like those by Coca-Cola and by a handful of other companies last week, to count the cost of options as expenses, which reduces earnings.
Trying to tell whether a share -- or the whole market -- is overvalued by comparing its past and present P/E ratios might make little sense. If investors' expectations take time to catch up to more cautious earnings reports and higher P/E ratios, the market could be headed for more trouble.
"I just don't believe all these earnings," Professor Shiller said. "If you don't believe them, then P/E ratios are really high. Investors are not going to tolerate that."

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Health Care Appeals Are No Snap

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE ANDREWS; Michelle Andrews is a freelance writer in Manhattan specializing in health care. Her column on its economics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: moneymeds@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IMAGINE that you're sick and your health plan turns you down for treatment you consider essential. For some people, this scene is all too real. 
 In 42 states and the District of Columbia, you can appeal your health plan's decision to an independent reviewer that will evaluate the evidence in your case and make a ruling. Last month, the Supreme Court gave its official stamp of approval to state laws governing that appeal process, ending longstanding uncertainty about its legality. 
 For consumers, having access to an independent review is certainly better than nothing -- especially when the patients' bill of rights, which would mandate such reviews, is still stuck in Congress. But the situation is hardly ideal. State laws vary widely, and even the most consumer-friendly ones force people to navigate a thicket of regulations, a daunting process for patients who are already sick and scared. 
Most states require consumers to first exhaust the internal appeals process of their plan. That can mean going through two or more levels of review, which can take months.
There are other stumbling blocks. About a dozen states limit who can use the process, excluding, for example, people who are part of preferred provider organizations or have individual health plans. California, Texas and Connecticut refuse to review after-the-fact denials. This means that if you get the treatment you think you need and then try to reverse a denial retroactively, your case won't be considered. In some states, you have just 20 days or less to file an appeal after a denial. The list goes on. 
Many cases are not pursued all the way through the system. In New York, for example, consumers appealed 25,527 denials to their health plans in 2000, but only 910 made it through external review, said Joanna Rose, spokeswoman for the New York State Insurance Department.
Karen Ignagni, chief executive of the American Association of Health Plans, a trade group based in Washington that supports independent review, said the low numbers showed the positive effect of health plans' internal appeals processes, which resolve disputes that might otherwise have gone to external review.
But Karen Pollitz, project director at Georgetown University's Institute for Health Care Research and Policy, isn't so sure. Pennsylvania's experience illustrates how many people drop out of the process before the independent review stage. From January 1999 to September 2000, consumers filed nearly 8,200 appeals with their health plans. At the first level of internal appeals, the health plans upheld their own decisions 55 percent of the time, said Ms. Pollitz, who recently wrote a report assessing state external review programs. 
But despite losing their appeal, only 1,062 consumers, or 24 percent, went on to the second level of internal appeals. At the second appeals level, health plans upheld their own decisions 58 percent of the time, but an even smaller proportion of consumers, 124 people, or 20 percent of the 618 who had been denied, went on to file an external appeal. 
"It seems people just get worn out, and they don't go on," Ms. Pollitz said.
That's unfortunate, because there is evidence that people who persevere can be successful. Five years ago, chronic lymphocytic leukemia was diagnosed in Terry Rigdon, 59, a sales clerk from Tulsa, Okla. When chemotherapy failed to halt the progress of the disease, she said, her doctor suggested a bone marrow transplant. That is a reasonable treatment for a relatively young, healthy person for whom standard treatments are not working, according to an expert, Dr. Wyndham Wilson, head of the lymphoma section of the Center for Cancer Research at the National Cancer Institute in Bethesda, Md. But Mrs. Rigdon's health plan said it denied the request, calling the procedure experimental.
Mrs. Rigdon waived her rights to her health plan's internal appeals process and went directly to an expedited external review. All states allow accelerated reviews in cases when a patient's life or health is in imminent danger. With the help of her nurse and the Patient Advocate Foundation, a nonprofit organization in Newport News, Va., Mrs. Rigdon submitted a case file of supporting documents from her doctor and articles from medical journals demonstrating the appropriateness of the treatment. Within days, her health plan's decision was overturned. 
Mrs. Rigdon was lucky to have had outside help; many patients are not as fortunate. Ron Pollack, executive director of Families USA, a consumer health care organization based in Washington, says state ombudsman programs are necessary to ensure that people get the help they need. Nineteen states currently have such programs in place for people covered by private insurance. 
"Many people are intimidated by the idea of going up against the big H.M.O.," he said, "and unfortunately, they're often too sick and too frail to appeal at the time when the service is essential."
Pity.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Travel Slump Is Translating Into Luxury for Less

BYLINE:  By JANE L. LEVERE 

 BODY:
THESE are tough times for the travel industry. Concerns about the stock market, the economy and potential terrorism have led many people to rethink or even forgo their travel plans, leaving some airlines, hotels, cruise lines and tour operators scrambling to fill vacancies.
 But for consumers still willing and able to travel -- sometimes at the last minute -- that means more discounts, particularly from high-end companies, many of which have been hurt severely. Many of those discounted luxury vacation deals can be found online. 
 David and Cookie Maleh of Brooklyn say they found a good deal on a last-minute trip to Barbados last spring. The Malehs and another couple stayed at Sandy Lane, a five-star resort on the beach. For $3,129 a couple, they each received roundtrip coach air fare and four-night accommodations, including breakfast, golf privileges and spa treatments. Such a trip would normally cost $4,737 a couple, according to Wanderluxe.com, a new service the Malehs used to made their arrangements. 
"It was a first-class trip," said Mr. Maleh, 36, a children's clothing manufacturer.
Deals like these certainly abound, but not every vacation package may be a bargain -- or even very luxurious. 
AllLuxuryHotels.com, for instance, sells rooms at 1,800 hotels worldwide, but only 20 percent of them are rated four and a half or five stars; a five-star rating is the industry standard traditionally deemed luxury. The remainder are rated at four stars.
Most travel Web sites do not display prices of the various components of the packages, so consumers have no quick way to know how much of a discount they are receiving unless they try to price a comparable trip on their own. (At Wanderluxe, coach air fares on its vacation packages are 20 to 60 percent off retail prices, while hotel rates at AllLuxuryHotels.com may range from no discount to up to 70 percent off the published rate.)
Sometimes, travel Web sites may not include important information like weather trends at destinations.
"You could be buying a hotel room in the Caribbean in the hurricane season, and you might not know this if you were buying simply on price," said Perry Lungmus, the executive vice president for marketing at Virtuoso, a consortium of high-end travel agencies.
Wanderluxe, which is now being tested, is owned by executives of the World Travel Specialists Group, a corporate travel agency in New York that said small stakes in Wanderluxe are held by Delta Air Lines and American Airlines, a part of AMR. Another site specializing in discounted, upscale travel is LuxuryLink.com. About one-quarter owned by Gannett, the large news media company, LuxuryLink has sold discounted hotel packages, cruises, tours and other vacations, both through auctions and at fixed prices, since 1998. LuxRes.com sells individual hotel rooms and hotel packages, often at discounts. The site, started last spring, is controlled by the Leading Hotels of the World, a distribution and marketing company for five-star hotels.
Other sites include two hotel consolidators that began selling discounted four- and five star-hotel rooms last summer: the Premier Collection service of the privately held Quikbook.com, and AllLuxuryHotels, a division of Hotels.com, a majority of which is owned by USA Interactive. Among others are 1st-Air.net, a broker that has sold discounted first- and business-class airline tickets since 1997, and firstclassflyer.com, which went on line last spring. It does not sell air travel, but it has published a monthly newsletter with advice on finding deals on first- and business-class fares since 1996.
Henry H. Harteveldt, an analyst in San Francisco for Forrester Research, which specializes in technology, says sites like these are proliferating "because there's an awful lot of excess inventory out there."
"They help bring customers that these properties and carriers might not necessarily know," he said.
Many of the travel industry's woes stem from a drop in business travel over the last 18 months, industry analysts say. Business travelers, who traditionally patronize luxury hotels, are either cutting back on their number of trips or staying at less expensive hotels. The problem of excess supply has been aggravated, analysts say, by the fact that many high-end lodging and cruise companies have added hotels and ships in recent years.
BJORN HANSON, who oversees the hospitality practice at PricewaterhouseCoopers, says luxury hotel companies in particular are working with the luxury travel sites because their business has been so weak. He predicted that on any given night this year, about one-third of the 600,000 most luxurious hotel rooms in the United States will be vacant. He also forecast that revenue per available room for domestic luxury hotels, which slid 11.6 percent last year, will dip an additional 0.8 percent this year, while revenue per available room for all types of hotels nationwide, which dropped 7 percent last year, will fall 0.7 percent. The revenue calculation is widely used in the industry to measure a hotel's performance.
Dr. Hanson also said travel Web sites were getting far more luxury hotel rooms to sell than in the past.
"The Internet no longer has the image of being just for price-sensitive travelers looking for cheap rooms," he said.
Still, travelers should take precautions when booking a hotel room, cruise or travel package online. To find out more about a site's reputation, they can talk with other travelers, try travel chat rooms or contact the Better Business Bureau to check if any formal complaints have been lodged.
Shoppers should also make sure that they understand a site's booking rules and policies. Sites like Quikbook allow travelers to look, book and buy online, while others like Wanderluxe sell only by phone through an agent. Although some sites permit cancellations and changes for a fee, vacations sold by others, like Wanderluxe, are usually nonrefundable. 
Consumers should make their purchases with a credit card, experts say; if there are problems, or if a site fails, they may have recourse through the card issuer.
Comparison shopping is important, too. Rates on a Web site can be checked against those offered by travel agents and other sites, as well as those offered directly, both online and off, by the hotel, cruise line or tour operator. 
For instance, a 12-night Pacific cruise for two departing on Aug. 24 on the Seabourn Spirit was $2,390 cheaper on Cruise411.com, a site that sells many types of discounted cruises, than on LuxuryLink. But a search failed to find a price lower than the $249-a-night rate available from Quikbook next month at the Peninsula hotel in Chicago; the next cheapest rate was $295, obtained from the hotel's reservations department and Web site.
"If you know what you're doing, you can get a trip for one-third to one-half off," said Kay Latona, 58, a retired lawyer from Fort Lauderdale, Fla., who has bought three vacations for herself and her husband Jack, 63, a lawyer, through LuxuryLink over the last two years. Her most recent trip was a 10-night Kenyan safari in June; it cost $5,515 a couple, without air fare.
"If you hit it right, it's a big win," she said. "But if you haven't, it's not the end of the world, because if you wait two or three months, that trip will probably come up on the site again."
You may not want to wait too long, however.
"There's no guarantee these sites will have the same access to inventory they do now as the economy starts to recover," said Mr. Harteveldt, the Forrester analyst.

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
Creditworthy?Be Credit-Wary, Too

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
I LIKE to think of myself as a fairly intelligent, financially sophisticated person. I know that big businesses don't always have my best interests at heart, that the customer is rarely right. I pride myself on not being a sucker.
 So you can imagine my annoyance when I read my most recent MasterCard bill and noticed two annual percentage rates: 14.5 percent for purchases and 19.99 percent for a $300 cash advance I took out in February. 
 As a rule, I pay my credit card bill in full, or at least in large chunks. I try to keep my balance below $3,000. What I didn't know was that my payments didn't cover cash advances. I also didn't know that I was being charged a monthly rate for purchases but a daily one for the advances (or that it's possible to have several A.P.R.'s on one card).
I called Citibank and asked how to pay off the cash advances. Online? Impossible. At the A.T.M.? No. In person at the bank? Sorry. Although I can do just about all my banking electronically these days, short of having my PC spit out money, I was told that I cannot pay cash advances that way. I had to send a check to a special unit, thereby accruing even more interest charges until the check arrived. 
You probably think that I'm a little naive, but I was genuinely stunned. If I'm finding all this a bit confusing, how about other young people, particularly college students and recent graduates? Within weeks of arriving on campus, most students are bombarded with credit card applications. 
"College kids are a good market -- the balances are low, so the risk to the lender is very small," said Howard Dvorkin, the founder of Consolidated Credit Counseling Services in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. 
Seventy-seven percent of full-time undergraduates at four-year schools have credit cards, according to a 1999 study by Michael E. Staten, a business professor at Georgetown University. While many students can manage their debts, some with help from their parents, others run into problems. A recent report by the National Center for Education Statistics found that 41 percent of graduating college seniors had $3,000, on average, in credit card debt. 
Credit card companies entice students with incentives like free baseball caps, compact discs, mouse pads and cheap airline tickets. Many schools encourage such solicitations; they usually get perks themselves whenever students, alumni or employees sign up. (First USA, for example, is paying the University of Oklahoma $13 million over 10 years, and gives the school 0.4 percent of every purchase made on the university "affinity" card.)
"It's hard when you're 18 or 19 and everyone else seems to come from money, and Visa, MasterCard and American Express are throwing offers of $3,000 at you," said Steve McKelvey, now 36, who works for a paper company in Valley Forge, Pa. As a student at the College of Wooster, in Ohio, Mr. McKelvey was issued four different cards, even though he had no income. 
Mr. McKelvey graduated in 1990 with a degree in music, along with $27,000 in student loans and $13,000 in credit card debt. Several months later, he was in bankruptcy court.
Eventually, he consolidated his student loans through the Pennsylvania Higher Education Assistance Agency -- those loans don't disappear even if you file for personal bankruptcy -- and began the task of rebuilding his credit. He has no black marks on his credit report today, he said, and his student loans will be paid off in March. "I will finally know, at the age of 37, what it's like to have no debt," he said.
Kevin Rubel, 22, cannot wait to see that day. Until last July, he was a student at Northeastern University in Boston, majoring in marketing. In three years, he had maxed out five cards, for a total of $6,000. That, compounded with $15,000 in loans, left him deep in red ink. He had to move back home to West Palm Beach, Fla.; he is now a senior at Florida Atlantic University. He also works two bartending jobs and pays Mr. Dvorkin a $15 fee each month to help him sort it all out, along with $500 to be distributed to the credit card companies.
"This is the toughest year of my life," he said. "There should be restrictions on credit card companies. They shouldn't be allowed to do what they do."
Some schools, like Georgetown University and the University of California at Irvine, have banned credit card solicitation on campus; the State of Arkansas requires universities to offer credit seminars at freshman orientation. The MBNA Corporation, a credit card giant that issues cards to students, conducts such sessions on campuses, as does Mr. Dvorkin's service.
Interestingly, Mr. McKelvey thinks the onus is on the student. "Obviously, companies are more aggressive than they've ever been, but the issue of personal responsibility has got to be raised in any discussion," he said. 
TRUE, young people must use credit responsibly -- and exercise restraint when they see that hot new leather jacket at the mall. It is also the responsibility of schools, parents and the credit card companies to educate them. 
After hanging up the phone with Citibank, I immediately mailed a check. I called 10 days later; the check had arrived, but I was told that I still owed $4.75 in interest. As a favor, the customer service representative offered to move that over to my purchase charges. 
And by the way, he asked, had I heard about the new gold card that the bank was offering? It has the same $50 annual fee as my current card, which accumulates frequent-flier miles on American Airlines. But the new one requires fewer miles for a free ticket. And, oh yes -- it also has "flexible spending," which means that I could go over my $13,100 credit limit.
"As long as you pay back what you go over that month you're fine," the customer representative said; otherwise, there is a $29 monthly fee on top of regular charges. "So, do you want it?" he asked.
I thought for about 20 seconds, weighed the options, inhaled deeply and asked how soon it could arrive. How's that for self-control?

CORRECTION-DATE: July 28, 2002

 CORRECTION:
The Preludes column on the Personal Business page last Sunday, about student credit card debt, misstated some financial circumstances from the student years of Steve McKelvey, who is now 36 and employed at a paper company in Valley Forge, Pa. Mr. McKelvey said that he incurred the bulk of $27,000 in student loans and $13,000 in credit card debt while a graduate student at the University of Michigan and in a later relocation, not as an undergraduate at the College of Wooster in Ohio, and that he had indeed received income from student jobs.
The column also misstated the year in which Mr. McKelvey graduated from Wooster. It was 1991, not 1990.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: LOWER EAST SIDE; 
Not on My Sidewalk: The Battle Over Street Trees

BYLINE:  By KELLY CROW 

 BODY:
Trees grow almost everywhere in this city, some in pits of earth between slabs of sidewalk. Councilwoman Margarita Lopez, who represents the Lower East Side, has seen many such trees grow to the point of cracking their concrete confinements, and she knows better than to blame them for the damage. 
 Ms. Lopez has spent the last 18 months trying to pass a law that would require the city to ask people's permission before it plants any more sidewalk trees. More specifically, she wants to give property owners a legal way to reject trees offered by the Parks Department or private groups. 
 The bill is now before the Housing and Buildings Committee. If it dies in committee, Ms. Lopez will try again in the fall.
Last week, Rosie Mendez, the councilwoman's chief of staff, said the bill was not prompted by a particular tree or by a general dislike of them. Indeed, Ms. Lopez's district, the Lower East Side, regularly clamors for more greenery. 
"We are not trying to seem antitree here," Ms. Mendez said. "This is not really even about trees. This is about economic injustice."
What bothers Ms. Lopez is that city law has long held building owners responsible for repairing sidewalks that border their properties. The cost to fix a tree-buckled stretch varies, but $8 to $27 per square foot is average, said Keith Calb, a Transportation Department spokesman.
A brownstone owner is responsible for the sidewalk to the curb. Store owners could be liable for up to a block of sidewalk. Last year, the department doled out 3,000 sidewalk violations, most of them tree-related.
"We know the price tag can be high," Mr. Calb said, "but our agency's first concern has to be with pedestrian safety, not trees."
The Parks Department is concerned about trees, however, particularly the reduced presence they might have on city sidewalks if the bill becomes law.
"Please let us keep planting trees," said Jane Rudolph, a department spokeswoman, "and I promise we'll come shave the roots, we'll trim or do anything to keep them there." KELLY CROW

An article in the Neighborhood Report pages on July 21 about street trees misstated the surname of a spokesman for the city's Department of Transportation, which requires property owners to repair tree-damaged sidewalks. He is Keith Kalb, not Calb.
