HEADLINE: The Relevance Of 'Sex' in a City That's Changed 

BYLINE:  By JULIE SALAMON 

 BODY:
"SEX and the City" sashayed into public consciousness in the summer of 1998, when sex had become, if not the national pastime, the reigning political story. Monica Lewinsky had just been featured on the cover of Vanity Fair, and her name was regularly mentioned on the front pages of major newspapers. The Clinton-Lewinsky affair had made lewd gossip an acceptable form of political commentary, and "Sex and the City" quickly became part of the pundit glossary.
 The show, a smart and frisky comedy, became an instant hit, and not just in New York, though the city became an essential character, an otherworldly backdrop of glamorous hedonism and larger-than-life yearning. This was New York rarefied, the glittering city of after-hours parties, where models and Wall Streeters mingle with the almost-beautiful and the not-quite-rich, and a crucial component of social I.Q. is the ability to spot a Birkin bag across a crowded room. 
 After Sept. 11, however, Manhattan acquired a terrible new symbolism, and economic uncertainty has taken a toll on hedonism, at least of the expense-account kind. Osama bin Laden has outpaced Monica Lewinsky by 17 to 1 in the pages of The New York Times over the last year. Sarah Jessica Parker, who plays Carrie Bradshaw, the newspaper writer whose column tracks her adventures in dating, is pregnant in real life. Kim Cattrall, who plays the public relations vamp, Samantha, published a sex manual with her husband this year -- in which she confessed that she didn't enjoy her 20 years of sex before meeting him. And earlier this month, Candace Bushnell, the sleek blonde writer whose libidinous columns in The New York Observer and subsequent book spawned "Sex and the City," got married, at 43 (to a man 10 years younger than she, but still, married).
Tonight "Sex and the City" begins its fifth season on HBO in a world solemnized by terrorism and, apparently, newly appreciative of the joys of marriage. What does this mean for a show that has relied on an unending sense of youth and blitheness? Has "Sex" become irrelevant?
Not at all. It's a different show than it was, not as lighthearted, but it's still involving and inventive. Chastity hasn't replaced promiscuity. There's still plenty of sex and plenty of talk about sex. But judging from the poignant first two episodes, the real subject of the new season -- absurd though it may seem -- could be loss of innocence, personal and global (recognizing that in New York, it's become difficult to distinguish one from the other).
Longtime viewers noticed in January, when new episodes that had been filmed before Sept. 11 were first shown, that the title sequence had been altered. Ms. Parker still tiptoed through the city landscape in a tutu-like skirt, and got splashed by a bus, but the twin towers -- previously prominent -- had been edited out. It seemed a wan effort, as though the producers, by reflecting the new skyline but leaving the rest unchanged, were trying to pretend that everything was the same. The premiere of the new season, filmed after the attack, dispels those fears.
Without mentioning the destruction of the World Trade Center, the opening episode alludes to it. "If you want to do your patriotic duty as New York women, you come shopping with me right now and throw some much-needed money downtown," Carrie says to her friends. When Samantha describes her unfaithful lover as toxic, Carrie replies: "Manthrax?" Beyond the jokes, however, is the sense that life has changed irrevocably, that the perpetual childhood is over. "Maybe you have to let go of who you were to become who you will be," Carrie muses after another disillusioning night on the town.
The show's producers and writers -- led by Darren Star, its creator, and the executive producer Michael Patrick King -- have had a palpable affection for the city, though the sentiment was often distilled through martini-dry observations. "Manhattan, for millions of our forefathers the gateway to hope, opportunity and happiness beyond their wildest dreams," Carrie wrote in one of her columns in the second season. "Today that hope is still alive. It's called the first date." Ms. Parker's voiceover was accompanied by dreamlike images of immigrants melding into visions of glossy contemporary New Yorkers, dining and partying. "On Saturday nights, every restaurant in Lower Manhattan resembles its own little Ellis Island. Hordes of single women crowded into a hot, cramped space, hoping to make it to their final destination. The state of matrimony -- or at least to get a hot meal in transit."
The show's allure has always relied on the juxtaposition of frivolity with serious concerns. The four women, all financially self-sufficient, have tempered their flip cynicism with hope, and their man-obsession with a desire for independence, legal and spiritual. In past episodes, Miranda the lawyer (Cynthia Nixon), on buying her first apartment, discovered that her mortgage agreement assumed she was dependent on a father or husband. In another, Carrie admitted that the main attraction of baseball for her was the opportunity to drink and smoke publicly in the afternoon without reproach. While the four women -- especially Ms. Parker's shoe-obsessed Carrie -- represent a fashion-conscious breed, they can also look realistically bedraggled in the wake of too much socializing, emotionalizing or, yes, even too much sex.
With all its frankness, "Sex and the City" almost never leers as it chronicles the brutality and absurdity of upscale mating rituals. In its funny and provocative debut four years ago, Carrie posed a question that was emblematic of the show's style, insouciant, yet not. "Can women have sex like men?" It wasn't a matter of positions -- though the show capitalized on HBO's laissez-faire attitude toward demonstrating them -- but of emotions. Could women engage in casual sex without the aftershock of attachment, longing, obsession? It was also a matter of language. Carrie and her friends talked about sex and men and body parts bluntly and vulgarly. But they were just as candid about their fears of growing old alone. These narcissistic tough cookies, played by a wonderful ensemble cast, had a surprising, wistful core.
They've always known the party couldn't go on forever. The show's producers haven't kept them locked in time, like sitcom characters, but allowed them to change -- to grow up, like it or not. Rather than pretend that the actresses were ageless, the series has had them confront unsexy issues like menopause. In the most recent season, under Mr. King's guidance, "Sex and the City" had already become more sober, the humor less carefree. Miranda, the hard-edged lawyer, became pregnant accidentally and then decided to have the baby after considering abortion. Samantha, too, let her guard down and fell in love. Charlotte (Kristin Davis) dropped her career for marriage and motherhood, only to find out she was infertile. Carrie became engaged to a nice but dull man and then, ever ambivalent, broke it off.
These characters may be confounded by their decisions -- and indecision -- but they won't be doomed to the fate of Lily Bart, their literary ancestor, a single woman navigating the New York social scene a century ago. Edith Wharton describes the dilemma that would eventually lead to Lily's suicide in "The House of Mirth":
"She had been bored all the afternoon by Percy Gryce -- the mere thought seemed to waken an echo of his droning voice -- but she could not ignore him on the morrow, she must follow up her success, must submit to more boredom, must be ready with fresh compliances and adaptabilities, and all on the bare chance that he might ultimately decide to do her the honor of boring her for life.
"It was a hateful fate -- but how escape from it? What choice had she?"
As the new season opens, Carrie considers her choices, including the prospect that she may always be on her own. Her bravado has been shaken, especially after a lunchtime encounter with a worst-case portent of the future. A crazy old woman in a beret (Sylvia Miles), with scraggly bottle-blonde hair, begins chatting about how she used to look like Carrie until she broke up with a man -- in 1982 -- because she thought something better would come along. "Never happened," she says. Then there's another confrontation, this one with her friend's new maternal breasts, as Miranda flips down her nursing bra and tries to carry on a conversation while her baby tries to latch onto her nipple. Cynthia Nixon beautifully captures Miranda's frustration as Carrie tries to reassure her with a joke: "You're still one of us, only now you're the one with the biggest boobs." It doesn't reassure either of them, now that function as well as form has been altered.
Yet the show hasn't lost its charm or its sense of hopefulness. When a man offers to take Carrie home from a dance, he says, "It's rough out there."
"It's not so bad," she says, heading into the Manhattan night alone. Both she and the city seem more fragile, yet still willing to believe in possibility. At this moment, that sense of optimism is almost as seductive as sex.

Sex and the City
HBO, Sundays at 9 p.m., 8 Central.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Queens; 
Retail Space Being Filled at New Kennedy Terminal

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
HERMES, Ferragamo and Hugo Boss are names usually linked with shopping on Fifth and Madison Avenues or at an upscale regional mall. By next spring they will also have stores at the 100,000-square-foot retail corridor at Terminal 4 at Kennedy International Airport. 
 The three stores are part of a group of 13 retailers that will take a total of nearly 13,000 square feet in the corridor and complete its leasing, albeit more than a year after it was completed, as part of the $1.4 billion construction of the new terminal, which is mainly for international carriers. The corridor is positioned before the airline security checkpoints and is designed to resemble a suburban mall. 
 The commitment, industry professionals say, reflect a move toward higher-end stores at airports, long associated with tacky and overpriced souvenirs. 
It comes at a time when retailing at airports is still feeling aftershocks from the economic downturn and the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. These effects include a drop in the number of air travelers and a growing focus on security, which in most cases has resulted in stretching the time passengers spend at airports.
Nationally, most passengers are arriving two hours before departure, nearly double the previous wait, according to the Center for Airport Management, a retail leasing and consulting firm in Portland, Ore., and the number of travelers, though increasing, is still 10 percent lower than it was last year. 
For the region's major airports -- J.F.K., La Guardia and Newark -- as of May the number of travelers was down 17 percent from last year, according to the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. At J.F.K.'s Terminal 4, with a projected six million passengers this year, the count was down 15 percent.
Projections nationally and in the region are that the gaps will continue to close this year and hardly exist by next year.
Meanwhile, passengers' longer stays in airports could mean "a growing opportunity for retail, which is moving toward more luxury goods," said Stephen Yalof, president of Robert K. Futterman & Associates, a retail consulting group in Manhattan. In recent years food offerings have gone from cafeteria-style outlets to national fast-food chains and sit-down restaurants, he said, adding that a similar upgrade is in order for the retail space. 
It is the next logical step, added Shelly Klapper, president of the Center for Airport Management, which works with JFK IAT, the consortium that manages Terminal 4.
The trend is evident at other airports, including Terminal C at Newark International Airport, run by Continental Airlines. Kenneth Cole, offering men and women's shoes and apparel; Johnston & Murphy, a men's footwear and apparel store; and L'Occitane, which sells upscale personal care products and cosmetics, are among the retailers opening shops at that newly renovated and enlarged terminal. The shopping area at Newark's Continental terminal grew by 38 stores, to 97, according to Westfield America, the Australian shopping center developer that manages the retail space there.
At J.F.K.'s Terminal 4, the retail concept since planning began in 1996 has been "to give travelers the same mix of retailing and pricing they would find on New York City streets," said David Sigman, executive committee member at JFK IAT. The consortium is made up of Schipol USA, the United States subsidiary of a Dutch company that manages airports in the Netherlands and in several other countries; LCOR, a national real estate company; and Lehman Brothers, the investment bank.
The consortium signed a seven-year lease for all 13 stores left in the corridor, as well as two small ones in the arrival hall, with an Austrian company, Saveria JFK, which brought in the tenants and will manage the outlets as their franchisee. Other tenants include Swatch and Tie Rack as well as a gift shop offering Mont Blanc pens and Swarovski crystal, said Rakesh Sardana, president of Saveria. His company, based in Vienna, operates stores in downtown Vienna and at Vienna International Airport. 
The latest arrivals will join 25 existing tenants and food outlets, including DKNY apparel and Sylvia's of Harlem, a carry-out soul food store. The Metropolitan Museum of Art will open a 1,300-square-foot store in November, said Sally Pearson, the museum's vice president and general manager of merchandising and retail.
"We are in high-traffic, high-tourist places," so airports make sense, Ms. Pearson said.
Earlier attempts to market the site that Saveria has leased fell through. First Nuance, an affiliate of Swissair, had negotiated a lease for the space, but was unable to complete the deal after the airline filed for bankruptcy last fall. (A new airline, Swiss, has since replaced Swissair and is one of 44 carriers that fly out of the terminal.) There was also interest from retailers to lease one store at a time, but JFK IAT preferred to lease all the space to one management firm, which then would be responsible for filling the individual stores. 
Mr. Sardana said he proceeded because "seeing into the future and beyond the cyclical nature of air travel, it made business and economic sense to be in a new and truly international terminal." It also seemed right to support New York, he added.
Nationwide, airport retailers have benefited from the fact that while there are fewer passengers, they are staying in terminals longer, said Mr. Klapper of the Center for Airport Management. Compared with a year earlier, he said, business is up 14 percent at food-oriented concerns and 6.5 percent at newsstands. Though business at specialty retailers has fallen 3 to 5 percent, the drop has been lower at airports than at traditional shopping malls, where business has declined by 6 percent.
Accommodating bomb detection machines -- some the size of minivans -- could result in a store or two being eliminated in some airports. In some cases, heightened security also has resulted in long lines and travelers too frazzled to shop in stores located before the security check points.
Even before Sept. 11, Mr. Klapper said, the airline industry was seeking to improve retailing at airports to capitalize on travelers' spending power, in part by making their waiting time "less stressful." 
THE retail corridor at Terminal 4, designed by Communication Arts of Boulder, Colo., attempts to meet those goals by offering diverse shops and a pleasant environment. Of the 100,000 square feet of total space in the retail corridor, only 60,000 feet is for the stores and restaurants themselves, and the rest is dedicated to seating and landscaped areas. 
Carol Fish, commercial director for JFK IAT, said Saveria's payments to her company this year would approach $1 million. These payments are made up of a base rent and a percentage of sales. The entire corridor will generate $15 million this year in revenue to JFK IAT. Based on those numbers, payments in the corridor average $250 a square foot. 
The terminal, Mr. Sigman said, was designed with room for the updated security equipment, eliminating the need to take space away from the retail corridor. It also has 12 check-in positions at each of its two security checkpoints, cutting down on lines and limiting the processing time to about 12 minutes, he said. 
As for the rest of the time, Ms. Fish said, the focus "is to keep people in the retail corridor, so all departing passengers must pass through it on their way to the two departing concourses." It is also open to nonpassengers and airport employees.
Still, not all retailers were successful in the terminal's first year. Three stores -- a gourmet food purveyor, a Southwestern apparel shop and a food outlet -- have closed or plan to move out because "they weren't the right concept," Ms. Fish said, noting that such turnover is not uncommon. She said a redesign is being considered to add stores beyond the security points to capture more shoppers. 
Mr. Sardana of Saveria said the retail environment and layout at Terminal 4 appeal to him. So does the chance to operate 15 stores rather than one or two, lowering the usually high operating costs at airports, he said, adding that the stores will start to open in November and continue through next spring.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Carol Fish, commercial director at Terminal 4, and Rakesh Sardana of Saveria, which will run 15 stores there. (Kevin P. Coughlin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK TRANSIT; 
Articulated Buses Keep Rumbling, Despite a Litany of Complaints

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
To some riders, articulated buses are big, bad bulls wreaking havoc in the quiet china shop of the Upper East Side. To the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, they are a cost-effective answer to the city's increasing load of mass transit users. Two years of hearings, meetings, petitions and studies have failed to resolve that difference of opinion. 
 In 2000, the authority introduced articulated buses, which are 20 feet longer than normal buses and can hold 50 percent more passengers, on the crosstown routes at 79th, 86th and 23rd Streets. From the first, the newcomers were greeted by a steady drumbeat of complaints about safety, accessibility, noise, and the frequency of service. 
 But despite the vocal opposition of many residents, along with Community Boards 6 and 8, the New York City Transit Riders Council and a cadre of local politicians, it seems the buses are here to stay, a decision that strikes many people as utterly baffling.
"With the amount of opposition from riders and the long list of criticisms and safety concerns, the M.T.A.'s response so far is just mystifying," said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, who represents portions of Manhattan and Queens and recently helped the city obtain $5 million in federal funds to build the Second Avenue subway. "Despite significant public dissatisfaction and a clear deterioration in service, the M.T.A. has not only refused to back off on the use of articulated buses, but has ordered more."
Indeed, 240 new articulated buses, destined for service on First, Second and Lexington Avenues, will rumble in later this year. 
"The transit authority is a creature unto itself," said Gifford Miller, the speaker of the City Council, who has steadily but unsuccessfully pushed to have the buses removed from crosstown routes. "I would like to see them be more responsive." 
New York City Transit, which operates the authority's subways and buses, maintains that bigger buses are better. 
"We are able to provide service to more customers with fewer buses on an economical basis," said Millard Seay, senior vice president for buses. Last year, four articulated buses were used for every five regular buses during off-peak times, providing a 17 percent increase in capacity. Fewer buses mean fewer bus drivers, a major cost savings.
Furthermore, Mr. Seay said, the agency has studied every complaint. Those studies, he said, showed that the buses are safe, efficient and well liked. "Based on our results, the highest rated routes in Manhattan were the articulated routes," he said.
The agency cites increased ridership as the ultimate indication of the buses' success. However, according to their records, while ridership on the 23rd Street crosstown bus increased 9.5 percent from 1999 to 2001, on the 86th Street route it increased 7.4 percent, the average increase for Manhattan. And on the 79th Street route, it rose 6.7 percent.
The agency's findings strike some as miraculous, others as malicious.
"We were fairly astounded that the M.T.A. believed everyone liked these buses," said State Senator Liz Krueger. 
Trudy Mason, a member of the Transit Riders Council, added, "This, to me, is the quintessential example of the arrogance of power." ERIKA KINETZ

GRAPHIC: Photos: An articulated bus is 20 feet longer than the normal bus, shown at left, and can hold 50 percent more passengers. (Photographs by Joyce Dopkeen/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: It's Still a Man's, Man's, Man's World 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI 

 BODY:
FOR all the talk about golf's having become a sport of inclusion, events last week exposed some rents in the theory.
 Asked whether women should be allowed to join the Augusta National Golf Club in Georgia, home of the Masters tournament, whose 300 members include top executives of I.B.M., Citigroup and other big companies, Tiger Woods offered a noncommittal answer. "They're entitled to set up their own rules the way they want them," he said. 
 From a player who 15 years ago would not have been allowed at numerous private clubs because of his race, the response reflected a lingering contradiction in golf: it is still not all right for women to be members of some of the most exclusive golf clubs in the world. Of the four major men's tournaments this year, two -- the Masters, which Mr. Woods won in April, and the British Open, which began Thursday at Muirfield in Scotland -- are at clubs that do not accept women as members. The course that will be host to the British Open in 2003, Royal St. George's, has only in the last five years taken down its sign prohibiting "dogs and women." But there are some things you don't have to spell out: the club still excludes women from membership. 
Mr. Woods spoke at a press conference in Scotland, where he was trying to win his third consecutive major tournament of 2002 on the way to golf's Grand Slam. His comments focused instant attention on a dispute between the chairwoman of the National Council of Women's Organizations, Dr. Martha Burk, and the chairman of Augusta National, William W. Johnson, known as Hootie. In June, Dr. Burk had sent a letter to Mr. Johnson urging him to invite a woman for membership before the 2003 Masters.
Mr. Johnson's reply, in a statement released to the public, was defiant. He said that the club's membership policies were its own business, adding: "We will not be bullied, threatened or intimidated." There may come a day when women will be invited to join Augusta National, he said, "but that timetable will be ours and not at the point of a bayonet."
Now it turns out that the dispute may have been counterproductive, delaying what might have been Mr. Johnson's steps to invite a woman to join. The 71-year-old Mr. Johnson, who has unusual sway over who is asked to join, had told members he was hoping to retire "on a more open note" by inviting a woman in, according to one club member who spoke on the condition of anonymity last week because Augusta's bylaws forbid members to discuss club matters. But now Mr. Johnson is less likely to do so, the member said, since it will appear that he has caved to outside pressure.
"We do not intend to become a trophy in their display case," Mr. Johnson said in his statement, referring to Dr. Burk's organization, which comprises 160 women's groups. The Augusta member said he did not know which women Mr. Johnson had considered.
Dr. Burk said she has not neared the end of her confrontation with Augusta, which does allow women to play as guests. "We will not take the view that some have: 'Tiger has spoken and now it's over,' " she said. "It is not over. For all my respect for him, Tiger is naive when it comes to changing course."
One likely strategy for women's groups -- hinted at by Dr. Burk -- is to turn the spotlight on corporate sponsors of competitions at clubs that bar women as members. Very few do, but among them, Augusta and Muirfield are two of the most prominent in the world.
Gabrielle Reece, the former volleyball star who is now training to become a professional golfer, said in an interview that she was surprised that Carleton S. Fiorina, the chairwoman of Hewlett-Packard, a sponsor of the British Open, would want her company associated with a club that doesn't let women join. "She couldn't even play there," Ms. Reece said -- not as a member, anyway. Telephone calls on Thursday and Friday seeking comment from Hewlett-Packard representatives were not returned.
Of the more than 17,000 golf courses in the United States, 72 percent are open to the public in some way, according to the National Golf Foundation. Mike Tinkey, the deputy commissioner of the National Golf Club Owners Association, said that to his knowledge no study had been conducted about what percentage do not allow women as members. "Thank goodness it's pretty much an archaic animal," he said.
Laws regarding private clubs are balanced on one side by the First Amendment right to free association (under which a club can discriminate against any group), and on the other by state and federal antidiscrimination statutes (under which, in certain cases, a club cannot). In some states, if a private club behaves like a "public accommodation," it can be forced to abide by antidiscrimination laws -- for example, if it has a public liquor license or makes itself available for lease for public events.
The sport of golf, as played at private clubs, has been forced to open its doors at least a crack in the past dozen years. In 1990, the Shoal Creek Country Club, near Birmingham, Ala., gave a black man an honorary membership as part of an agreement to head off picketing of the Professional Golfers Association Championship by civil rights groups.
Since then, race has become less of a public issue, with many clubs that had previously denied membership to blacks admitting them, even though their numbers are small. The expense of playing golf at a private club, where an initiation fee of tens of thousands of dollars and annual dues in the thousands, is a exclusionary factor all by itself. There are about six black men among the estimated 300 members of Augusta National, including Lloyd Ward, the chief executive of the United States Olympic Committee, who said before the Masters this year that he would lobby the club to invite women in as members but has not made any public statement on the subject since.
In more recent years, it is women who have applied the most pressure to golf clubs to end practices that favor the old guard. In 1995, a group of women who were members of the Haverhill Golf and Country Club, outside Boston, sued the club, saying it had denied them full membership privileges by, for instance, giving men more desirable tee times. In an unprecedented decision in 2000, the women won their case and a state judge put Haverhill under the court's supervision, overseeing new guidelines about membership, tournament participation and tee times.
The real pressure on high-profile clubs like Augusta may come from corporate sponsors responding to public opinion.
Donna E. Shalala, who served as secretary of health and human services in the Clinton administration and is now president of the University of Miami, urges corporations involved in tournaments held at men-only clubs to use their economic clout to help change the rules.
"These are public companies that advertise themselves as good places to work for women," she said. "But they would never think of holding these tournaments at clubs that discriminated against blacks."
Jim Andrews, the editorial director of The IEG Sponsorship Report, which describes itself as a watchdog of corporate underwriting of public events, said that corporations may find that the risk of angering the public may outweigh the commercial advantages of sponsoring golf's most-watched events. "They take a calculated risk," he said. "There are certainly the positive benefits in terms of exposure, but they are keeping their fingers crossed. There is certainly a reason for people to shine a light on the subject."
Last week, three sponsors of the Masters -- Coca-Cola and I.B.M., which advertised on the CBS television broadcast, and Cadillac, the official car -- sidestepped the debate. Spokesmen for all three emphasized that they sponsored the one-week Masters tournament, but not Augusta National Golf Club.
The policies of Augusta, which owns and administers the Masters, violate the guidelines of all of golf's domestic governing bodies: the Professional Golfers Association Tour, the P.G.A. of America, the Ladies Professional Golf Association and the United States Golf Association. None of those groups will hold a tournament at a course that excludes people from membership on the basis of religion, race or sex.
Not all women agree that Augusta should be open to women. Lee Heffernan, a co-author of "Gentlemen Only: An Insider's View of Golf in Augusta, Georgia, and What She Found at the End of Magnolia Lane," whose father, Henry Heffernan, was a club member, supports the current policy. "They don't just discriminate against anybody," Ms. Heffernan said. "They discriminate against everyone. Even Bill Gates hasn't been asked to join."
No matter how Tiger Woods fares at Muirfield -- or at the remaining major men's tournament of the year, the P.G.A. Championship next month, at Hazeltine National, outside Minneapolis, which admits women as members -- the issue will continue to simmer.
Jane Smith, the chief executive of Business and Professional Women USA, a member of Dr. Burk's council, said her organization supported membership for women at all golf clubs. "Our legacy is built on supporting women's rights and civil rights," Ms. Smith said. "While we are pleased that this club opened its doors to men of color some years ago, we do hope that the same aggressive steps of inclusion are taken by the Augusta National Golf Club as it prepares for the Masters."

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
With Stocks in Crisis, Greenspan's Nostrums Fall Short

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
WHEN Alan Greenspan spoke on Capitol Hill last week, Washington politicians were as worshipful as ever. Back on Wall Street and Main Street, however, it is becoming painfully clear that Mr. Greenspan's ability to revive the economy has lost its punch. Look no further than the almost 400-point drop in the Dow industrials on Friday.
 Mr. Greenspan's aggressive interest rate cuts were supposed to buoy the economy. Unfortunately, the sickly stock market is acting as a counterweight to any buoyancy. 
 Using history as a guide, the stock market should be higher now than it was a year ago. Since 1948, six months after a recession's trough, stocks have jumped an average of 24 percent from the previous year. But at the end of June, six months from the recession's probable end, stocks were down 18 percent from last year. That means the market has underperformed its typical post-recessionary move by 40 percentage points.
Jan Hatzius, the senior economist at Goldman, Sachs who provided these data points, has concluded that Mr. Greenspan's aggressive rate cuts have already been "spent" in the economy, especially in housing. Unfortunately, the effect of the stock market's sorry performance has yet to be felt. As a result, Mr. Hatzius thinks that economic growth will be stuck between 2 and 3 percent well into 2003.
While rate cuts work fast to help the economy, the effects of the stock market typically lag behind. This time, Mr. Hatzius expects a longer lag. "Normally when you get a big stock market setback, consumers have a harder time getting credit," he said. "But there are more alternative sources of credit for consumers now and the Fed is very eager to keep access to credit good."
As a result, consumers are still spending and remain in denial about what the stock market has done to their net worth. Anecdotally, this denial can be seen in the refusal of investors even to open their brokerage and mutual fund account statements. More quantitatively, it is evident in the personal savings rate, which remains at a rock-bottom 3.1 percent. The rate normally rises as household wealth drops.
Mr. Hatzius said the current saving rate indicates that consumers are still counting on capital gains to augment what they are socking away in the bank or the mattress. They are not alone; companies that should know better -- I.B.M., for example -- are assuming 9.5 percent returns in their pension plans this year.
Once consumers realize that the stock market will no longer bolster their savings, they will rein in spending and start setting aside more income. That will be a big negative for consumer spending, the only area of the economy that has been strong.
Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley, believes that further job cuts and softening home prices will force consumers to face reality. "Consumers who are savings-short and overly indebted are going to have to pull back and it's going to be a multiyear retrenchment," he said.
Household debt is now at 75 percent of gross domestic product, a record. And debt service as a ratio of disposable income stands at 14 percent, just below the all-time high of 14.3 percent recorded late last year. 
With consumer debt off the charts, Mr. Roach said he was "pretty appalled" by Mr. Greenspan's recent testimony. "He said that we can keep the consumer afloat by helping him extract equity from his home to finance expenditures," Mr. Roach said. "With the real economic reverberations of the popped equity bubble just starting to sink in, the Fed seems more than willing to risk inflating another bubble in order to temper the distress."
Perhaps the housing bubble has helped consumers take the stock market's carnage so stoically. If so, what bubble will emerge to calm them when housing prices fall?

HEADLINE: Business; 
Far From Wall St., Martha Stewart Is Thriving

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
MARTHA STEWART's poster visage beckons Japanese shoppers into her new boutique off the Ginza, and a steady flow of women enter to explore a world of glue guns, towels in 24 colors and gardening tools stamped MS.
 A world away from an investigation into accusations of insider trading, the voice of Ms. Stewart booms from a video monitor in the store. Ms. Stewart, the one-woman brand of American home fashion, gently if somewhat hypnotically commands shoppers in English (with Japanese subtitles): "Coordinate the bedroom, coordinate the bathroom, coordinate the kitchen." 
 Judging by the flashing digital cash registers of Japan, American business scandals, like political fights, can stop at water's edge. 
In its first overseas expansion, Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia has entered 226 Seiyu department stores with Ms. Stewart's brand-name products, and sales are on target to meet the first-year goal of $11 million a month, double the rate of the first six months of sales, through March. The 164-page August issue of "Martha," a glossy, nine-month-old magazine in Japanese, is full of advertisements and is nearly as thick as its 11-year-old American parent magazine. Completing the link of media and merchandise, the Shop Channel, a cable network, sells "Martha by Mail" bath and kitchen products, and the "Martha Stewart Living" program, dubbed in Japanese, appears four times daily on other television channels.
Japan is proving so welcoming to Martha Stewart and her homemaking makeovers that she is now studying expansion to South Korea and Australia, said Sharon Patrick, president and chief operating officer of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, in a telephone interview.
Business was not dented by tiny articles in Japanese newspapers about accusations that Ms. Stewart had benefited from insider knowledge to unload shares of ImClone Systems just before they tumbled last December. Ms. Stewart has denied wrongdoing.
In Japan, Ms. Patrick said, "sales are where they are expected." Addressing the stock trading, she added, "In an odd way, it brings more of the subject of Martha and the products into the limelight."
The Japanese may be indifferent to the scandal because Ms. Stewart is not a household name here -- at least not yet. She may also be benefiting from Japanese society's elevation of domesticity to a high art form. And insider trading does not carry the same stigma in Japan that it does in the United States. Many Japanese equate any type of investing in stocks with gambling.
"I was disappointed a little, but then I was not so surprised," Yuko Watanabe, 48, a homemaker and bead artist, said after buying three towels -- one light blue, one cream and one white -- at a Martha Stewart store here. "She is such an aggressive businesswoman, and that kind of people have many sides to life. But that does not affect whether or not I buy Martha Stewart goods."
KUMI SATO, founder of the Web site Womenjapan.com, said "Women who are Martha Stewart shoppers could not care less about the scandal." Referring to Ms. Stewart's earlier Wall Street career, Ms. Sato added: "Either they don't understand it or they chalk it up to, 'she was a stockbroker.' "
The insider-trading accusations have not gone completely unnoticed. To some, they portray Ms. Stewart as an overreacher, a potentially fatal flaw in a society where modesty and harmony are prized by men and women alike.
"It ruins her appeal because you feel that she is a corporate executive, and what she is doing is making a profit, and that is leading her to the insider trading," said Ikuko Narusaka, 45, a homemaker and piano teacher. "It gives you the impression that she could do anything for profit."
In Japan, the basic question for Ms. Stewart is whether she can establish a lasting beachhead. Japan is a notoriously difficult retail environment, littered with the bones of larger foreign whales than her company.
Two discount retailers, the Carrefour Japan Company and Costco, are widely seen as struggling here. Recent foreign departures from Japan's retail scene include the Boots Company, a British drugstore operator, and Sephora, the French cosmetics chain owned by LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton. There are a few successes: Toys "R" Us Japan, which opened its first store here 13 years ago, now has 120 stores and is Japan's largest toy retailer.
Wal-Mart Stores, the world's largest retailer, has long studied Japan, the world's second-largest economy. This spring, Wal-Mart finally made its move, also picking Seiyu, Japan's seventh-largest retailer, as its partner. Wal-Mart will open some stores with Seiyu, a supermarket chain that also sells housewares, appliances and general merchandise. The name of the joint-venture stores will still be Seiyu.
Sales at Seiyu have declined for three years, partly because many Japanese consumers consider its range of goods too diffuse and opt to shop elsewhere. Wal-Mart is investing $46 million in the company and has an option to buy a controlling stake.
"General merchandise is weak in a supermarket like Seiyu," said Kazunori Tsuda, a retail analyst at the Daiwa Research Institute. "So they picked up Martha to recover the weakest part of the store."
The Martha Stewart stores are actually sections inside Seiyu stores, except for the Ginza store, which is in the same building as Muji, a retailer that is a Seiyu affiliate.
Executives of Seiyu declined to be interviewed, but Ms. Patrick called the company a conscientious "brand steward" for the 1,500 MS products it now carries. Noting that the Martha Stewart magazine already has a circulation of 100,000 in Japan, she said that "Seiyu thinks we are on target" to hit a merchandise sales goal of $135 million this year.
Royalty and licensing fees make Japan profitable for Martha Stewart, Ms. Patrick said, though she declined to say by how much. Seiyu is taking "the inventory risk," she said, so "we do not have a high risk profile for this venture."
The retail marriage of Ms. Stewart and Japan is working partly because Ms. Stewart, 60, has long had a genuine fascination with Japan and its food, gardens and home furnishings. Over the last two decades, she has traveled to Japan at least 20 times, acquaintances say. A frequent visitor to the huge Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo, she has filmed culinary television programs there with Nobuyuki Matsuhisa, the celebrity chef-owner of the Nobu restaurant chain.
Momoko Sano, the Martha Stewart brand manager here, said, "In her house, she has a Japanese teapot, Japanese plates, Japanese fabrics, Japanese lacquerware -- she loves Japanese lacquerware." Ms. Sano got to know Ms. Stewart in the late 1980's, helping her edit and translate her book on weddings into Japanese. Before starting her businesses in Japan, Ms. Stewart had several best-selling books here.
On Sept. 11, Ms. Stewart was in Tokyo. After inaugurating the Ginza store and holding a party to introduce her magazine, she returned that night to her hotel.
"Martha turned on the television in her hotel room, and I heard her scream," Ms. Patrick recalled. "I was across the hall and I ran out, and there it was on CNN -- the twin towers."
Stranded because trans-Pacific flights were suspended, Ms. Stewart retreated to her favorite Japanese city, Kyoto, where she visited temples and gardens. Four months ago, she was back in the Kyoto area. "We visited the Miho Museum outside of Kyoto, where we walked through a most fragrant grove of Ume trees, blossoming in white and pink and red blossoms," she recounted in her April magazine column, "A Letter from Martha." "On Friday, I started my day very early, visiting my favorite store, Aritsugu Knife Shop in Nishiki."
She concluded: "I could have stayed weeks longer, traveling, looking, investigating. I long to understand more about Japanese ways and Japanese lifestyle."
This sensitivity to Japan contributes to the appeal of her products here. About 90 percent of those on sale through Seiyu have been "Japanized," either by adjusting for color preferences or by reducing their size to fit Japanese bodies and houses, which are generally smaller than Americans'.
But Ms. Stewart's products also come in colors not often seen in Japan, where tones of burgundy and blue dominate. "That is not us," Ms. Patrick said. "We are warmer and lighter, more toward pastels."
ON a recent afternoon, Toshiko Otani paused outside the Ginza store, holding a pastel-green Martha Stewart shopping bag. "I like the variety and colors of the towels," said Mrs. Otani, opening her bag to show three hand towels, one a blush of pink, one light yellow and the other lime green. "The prices were appropriate, too."
Economic growth in Japan pretty much stopped about a decade ago. An increase in unemployment has weakened consumer demand and made shoppers more price-conscious. According to Seiyu, Martha Stewart's best-selling products in Japan include fleece bedroom slippers at 557 yen, or about $4.64, a decorative toilet mat at $15.04 and a bath towel at $7.84. Other towels go for $3.20 and glasses for $5.70.
Societal changes may also help Ms. Stewart make the trans-Pacific leap permanent.
"Young people are interested in interior decoration, so the timing is right," said Kyoko Michisita, a book translator who visited the Ginza store out of curiosity after having translated two of Ms. Stewart's columns. "There is a strong trend among young couples toward choosing a table they like, choosing a dish they like."
Ms. Watanabe, the bead artist, said Ms. Stewart's expansion here coincided with a trend toward increasingly Westernized homes among affluent Japanese.
"Martha Stewart goods can be easily accepted into Japanese households because many Japanese homes, including mine, are not so Japanese in taste anymore," Ms. Watanabe said. She followed Ms. Stewart's television-show advice, she said, about how to coordinate the colors of her flowers and how to paint leaves on ceramic tableware.
"We remodeled tatami mat rooms into Western-style rooms," she said, referring to rooms covered with traditional straw mats. "We have Spanish furniture. When I make some Japanese traditional ornaments at New Year's or some seasonal occasions, my son says: 'It does not match our house.' "

HEADLINE: Stocks Are Only Part of the Story 

BYLINE:  By Alan S. Blinder; Alan S. Blinder, former vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, is a professor of economics at Princeton.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J. 

 BODY:
King Canute could not command the tides, and apparently neither George W. Bush nor Alan Greenspan can command the stock market. In recent days, both the M.B.A. president and the oracular Federal Reserve chairman have tried to calm the markets with reassuring words about the economy. But the stock market has kept on falling: on Friday it had one of its worst days ever, losing 390 points. Since President Bush addressed Wall Street July 9, the Dow Jones industrial average has declined more than 10 percent, to its lowest level in almost four years.
 Those who get their economic news from television may come away with the impression that the economy and the stock market are two sides of the same coin. If the market is heading south, then the economy must be, too. But it's not true. 
 The United States economy is most emphatically not falling right now. The stock market may be the TV star. But it is the economy that generates the jobs and puts the food on our tables. And fortunately, the economy is doing much better than the market. If you want to bolster your confidence, turn off your TV and drive to the mall.
Normally, the economy and the market move consistently, though certainly not in lock step. The reasons are clear. A strong economy generates high and rising corporate profits, which is the traditional basis for high stock values. A rising stock market also gives the economy a boost by creating wealth for consumers and by making it easier for firms to raise capital, both of which were major factors in the boom of the 1990's. When things turn downward, all these mechanisms get reversed: a sagging economy drags profits and stock prices down, and a sagging stock market slows the economy.
Finally, because investors are supposed to look forward, the stock market should be a leading indicator of where the economy is going. And it is -- to a limited extent.
But while it is normal for the economy and the markets to move together, the two sometimes go their separate ways. For example, the Dow fell almost as much, in percentage terms, on a single day in October 1987 than it has in the entire recent bear market. But the economy kept growing strongly. It was such behavior that led to the economist Paul Samuelson's famous quip that the stock market has forecast nine of the last five recessions.
So it would be a mistake to interpret the stock market's current woes as a forecast of a double-dip recession -- a mistake that Alan Greenspan is certainly not making.
Consumers are spending, the housing market remains buoyant, and even business investment is coming back. The economic indicators are simply not signaling a sick economy. The gross domestic product grew at a 6.1 percent annual rate in the first quarter of this year, and something like 2.5 percent is expected for the second quarter. (The Commerce Department will announce the final figures at the end of the month.) That would clock the average growth for the first half at 4.3 percent -- not bad. The Federal Reserve expects growth of about 3 percent in the second half of this year, and the consensus among private forecasters is a bit higher.
It is true that economic forecasting is an imprecise science, to say the least. But it is far more accurate than market forecasting, which is basically impossible. And economic forecasts like this, coming from a wide variety of sources inside and outside government, should give us some comfort that the economy is heading uphill.
So why, then, is the stock market in shambles? While the market never tells you why it does what it does, it's unlikely that worries about the economy are weighing it down. Instead, the best guess is that the stream of scandalous corporate revelations is taking a heavy toll on stock prices, and investors fear there is more to come. Confidence in the earnings reports of American companies, not to mention the ratings of the analysts who follow them, has been damaged if not destroyed.
The key question is whether this illness will be confined to the stock market or spread to the larger economy. If the stock market destroys enough wealth, or if the depressive psychology infects the credit markets, the financial turmoil could become severe enough to damage the economy. The tail could drag down the dog. That is why we must stop the market's downward spiral.
But how? Words, if chosen artfully, may help a bit. But talk is cheap -- which may be why the markets shrugged off even the reassuring words of Mr. Greenspan, their most trusted guru. This just may be one of those moments when both the markets and the body politic are calling for action, some of which must be government action.
Can it be true that financial markets want the government to regulate them more? Paradoxically, the answer is yes. The markets have long had an ambivalent attitude toward government intervention. When things go well, they want to be left alone. But when things start to fall apart, they want Washington's help.
The reaction to President Bush's recent speeches was instructive. If Wall Street were truly opposed to government help, one might have thought that market participants would have breathed a sigh of relief: the president spoke loudly but carried a small stick. Instead, stock prices tanked.
There is a message here. Congress hears it, and even Mr. Greenspan -- who is not normally a proponent of government regulation -- hears it. But does President Bush hear it? The message is this: While changes in private-sector behavior will eventually fix many of today's accounting and corporate governance problems, the markets are clamoring for decisive government actions now.
Speeches have not worked. It is time to see if actions will speak louder than words.

HEADLINE: The Confidence Crisis 

 BODY:
Wall Street's alarming dive in recent weeks, capped by the 390-point drop in the Dow on Friday, may just be another example of the irrationality that can sometimes grip the markets. The recovery, after all, has been progressing fairly well, and Alan Greenspan advised Congress last week that the economic outlook was reasonably promising. But economic fundamentals are being overrun by a host of uncertainties, which begin with doubt about America's corporate elite and end with concern about shaky leadership in Washington.
 Although investors, watching their assets and retirement funds vanish, may wish that the Bush administration could end the market slide with a snap of the finger, everyone knows capitalism does not work that way. The president cannot simply add Wall Street bears to his list of evildoers and declare war on plunging equity prices. Still, it's hard to imagine an administration in a worse position to deal with the crisis of confidence in American business. Mr. Bush himself is a product of the cowboy end of the Sunbelt economy, and if Americans look at him and see the shadow of Enron ethics and WorldCom accounting, his effectiveness as chief executive will be undermined. 
 Yet so far, Mr. Bush has done little to separate himself from the excesses of some of his friends and campaign contributors. Vice President Dick Cheney continues to be mum about his role as chief executive of Halliburton. The secretary of the Army continues to be a former Enron executive whose attempts to vindicate his behavior as a businessman have been more embarrassing than convincing. The Securities and Exchange Commission continues to be run by the former lawyer for the accounting industry. Mr. Bush is a man who believes strongly in loyalty, and who as a result is able to run a White House that benefits from an extremely low level of public squabbling. But his current intransigence is not good for his administration or the nation.
The markets will not right themselves just because Army Secretary Thomas White is tossed to the dogs or the vice president finally agrees to discuss his business career. But Wall Street would certainly be soothed by some sign that Mr. Bush is firmly in control. The most chilling result in last week's New York Times/CBS News Poll was that 45 percent of the respondents said they thought "other people are really running the government" -- exactly the same percentage as said the president was in charge. That is no way to run a White House when the nation's worst domestic problem is a lack of confidence in its economic and political leaders.
It has been repeatedly noted that Mr. Bush's economics team, led by Treasury Secretary Paul O'Neill and the chief economic adviser Lawrence Lindsey, does not have the stature that his foreign affairs advisers enjoy, or that Robert Rubin had when he held Mr. O'Neill's job. The very fact that everybody keeps saying it is one of the problems. When the public believes that an administration's underlings are really in charge, that administration is the last one that can afford to have lightweights in those positions.
Mr. Bush continues to enjoy the good will of the American people, but that will never be enough to stabilize the markets, especially if good will seems based in part on the perception that he is not really running the store. It is time for him to show that he's in control -- by directing Mr. Cheney to talk about his financial past, by getting rid of obvious sore thumbs like Mr. White and by replacing appointees like Harvey Pitt at the S.E.C. with strong figures who have the confidence of the business community.

HEADLINE: Word for Word/'Greenspan Shrugged'; 
When Greed Was a Virtue And Regulation the Enemy

BYLINE:  By BILL GOLDSTEIN 

 BODY:
IN 1996, he questioned the "irrational exuberance" of the American investor. Last Tuesday, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, brought that era to a definitive end with his diagnosis that "an infectious greed seemed to grip much of our business community." Acknowledging he was wrong in his long-held belief that the government should not regulate the accounting industry, Mr. Greenspan also said: "It is not that humans have become any more greedy than in generations past. It is that the avenues to express greed had grown so enormously."
 Mr. Greenspan's embrace of greater regulation is a remarkable turnaround for an economist who for many years was a close friend and colleague of Ayn Rand, the high priestess of unfettered capitalism, who fulminated against the ideas Mr. Greenspan now espouses. In the early 1950's, while in his 20's, Mr. Greenspan was a member of Rand's inner circle (they called themselves the Collective), and was among those who read her influential 1957 novel, "Atlas Shrugged," in manuscript. It was written, Rand once said, "to glorify the real kind of productive, free-enterprise businessman in a way he has never been glorified before." But, she added, "I make mincemeat out of the kind of businessman . . . that runs to government for assistance, subsidies, legislation and regulation." 
 Forty-five years after the publication of her magnum opus, which Rand herself compared to the Bible, greed apparently represents a greater danger to capitalism than government bureaucrats. But back then neither Mr. Greenspan nor Rand seemed to have envisioned the unethical behavior of some of today's captains of industry. Excerpts follow from Rand's work and from a 1963 essay written by Mr. Greenspan for The Objectivist Newsletter, which was devoted to Rand's philosophy. BILL GOLDSTEIN
In Mr. Greenspan's essay, titled "The Assault on Integrity," he wrote at length about the functioning of a healthy free-enterprise system and the perils of regulation. (Years later, however, in a profile in The New Yorker, a colleague recounted his warning "to distinguish carefully between what he believes personally and how he acts as chairman of the Fed.")
Protection of the consumer against "dishonest and so-called unscrupulous business practices" has become a cardinal ingredient of welfare statism. Left to their own devices, it is alleged, businessmen would attempt to sell unsafe food and drugs, fraudulent securities, and shoddy buildings. Thus, it is argued, the Pure Food and Drug Administration, the Securities and Exchange Commission and the numerous building regulatory agencies are indispensable if the consumer is to be protected from the "greed" of the businessman.
But it is precisely the "greed" of the businessman or, more appropriately, his profit-seeking, which is the unexcelled protector of the consumer. . . .
What collectivists refuse to recognize is that it is in the self-interest of every businessman to have a reputation for honest dealings and a quality product. . . . Thus the incentive to scrupulous performance operates on all levels of a given field of production. It is a built-in safeguard of a free enterprise system and the only real protection of consumers against business dishonesty.
Actually, Mr. Greenspan wrote, a greater threat to a free-market economy with no barriers to ambition or achievement was posed by the government. 
Government regulation is not an alternative means of protecting the consumer. It does not build quality into goods, or accuracy into information. Its sole "contribution" is to substitute force and fear for incentive as the "protector" of the consumer. The euphemism of government press releases to the contrary notwithstanding, the basis of regulation is armed force. At the bottom of the endless pile of paper work which characterizes all regulation lies a gun. . . .
Protective legislation falls into the category of preventive law. Businessmen are being subjected to governmental coercion prior to the commission of any crime. In a free economy, the government may step in only when a fraud has been perpetrated, or a demonstrable damage has been done to a consumer; in such cases the only protection required is that of criminal law.
Mr. Greenspan's essay was reprinted in 1966 in "Capitalism: The Unknown Ideal," together with Rand's operatic articulation of some of her views, titled "America's Persecuted Minority: Big Business":
If a small group of men were always regarded as guilty, in any clash with any other group, regardless of the issues or circumstances involved, would you call it persecution? If this group were always made to pay for the sins, errors, or failures of any other group, would you call that persecution? If this group had to live under a silent reign of terror, under special laws, from which all other people were immune, laws which the accused could not grasp or define in advance and which the accuser could interpret in any way he pleased -- would you call that persecution? If this group were penalized, not for its faults, but for its virtues, not for its incompetence, but for its ability, not for its failures, but for its achievements, and the greater the achievement, the greater the penalty -- would you call that persecution?
If your answer is "yes" -- then ask yourself what sort of monstrous injustice you are condoning, supporting, or perpetuating. That group is the American businessman. . . .
Every movement that seeks to enslave a country, every dictatorship or potential dictatorship, needs some minority group as a scapegoat which it can blame for the nation's troubles and use as a justification of its own demands for dictatorial powers. In Soviet Russia, the scapegoat was the bourgeoisie; in Nazi Germany, it was the Jewish people; in America, it is the businessman. 
The hero of "Atlas Shrugged," John Galt, maintained that executives who commit fraud betray their own highest values:
Honesty is the recognition of the fact that the unreal is unreal and can have no value, that neither love nor fame nor cash is a value if obtained by fraud -- that an attempt to gain a value by deceiving the mind of others is an act of raising your victim to a position higher than reality, where you become a pawn of their blindness, a slave of their nonthinking and their evasions, while their intelligence, their rationality, their perceptiveness become the enemies you have to dread and flee.
For his part, Mr. Greenspan argued in 1963 that moral values "are the motive power of capitalism":
Capitalism is based on self-interest and self-esteem; it holds integrity and trustworthiness as cardinal virtues and makes them pay off in the marketplace, thus demanding that men survive by means of virtues, not of vices. It is this superlatively moral system that the welfare statists propose to improve upon by means of preventative law, snooping bureaucrats, and the chronic goad of fear.
Rand, of course, also had plenty to say about virtue and integrity, as in this 1944 letter to a friend who asked for advice on how to meet "a worthwhile woman":
One finds worthwhile men and women among people who work. Follow me here very carefully, forgetting the cheap generalities which all our modern minds have been stuffed with. I do not mean LABOR. I do not mean people who have to earn their living. I do not mean proletarians. . . . I mean what you and I understand by the term "competent people." People who love to work, who are good at it, serious about it and concerned primarily with it. Bright, creative, productive, ambitious people. People who get money for their work, but who do not work primarily for the money -- whether it's a weekly pay envelope or a thousand dollar bonus. People who are ambitious -- not to climb socially, not to get wealth and titles -- but ambitious to do more and more work of a better and better kind. . . .
In a general way, that is the advice I'd give you: look for places where sincere people are working hard -- and go there. Choose by the nature of the work. Going incognito into a convention of ditch diggers would do you as little good as going to the swankiest Wall Street party.

HEADLINE: Wary Eye on Wall St. and Washington 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Not long ago, United States investors were true believers. They trusted corporate executives to be truthful about their companies' performance and prospects. They felt sure that the stock market was the only path to a prosperous future. And they trusted Alan Greenspan to steer the economy through any storm.
 But by the end of last week, the investor trust on which the bull market of the 1990's had been founded seemed to have almost entirely vanished. As the Dow Jones industrial average careened to a loss of almost 400 points by the close of trading on Friday, it became clear that many investors may have finally stopped believing. 
 Thanks to Enron, WorldCom, Global Crossing and Tyco, confidence in corporate executives and the validity of their companies' earnings is gone.
And with trillions of dollars in lost stock market wealth, so is the trust in company shares as the way to a comfortable retirement.
After Mr. Greenspan's testimony in Congress last week, investors' faith in him suffered some severe slippage.
This, market strategists say, is what a stock bubble looks like after it has popped. Unfortunately, economists add, the stock decline is so bad that it now threatens to weaken the economy's last pillar of strength: consumer spending. If consumers shut their wallets, hope for an economic recovery goes out the window.
"I don't think we've got an awful lot of problems in the economy," said Alan Kral, portfolio manager at Trevor Stewart Burton & Jacobsen in New York. "But we could if we totally undermine consumer confidence by knocking down the market."
A good hard knock is certainly what the market took on Friday. The Dow Jones industrial average lost almost 5 percent for the day and fell 7.7 percent for the week.
According to Thomas McManus, chief United States strategist at Banc of America Securities in New York, $6.7 trillion has been lost in stocks since the peak in March 2000. 
This wealth destruction has finally begun to register with investors who, until recently, were holding onto their falling stock positions with an admirable stoicism. "Confidence has been pretty beat up," Mr. McManus said. "I think it's pretty clear there are going to be more ugly revelations at companies. I think there's a chance that there will be some investors who have such a bad experience that they will never want to touch stocks again. The pressure is going to be greatest for the people who got in late because they are the ones who are looking at this as a really disastrous move."
What economists fear most is that investor losses will translate to a slowdown, or worse, in consumer spending. While corporate spending has been nonexistent for months, consumers have kept their wallets open. Low interest rates and surging home prices have encouraged them. 
But as consumers recognize the extent to which the falling stock market has decimated their retirement accounts or their children's college savings plans, their spending may come to a halt. If corporations make additional rounds of job cuts, this possibility may become a reality. 
"The really big risk is that consumers will reawaken to the timeless truth that the best way to save money is to stop spending," said Richard Hastings, chief economist at Cyber Business Credit, a retail advisory firm in New York. "And I think that will impact aggregate demand in a way that has not been seen since the 1930's."
Economists at Goldman, Sachs, for example, say that weakness in consumer spending will curb economic growth not only for the remainder of this year, but well into 2003. As a result, the firm recently lowered its estimates for gross domestic product growth to 2.5 percent this year and 2.8 percent in the next.
"My feeling is the stock market is telling us something about the economy," said James Paulsen, chief investment officer at Wells Capital Management in Minneapolis. "That the economy is going to be really bad for the rest of the year. I also think what it's telling us is the consumer is going to get close to capitulation in the second half."
It wasn't supposed to be this way. After a year and a half of interest rate cuts, the economy was supposed to be chugging along. Investors were told over and over again that six months after the Federal Reserve began cutting rates, stock prices were always higher. Instead, corporations are struggling with profits, the stock market is making new lows and the economic data are weak.
Apart from doubts about whether corporate financial statements are reliable, many investors still believe that the broad market is overvalued in relation to actual profits. Many of them are staying on the sidelines until they see a turnaround in profits, which remain under pressure. 
With economic weakness still weighing on the market, investors are beginning to doubt Mr. Greenspan and his control over the economy. Indeed, one of the biggest shifts that market strategists sensed last week among investors was a diminished trust in the Fed chairman.
Throughout the two years since the stock market peaked, investors have viewed Mr. Greenspan with something approaching awe. Now they are wondering if he can do anything to stop the market's slide. 
"Greenspan did not have his typical calming moments in front of Congress," Mr. Kral, the portfolio manager, said of his testimony last week. "He came away looking like a follower in the marketplace, not a leader. And that undermined some people's conviction with regard to the market's direction."
As they begin to wonder about Mr. Greenspan's power, investors' fears can only escalate. "Behind this downward move is a Fed impotency panic," said Mr. Paulsen. "What's the catalyst that can turn the market around? Usually it's the Fed." But he added that investors seem to be so anxious these days that if the Fed moved, it might scare investors even more, if temporarily.
Many investment strategists think that investors are spending the weekend sorting through their fears of what the coming weeks might bring. These ruminations may results in further selling on Monday. As Mr. McManus pointed out, markets rarely hit their lows on Fridays.

 INTERNATIONAL 3-12

U.S. Errors in Attacks Killed Hundreds of Afghans
The American air campaign in Afghanistan, based on a high-tech, out-of-harm's way strategy, has produced a pattern of mistakes that has killed hundreds of Afghan civilians. On-site reviews of 11 airstrikes that left as many as 400 civilians dead suggests that American commanders have sometimes relied on mistaken information from local Afghans. Also, the Americans' preference for airstrikes instead of riskier ground operations has made it harder to discover when intelligence is wrong. 1

Talks With India and Pakistan
The British foreign secretary, Jack Straw, went to Pakistan and India hoping to contain a recent rise in tension over the disputed region of Kashmir, and he said afterward that he was "happy" with the discussions so far. Mr. Straw admits progress, but said that "more needs to be done." 6
