HEADLINE: Con Edison Braces For Hot Workday After Fire at Plant 

BYLINE:  By SARAH KERSHAW 

 BODY:
New York City officials are urging Con Ed customers across a large section of Lower Manhattan to use electricity sparingly today in an effort to prevent a power failure in the wake of Saturday's major explosion and fire at an electrical transformer on the East River.
 Consolidated Edison officials said yesterday that its East River Generation Station, on 14th Street and Avenue C, was prepared to deliver enough power to its roughly 63,000 customers in the affected area, from 14th Street to the Battery, west of Broadway. 
 Most workers are returning to the area today for the first time since an explosion rocked the power plant shortly after noon on Saturday, spewing acrid black smoke, sending orange flames 30 to 40 feet in the air, and cutting power to 63,500 customers south of 14th Street for eight hours. Temperatures today are expected to be in the 90's in New York, with high humidity, a combination that can strain the power grid even when it is not compromised. 
Con Ed officials said the fire was sparked by an arc of electricity created by a short-circuit in the East River plant. But the cause of the short-circuit was not known. 
"It's going to be some time before we can really piece together the specific scenario of what happened, what failed first, what wires were damaged," said Louis L. Rana, vice president for Con Ed's electrical operations in Manhattan. "It's actually a very complex issue."
Mr. Rana described the damage to the plant as "massive." The transformer and the surrounding steel electrical connections -- some of which grew so hot during the fire that they melted and "vaporized" -- were severely damaged.
City officials said they had not yet estimated the economic losses that businesses in Battery Park City, TriBeCa, SoHo and the West Village -- already reeling from the effects of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack -- suffered from the blackout.
The three-alarm fire, one of the most serious electrical blazes in city history, also disrupted subway service in Manhattan. The fire was brought under control within several hours, and most electrical and subway service was restored by Saturday evening, although some Con Ed customers reported sporadic power failures yesterday.
Mr. Rana said that by yesterday afternoon, Con Ed workers had repaired or replaced six of the seven underground cables that run electricity from the 69,000-volt plant to two substations on the Lower West Side.
"I'm confident the day will go smoothly for downtown Manhattan," he said when asked if power failures related to the transformer fire were expected today. "But we are still asking customers to use energy wisely and to conserve."
The city also has in place a set of contingency plans should another power failure occur, said Michael Dendekkera, a spokesman for the city's Office of Emergency Management. The plans include using mobile electricity generators, setting up "cooling centers" outside the area of a blackout, and monitoring hospitals and buildings taller than six stories, many of which rely on electricity to pump water from tanks into the upper floors of apartments.
The Office of Emergency Management urged residents and businesses to limit their use of "nonessential" appliances and electronic equipment. Con Ed, which has posted energy-saving tips on its Web Site, www.coned.com, encourages customers to set their air-conditioners and thermostats at 78 degrees and notes that fans use much less electricity than air-conditioners.
After initial fears that a terrorist attack might be to blame for Saturday's transformer explosion, city and Con Ed officials quickly ruled that it was an accident. They said the plant was not under especially heavy strain because Saturday was not particularly hot for mid-July and the weekend demand for power is 20 percent less than that of weekdays. 
Saturday's power failure was the third in a week in the city and was by far the most serious -- not counting Sept. 11, when a substation in 7 World Trade Center was destroyed -- since a 1999 blackout in Washington Heights and Inwood.
And it came at a time when utilities in the New York region are bracing for the specter of serious power failures because demand is higher than anticipated. 
The owners of Aquagrill, a trendy restaurant on Spring Street in SoHo, said yesterday that they were still without Con Ed power and were using a mobile generator, which they were renting for $2,000 a day, to power the refrigerators, lights and air-conditioners at their establishment.
The owners, Jennifer and Jeremy Marshall, said that they first lost power on Thursday night, when the second electrical failure of last week knocked out power to the Avenue of the Americas and Spring Street, causing subway service disruptions that lasted into Friday morning. (The first failure occurred Tuesday night, when power along the A and C subway lines, between Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, and Lower Manhattan, was out for about two and a half hours.) 
Their power was restored Saturday morning, the Marshalls said, only to be lost later in the day after the explosion at the East River plant. 
After the blackout that crippled Upper Manhattan in July 1999, the city sued Con Ed, saying that the utility had failed to properly design and maintain the network of cables that distributed electricity to the area.
Rudolph W. Giuliani, who as mayor often criticized Con Ed, said at the time that the company had cost the city millions of dollars for the extra police officers, firefighters and other city employees working during the 18-hour blackout. 
But a spokesman for Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that Mr. Bloomberg, who went to a command center near the East River plant on Saturday but made no public appearances yesterday, was "pleased" with the utility's response to the latest problem.

HEADLINE: WORLDCOM'S COLLAPSE: THE OVERVIEW; 
WORLDCOM FILES FOR BANKRUPTCY; LARGEST U.S. CASE

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO and RIVA D. ATLAS 

 BODY:
WorldCom, plagued by the rapid erosion of its profits and an accounting scandal that created billions in illusory earnings, last night submitted the largest bankruptcy filing in United States history.
 The bankruptcy is expected to shake an already wobbling telecommunications industry, but is unlikely to have an immediate impact on customers, including the 20 million users of its MCI long-distance service. 
 The WorldCom filing listed more than $107 billion in assets, far surpassing those of Enron, which filed for bankruptcy last December. The WorldCom filing had been anticipated since the company disclosed in late June that it had improperly accounted for more than $3.8 billion of expenses. 
Few experts or officials expect WorldCom's service to deteriorate noticeably, at least in the near term. "I want to assure the public that we do not believe this bankruptcy filing will lead to an immediate disruption of service to consumers," Michael K. Powell, chairman of the Federal Communciations Commission, said last night.
But industry consultants said they could not imagine how the belt-tightening expected in bankruptcy would improve service that is already, in some respects, sloppy. Page A12. 
WorldCom's collapse has already reverberated through jittery financial markets, and is likely to be felt in the wider economy, with banks, suppliers and other telephone companies devising strategies to contain their exposure.
WorldCom, built through rapid acquisitions, accumulated $41 billion in debts. Founded in 1983 as LDDS Communications, it became the nation's second-largest long-distance company and the largest handler of Internet data.
Company executives said they intended to remain in business, and have been promised new financing from banks to do so. "We are going to aggressively go forward and restructure our operations," John W. Sidgmore, WorldCom's chief executive, said in an interview last night. "I think ultimately we will emerge as a stronger company."
While WorldCom has already cut its work force significantly, Mr. Sidgmore said last night that he did not expect further layoffs for the time being. He said he would remain WorldCom's chief but would be joined by a chief restructuring officer brought in by creditors.
Some creditors, however, have questioned whether Mr. Sidgmore, who has served on WorldCom's board for years, should remain in charge. Mr. Sidgmore took over as chief executive in late April after the board ousted Bernard J. Ebbers, one of the company's founders.
Shareholders, who owned what was once one of the world's most valuable companies, worth more than $100 billion at its peak, are expected to be virtually wiped out. With the bankruptcy filing, control passes instead to the banks and bondholders who financed WorldCom's growth.
Besides its own overambitious strategies and flawed accounting, WorldCom also fell victim to a glut of telecommunications capacity. 
Cheap and plentiful financing allowed companies rapidly to build transcontinental and transoceanic fiber optic networks in the 1990's. The additional capacity resulted in lower prices for WorldCom's services, which include basic phone service and the transmission of Internet data for large companies.
Mr. Sidgmore said last night that he was opposed to breaking up WorldCom and selling its pieces, aside from an effort already under way to part with peripheral units like businesses in Latin America and some other operations. This approach would rule out selling UUNet, a large Internet backbone operation, or MCI.
But once the company reorganizes, and investors gain a better understanding of its twisted finances, WorldCom could become an attractive acquisition target, analysts say.
WorldCom's crisis deepened last month when it disclosed that Scott D. Sullivan, the chief financial officer, had devised a strategy that improperly accounted for $3.85 billion of expenses. Mr. Sullivan was fired by the board and David F. Myers, the financial controller, resigned.
The Securities and Exchange Commission has charged WorldCom with fraud and the Justice Department has begun a criminal investigation of its business practices. 
In an attempt to regain its credibility, WorldCom's board elected two new members to replace Mr. Sullivan and Mr. Ebbers: Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, a private attorney who was attorney general in the Johnson administration; and Dennis R. Beresford, a former head of the Financial Accounting Standards Board and a professor of accounting at the Terry College of Business at the University of Georgia.
The two were also appointed to a special committee to oversee the internal investigation being led by William R. McLucas, the former chief of the enforcement division of the S.E.C. 
WorldCom filed for bankruptcy shortly before 9 last night in Federal District Court in Manhattan.
Its international operations, which include companies in Brazil and Mexico, were not included. 
The filing will relieve WorldCom of about $2 billion of interest payments in the coming year. Lower debt costs could allow WorldCom to compete on a stronger footing with its rivals, involving a potential price-cutting strategy that has analysts concerned about the wider strength of the telecommunications industry.
"WorldCom probably won't get any new big contracts from its current customers, but it probably won't lose any either, because of the difficulty and complexity involved in switching carriers," said Glen Macdonald, a vice president with Adventis, a consulting firm in Boston. 
WorldCom, based in Clinton, Miss., scrambled in recent days to secure new financing from its banks after its cash dwindled to less than $300 million from more than $2 billion in May. WorldCom said last night that it had received commitments for up to $2 billion in additional bank financing. Such new loans to companies in bankruptcy receive top priority in repayment. 
WorldCom must now deal with holders of $28 billion in bonds as well as 27 banks that loaned the company $2.65 billion last May.
But in contrast with other companies that have recently filed for bankruptcy, including Enron, WorldCom has many more tangible assets, generating actual revenues, lawyers said -- improving the odds that the company could emerge from bankruptcy as a going concern.
The creditors first in line to be repaid will be the three institutions -- Citigroup, J. P. Morgan and General Electric Capital -- that have pledged to arrange a loan of up to $2 billion, known as debtor in possession financing, to WorldCom. The lenders were comfortable pledging the funds in part because of the company's stream of customer payments, such as phone bills, one executive close to the company said last week. Citigroup is leading the new financing in part to protect what it is already owed by WorldCom.
WorldCom's bankruptcy filing, like Enron's last December, came on a Sunday. Companies often prefer to file over the weekend, because the status of any business transactions in process at the time of a filing would be open to question in court. 
WorldCom's lenders and its bondholders were taking steps, even before the bankruptcy filing, to protect their claims. Just over a week ago, the banks that participated in the earlier $2.65 billion loan tried, unsuccessfully, to get a court order limiting WorldCom's access to the loan. The banks ultimately reached a settlement with WorldCom that placed few restrictions on the company's ability to use the cash.

HEADLINE: Talk of Rules for Accountants Is Matched by Campaign Gifts 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN

 BODY:
As accounting scandals roil the stock market and stimulate a wave of regulatory bills in Congress, New York State lawmakers have also begun to ponder ways to tighten oversight of accounting firms and eliminate potential conflicts of interest.
 At the same time, campaign finance reports filed last week show that the nation's biggest accounting firms began pouring more money than ever into the state's political races. The four firms left of what was once the Big Five -- Deloitte & Touche, Ernst & Young, PricewaterhouseCoopers and KPMG -- have given more than $350,000 to candidates and legislative fund-raising committees so far, up from $150,000 in the same period before the last governor's race, in 1998. 
 Of that $350,000, nearly half, $160,000, was contributed since Arthur Andersen went on trial in May for shredding documents. After WorldCom admitted a $3.8 billion overstatement of its cash flow in June, $73,500 streamed into state campaign chests in three days. 
"Their real concern, and indeed ours, is that New York not move out ahead of Washington," said Louis Grumet, the executive director of the New York State Society of Certified Public Accountants. Only New York and California are considering passing their own laws instead of waiting for reforms to wend their way through Congress.
The firms would not say if the New York proposals had motivated the contributions. None of the measures had moved beyond the incubation stage when the legislative session ended earlier this summer.
"We just don't discuss these matters," said Robert Zeitlinger, a spokesman for KPMG, which gave $50,000, less than the other three. A spokesman for PricewaterhouseCoopers referred questions to another executive, who did not return several calls. Neither did a spokesman for Deloitte & Touche. A spokesman for Ernst & Young, which along with its political action committee gave the most, $150,000, said he could not immediately explain the increase in donations. The lobbyist for the four firms, Kenneth L. Shapiro, did not return calls to his Albany office on Thursday and Friday.
Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky said that the donations were clearly an attempt to head off regulation. Mr. Brodsky is sponsoring two bills that are intended to prohibit accounting firms from practices like auditing companies that also hire them to do consulting.
"They are willing to go to any length to protect themselves no matter what the cost is," he said. "They didn't get civic-minded in June of 2002."
The biggest beneficiary of the new largess was Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican who is running for a third term. He has received nearly $100,000 from the four firms, most of it this year. In 1998, he received $35,000 before the election.
Asked about the contributions, the governor's campaign spokeswoman, Mollie Fullington, repeated what has become the campaign's stock response to questions about fund-raising: "We're pleased that the governor's proud, strong record of accomplishment for all New Yorkers has resonated with people of all walks of life."
The firms gave far less to Mr. Pataki's Democratic opponents. One of those men, Andrew M. Cuomo, received $10,000 from Ernst & Young. Another, H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller, received nothing from the firms, but his running mate, Dennis Mehiel, who is running for lieutenant governor, netted $15,000 from Deloitte & Touche.
Mr. McCall's fund-raising policy does not prohibit such contributions, said a spokesman, Steven Greenberg. "But, in light of what's going on, we have certainly not been seeking them, and we would scrutinize them very carefully," he said.
"As the accounting industry takes on a more and more negative presence," Mr. Greenberg added, "Governor Pataki takes more and more money from them." 
The firms took special note of Eliot L. Spitzer, the Democratic attorney general who has thrust himself into the Wall Street scandals with his investigation of Merrill Lynch and other investment banking firms. Each accounting firm paid $5,000 to attend a fund-raiser for Mr. Spitzer's re-election campaign where the United States Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle, was the host, said a spokesman for Mr. Spitzer, Darren Dopp.
"It's new money," Mr. Dopp said. "They had not donated to Mr. Spitzer before."
Mr. Dopp said that Mr. Spitzer was investigating investment firms because one responsibility of his office was to protect private investors, but that responsibility did not extend to oversight of accountants.
Much of the rest of the firms' donations have gone to committees that finance legislative races.
Mr. Brodsky, Democrat of Westchester, and State Senator Kenneth P. LaValle, Republican of Long Island, who has also introduced accounting oversight bills, said New York should lead the nation in accounting oversight because the state's economy depended so much on Wall Street. 
"I have no problem with New York law being tougher than federal law, because we're talking about restoring faith with the investing community," Senator LaValle said.
Both legislators said that an overhaul of the law was long overdue. Although the accounting profession has evolved considerably, the state regulates only accountants that work on financial statements, not those that provide tax preparations, consulting, financial planning or management advice.
The laws defining practices that are regulated have not been updated substantially since 1947, said Daniel Dustin, the executive secretary of the state board that oversees the profession.

HEADLINE: Investors Brace ForOpening Of New Week On Wall Street 

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Even for investors who lived through the bear market of the 1970's, the relentless slide of stocks since March has been deeply disturbing. When the markets open today, Wall Street will be on edge. 
 Markets rarely move in one direction, whether straight down or straight up. Yet for the last four months, stocks have plunged day after day, and week after week, climaxing with Friday's 390-point drop in the Dow Jones industrial average. 
 Optimistic comments about the economy from Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, and better-than-expected profit reports from some companies have not stopped the skid. Speeches by President Bush meant to reassure investors have instead seemed to frighten them.
But if history offers one certainty, it is that the slide will not go on forever, and investors who have the fortitude to step in just when the market looks its worst will probably be rewarded.
So what might stop the skid? Here are five possibilities: Stock buybacks, the Federal Reserve, the Bush administration, small investors and the market itself. 
After the crash of 1987, many companies announced plans to buy back their own stock, providing a strong signal that they thought that their shares were cheap. But in this downturn, the effect of buybacks has been more muted. Many companies already buy back shares regularly to offset the additional shares issued as a result of stock option grants they give employees, so announcements of buyback programs do not send as strong a message as they did 15 years ago.
To compensate, companies could expand their buyback plans. But buybacks eat up corporate cash, and when the debt markets are unsettled and the economy uncertain, many chief executives are wary of spending money if they do not have to do so.
Still, if stock prices continue to fall, expect to see more announcements of expanded buybacks and more executives buying their companies' stock in the market, rather than through options programs. Insider buying, if it happens, would be a strongly bullish signal.
The Federal Reserve can also help. When the Dow gained 400 points in the last 90 minutes of trading last Tuesday, the tight-knit community of hedge fund managers was filled with rumors that the Fed had somehow intervened to prop up stocks. The idea that the Fed had directly bought stocks is far-fetched, to say the least.
But the Fed does have at least three ways to support stocks indirectly. It can buy Treasury bonds and notes from banks, an action that puts more cash into the banking system. It can also lower short-term interest rates, a step that should help the economy by decreasing the cost of borrowing.
Lower rates might also encourage investors to take some of their savings out of money market funds and put them into stocks.
With the support of the Treasury Department, the Fed can also step into the currency markets to support the dollar, whose recent fall has been a burden on stocks.
But it is far from clear that the Fed thinks it needs to intervene. The sell-off has been orderly until now, and stocks are hardly trading at bargain levels. Mr. Greenspan may well view the downturn as painful but necessary to correct the speculative excesses of the bubble, and refrain from action as long as the plunge does not seem to be hurting the real economy.
The Bush administration -- including the president and his economic team -- have had little success so far in their efforts to restore confidence. Despite the federal government's rising budget deficit, the president's main economic priority appears to be making permanent a tax cut that was conceived during a surplus and would favor the richest Americans.
Paul H. O'Neill, the Treasury secretary, carries relatively little weight on Wall Street or in Washington.
Meanwhile, Harvey L. Pitt, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, has become the focus of scorn among many investors for his ties to the accounting industry at a time when corporate accounting is in its worst shape since before the S.E.C. was created. To many investors, Mr. Pitt appears to have been slow to grasp the seriousness of the problem, and some of them say his proposed reforms have been weak.
Wall Street might greet a change at the top of the S.E.C. or the Treasury Department as a sign of the president's great concern about the market's slide.
A wave of buying from small investors, either directly or through mutual funds, would also provide important short-term support.
But individuals appear increasingly panicked by the plunge. After buying funds almost every week between October and May, investors have sold shares for each of the last six weeks, and the redemptions are accelerating, said Thomas McManus of Banc of America Securities. For the week ending last Wednesday, investors sold $11 billion in stock funds.
As a result, instead of propping up the market, small investors appear to be worsening its slide, at least for the time being. 
In the short run, the best reason to expect a strong rally is the market itself. Stocks do not move one way forever. Most technical indicators, like the ratio of stocks falling to stocks rising, show the market is overdue for a sharp turn. 
The gains could be prompted by an unexpected piece of corporate or economic news, or they could simply come from investors who think that stocks have fallen too far, too fast, and that they are ready to turn.

HEADLINE: Europeans Split With U.S. on Need for Iraq Attack, Citing Mideast as Priority 

BYLINE:  By PATRICK E. TYLER 

DATELINE: LONDON, July 21 

 BODY:
The last thing Europe wants is to be accused of going wobbly on Iraq. 
 But the American talk of overthrowing Saddam Hussein by military force is raising alarms in European governments. 
 They are saying that any American miscalculation could undermine the international coalition that is fighting against terrorism, and the broad-based diplomacy needed to solve the crisis between Israel and the Palestinians. Also, they fear that a drive against Iraq would drive a wedge between Britain and the rest of Europe.
An exasperated French official said in an interview in Paris on Friday that some of President Bush's conservative aides have become "obsessed about Iraq, while we are obsessed about achieving peace" between Israelis and Palestinians. "The important thing is to build a coalition for peace in the Middle East, not to build a coalition for war in Iraq," he said. 
Washington's increasing talk of "regime change" is hindering diplomatic strategies to press Mr. Hussein to open his country again to United Nations inspectors searching for weapons of mass destruction, this official said. 
Those reports continued with a British newspaper report on Friday that Prime Minister Tony Blair is preparing for a significant call-up of military reserves in the fall and that he has pulled an armored division out of training exercises so it could be made available for special deployment later this year.
In the House of Commons, Mr. Blair said that Britain has gathered extensive evidence that "Saddam Hussein is still trying to develop weapons of mass destruction" and that Britain will publish the evidence "at the appropriate time." Last fall, the British government published the first detailed report that Osama bin Laden was directly linked to the Sept. 11 attacks on the United States, thus laying down an important predicate for the war in Afghanistan. 
There is a striking agreement in European capitals that Mr. Hussein's government is dangerous and may need to be confronted one day. But any agreement breaks down over strategic priorities in the Middle East, which Europeans consider neighboring territory for trade and security. With America the lone superpower, they are ever prickly over any hint that the United States is ignoring their views or assuming, as one German official said, "that we are Euro wimps" when it comes to the use of force.
The European Union's top security official, Javier Solana, warned in an interview of a "self-fulfilling prophecy" of war against Iraq. "If Saddam Hussein thinks that this option is inexorable, why would he yield to inspectors?" Mr. Solana said.
He said it would be "very, very difficult" to sustain allied support for an assault against Iraq unless progress is first made toward creating a Palestinian state.
The debate with Washington reminded The Economist magazine of Churchill's confidence that, "You can always rely on America to do the right thing, once it has exhausted the alternatives." The right thing, for Europe, is to concentrate first on getting Israelis and Palestinians to desist in a conflict that is roiling emotions and shaking governments across the Arab world.
One European leader said King Abdullah II of Jordan came to him "in tears" over recent reports that the Americans were thinking of attacking Iraq from Jordanian air bases at a time when Arab frustration with the lack of progress on the peace front is soaring. 
Besides the Middle East, Europeans point out that it is critical to achieve some stability in Afghanistan, where Western intervention has destroyed the Taliban, but has not assured that the interim government of Hamid Karzai will succeed as a stable replacement. 
"There is a lot of understanding of U.S. impatience vis a vis Iraq," said an adviser to Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany. "At the same time there is a tremendous amount of concern about anything that would destabilize the situation in the Middle East. Things are bad enough now and we don't need to worsen them." 
European leaders, as well as most Arab states, welcomed the meetings just held by Arab foreign ministers and Western governments on how to improve security for Israel against suicide bombers while at the same time moving toward negotiations that would realize the vision of a Palestinian state within three years. Yet this American-backed initiative is barely a first step and will require months of intensive diplomacy to generate real progress, officials said. 
"The timing is very narrow to get something going that changes the attitudes of Arab leaders and public opinion in the region," said Mr. Solana, especially if the United States wants to consider a military campaign in Iraq this winter. There is also the question of the Palestinian elections in January, he said. Would they take place during a buildup for war in Iraq and under Israeli occupation? 
"It's going to be very difficult to have elections under these conditions," he said. 
Interviews with officials in London, Paris and Berlin revealed striking agreement that the Israeli-Palestinian conflict represents the highest priority for Western governments, not only to end the carnage, but also to strengthen Western credibility in the face of the appeal of militant Muslims, who are exploiting the plight of the Palestinians to increase support for violence. 
Mr. Blair's government, the United States' closest ally, surprisingly distanced itself from Mr. Bush's call for the removal of the Palestinian leader, Yasir Arafat, saying that it would do business with whomever the Palestinians elect. A senior British official suggested that the United States should push harder for a peace agreement between Israel and the Palestinians because otherwise "it may not be possible" to build support for action in Iraq. 
"We need to get the show back on the road," he said, adding that "American energy" was essential to create the basis for new negotiations between Israelis and Palestinians. 
Britain, too, has distinguished its position on a change of government in Iraq from the Bush administration's. "We believe that regime change is desirable, but ending the threat of weapons of mass destruction is our objective -- getting the inspectors back in," the British official said. 
As for a possible military campaign, the official said that, "Obviously, planning is going on" and that European criticism of Britain's support for American military intervention would not affect British policy. 
"Nobody wants to go into a war, but sometimes you can't avoid it," the official said. "We'll look after our own interests and if others are not as a resolute as us, then they're not, but we are not going to change our position because of it." 
Britain's determination to remain shoulder to shoulder with the United States still leaves major questions hanging over the prospect of any campaign in Iraq.
In London, Paris and Berlin, the fundamental questions posed to Washington have been the same. Who would guarantee the territorial integrity of Iraq after a war? What government would replace Saddam Hussein's? Is America prepared to invade and occupy Iraq for a decade or more to protect a successor government from subversion and attack from Iraq's neighbors, Iran and Syria? Who would pay for the war? 
"The questions have been asked, but the answers have not been given," a French official said.
"We will be directly hurt if there would be a miscalculation," said the German foreign minister, Joschka Fischer, in an interview in Berlin.
He expressed doubt that Mr. Hussein represented a strategic threat to Western security and indicated that he was more concerned about the threat to European security from a new war in the region that might further inflame the passions of Arabs who want to see an end to the Israeli occupation of Palestinian territories. 
"Our people were hurt badly, wounded or burned to death, in Djerba," he said, referring to the German tourists who were victims of a truck bomb attack on a Tunisian island this spring.
"Millions of Germans," he added, "go to the Mediterranean summer and winter," and "we have millions of Muslim immigrants from the region." 
In the end, he said: "It is a decision of the United States. I mean this will have results for all of us, but first of all it is a debate in the United States. It is not a debate here, not a decision here." But there was also a palpable strain of disappointment in Berlin over the failure of the United States to include its allies in that debate. 
"After Sept. 11, we had the feeling there would be a more multilateral approach" to international affairs by the Bush administration, said the adviser to Mr. Schroder. But more recently, "We have been seeing a very assertive administration on the move in so many areas that people on this side of the Atlantic come to the question whether really there is a new approach."

HEADLINE: Turkey Warns U.S. of Difficulties in an Assault on Baghdad 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL SIMPSON 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, July 21 

 BODY:
Reiterating Turkey's concerns about military action against Iraq, Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit warned the United States today that it faced a long war if it decided to topple President Saddam Hussein of Iraq by force.
 Turkey, a NATO ally whose support would be vital for any operation in neighboring Iraq, has made it clear in recent weeks that it publicly opposes American military intervention. 
But diplomats say Turkey has been pressing the United States in private for economic support in the event of a strike that is increasingly viewed as inevitable here. 
 Mr. Ecevit said in a television interview that he did not know when an attack on Iraq might come, but he warned that Mr. Hussein retained the technological and economic ability to put up a long fight, despite sanctions imposed after the 1991 Persian Gulf war.
"It will not be possible to get out of there that easily," Mr. Ecevit said. "President Bush is a friend of Turkey. We do not want to hurt his feelings, but it is our duty to make our concerns known."
Turkey, a predominantly Muslim country from which American warplanes continue to enforce a no-flight zone over northern Iraq, feels aggrieved about the consequences of the gulf war, which it believes cost it billions of dollars in lost trade. In addition to asking the United States to write off more than $4 billion of debt, Turkish officials want to secure postwar development contracts in Iraq if Mr. Hussein is ousted, Western diplomats say.
Turkey also fears that a prolonged conflict could encourage Kurds in northern Iraq to demand an independent state, possibly inducing Turkish Kurds to renew a separatist guerrilla struggle that claimed 30,000 lives before a cease-fire in 1999.

HEADLINE: Sri Lankan Says U.S. Drive on Terror Helps Peace Effort 

BYLINE:  By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

 BODY:
The first Sri Lankan leader to visit Washington in nearly two decades said yesterday that the American-led campaign against terrorism had helped his government's chances of ending a long civil war -- even though Sri Lanka has never figured in the search for Al Qaeda.
 The Sri Lankan, Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe, said in an interview that he would ask President Bush and other officials in meetings on Monday and Tuesday to expand diplomatic support for his government and to consider a trade and investment agreement to help rebuild the country's economy. 
 He said he hoped peace talks would start in August to end the war, which has killed tens of thousands of people and uprooted many more. A cease-fire is already in effect. 
Both a higher awareness worldwide about the destructiveness of terrorism and a new resolve among Sri Lankans to stop the war are traceable to the attacks on the United States and the response to them, he said. 
"After last September, we have benefited, because the world has been looking around and they've been more concerned," said Mr. Wickremesinghe, speaking by telephone from Washington. "That's also led to the fact that in places like Sri Lanka, where a political solution can be found, we should go for it."
Since the early 1980's, the Sri Lankan government, dominated by the country's ethnic Sinhalese majority, has confronted a Tamil rebellion in the island's northeast that also sent suicide bombers into the capital, Colombo. 
A reclusive and ruthless Tamil rebel, Vellupillai Prabakharan, and his Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam, were responsible not only for assaults on Sinhalese targets but also for the harsh subjugation of Tamils and Muslims (a separate ethnic group largely descended from Arab traders) in areas under rebel control. The Tigers raised money from a Tamil diaspora in North America, Europe and Southeast Asia. 
The Sinhalese political establishment and a generation of moderate Tamil leaders were devastated by assassinations. Hundreds of ordinary people died in bus bombings and other attacks.
Well before the attacks last September, the United States, Britain and Malaysia had listed the Tigers as a terrorist organization. After Sept. 11, funds linked to the organization were frozen. 
India had also banned the organization and charged Mr. Prabakharan with planning the assassination of Prime Minister Rajiv Gandhi in 1991. Mr. Gandhi had tried to reverse years of training and financing of the Tigers by Indian intelligence officials -- an operation similar to what India now says Pakistan conducts in Kashmir.
After Sept. 11, Canada and Australia also curtailed the activities of groups linked to the Tigers in those countries.
Sri Lankan officials say the cumulative effect was almost immediate. Short on cash, the Tigers sued for peace, if only to buy time. 
Mr. Wickremesinghe, whose right-of-center United National Party won a national election in December on a peace platform, moved quickly into the vacuum.
He was welcomed enthusiastically by Tamils when he visited Jaffna, the center of Tamil culture, in March, the first prime minister to go there in more than 20 years.
Christina B. Rocca, the American assistant secretary of state for South Asia, and Brig. Gen. Tmothy Gormley of the Marines stood beside him there. It was one of the strongest gestures of support the United States had ever made to the embattled Sri Lankan government.
"I think the support they have given us has been very helpful, and that will continue," Mr. Wickremesinghe said. "What we will do now is discuss the next options."
Cease-fire monitors from several Nordic countries, led by a retired Norwegian officer, are on the ground in disputed areas. But peace talks have been delayed because serious issues remain unresolved.
Mr. Wickremesinghe said he was not worried by the delay because, day by day, Sri Lankans themselves are bringing the country together through commerce along recently reopened roads and in restored air services.
"The people-to-people process is taking hold very fast, and that's what counts most," he said. 
Among the troublesome issues remaining are the forced recruitment of child soldiers by the Tigers and extortion of money by the rebels in Tamil neighborhoods. 
Muslim Sir Lankans also fear they will be singled out for abuse by Mr. Prabakharan's agents if the Tigers gain control over an interim administration in the northeast, where the Muslim presence is significant. Mr. Wickremesinghe said he would appoint a Muslim leader, Rauf Hakeem, to his negotiating team to safeguard Muslim rights in coming talks.
"The interim administration must operate within a democratic framework and respect for human rights," the prime minister said. "The court system of Sri Lanka will operate, so human rights can be safeguarded and it can be transparent. It will be difficult for the interim administration to operate otherwise. The whole world will be watching them."
The Tigers want to have a ban on their organization in Sri Lanka lifted before talks begin. The government has said it is prepared to do that within perhaps 10 days of talks so the organization can take on political functions.
"What you're seeing in the country is that the people do want peace -- sometimes ahead of the government, ahead of the L.T.T.E., ahead of other political forces," Mr. Wickremesinghe said, using the rebel group's initials. "After a long time, there is one country functioning as one economic unit. We are gradually, I would say, limping back to normal."

CORRECTION-DATE: July 26, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Monday about comments by Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe of Sri Lanka on world terrorism referred imprecisely to his visit to Washington. While it was the first official visit in two decades by a government leader from his country, President Chandrika Kumaratunga made a private trip in 1999.

HEADLINE: Lawmakers Court Business While Deploring Its Misdeeds 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, July 21 

 BODY:
Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader who has been putting a new emphasis on cleaning up corporate America, celebrated 25 years in Congress on Thursday with a $500,000 fund-raising reception at a downtown hotel. Among those paying up to $5,000 to attend were dozens of Washington representatives of that very same corporate America.
 One night earlier, centrist House Democrats of the Blue Dog Coalition took a break between votes to travel six blocks from the Capitol to an elegant private home, where representatives of software giants Microsoft and Intuit joined other high-tech lobbyists at a $1,000-a-person reception for the group. Envelopes containing donations were stacked neatly on a table at the front door. 
 This weekend at the Greenbrier Resort in West Virginia, business representatives whose political action committees paid $15,000 for the privilege spent quality casual time with a half-dozen senators, courtesy of the National Republican Senatorial Committee.
While Congress is putting the spotlight on business practices in response to a spate of corporate malfeasance that has shaken the markets and shrunk the retirement accounts of constituents, both parties continue to rely on the corporate sector as a steady font of campaign cash -- even as they jockey for supremacy on the subject of who is going to reform Wall Street.
With just a few days remaining before the August recess, lawmakers looking to bolster their campaign bank accounts have ignited a midsummer fund-raising frenzy. Capitol Hill town houses and association offices that serve as regular reception sites are booked solid, as are the Democratic and Republican clubs.
Fund-raising parties that insiders refer to politely as "events" take place morning, noon and night. Business representatives are being asked to do their share -- to the point where they report feeling besieged.
"I get e-mails, I get faxes, I get phone calls from members and from their staffs," said a lobbyist who said he fields up to a dozen pleas a day. "It is annoying."
Lawmakers make no apologies for the fund-raising activity or their reliance on business interests. 
"This is the political season, and people need to raise resources to get their message out," said John Feehery, a spokesman for House Speaker J. Dennis Hastert, Republican of Illinois, who was scheduled for one of his regular, $1,500 per guest breakfasts this week. "It is the nature of the business." 
Members of both parties say the conduct of a few corporate outlaws does not put businesses off limits as a source of campaign money. They also say that business leaders who follow the rules are eager to see corporate abuse end, because it tarnishes them all.
"I get support and have always gotten support from business," said Representative Mike Thompson, Democrat of California, who attended the Blue Dog reception. "There are good businesses run by good ethical business people from my hometown in St. Helena to St. Louis. There are just a few bad apples who have created a problem."
Tom Ochs, political director for the New Democrat Coalition, said his organization intended to draw on the resources of well-run businesses to back candidates who support sensible changes in donation laws.
"Because of what Enron did, does that mean you will not take any money from anybody who had anything to do with the utility business, the energy business?" asked Mr. Ochs, whose group will use its members, like Senators Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut and John B. Breaux of Louisiana, to star at a string of events for Democratic Senate candidates. "Of course not."
Critics say the financial ties between corporations and Congress have played a role in the current economic turmoil. But they say lawmakers refuse to curb their appetite for corporate backing.
"What you have in Washington these days is a total disconnect between the very tough rhetoric from our elected leaders on corporate accountability and their continued chase of huge sums of corporate and business contributions," said Fred Wertheimer of Democracy 21, a group advocating overhaul of campaign financing regulations. A recent report by the group said corporations and business leaders gave $1 billion in large soft money contributions to the two parties over the last decade, $636 million to Republicans and $449 million to Democrats.
Mr. Gephardt, of Missouri, who has much at stake in the next election because a swing of a few seats could make him speaker, has been working overtime on fund-raising, including the reception on Thursday at the Mayflower Hotel and a luncheon earlier that day. "Your resources will help us win races all over the country," he told a wine-sipping audience of 100 or so at the hotel.
Guests included representatives of the airline, high-tech and automotive industries, and Washington lobbyists with many corporate clients. Mr. Gephardt's office declined to provide a list of people who attended, but his campaign finance report as of June 30 showed recent contributions from communications, banking and finance, construction and real estate interests, among others. Aides said many of those gifts reflected money for the reception.
Aides also said Mr. Gephardt spent a total of about 24 hours near the end of June raising soft money for the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, much of it from business executives. Earlier this month, aides said, Robert W. Pittman, the AOL-Time Warner executive who resigned on Thursday, held a fund-raiser at his Manhattan apartment for Mr. Gephardt.
Advisers to Mr. Gephardt reject any suggestion that his push for new business regulations should disqualify him from raising corporate donations. They say his agenda has drawn strong support from corporate officers. "What Mr. Gephardt and Democrats are saying is not anti-business, it is anticriminal behavior," said Erik Smith, his spokesman.
Signs suggest lawmakers are becoming increasingly concerned about their corporate connections. Some have returned or given to charity donations from companies like Enron and WorldCom that are at the center of the current maelstrom.
Democratic senators were stung recently when The Washington Post reported that shortly after voting on new corporate accounting standards, about a dozen senators flew on corporate jets to a Nantucket retreat for large contributors. The party said that it paid the companies $43,000 for the flights and that Republicans take corporate jets as well.
Representative Charles W. Pickering Jr., a Mississippi Republican who is in a tough race against a Democratic incumbent after redistricting, last week decided to cancel a fund-raising reception aboard a yacht after the campaign of his opponent, Representative Ronnie Shows, said it showed Mr. Pickering was out of touch with working people in Mississippi, where the collapse of corporate citizen WorldCom has taken a toll.
"It was a stupid idea from a hired fund-raiser," said Henry Barbour, a spokesman for Mr. Pickering.

HEADLINE: Rematch Produces Spirited Primary Race for Assembly Seat in Brooklyn 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
On any given morning, Hakeem S. Jeffries can be found at the entrance to one subway station or another in Brooklyn, handing out campaign literature and passionately explaining to anyone who will listen to what he considers the deficiencies of Assemblyman Roger L. Green, a 22-year incumbent whom Mr. Jeffries hopes to unseat.
 If Mr. Jeffries's portrayal of Mr. Green's record in the 57th Assembly District, which includes Fort Greene and Clinton Hill, seems well rehearsed, it is because he has spent the last two years relentlessly preparing for a rematch in a Democratic primary that is widely viewed as one of the most contentious contests of this year's legislative elections. 
 Two years ago, Mr. Green survived a strong challenge from Mr. Jeffries, a lawyer, who managed to win 41 percent of the vote in the primary, an unusually impressive showing for a political novice running against one of the Assembly's long-serving and most influential members. In the two years since that race, Mr. Jeffries, 31, has devoted a great deal of energy to organizing and preparing for this year's primary.
By all appearances, Mr. Green, 53, is taking nothing for granted this time around. He has enlisted the support of everyone from young people well known in the hip-hop world to the Brooklyn political establishment, which was very much on his side two years ago. And he has brought to his campaign Bill Lynch, the political strategist who managed both mayoral campaigns of David N. Dinkins.
As chairman of the state Black and Hispanic Legislative Caucus, Mr. Green is viewed as an eloquent spokesman for the concerns of residents of the state's urban areas. And he won praise in some quarters -- and condemnation in others -- for having taken a lead role in stymieing Rudolph W. Giuliani's efforts to get legislative approval to run for a third term as mayor.
In many respects, the themes highlighted by the two candidates are virtually unchanged from two years ago. Mr. Jeffries portrays Mr. Green as well intentioned, but insists that he has become a comfortable, ineffective career politician whose constituent service has become so lax that his staff members rarely return telephone calls.
"He is a man with absolutely no plan to address the some of the most pressing issues in the community, said Mr. Jeffries, who is on leave from the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison. "For example, he has no plan to address the inadequate performance of the public schools and the crisis of people being unable to afford housing. And there has been an utter lack of economic development in his 22 years in office."
Moreover, Mr. Jeffries asserts, Mr. Green's "office is legendary for a string of broken promises to constituents, missed meetings and un-returned phone calls that have piled up on top of each other during the last 22 years."
Mr. Green, meanwhile, who is also the chairman of the Assembly's Children and Families Committee, talks proudly of his education-related work, saying that his most significant achievements have been in that area, including development of the Benjamin Banneker Academy, a charter school on Clinton Avenue in Brooklyn that specializes in math, science and technology. His office proposed and designed the academy, Mr. Green said.
"The bottom line is that I have focused on those issues that I feel strongly about," Mr. Green said. "And those are education services and children and families."
At Banneker, he said, "98 percent of the students passed the language arts Regents exam, 100 percent passed the math and science exam."
"That's the school I started and wrote the proposal for with my own hands," he said. "I'm the only elected official that has ever built a school from the ground up."
Mr. Jeffries, Mr. Green said, has chosen to ignore the accomplishments of his 22 years of incumbency. "It's not his time yet," Mr. Green said of his opponent. "Because of the positions I have in the Assembly, we're now poised to do some serious things for the district, and we're already doing some important things."
More pointed barbs have already started flying in what promises to be hard-fought campaign. For example, Mr. Jeffries blames Mr. Green for redistricting changes that placed Mr. Jeffries's home one block outside the borders of the 57th Assembly District. "It was a desperate act by a career politician trying to save his government job," Mr. Jeffries said.
Mr. Green, meanwhile, insists that the district lines were shifted as part of an effort to remove some sections of the more affluent neighborhoods of Park Slope and Prospect Heights, where Mr. Jeffries lives, and make room for public housing complexes that would increase the number of black and Hispanic residents, thereby insuring that the district was protected under the federal Voting Rights Act. "I didn't even know where Hakeem lived," Mr. Green said.
As in 2000, Mr. Jeffries has marshaled a large group of young volunteers. And since then, he has become better known in the district and was involved in starting a political club, the Brooklyn Freedom Democratic Association.
With seven weeks left before the primary, Mr. Jeffries has raised about $55,000, roughly the total amount he spent in the 2000 campaign. Mr. Green said he has raised $40,000 and vowed to "raise and spend whatever it takes" to withstand this latest challenge.
"I plan to demonstrate that there is no truth to the notion that I'm vulnerable," Mr. Green said. "We're getting a lot of support. It would be different if I were really ineffective and feeble. But I'm in a position to be of real assistance to my constituents."

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-7

Iran Link and a Cover-Up Charged in 1994 Bombing
A witness in the case involving the bombing of the Argentine Jewish Mutual Aid Association in 1994 has said the Iranian government organized and carried out the attack and then paid Argentina's president at the time, Carlos Saul Menem, $10 million to cover it up. A1

Americans Shun Overseas Jobs
The State Department is having difficulty filling hardship posts overseas, as Americans shun jobs over security and lifestyle concerns. Sixty percent of American embassies and consulates are designated hardship posts for reasons ranging from security threats to poor hospitals to oppressive weather, and those missions report a vacancy rate 50 percent higher than in richer nations. A1

Israel Backs Off Deportations
Israel appears to be backing off from its plan to deport relatives of West Bank Palestinians accused of suicide bombings to the Gaza Strip. Prime Minister Ariel Sharon said the government would abide by the legal finding that only relatives found to be directly involved in supporting suicide bombers could be deported. A3

Turkey Warns Against Iraq War
Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit of Turkey warned that President Saddam Hussein of Iraq has the capability to put up a long fight. Turkey, a NATO ally whose support would be vital in any operation in Iraq, opposes American military intervention there. A5

U.N. Anti-Tobacco Plan
The World Health Organization has drawn up a treaty that would phase in bans on cigarette advertising and sports sponsorships by tobacco companies. The United Nations agency's member countries have been negotiating for two years to arrive at the pact by a May 2003 deadline. A7

Suspects Arrested in Greece
Two more suspects were charged with involvement in the string of attacks since 1975 by Greece's November 17 urban guerrilla group, including the killing of an American Air Force sergeant and a British brigadier. A3

The View From the Vatican
Pope John Paul II will visit Canada for the Roman Catholic Church's World Youth Day. He has no plans to stop in the United States and address the concerns about sexual abuse by priests. To some American Catholics, that is bitterly disappointing and confusing. A3

Sri Lanka to Seek Support
Prime Minister Ranil Wickremesinghe of Sri Lanka said the new awareness that the American-led campaign against terrorism has brought worldwide and new resolve in his own country may help end the civil war. Mr. Wickremesinghe said he would ask the Bush administration to consider an agreement to help rebuild the country's economy. A6

NATIONAL A8-14

Plan for Security Agency Enters the Details Phase
The drive to create a Homeland Security Department is racing quickly through the legislative process. The bill closely mirrors President Bush's original proposal to merge 22 federal agencies into a single department. Now the most contentious issues will come to the forefront. A10

An Ideological Battle
President Bush wants to fill a federal appeals court seat with Priscilla Owen, a conservative judge from Texas with a strong record of opposing abortion rights. Senate Democrats and their liberal allies are certain to challenge Justice Owen's nomination, the latest in the continuing battles between Mr. Bush and the Democrats over the ideological shape of the federal courts. A10

Priests and Religious Orders
Leaders of the nation's 125 Roman Catholic religious orders will meet next month and confront the issue of what to do with sexually abusive priests who belong to religious orders, like the Jesuits, Franciscans and Benedictines. A9

More Money for Superfund
The Environmental Protection Agency has restored money to clean up 11 toxic dump sites under its Superfund program, after having previously told local officials that they would not receive any money this year, agency officials said. Still, many other sites may not receive money that regional officials have requested. A8

A Town and Its Meatpacker
A series of problems, including a huge recall, E. coli fears and a slumping stock price, are raising questions over what the future holds for ConAgra Beef Company and for residents of Greeley, Colo. A8

African-American Museum
Organizers say a proposal for a comprehensive African-American museum on the Mall in Washington is closer to reality after 12 years of legislative setbacks. A10

Fund-Raising Frenzy
Politicians like Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, continue to rely on the corporate sector as a steady source of campaign cash even as both major parties jockey for supremacy on the subject of who is going to overhaul Wall Street. A11

Child Care Gap
A new study says only one in seven parents is able to find a preschool or center-based care in California, even though spending for child care in the state has nearly quadrupled to $12 billion since 1996. A9

Tire Safety Concerns
Tire makers want the federal government to revisit a rule that requires tire-pressure warning lights in some new vehicles. The makers say the lights might fail to provide adequate warnings even when tire pressure is dangerously low. A13

NEW YORK/REGION B1-6

Weekday Test Begins For Strained Power Grid
City officials are urging Con Ed customers across a large section of Lower Manhattan to use electricity sparingly today in an effort to prevent a power failure in the wake of Saturday's major explosion and fire at an electrical transformer on the East River. A1

The Passaic Comeback
The Passaic River, once considered the finest rowing river in the Northeast, is poised for a rebirth. With most offending industries gone, the water quality is improving. Up and down the river, cities and suburban towns that used to treat the Passaic like a toilet are planning waterfront promenades and parks. B1

Caught Here and in Ghana
Data Management Internationale, a Delaware firm that has been digitizing information for New York City since March, sends some of its work to a back office in Ghana. That means just days after tickets have been written out on New York streets, they are sent as digital photographs to computers in downtown Accra, Ghana's capital, where workers try to transcribe the handwritten scrawl of New York police officers into searchable databases. A1

ARTS E1-10

Glorifying Mafia Songs
A little-known form of Italian folk music will soon make its American debut with the release of a CD titled "Il Canto di Malavita" despite questions in Italy over the legality of the distribution and performance of music that glorifies the Mafia. B1

California's push for zero-emission vehicles could soon force automakers to sell more than 100,000 electric cars and other highly fuel-efficient vehicles in the state each year. That immediate concern has overshadowed a bill requiring automakers to cut carbon dioxide emissions by 2008 and has prompted them to spend billions of dollars developing new technologies. A1

Radio stations nationwide are increasingly switching to hip-hop formats. The changes are largely propelled by economics. HEADLINE: Ulster Catholics' Clout 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 For an American who has visited Belfast frequently, there are striking parallels between the conflict in Northern Ireland and the American civil rights movement. 
 You report on Northern Irish Protestants' "growing feeling of precariousness in the land they once dominated" (front page, July 18). 
This is similar to the resentment of some whites in the United States as blacks first made political gains.
What Northern Irish Protestants resent is the the success of Catholic community organizing. Thirty years of struggle have trained Catholics in the democratic skills necessary to promote their equality and economic development. Protestants, long the beneficiaries of sectarianism, never had to do this. Now they feel powerless because Catholics are active citizens.

KEVIN J. CASSIDY
Fairfield, Conn., July 19, 2002

The writer is a professor of politics at Fairfield University.

HEADLINE: ON THE GROUND: In Phoenix; 
Technology and Rapid Growth in the Valley of the Sun

BYLINE:  By MARK A. STEIN 

 BODY:
Phoenix is the leading contender to become the home of the International Genomics Center, a collaborative effort by industry and universities to use the human genome to find cures for specific cancers. City leaders say that winning the nationwide contest to be the host of the center will make Phoenix a major locus for genetic research.
 That, in turn, could accelerate the city's rapid growth. In the last decade, Phoenix passed Dallas, Detroit and San Diego to become the nation's sixth-largest city, and is closing in on Philadelphia. The metropolitan area, 15th largest in the United States, includes 5 of the country's 20 fastest-growing cities: Glendale, Scottsdale, Chandler, Gilbert and Peoria. 
 The Valley of the Sun, as the area is known, is the third-largest semiconductor manufacturing area in the country and has the biggest concentration of call centers -- 173 and counting, according to the Greater Phoenix Economic Council. It is also home to four Fortune 500 companies: Avnet, Allied Waste Industries, Pinnacle West and Phelps Dodge.
A car is the easiest way around. For people who do not drive, try ExecuCar, a business-class car service (888-473-9227)

HOTELS
Many business travelers recommend the BILTMORE (602-955-6600, $175 to $1,425) as much for its Frank Lloyd Wright-inspired architecture as for the 24-hour business center and other services. "If I was coming to Phoenix, knowing what I know, I'd only stay at the Biltmore," said Allen Maag, chief communications officer for Avnet. Like all hotels here, the price of rooms moves inversely to the temperature.
Phoenix and Scottsdale have long been tourist destinations with outdoor activities like golf and indoor luxuries like spas, and many hotels compete to outpamper guests. The CAMELBACK INN (480-948-1700, $149 to $470), a Marriott hotel, has data ports in every room for work -- and several suites with private swimming pools for relaxation. It also has two 18-hole golf courses. "It's like a summer camp for adults," said Maureen E. O'Toole, vice president of Salomon Smith Barney in New York who often travels to Phoenix.
In the same league is the PHOENICIAN (480-941-8200, $179 to $729), a Starwood property with 654 rooms (each with a data port), golf, tennis and nine swimming pools. Among its seven restaurants is Mary Elaine's, one of the best in the city. "It has great service and wonderful amenities," said Armando Flores, executive vice president for business services at Pinnacle West.
Smaller and a bit more intimate is the ROYAL PALMS (602-840-3610, $99 to $505). "Some of our regulars -- employees who come back and back and back on business -- prefer the Royal Palms because it's got that smaller elegance that makes them feel more at home," said David Birk, senior vice president and general counsel for Avnet.

RESTAURANTS
GREGORY'S WORLD BISTRO (480-946-8700, $110 for dinner for two with wine) has the most inventive menu -- with dishes that have included salmon ceviche with white-bean hummus; apple-crusted, pan-roasted sturgeon; and a wild-mushroom pierogi in a caviar cream sauce -- and attentive service. It is open only for dinner in the summer, and is closed on Sundays.
DON & CHARLIE'S AMERICAN RIB AND CHOP HOUSE (480-990-0900, $60) has a name that sums up its Southwestern barbecue menu but gives no hint of its extraordinary sports-themed decor, a favorite of major league ballplayers during spring training. "The most sports memorabilia in any one place west of Cooperstown," Mr. Maag said.
Near the Arizona State University campus in Tempe is HOUSE OF TRICKS (480-968-1114, $70), where fresh fish and chops are served to the sound of a gurgling fountain in the landscaped courtyard of a 1920's cottage. Closed on Sundays.

ENTERTAINMENT
The best place for casual conversation is the lobby bar of the Royal Palms, a lovely and comfortable room with generous cocktails. For a good view, there is plenty of competition, from the TOP OF THE ROCK (602-431-2370) at the Wyndham Buttes Resort to the revolving COMPASS restaurant (602-440-3166) atop the Hyatt Regency downtown. But the best may be the WRIGLEY MANSION CLUB (602-955-4079) on Camelback Mountain; it operates as a private club to conform to zoning regulations but anyone can join on the spot for $10 a year.
For music, try the RHYTHM ROOM (602-265-4842), which offers a regular schedule of live blues, jazz and country music. For a taste of the Old West, there is RAWHIDE (480-502-1880), a kitschy but entertaining reconstruction of a frontier town circa 1885.

ON YOUR OWN
Of several museums of Native American culture, the best known is the HEARD MUSEUM (602-252-8848), which recently added 50,000 square feet of exhibition space. It is now showing paintings and sculpture by leading artists of the Native American Fine Art Movement.
The DESERT BOTANICAL GARDEN (480-941-1225) has one of the world's largest and most diverse collection of desert plants. The garden stays open late and is lighted to allow cool nighttime strolls in the summer.
The Grand Canyon is too distant for a day trip, but OAK CREEK CANYON near Sedona (the local tourist bureau is at 928-282-7722) is only about two hours away, straight up Interstate 17. The best hike is along the heavily wooded west fork of Oak Creek, cool in summer and bursting with color in the fall.
For the best buys on turquoise jewelry: the shops of OLD TOWN in Scottsdale.

LOCAL LORE
Don't be alarmed by the sight of an armed man outside a bank. Arizona law lets people carry firearms, and many choose to do so in a holster strapped to their hip, Old West-style.
Phoenix is a diverse city in a uniquely Southwestern way. Not only are about a third of the residents of Hispanic descent, but Phoenix has the largest population of Native Americans of any big city.

HEADLINE: Back to the Drawing Board 

BYLINE:  By Susan S. Szenasy; Susan S. Szenasy, editor in chief of Metropolis magazine, is a co-founder of R.Dot (Rebuild Downtown Our Town) and a teacher of design history and ethics at Parsons School of Design.

 BODY:
The six plans proposed for rebuilding the World Trade Center site in Lower Manhattan go on display tomorrow in Federal Hall at Wall and Nassau Streets. In this historic place, where George Washington took the oath as our first president, visitors can study the proposals drawn up by the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. Both these organizations -- having been treated to worldwide editorial derision since the plans became available last week, plus a day of public contempt (live at the Javits Center) on the weekend -- have decided to rethink their efforts. It isn't hard to see why.
 Each of the six schemes is dominated by an office park that could be anywhere --tall buildings arrayed in either L or U shapes. Each plan has similarly massive retail spaces, calling to mind the suburban shopping malls along any highway service road. And each scheme offers up some space for a memorial to the victims of Sept. 11. The word memorial is on all the plans, showing that the planners see the need to remember our day of great loss and destruction. Or perhaps they're putting this word out front because all their plans are dedicated mainly to the financial obligations of the current lease holders for 11 million square feet of office space, 600,000 square feet of retail space and a 600,000-square-foot hotel. 
 Those who visit Federal Hall or log on to www.renewnyc.org will get an opportunity to study the plans in some detail, including bird's-eye views of Lower Manhattan spinning around. It's easy to be seduced by the technology. But you'll get over it quickly, as did the more than 4,000 people, mostly area residents and workers, who attended the town hall meeting at the Javits Center on Saturday. We were seated 10 to a table, forming a skeptical and wary crowd. Those in charge assured us they wanted our feedback. That's what the wireless keypads were for. By the end of the long day, there were signs that the "decision makers," as the men in charge of rebuilding were called, realized that the original program needed some reassessment. Probably the two most common comments were "timid" and "boring."
For those of us who believe in the power of informed planning and inspired architecture, what we saw was especially disturbing. Is it possible that our city's robust architecture offices -- the firms who worked on the plans were Beyer Blinder Belle, Architects and Planners; Peterson/Littenberg Architects; Skidmore, Owings & Merrill; and Cooper, Robertson & Partners -- can only come up with such anemic proposals?
Ever since I first saw the plans at the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation office last week, and again as I walked away from the Javits Center on Saturday, one thought kept going through my head. It had to do with ethical professional behavior, with how architects and planners view their obligations and responsibilities. The Lower Manhattan and Port Authority planners understood their obligation in the narrow sense: to serve their clients, forgetting their larger obligation to the people of New York. While they made much of designing for the millions who are expected to visit the memorial, they neglected the men, women and children who live and work and go to school and play in the area now and will do so in the future.
Most significantly, the planners left out residential buildings from the site. Housing, the lifeblood of any city neighborhood, was not requested by the clients. But these planners and architects are professionals who understand the facts of urban life very well. They're learned people who know that it is many individuals, going about their daily lives, who animate the streets and create the vitality that cities like New York exude. By keeping a narrow focus, they designed a place that would almost have to seem desolate.
Ultimately, would their clients be happy with such sterility? Will such a space attract the tenants they want? Will there be enough jobs to fill all those millions of square feet as computerization continues to change the places and the ways of work?
Thinking about these six tentative plans and the surprisingly loud and consistent cries of disappointment that greeted them, I wondered if we have lost our knack for bringing together big bucks with big ideas. In earlier generations, planners had the gumption and the vision to build grand and memorable public projects like the Brooklyn Bridge, the Lincoln Tunnel and Rockefeller Center. Are we at the end of our creative run? Have we reached a moment when we are capable of designing only bland office parks and lightly nostalgic shopping malls? If so, we better snap out of it and fast. We can start in lower Manhattan.
New Yorkers expect a 21st century city to rise from the ashes of the twin towers and connect with the historic city. We need a "high-tech Machu Picchu," someone said at our table in the Javits Center.
Our culture has so many talented architects and planners, both within the large, established companies and at younger firms. When will we start asking them to help us imagine our future? We need designs that will truly revive and support our economy and satisfy our dreams for a world-class metropolis. These architects and designers need planners who are skilled at analyzing demographic and economic trends and who can use this information to create a realistic plan on which to build.
There are many ways to honor those who turned to dust, and those who were forever scarred, on that horrible day last September. While we must build a memorial for them -- and a burial ground for those whose remains were never found -- the most respectful memorial to the future our lost New Yorkers might have had will be a beautiful new city rising from that 16-acre hole in the ground. This architectural masterpiece will become the hopeful place that people are so desperately asking for, a place worthy of being a pilgrimage site.

HEADLINE: Turkish Party Balks at Call From Premier To Delay Vote 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL SIMPSON 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, July 22 

 BODY:
The biggest party in Turkey's fragile governing coalition threatened today to bring down the government unless Prime Minister Bulent Ecevit stuck to an agreement to hold early elections in November.
 Mr. Ecevit, who is 77 and in poor health, was forced last week to agree to call the elections after defections by half his party's lawmakers caused the government to lose its majority in Parliament. But he said over the weekend that he might change his mind. 
 He urged political rivals, including former supporters who have quit to form a new party, to back him for the sake of Turkey's stability -- an issue that is also of concern to the United States as it considers whether to attack neighboring Iraq.
But Mr. Ecevit's coalition partners gave short shrift to his appeal to postpone elections until next spring at the earliest.
Devlet Bahceli, the deputy prime minister, said he would pull his Nationalist Action Party out of Mr. Ecevit's government if he tried to remain in power beyond Nov. 3, the date tentatively set for the election.
"A development like this would invite a crisis situation," Mr. Bahceli said. He warned that political uncertainty could have a destabilizing effect on financial markets because it could jeopardize a $16 billion International Monetary Fund bailout for Turkey's troubled economy.
"If elections are postponed or if conditions emerge that would make it impossible for them to be held, it will be impossible for us to carry on in the government," he said.
His threat increases pressure on Mr. Ecevit, but would mean little in practice at this stage unless lawmakers from other parties agree to recall Parliament from its summer recess.
An attempt by opposition parties to summon members for a vote on the election date failed today because too few showed up for the motion to be debated.
Although most parties favor an early election, many politicians believe it is even more important to enact the civil rights reforms that are needed to make Turkey eligible for European Union membership by the time the group holds a summit meeting in December.
Ismail Cem, the former foreign minister, is among those focusing on the rights issues. He has grouped fellow defectors from Mr. Ecevit's camp under the umbrella of his New Turkey Party, which he formally introduced today.
Mr. Bahceli's party, which has replaced Mr. Ecevit's as the largest in a three-way coalition, opposes moves to expand the civil rights of Turkey's Kurdish population and to abolish the death penalty.
Politicians are now scrambling to form new alliances that would allow the legislation to be passed, along with economic reforms required by the International Monetary Fund.
A new parliamentary session to debate the election date and some of these new laws is scheduled for Monday, but political analysts question whether it will take place unless a new consensus emerges.
"Everything is still up in the air," said Ilter Turan, a political scientist at Bilgi University in Istanbul.

HEADLINE: Population-Control Politics 

 BODY:
There is a mind-bending illogic behind the Bush administration's decision yesterday to withhold $34 million from the United Nations Population Fund, which is working in China despite continued practices there of coerced abortion and sterilization. It is precisely because of China's reprehensible policies that the U.N. presence is important. Cutting off funds to the agency is an inexcusable sop to right-wing anti-abortion activists in an election year. It will increase the number of abortions worldwide by depriving poor women of the education and help they need and that the U.N. agency provides. 
 The U.N. Population Fund is the world's biggest agency focused on women's reproductive health and the only serious external force in China trying to change the way local officials hold down population growth. Last year Secretary of State Colin Powell praised its "invaluable work." Faced with accusations that the agency was complicit in Chinese misdeeds, the administration sent in a study team in May. It found no evidence that the fund knowingly supports or participates in any Chinese program that coerces abortion or sterilization. It recommended that the $34 million requested by Congress for the agency last year be released. 
 Instead, the administration refused yesterday to do so because of China's continuing birth-control practices. This means that some 12.5 percent of the agency's budget is now wiped out and that vital and worthy programs like midwife training in Algeria and a new AIDS center in Haiti are suddenly without funding they need.
The administration says it will give the $34 million instead to the Child Survival and Health Program Fund, part of the State Department's Agency for International Development. The problem is that that agency cannot duplicate the work of the U.N., which operates in dozens of countries where the United States has no aid presence. Reproductive health and freedom of women are central to the improvement of poor societies. The U.N. Population Fund is one of the most important forces at work today helping poor women. The United States should be supporting it, not undermining it.
